column2: A sparkling Diwali for Lucknowites
column3: The festival of lights was celebrated with much zeal at a prominent club in the city. The attendees looked spectacular in their traditional attires. Chief guest, Major General Pravesh Puri was accompanied by wife Hemi and daughter Gulnar. The celebration saw a series of dance performances along with aatishbazi and a lucky draw. (L) Devyani, Shrishti and Malvika (R) Gulnar Puri (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Devyani, Shrishti and Malvika (R) Gulnar Puri (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) There was Salsa, Belly dance, Sufi, Bollywood Dance and fireworks which kept the adults and the kids completely enthralled. The people, later on, moved towards the dance floor and thoroughly enjoyed grooving to the beats of Bollywood numbers like Urvashi, Pardah, Illahi, Dilbar, etc. The energy on the dance floor was palpable and infectious attracting most of the crowd on the dance floor. The guests had a great time at the party. Paridhi, an attendee said, “I absolutely loved the fireworks. It was a great evening full of fun.” — Yashi Agarwal (L) Lakshmi Priya (R) Harsh Singh (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Lakshmi Priya (R) Harsh Singh (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Laxman Datt and Shyamn Pandey (R) Archna Raj and Tarun (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Laxman Datt and Shyamn Pandey (R) Archna Raj and Tarun (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Malvika and Hemant (R) Nidhi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Malvika and Hemant (R) Nidhi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Pravesh and Hemi Puri (R) Shyam Singh and Dr Maya Dhami (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Pravesh and Hemi Puri (R) Shyam Singh and Dr Maya Dhami (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Romaa (R) Shardul and Sheetal (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Romaa (R) Shardul and Sheetal (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Suparna Ghoshal and Jyotirmoy (R) Sanjana Bhalla (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Suparna Ghoshal and Jyotirmoy (R) Sanjana Bhalla (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L-R) Deepali, Sangeeta and Pooja (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L-R) Deepali, Sangeeta and Pooja (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

column2: Why dust bowl Ghaziabad is India’s pollution hotspot
column3: GHAZIABAD: Dust that won’t disperse and traffic congestions that don’t ease — the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) has identified these as the factors exacerbating air pollution in Ghaziabad, one of the most polluted cities in the country at the moment. “We identified over 20 areas in the city where dust pollution is the most severe. Different agencies and departments have been asked to carry out water sprinkling since the Graded Response Action Plan kicked in. The Ghaziabad Municipal Corporation is responsible for water sprinkling along a 90-km stretch within the city’s municipal limits and for mechanized sweeping along another 106-km stretch,” a district official said. Track the pollution level in your cityOn paper, regular water sprinkling is being done on several such stretches — Mohan Nagar to GT Road, Sahibabad to Maharajpur, Sahibabad to Chandra Vihar, Meerut Road to Dudheshwarnath Temple, Vasundhara to Prahladgarhi and Dabur Chowk to UP Gate, among others — to control dust pollution. On the ground, it does not show. Unpaved stretches – in Nandgram, Loni’s Rashid Nagar, Bhatta Number 5 Road in Sikroad, Vijay Nagar bypass and Siddharth Vihar — remain clouded in dust all through the day. The official explanation was that these roads are “interior” ones. “These stretches are sources of dust pollution, but are internal roads within colonies. We have taken care of the main roads, which are in good shape,” the district official said. Then there are areas – in Indirapuram and Shastri Nagar – with no green paving, which doesn’t help control dust either. Ghaziabad Development Authority (GDA) vice-chairperson Kanchan Verma offered a defence: “Green paving has been done across most of the city, but there are many pavements we are yet to cover. The immediate problem that we face is that of encroachment by street vendors. Evicting them from the roads is a major challenge, because of which we have not been able to complete green paving on many stretches.” For now, the Authority has identified sections it plans to develop as “model roads”. “We have selected 10 spots where these model roads will have green paving. But work on it will be finished only by next year,” Verma added. For traffic congestion, the other big contributor to Ghaziabad’s pollution, the GDA has brought the Central Road Research Institute (CRRI) on board to prepare a traffic mobility plan. “The CRRI has pointed out 14 major intersections with the highest traffic congestion — the most prominent being GDA Old Bus Stand, Choudhary Mor, Indirapuram SRS Cinemas and Kanawani Intersection. The CRRI has also recommended changes in road design in some places. We have implemented the recommendations in Indirapuram and will do so in other parts of the city soon,” Verma said.

column2: Now, a digital Ramayana show in Ayodhya soon
column3: LUCKNOW: On Saturday, Ayodhya was witness to a spectacular show where the return of Lord Ram from Ayodhya was recreated and over 5 lakh diyas were lit of celebrate Deepotsava. The temple town will soon experience another show to remember - digital Ramayana. The state government on Thursday decided to renovate the Ayodhya Shodh Sansthan, a plan that will include the digital version of the epic. While the government has already planned a statue of Lord Ram on the banks of the Saryu in Ayodhya, it has also put thrust of promoting religious tourism in the state by developing circuits and cultural programmes in Ayodhya, Vrindavan and Chitrakoot. For the renovation of the Ayodhya Shodh Sansthan , a key tourist attraction for not only hosting the staging uninterrupted Ram Lila for over 14 years , but also housing historical artifacts related the Ramayana from different parts of India and the world . "Chief minister Yogi Adityanath wanted the institute to be renovated and modernized. Once the renovation work is done, the sansthan will put up the digital Ramayana as an attraction for tourists and pilgrims visiting Ayodhya," said principal secretary (culture) Jitendra Kumar. "Ayodhya is in the process of getting a major facelift, with various departments engaged in construction work of developmental projects and the culture department has finalised its Rs 20-crore project for the Sansthan," said Kumar. "Apart from digital Ramayana, a special light-and-sound show depicting "Ram Van Gaman" (Lord Ram's journey from Ayodhya to Chitrakoot traversing forests during his exile) would also start. All publications and journals of the Sansthan would also be digitized," added Kumar.

column2: Lucknow: Speeding bus crushes two kids sleeping on pavement
column3: LUCKNOW: Two minor girls were crushed to death in their sleep and five persons grievously injured when a speeding bus hit a three-wheeler and climbed a pavement at Engineering College intersection in Jankipuram early on Thursday morning. The interstate bus, coming from Delhi, also bulldozed a passenger shed and rammed two power poles - holding up a 33KV transmission line - before coming to a halt. The driver fled the spot, leaving behind the vehicle with 60 passengers. Police have identified the deceased as Pooja (6) and Khusboo (13). The injured include their brother Karan (4), father Dinesh (40) who owns a paan shop and cobbler Babbu (20). The driver and a passenger of the three-wheeler, Saddam (18) and Akram (50), were also injured. The father-son duo and Babbu have suffered multiple fractures while Saddam and Akram have head injuries. They are all critical, doctors at KGMU said. According to eyewitnesses, the accident took place around 5.30am. The bus in top gear first hit the three-wheeled passenger vehicle, which overturned on impact. As the bus next ran over sleeping pavement dwellers and ploughed into the poles, two policemen on patrol called for backup and directed Lucknow Electricity Supply Administration to snap power supply. With the help of local residents, police pulled out the victims from under the mangled bus and the threewheeler. Pooja and Khusboo were declared brought dead at KGMU. Shyamu Verma (28), an eyewitness, said it was no less than a miracle that some of the victims survived. Jankipuram SHO Mohammad Ashraf said the 60 passengers inside the bus received minor bruises. “The driver fled the scene. He will be identified and booked,” the officer added.

column2: Lucknow: Blame foul air for cutting your life short by 8.6 years
column3: LUCKNOW: Life expectancy in UP can increase by 8.6 years if concentration of superfine particles (PM 2.5) is brought down to permissible limit, says a study on air quality life index (AQLI) released by the Energy Policy Institute at the University of Chicago (EPIC) on Thursday. Recognised by World Health Organisation (WHO), the study has found that continuous exposure to PM 2.5 damages the respiratory system, the heart and the brain. This makes people age faster and reduces their life expectancy, said Ashirbad S. Raha, senior associate director of communications at EPIC's Delhi branch. "The permissible PM 2.5 level, according to WHO, is 10 microgram per cubic metre of air. Sustained exposure to an additional 10 microgram per cubic metre can reduce life expectancy by 0.98 years. Similarly, if PM 2.5 concentration is 30 microgram per cubic metre, life expectancy goes down by 1.96 years, and so on and so forth," Raha explained. Track the pollution level in your cityThe study has also found that the annual average PM 2.5 concentration in the air of UP is 8-9 times higher than the permissible limit. "In other words, foul air is reducing life expectancy of the people in this state by 8.6 years," Raha said. Life expectancy is the average period a person may expect to live. According to government data, the life expectancy in UP is around 64 years. The EPIC study used satellite derived data to measure the annual average concentration of PM 2.5 in all the 75 districts of the state and its impact on life expectancy in each district. The average of the districts was taken to find the impact of pollution on life expectancy in UP. Data revealed that Hapur is on top of the low life expectancy table with a reduction by 11.18 years, followed by Bulandshahr (11.13 years) and Ghaziabad (10.74 years).

column2: Lucknow: One-year-old girl on maid's watch drowns in bathtub
column3: LUCKNOW: The toddler daughter of a city contractor drowned in a bathtub while under supervision of a maid at their Manas Enclave home in Indiranagar on Thursday. The family has not lodged any complaint of negligence against the maid and police are seeing it as a tragic accident.  The incident took place around noon when the year-old girl and her twin brother were making a splash in the tub. Since the boy finished bathing first, the maid wrapped him in a towel and took him to the room. She returned within five minutes to find the little girl floating face down in water, unresponsive. It is suspected that the toddler tried to stand up and somehow slipped. She fell head first into the water and drowned. Her parents were not home. Other members of the joint family rushed her to RML hospital, where she was declared brought dead. Indiranagar SHO Santosh Kumar Kushwaha said neither the child's father, who runs a business of construction materials, nor any other family member had lodged a police complaint against the maid. "Prima facie, it is an accidental death," he added.

column2: Lucknow: Chhath Puja begins with songs, lights, feast & fast
column3: LUCKNOW: Devotional songs rented the air, arterial roads wore festive lights and the authorities reviewed ghat safety as the four-day Chhath Puja began in the city on Thursday. While vratis (fasting devotees) bathed in holy water, prepared satvik food at home and embarked on their 36-hour nirjala (without water) fast, others thronged markets for a last-minute shopping binge. The fast will continue till second day rituals of kharna when Chhathi Maiyya is offered kheer (rice cooked in milk), puri and thekua (fried sweets made of banana and coconut) before vratis eat after sundown. The third and fourth days are considered the key days of Chhath as devotees go waist-deep in water to offer arghya to the sun god. The evening rituals are known as sandhya or sanjhiya arghya while the morning prayers is called suryodaya or bihaniya arghya. Since the Gomti riverbank adjoining Lakshman Mela Ground is expected to witness the heaviest footfall on Saturday and Sunday, women were seen demarcating their vedis (seat of worship) with colours and lamps. Many were overheard discussing their arghya attire. "Chhath is to UPites and Biharis what Durga Puja is to Bengalis. While men and women busy themselves with puja preparations, children wait eagerly for the fried sweet called thekua. This traditional prasad is one of the high points of the festivities," said vrati Aruni Jha, a resident of Sadar. As citizens soaked in celebrations, the authorities monitored arrangements at the 12 Gomti ghats designated for Chhath rituals, including Jhulelal and Kudia. District magistrate Kaushal Raj Sharma made a final inspection on Thursday along with officials of Lucknow Municipal Corporation. "Ghats have been cleaned and parking provisions made. Ambulances and teams of NDRF (National Disaster Response Force) and SDRF (State Disaster Response Force) will be on standby for the safety of devotees," Sharma said.

column2: NRC after survey in UP, says CM Yogi Adityanath
column3: LUCKNOW: UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath has said a survey is underway to "determine the extent of illegal immigration" to the state, based on which the government would decide whether to roll out an Assam-like exercise to create a National Register of Citizens (NRC). This was the first occasion when Yogi spoke about NRC implementation in UP. Yogi, who made the announcement while speaking at an awards function of a private school here on Wednesday, had earlier welcomed Union home minister Amit Shah's announcement that NRC would be implemented across the country. Campaigning for the just concluded bypolls, Yogi had also said that UP could take lessons from Assam and implement the proposed exercise in phases. Government spokesperson Mahendra Singh later said that UP would implement the NRC proposal "100%". A senior official of the home department confirmed on Thursday that the police department was carrying out a survey to detect illegal immigrants. On October 1, DGP OP Singh had directed all district police heads to depute teams to identify illegal Bangladeshi and other immigrants and submit the findings to the home department. The order mentioned that many people of Bangladeshi origin living illegally in UP had gone off the radar. Singh said locations where illegal immigrants were most likely to be found, including railway stations and bus terminals, should be scanned and the identities of those living there should be verified.

column2: Lucknow: Four held with beef, two for smuggling cattle
column3: LUCKNOW: Four men were caught with 250kg of cattle meat in Saadatganj while two men were arrested for illegally transporting 20 cattle in Banthra on Thursday. All six have been booked under the Uttar Pradesh Prevention of Cow Slaughter Act. Saadatganj SHO Mahesh Pal Singh said Vavan (32), Saif Ali (23), Vakiv (21), residents of Saadatganj, and Farhan (32) of Bazar Khala, were arrested with 250kg of cattle meat in a car, two country-made guns and five .315 bore bullets besides Rs 45,000 in cash. The accused have been booked under Prevention of Cow Slaughter Act and Arms Act. "We are tracing three absconding accused, Rahil, Mohsin and Khalid," SHO said. The arrests were made following a tip-off about a gang selling prohibited meat. Meanwhile, Banthra SHO Ramesh Singh said Afzal (28) and Papu (27), residents of Auraiya, were arrested for illegally transporting 20 prohibited cattle from Etawah to Bihar in a truck. Three cattle were found dead in the truck and a country-made gun and two .315 bore bullets were recovered from Afzal.

column2: 10 teachers sacked in Sitapur for marksheet fraud
column3: LUCKNOW: The basic shiksha adhikari (BSA) of Sitapur dismissed 10 teachers of government primary schools on Thursday for securing jobs by using fake BEd marksheet and certificates and lodged FIR against them. The action was taken after Allahabad high court-monitored special investigation team (SIT) probing the case, handed the list of fake teachers to the basic education department. The case pertains to irregularities in the issuance of marksheets of 2004-05 BEd session of Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar University in Agra. BSA, Sitapur, Ajay Kumar said, "SIT found that these teachers had obtained BEd degree from Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar University, Agra, in 2005. An FIR has been lodged against them and their salaries stopped." Two fraudsters were teaching since 2010, four were employed in 2011, two in 2014 and two others in 2015. The fraudsters will have to deposit the salary and allowances, they had withdrawn during their service period.

column2: UP government partially shuts three power plants post Diwali
column3: LUCKNOW: Amid UP government's claim of providing 24-hour power supply in the state till November 3, three power plants were partially shut on October 28, resulting in overall dip in power generation by over 1,000MW on a single day. The units that have been shut are: three units each of 300MW capacity at Rosa thermal power plant in Shahjahanpur, and two units each of 110MW capacity at Harduaganj plant in Aligarh and Parichha plant in Jhansi. These units have not been revived yet. According to the data of Northern Region Load Dispatch Centre, all the units faced a "reserve shutdown", meaning they were forcibly closed following the dip in demand for power. On Diwali, the demand had touched 20,000MW and subsequently fell to around 15,000MW. The demand for power registered a significant fall after Diwali and therefore the units which could have wheeled in power to the state grid had to be shut down, said a senior official of Uttar Pradesh Power Corporation Limited. Last month, three big units of 660MW each in Bara Meja and Lalitpur faced a shutdown following shortage of coal and technical problem. The units, which are yet to be restored, have led to deficit of nearly 2000MW power supply in the state. Besides, the 110MW unit in Parichha which has been put in the refurbishment mode since July, is yet to light up. Energy minister Srikant Sharma said the state government was committed to provide 24-hour power supply in urban as well as rural areas. He said the shutdown of power plants was done owing to lesser demand. "There is sufficient availability of power in the state. The closed units will be lighted up as and when required," he said.

column2: SSP Varanasi among 14 IPS transferred
column3: LUCKNOW: Senior superintendent of police (SSP), Varanasi, Anand Kulkarni, was on Thursday shifted to Lucknow as SP cyber crime. Prabhakar Chaudhary, posted as SP Sonbhadra, has been made the new SSP of Varanasi while Ashish Srivastava has been made the new SP of Sonabhadra. Altogether 14 IPS officers were shifted along with two Provincial Police Service (PPS) officers in the state on Thursday. The government also transferred SPs of Mahoba, Kaushambi, Chitrakoot along with additional SPs posted in Lucknow and Allahabad.

column2: Lucknow DM transferred to Varanasi
column3: LUCKNOW: In a slew of late night transfers on Thursday, Lucknow district magistrate (DM) Kaushal Raj Sharma was shifted as the DM of Varanasi and will be replaced by Abhishek Prakash, who is currently the DM of Hamirpur. The transfers saw several DMs, special secretaries and vice-presidents of development authorities being reshuffled. Sunil Patel, special secretary, power, has been transferred as Mirzapur DM while Srihari Pratap Shahi, special secretary, urban development, is the new DM of Ballia. He will replace Bhawani Singh Khagaraut, who has been posted as special secretary, power. Manvendra Singh, Lalitpur DM is Farukkhabad DM while Yogesh Kumar Shukla, special secretary, estate department, is the new Lalitpur DM. Vijay Vishwas Pant, Kanpur City DM has been given additional charge of Kanpur Development Authority, replacing Kinjal Singh, who is now special secretary, agriculture produce. Nitish Kumar, special secretary CM, is Bareilly DM. Surendra Singh, Varanasi DM has been posted as special secretary, CM. Virendra Kumar Singh, Bareilly DM, is the new special secretary, panchayati raj department. Gyaneshwar Tripathi, vice-president, Aligarh Development Authority, is the new Hamirpur DM and will be replaced by Manmohan Chowdhary, special secretary, skill development. Neha Sharma, Rae Bareli DM, has been transferred as special secretary, backward development. Shubhrant Shukla, special secretary, CM, has been now posted as special secretary, estate department.

column2: Ghaziabad: 31-yr-old gets life term for raping two minor girls
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 31-year-old man was sentenced to life imprisonment on Thursday for raping two girls, aged 9 and 10 years, in July this year.  The special (POCSO) court that wrapped up the case within 68 days of filing of the charge sheet, also slapped a fine of Rs 80,000 on the man on Thursday. Half of the amount will be given to the girl, whose mother had lodged a police complaint. The other girl is untraceable since the incident, the special public prosecutor (POCSO Act), Ranveer Singh Dagar, said. He added: "The accused had raped the girls on two occasions between July 14 and 16. The girls stay in same building in a colony. Both their mothers worked as house helps. The accused, Ashok Yadav, was a fruit and vegetable seller at Sahibabad wholesale market."  Yadav knew the mother of one of the girls and used to visit their house often. On July 14, he visited the house and found the girls playing there. He lured them to the Sahibabad market on the pretext of buying them food and then took them to a secluded room and raped them.  He threatened them with dire consequences if they spoke to anyone about it. On July 16 evening, Yadav visited the house once again and raped both girls who were there.  The mother of one of the girls lodged a police complaint on July 18. Later, Yadav was booked for rape and criminal intimidation and under relevant sections of the Protection of Children against Sexual Offences Act and caught. Since then he has been lodged in Dasna jail. Special judge (POCSO Act) Mahendra Srivastava found the man guilty under IPC sections 376 AB (rape on girls under 12 years) and 506 (criminal intimidation) and under the SC/ST Act. Under IPC 376 AB, Yadav was awarded the maximum sentence of life imprisonment and Rs 50,000 in fine. Section 506 attracted two years' rigorous imprisonment and Rs 5,000 in fine. The court awarded 10 years in jail and a fine of Rs 25,000. The sentences will run concurrently, Dagar said. (The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

column2: Gangster Act against illegal e-waste recylers in Loni soon
column3: GHAZIABAD: Illegal e-waste recyclers in Loni will soon be booked under the Gangster Act. This was ordered by the Ghaziabad district magistrate on Thursday, soon after over 100 kg of e-waste was seized by a joint team of district administration and police from Loni's Sewa Dham area. A show-cause notice has also been issued to the SHO of Loni border police station over the amassing of e-waste by illegal vendors in the area, officials said.  TOI has already reported that these illegal units are involved in melting battery, cables and other e-waste material to procure valuable metal residues for local industries. The toxic fumes thus generated leads to a sudden spike in PM10 levels and other pollutants in the vicinity. Loni's air quality index is the worst in Ghaziabad currently.  DM Ajay Shankar Pandey, who led the team along with the SSP, said that e-waste is being brought to Ghaziabad from Delhi's border area and that he will write to the authorities in the national capital to look into the matter. Earlier, the district authorities had dismantled 30 such units in Loni and registered an FIR against five persons. "We have already requested the Central Pollution Control Board to conduct an investigation and suggest ways to deal with the problem of e-waste and its disposal," he said.  The SDM and the tehsildar have also been asked to prepare a list of vendors, who procure e-waste and then dispose them here in Loni, along with the names of people on whose land this activity is going on. "Not only the recyclers of e-waste but the owners of the land where the same is dumped will be booked under the Gangster Act," he said.  "The SHO of Loni has asked to submit a report on the supply chain of waste and who all are involved in this illegal business," the DM added. Officials said that vendors start their businesses during night hours to avoid detection. "The shortage of personnel does inhibit how we function," Prakash Singh, tehsildar of Loni Nagar Palika, told TOI on Wednesday. Pandey said besides scientific disposal of the waste, its transportation will also be the responsibility of a firm selected by the government for this purpose.

column2: Lucknow: Hit-and-run accidents claimed one life every day in 2017, two hurt daily
column3: LUCKNOW: One person was killed almost every day in a hit-and-run in the state capital in 2017, according to the recently released National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) data. Of the total 413 road deaths in the city that year, 339 were victims of hit-and-run accidents. In terms of this absolute number, Lucknow is in third place among the 19 ‘metropolitan cities’ after Delhi (458) and Jaipur (441). If the rate of incidence per one lakh population is considered, the state capital with 11.2 is in second place after Jaipur (13.3). Not just deaths, the number of those injured owing to rash driving is also high in Lucknow. On an average, two persons are injured daily given that the total number for 2017 was 807. In this category, Lucknow ranks fifth among the 19 cities. Two years down the line, there has been no let-up in hitand-run accidents in Lucknow. In most cases in 2019, police have not been able to identify the vehicles, let alone catch the driver. Experts feel the increase in number of vehicles and lack of stringent punishment are responsible for both reckless driving and resulting accidents. As recently as October 16, a 21-year-old mechanical engineering student was run over by a speeding car in front his college on Sultanpur highway. The vehicle has not been identified. In another hit-and-run on September 15, a toddler was crushed under the wheels of an SUV in Gomtinagar extension. The killer vehicle is yet to be tracked down. SP Vikrant Vir said surveillance cameras were being installed across the city. “These will help us catch culprits of hit-and-run cases. The cameras will also serve as deterrent for reckless motorists and bikers,” he added.

column2: Delhi's air quality drops to 'emergency' category first time since January
column3: NEW DELHI: The blanket of haze over Delhi thickened on Friday morning with the national capital's pollution levels increasing overnight by around 50 points, taking the overall air quality index to 459. A Central Pollution Control Board official said the AQI entered the "severe plus" or "emergency" category late Thursday night, the first time since January this year. Track the pollution level in your cityIf the air quality persists in the "severe plus" category for more than 48 hours, emergency measures such as odd-even car rationing scheme, banning entry of trucks, construction activities and shutting down schools are taken under the Graded Response Action Plan, the official said. The hazardous pollution levels forced a number of people to miss morning walks and other activities. Shubhomoy Sikdar, a Delhi-based journalist, said the pollution levels gave him a throat infection and he had to skip his daily sports session. Amanpreet Singh, a resident of Jangpura, said he has been avoiding morning and evening walks and preferring to stay indoors. The number of masked faces continued to grow as the city remained shrouded in pungent haze for the fourth consecutive day. At 8.30 am, the capital's overall air quality index stood at 459. It was 410 at 8 pm on Thursday. All the 37 air quality monitoring stations across Delhi recorded the air quality in the severe category on Friday morning. Bawana was the most-polluted area with an AQI of 497, followed by Delhi Technological University (487), Wazirpur (485), Anand Vihar (484) and Vivek Vihar (482). Neighbouring Ghaziabad was the most-polluted city in the country, with the levels of PM2.5 -- tiny particulate matter less than 2.5 microns that can enter deep into the lungs -- reaching as high as 493. Greater Noida (480), Noida (477), and Faridabad (432) also breathed extremely polluted air. An AQI between 0-50 is considered “good”, 51-100 “satisfactory”, 101-200 “moderate”, 201-300 “poor”, 301-400 “very poor”, and 401-500 “severe”. Above 500 is “severe-plus or emergency” category. Delhi is impatiently hoping for favourable meteorological conditions to blow away the toxic air, as health experts said the hazardous air pollution has become a serious health concern for about 2 crore residents. "Intake of every 22 micrograms per cubic metre of polluted air is equivalent to smoking a cigarette. So whether the PM2.5 level is 700 or 300 units, the impact is still as bad. People need to take precautions, especially those suffering from asthma, bronchitis or other respiratory illness," said Dr Arvind Kumar, lung surgeon at Sir Ganga Ram Hospital here. Weather experts said increased wind speed due to a fresh western disturbance approaching the northern region would help disperse pollutants faster from Saturday. Parents are a worried lot as health experts say children breathe faster, taking in more pollutants. Many took to Twitter to demand that schools be shut till the situation ameliorates. "We, as parents, request Delhi government to keep all schools (pvt and govt) shut for the time being," Anil Atri, a Delhi resident, posted on the microblogging site. "Whole Delhi air at hazardous levels now. Pollution at its peak. Activate all emergency measures. Close down schools @msisodia (sic)," another resident tweeted. Deputy chief minister Manish Sisodia had on Wednesday said the decision to shut schools would be taken "when the need arises". In November 2017, the government had shut schools for a few days due to the deteriorating air quality. The government, however, started distributing 50 lakh N95 masks, considered one of the good quality masks for tackling smog, among school students in Delhi on Friday morning. Meanwhile, the BCCI said it would carry on with the India-Bangladesh T20 at the Feroz Shah Kotla grounds on Sunday, disregarding concerns raised by environmentalists about the health of players and thousands of spectators. The AQI takes into account five chief pollutants -- particulate matter with a diameter less than 10 micrometres (PM10), PM2.5, ozone (O3), nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and carbon monoxide (CO). The higher the AQI value, the greater the level of air pollution and health concerns.

column2: Breast cancer survivors walk the ramp in Lucknow
column3: In a unique initiative, a fashion show for Breast Cancer survivors was organised by the Endocrine Surgery Department of King George Medical University (KGMU), Lucknow, at the Atal Bihari Vajpayee Scientific Convention Center recently, in which both men and women breast cancer survivors walked the ramp. The fashion show included two male breast cancer survivors along with 50 women survivors from various districts of the state, who participated in the ramp walk which was organised to create awareness among people about the disease. (L) Padmini Kolhapure (R) Anamika Bhatt (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Padmini Kolhapure (R) Anamika Bhatt (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) The chief guest for the event was Bollywood actress Padmini Kolhapure whereas the guest of the honour was playback singer Tripti Shakya. While interacting with the survivors, Padmini Kolhapure said, "Breast cancer is the most common of the cancers. I would like to request the families of the those afflicted with the disease to support them. If these women get a little support from their family, a little love, I think they will be able to encounter anything in their life." The Prem Rog actress also sang a song from her movie, Zindagi Pyaar Ka Geet Hai, Ise Har Dil Ko Gaana Padega. (L) Anand Mishra (C) Prof Rama Kant (R) Dr Arun Chaturvedi (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Anand Mishra (C) Prof Rama Kant (R) Dr Arun Chaturvedi (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) "The main objective of this program is to bring the patients who have already conquered this battle, in front of those who are suffering from breast cancer so that those who are struggling with this disease, will be motivated and will also increase their confidence to get their treatment done," said the organiser of the event, Prof Anand Mishra, HOD of Endocrine Surgery Department. Students enacting a play (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Students enacting a play (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) One of the male breast cancer survivor, Mehtab Khan, who lives in Shivpuri, Hussainabad, sharing his experience, said, "When I was diagnosed with the disease, I was told that its treatment will cost a lot of money which I was unable to afford. So I refused to get the treatment done but then I went to KGMU and Prof Anand Mishra helped me and did my treatment and that too at a very low cost." Rakesh Kumar Dwivedi from Hamirpur, UP, another survivor, shared, "I was diagnosed at the second stage of breast cancer in 2016. I was told to have an operation and I am totally healthy at the moment. I will also like to convey a message to others that if it is checked on time, cancer is not incurable." Breast cancer survivors (left and right) walking the ramp (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Breast cancer survivors (left and right) walking the ramp (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) A skit was also staged about the disease and its effect on people. A group of students also staged a play in an effort to create awareness about the disease and its prevention. — Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui (L) Tripti Shakya (R) Breast cancer survivors (left and right) walking the ramp (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Tripti Shakya (R) Breast cancer survivors (left and right) walking the ramp (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

column2: #LucknowChokes: Docs suggest measures to survive in the city
column3: This might be the ‘cleanest’ Diwali Lucknow has seenin recent years but the pollution level in the city is still in the severe/hazardous level. The day after Diwali, the city woke up to a drastically worsened air quality with the air quality index (AQI) rising to a ‘hazardous’ 326 and the number of people visiting hospitals with respiratory ailments going up by 15% as per reports. According to doctors the number of people complaining of respiratory problems, cough and sore throat has gone up by more than 30% in the past few days. Post Diwali, the air quality in Lucknow deteriorated further to 314 on Tuesday from being 304 on Monday, and went up even more on Wednesday. On Friday, till afternoon, the AQI in Lucknow was again in the red with it touching 324 at 3.30 PM, well over the hazardous range with Rajajipuram being the most polluted area with an AQI of 375 followed by Qiaserbagh with an AQI of 322.  While people are trying to do their bit by using air purifiers in their homes and going out wearing masks, doctors share a few suggestions to help people go about their daily lives in the toxic air. (BCCL)ENCOURAGE PHYSICAL ACTIVITIES WITHIN HOMEAnupam Sibal, Group Medical Director, Apollo Hospitals Group, accepts that the situation has been better this year but adds that the days after Diwali actually represent the damage that has happened. “When you look out of the window today, you can really see the damage that has happened to the environment. Things that we can do as parents is that we should not encourage any outdoor activities when the AQI is so high. The best time for a child to go out would be in the afternoon if they have to go to the park. We need to encourage activities within the house. Outdoor activities in schools have also been curtailed, though this is something that kids should not have to deal with, but in this situation, it is best advised to avoid being outside. If you have a history of respiratory problems or you feel uncomfortable going out, stepping outside is not recommended. While the AQI going beyond 300 is an important factor, the number is not everything. You have to see how you are feeling, irrespective of AQI levels,” he says. AVOID USING AGARBATTIS, MOSQUITO SPRAYS AND CAMPHORVivek Nangia, Director and Head of Pulmonology at Fortis Flt Lt Rajan Dhall Hospital, adds, “We need to decide on our outdoor activities depending on the AQI level. When the AQI is more than 400, then people should avoid going out. We should be restricting outdoor movement to the bare minimum and keep our indoor environment as clean as possible. Avoid using agarbattis, mosquito repellent sprays or using camphor inside your home. These are simple measures that one should be taking. Take a walk only when it is bright and sunny outside.” Hazratganj shrouded in smog on Friday (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Hazratganj shrouded in smog on Friday (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) WEAR PROTECTIVE CLOTHINGRashmi Sharma, Consultant Dermatologist at Fortis Hospital, Delhi, says that people are advised to wear protective clothing in this weather. "With increasing level of air pollution, problems like complexion mediated change, dryness, premature ageing, flare up of conditions like allergic-contact dermatitis, irritant-contact dermatitis, acne, psoriasis and eczema also increases. I recommend that people should avoid going out, and if you do, wash your face with a soap-free cleanser once you come back. You should frequently re-apply moisturiser and sunscreen should be used four-five times a day. In your diet, you should increase citrus fruits, and consume apples and cranberries. When going out, cover your face, wear bandanas, glasses, hand gloves and focus on protective clothing,” she advises. Meanwhile. Infectious Disease expert, KGMU, Dr Amita Jain, says, “People should try and stay indoors as much as possible specially in the early mornings and evenings. Also, wearing a good quality mask is imperative for the people right now.” KEEP YOURSELF HYDRATED Dr Rajiv Garg, Professor at the Dept of Respiratory Medicine, and Pulmonologist, KGMU, said, “The number of patients suffering from respiratory problems, specially asthma and COPD has increased by 30% off late. If the Air Quality Index (AQI) goes higher than 300, it is considered hazardous. If there is about particulate matter (PM) 22 micro grams/cubic metre in air, that’ll be equal to smoking one cigarette. In such cases, all I can suggest is for people to keep indoors or if at all they can’t avoid it, they should use good quality masks. Hydration is another helpful thing in such cases.” This Diwali, once again the air quality in Lucknow dipped to ‘hazardous’ levels, with the PM 2.5 concentration crossing 600 on the night of Diwali (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) This Diwali, once again the air quality in Lucknow dipped to ‘hazardous’ levels, with the PM 2.5 concentration crossing 600 on the night of Diwali (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) INSTALL AIR PURIFIERS IN SCHOOLSNeerav Arora, a homeopathy doctor in the city, advises, “There has been a massive increase in the number of patients suffering from respiratory allergies, bronchial asthma, acute exacerbation of COPD, pneumonia and possibly Tuberculosis in the last 15 days with increase in the air pollution and the smog settling down. As immediate precautions, one should maintain cleanliness in and around their houses, clean hands on a regular basis, wear masks before walking out in the open, avoid exposure to people already suffering from acute infections, keeping yourself well hydrated and avoid early morning and late evening walks." Adding further Arora says, “Taking vitamin C and Omega 3 fatty acids on a regular basis can help fight respiratory infections and allergies. We do not recommend masks for kids below the age of three because they can choke. Schools should ensure that they have air purifiers inside classrooms. Schools and parents should cut down on sports and games for kids because when you do any physical activity, your heartbeat goes up and you inhale more pollutants. Another age group that gets really affected by the poor air quality is the elderly. Using a mask is very important whenever going out and use air purifiers in cars as well.”  — With inputs from Yashi Agarwal

column2: Respect SC judgment, say mosques across UP
column3: AYODHYA/LUCKNOW: Mosques across Uttar Pradesh on Friday made an ‘elaan’ (announcement) for peace and brotherhood, and for respecting the Supreme Court verdict in the Ayodhya dispute due by the 17 th of this month. “Avoid any slogans, celebrations or complaints, and exhort national integration so that the country’s harmony is undisturbed,” was the collective message delivered to millions of Muslims in the state. In Lucknow, Imam of Aishbagh Eidgah and executive member of All India Muslim Personal Law Board (AIMPLB) Maulana Khalid Rasheed Farangi Mahali made an emphatic appeal to this effect in his address before Friday prayers. Mosques in Ayodhya and adjoining Faizabad also made appeals for peace. “There should be no outward celebrations or expression of remorse, sloganeering or such activities that hurt the religious sentiments of other communities after the verdict,” declared Mahali. “When the SC decides, we should all remember that the decision has been made by the highest court of law, and it should be respected by each one of us,” he added at the Eidgah in a room full of namazis. He also asked the youth to bust the myths about Islam on social media and appealed to all to hold national unity above all. “The current Islamic month of Rabi-ul-Awwal is Prophet Muhammad’s birth month. The Prophet made clear that Islam spreads love, harmony and brotherhood among all creations of Allah. He asked us to stay away from animosity. This is the time we prove with our actions that Islam is indeed a religion of peace,” said the cleric. Disseminating his appeal through social media, Mahali said, “To maintain peace is the responsibility of all and it has been a positive step that Hindu organisations like RSS and Vishwa Hindu Parishad have also asked for the same. The gesture is not limited to one community but has to be reciprocated. It is not a time to be fearful but to repose all trust in the country’s justice system.” Similar appeals, he confirmed to TOI, were made at mosques in Sitapur, Kanpur, Muzaffarnagar, Lakhimpur, Bahraich, Gorakhpur, Leherpur and other places. At Ayodhya’s Kotiya Masjid, Imam Ishtiaq Ahmed addressed devotees. “Everyone was asked to maintain calm in Ayodhya and accept the apex court’s verdict. No event should be given a communal colour,” said Babri Masjid litigant Iqbal Ansari, who was present at Kotiya mosque. Another litigant, Mohammad Umar, who attended prayers at Kewda Masjid of Ayodhya, said: “We were assured by the administration in a meeting on Wednesday that adequate security is present and there will be no breach of peace. We decided to share that assurance with our brethren, who were worried that mob from outside of Ayodhya will ruin peace here.” “The chief Imam told everyone to not be scared or leave the city but to respect the SC’s verdict,” he added. Even at political levels, efforts were made in Ayodhya for peace by holding peace meetings with influential locals. Such meetings were held by Peace Party on Thursday and Samajwadi Party on Friday.

column2: Health emergency in Delhi-NCR as pollution hits ‘severe+’ zone
column3: NEW DELHI: As pollution levels reached apocalyptic levels on Friday with nearly 44% of the capital’s PM2.5 load coming from stubble burning emissions in the neighbouring states, the Supreme Court-appointed Environment Pollution (Prevention and Control) Authority declared a public health emergency in Delhi-NCR and banned all construction activities till November 5. Track the pollution level in your cityThe Delhi government announced shutting down of schools during the same period. It also decided to stagger working hours of its offices during the implementation of the 12-day odd-even scheme, from November 4. EPCA chairman Bhure Lal, who wrote to the four NCR states as the pollution levels in the region entered the season’s worst in ‘severe plus’ category, also banned bursting of crackers during the entire winter season. Delhi’s air quality index (AQI) on Friday, according to CPCB, was at 484 — the highest this season. The previous high in 2019 was on January 3 when the AQI stood at 444. On November 9, 2017, the index touched 486, while on November 6, 2016, it had recorded an all-time high of 497. In terms of NCR, Noida had the worst air quality in the entire country with an AQI of 500, followed by Ghaziabad and Greater Noida, both at 496, Faridabad at 479 and Gurgaon at 469.

column2: Lucknow: Three more died due to dengue in October, season's toll at seven
column3: LUCKNOW: The district health department on Friday confirmed three more deaths due to dengue in the city, taking the toll to seven this season so far. Besides, 46 fresh dengue cases were reported, the highest in a single day this year. TimesViewThe dengue outbreak in the city has now assumed menacing proportion with over 1000 cases and six deaths. Most cases and deaths were reported in October which shows that anti-mosquito measures taken by the authorities failed in containing the virus. TOI had earlier highlighted reported how lack of coordination between the district health department and the Lucknow Municipal Corporation has taken the sting out of drive against dengue. People in many locality complained that anti-larvae spray is not followed by adequate fogging. Also, no action has been taken against vacant plots where water-logging has become haven for mosquito breeding. Authorities need to involve resident welfare associations and run a massive awareness as well as preventive campaign against dengue. The three deaths confirmed on Friday had taken place earlier but were taken 'on record' after an audit reported by various hospitals to chief medical officer (CMO) Dr Narendra Agarwal.  "After examining the documents of the death cases provided by the hospitals, we found that three more patients had died due to dengue in October," said the CMO.  The three deceased include Ramesh Pandey (43) from Preetinagar, who died at SGPGI on October 20, Siddharth Sankar Pandey (25) from Alambagh, who died at a private hospital on October 26 and Ankit Singh (27) from Bandariya Bagh who died on October 27. Of the total fresh cases reported on Friday, three were critical and admitted to KGMU. Other patients were out of danger and recovering in their homes. Meanwhile, health department teams also found 24 places, including agriculture directorate at Hazratganj, infested with the larvae of the Aedes aegypti mosquito, which carries the dengue virus.

column2: Bunty-Babli goes high profile, held in London for Rs 1.76 crore export fraud in Bulandshahr
column3: LUCKNOW/MEERUT: A Delhi couple who allegedly pulled off a Rs 1.76-crore export fraud in Bulandshahr, UP, and possibly conned banks and farmers out of another Rs 800 crore was arrested in London last month, more than four years after an FIR was registered against them. The Economic Offences Wing (EOW) of UP Police has moved a Westminster court for the deportation of Vir Karan Awasthi (51) and Reetika Awasthi (49), residents of Saket Nagar, Delhi. Director-general (EOW) Rajendra Pal Singh said the husband-wife duo, against whom Interpol had issued a red notice, were arrested from an apartment in Stafford Street at Mayfair, London, on October 9. "The court (in Westminster) has sought details of the prison where we plan to keep the couple. We have chosen Gautam Buddha Nagar (district) jail in UP. Details are being forwarded," he added. ASP (EOW), Meerut, Ram Suresh Yadav said a company in Bulandshahr registered the case against Bush Foods Overseas Pvt. Ltd, owned by the Awasthis, on September 11, 2015, and the state government handed over investigations to EOW (Meerut) in March 2016. According to the complaint lodged by victim Lokender Singh, owner of Saurabh & Co., Bush Foods purchased from his firm Rs 1.76-crore worth of paddy for export, but never paid a penny. The FIR charged the Awasthis with cheating, criminal breach of trust, forgery of valuable security, using genuine document as forged and criminal intimidation. "During investigations, we found that the (export) fraud is only the tip of the iceberg. The (total) fraud is worth over Rs 800 crore. Vir Karan fled to London soon after he was named in the FIR. Reetika managed to get a stay on her arrest, but Allahabad high court, on October 20, 2015, asked her not to leave country," ASP Yadav said.

column2: Woman assaulted for stopping four men from drinking in Aashiana
column3: LUCKNOW: A 35-year-old woman was assaulted by four men when she prevented them from consuming alcohol on the road near her house in Aashiana on Friday. Lodging an FIR in this connection, Rakesh Singh of Qila Gaon in Aashiana said Madan Kumar Gautam (27) of the same locality and his three aides were consuming alcohol on the roadside at around 6pm on Thursday. "My wife Geetanjali was passing through the area and objected to their act as the road is used by women and children. However, instead of heeding to her demand, the men got angry and had a heated exchange with Geetanjali," he said. Singh alleged that Gautam picked up a brick from the road and hit Geetanjali on her forehead. With the help of neighbours, Singh rushed his wife to Lok Bandhu Hospital in LDA Colony, and after preliminary treatment, shifted her to a private hospital in Bangla Bazar. Sub-inspector, Aashiana, Dalveer Singh Yadav said, "We have identified the aides of the prime accused who all are absconding. We are trying to trace their location."

column2: Swine flu returns to haunt Lucknow with 55-fold rise in cases
column3: LUCKNOW: It is not only dengue that is creating havoc in the state as swine flu (H1N1 virus) has also raised its ugly head registering a whopping 55-fold rise in the number of cases as compared to last year. While only 37 H1N1 cases and six deaths were reported in 2018, at least 2,086 people have been tested positive and 35 of them have lost their lives till October this year. Lucknow has registered the highest 550 cases this year. TimesViewThe health department has given directions to government hospitals to create isolation wards for swine flu patients and get medical staff vaccinated, but it also needs to create awareness among people to check the spread of the disease. Apart from general awareness through media, posters and placards should be put up in hospitals informing people about precautions. Separate arrangements should be made for the patients suffering with any kind of flu or with flu symptoms in the hospital and they should not be allowed to mix with others till the test rules out swine flu.According to experts, swine flu cases will increase in coming days as the virus flourishes from January to March and August to October. According to the data shared by the office of director (communicable diseases), 2,086 people have been tested positive this year, including 1,967 cases and 27 deaths between January and May. Despite being considered ‘off season’, eight cases were reported in June. A patient was tested positive in July who later succumbed to infection. In the second half of the year, 13 cases were reported in August, 49 in September and 48 in October. Four and three deaths, respectively, occurred in September and October. Between August and October, at least 110 cases and seven deaths have been reported across UP with Lucknow clocking the highest 40 H1N1 cases. District-wise comparison reveals that Lucknow registered 511 cases from January to July, 10 in August, 19 in September and 10 in October. Seven pregnant women tested positive in September and October. Meerut, with 399 swine flu cases and five deaths till October, is at second place followed by Ghaziabad (337 cases and one death). Director, communicable and vector-borne diseases, Mithilesh Chaturvedi said: “Though H1N1 cases have increased manifold this year, the fatality rate (number of deaths in every 100 positive cases) is low. The rate has come down to 1.68 this year as compared to 16.22 in 2018 and 3.40 in 2017 because of steps taken by the health department.” “Adequate supply of Tamiflu to primary health centres and district-level hospitals has been ensured. Funds have been provided for emergency requirements and isolation wards have been created in hospitals. Medical staff is also being vaccinated,” she said.

column2: Delhi's air at its foulest for the season; Noida India's worst
column3: NEW DELHI: Delhi saw its worst air yet this season on Friday. The Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) rated the pollution at an AQI of 484, similar to the all-time high of 497 recorded on November 6, 2016. The fate of the other NCR cities was similar, with AQI touching 500 in Noida, 496 in Ghaziabad and Greater Noida, 479 in Faridabad and 469 in Gurugram. Track the pollution level in your cityThe CPCB central control room showed PM2.5 in Delhi crossing the severe plus level of 300 micrograms per cubic metre and recorded 319 micrograms per cubic metre at 3am on Friday. According to SAFAR, the forecasting agency under the Union ministry of earth sciences, stubble burning contributed 44% to the PM2.5 load. PM10 also breached the severe plus mark of 500 microgram per cubic metre. The safe standards for these ultrafine pollutants are, respectively, 60 and 100 micrograms per cubic metre. At 8pm, the PM2.5 and PM10 readings were, respectively, 380.2 and 569.6 micrograms per cubic metre. There isn’t much to look forward to with the meteorological department saying the air quality will likely remain foul till at least Sunday. “Wind speed picked up a bit on Friday evening. However, substantial improvement is not expected before Sunday morning. In fact, the pollution level might remain severe on Sunday as well,” said Kuldeep Srivastava, IMD scientist. EPCA chairman Bhure Lal wrote to the chief secretaries of Rajasthan, Delhi, Haryana and UP and directed the cessation of construction activities, hot mix plants and stone crushers in Delhi, Faridabad, Gurugram, Ghaziabad, Noida and Greater Noida till the morning of November 5. All coal and other fuel-based industries that hadn’t shifted to natural gas or agro-residue too would remain shut in Faridabad, Gurugram, Ghaziabad, Noida, Bahadurgarh, Bhiwadi, Greater Noida, Sonipat and Panipat till November 5 morning. Lal noted that there were festivals coming up, but banned the use of any firecrackers. He said Diwali proved that fireworks resulted in “accumulation of toxins in the air”. Gurugram had its first severe-level pollution on Friday (AQI 469), as did Manesar (AQI 427). Haryana State Pollution Control Board promptly asked all district administrations, industries, construction companies and regional officers to comply with the EPCA bans. An advisory was also issued to the education department to restrict outdoor activities of students. HSPCB member secretary S. Narayan told TOI, “We are also undertaking measures like sprinkling of water and reducing road dust.” The AQI touched the 500 mark in Noida at around 5pm on Friday and it shared with neighbouring Ghaziabad the distinction of being the most polluted cities in the country. Uttar Pradesh Pollution Control Board officials warned that impurity level was likely to spike by midnight “because there is no ventilation”. UPCCB official Anil Singh said, “While we are taking action to mitigate dust pollution in Noida with water sprinklers and other measures, a low wind speed is causing a continuous build-up of pollutants.”

column2: Ghaziabad's answer to severe air: Shift monitoring stations
column3: GHAZIABAD: Four days of severe air on the trot has prompted the Ghaziabad district administration to finally dig out the reason - the city's four monitoring stations are located close to auto stands or petrol pumps and do not paint a clear picture of the overall air quality. Track the pollution level in your citySo, the Uttar Pradesh Pollution Control Board hassuggested that these monitoring stations be shifted to areas that are less prone to vehicular pollution and has written to the CPCB in this regard. Around 4pm on Friday, the average AQI in Ghaziabad was 496. Around 7pm, the Sanjay Nagar monitoring station clocked 658.  "The monitoring stations in Loni and Sanjay Nagar - which were made operational only this year - have continuously been showing high AQI for the past seven days now. Against this backdrop, we deliberated with the administration on the possible reasons," said Utsav Sharma, regional officer of UPPCB. "It was agreed that hyper-local factors around the monitoring stations have been causing the high AQI, which may be different from the actual picture. The administration has proposed that the locations of at least two of the monitoring stations be changed at the earliest," he added.

column2: Man fires at husband of ex in Aashiana, misses target
column3: LUCKNOW: A 30-year-old property dealer had a narrow escape when his wife's former boyfriend opened fire at him in Aashiana earlier this week. The incident took place on Tuesday, but an FIR was lodged on Thursday night. According to the police complaint, the accused who owns a shop in Aminabad is still obsessed with his former girlfriend and wanted her husband out of his way. Two days after Diwali, he came in front of their house and fired a round. The complainant, who was seated on a bike, ducked in time and the bullet missed him by a whisker. Aashiana sub-inspector Vinay Kumar Tiwari said, "We are verifying the statement given by the complainant and inquiring about the accused named in the FIR."

column2: Kamlesh Tewari murder case: Man held in Kanpur for supplying pistol to killers
column3: LUCKNOW: Uttar Pradesh Anti-Terrorist Squad (UP ATS) arrested a man from Kanpur late on Friday evening on charges of supplying firearm used in the murder of Hindutva leader Kamlesh Tewari in Lucknow on October 18. Police had recovered a .32 bore pistol from the scene of crime after the murder and later confirmed that Kamlesh was shot and stabbed. The arrested man was identified as Yusuf Khan (24), a native of Fatehpur. He has three FIRs - one under the Arms Act and two of extortion - against him in Surat which were lodged between 2015 and 2018. UP ATS made the arrest on the basis of specific information provided by their Gujarat counterparts about Yusuf's involvement in Kamlesh Tewari murder case. One of the alleged killers, Ashfaq, had supposedly purchased the pistol from Yusuf in Surat for Rs 50,000 in 2018. According to Gujarat ATS, Yusuf had handed over the pistol to Ashfaq in Surat before shifting base to UP. Investigators are now trying to decipher how and from whom did Ashfaq got the cartridges which were used in executing the murder. So far, police have arrested 12 people in connection with the murder case. Ashfaq and Moinuddin have been held for committing the murder while Maulana Sheikh Saleem, Rashid Pathan and Faizan have been arrested for hatching the conspiracy.

column2: Lucknow: Commuters flouted traffic rules while cops remained busy inaugurating the Road Safety Month close by
column3: Road Safety Month (November) in the city is a paradox in itself. While police were busy flagging off the campaign at 1090 Crossing on Friday, people were actively flouting traffic rules unchallenged barely 50 metre away. Between 4pm and 5pm, TOI saw violations ranging from quintuple-riding (five on a two-wheeler) and helmetless biking by both policemen and commoners to speeding, driving without seat belts and driving in wrong lane. Bikers and motorists on phone was a common sight; and then, there were overloaded passenger and goods vehicles. TimesViewThe inauguration of ‘Road Safety Month’ meant to enforce traffic rules and make people aware of law turned out to be an eyewash. Not only violators went past police squad at the inaugural venue with impunity, some who were caught got away without any challan by making lame excuses. This explains why people do not take traffic rules seriously in the city. Discipline becomes a habit only when people are made to understand that the traffic rules are for their own safety and the laws are enforced strictly.The opening ceremony, which began around 4pm, was attended by the who’s who of police, including ADG (Lucknow zone), IG (Lucknow range), IG (traffic), DIG (traffic) and the SSP. Stone’s throw from the function and right under the nose of senior officers, Young Lucknow was being reckless as ever while senior citizens tried to stick to safety guidelines. “We are faster than cops. We can play dodge forever. They will never catch us,” said one among three youths on a bike. Most auto-rickshaw drivers at 1090 Crossing were without uniform and were ferrying more than three passengers. Cars had tinted windows and most people behind the wheel forgot to strap on the seat belt. Lucknow police spokesperson Ashish Dwivedi, however, claimed they had booked 922 people for flouting traffic rules on Day One of the safety month. “As many as 318 were biking without helmet, 89 were penalised for driving in wrong direction,” he said. Dwivedi added that senior police officers made people aware about traffic rules and safety signboards at the inauguration.

column2: Bus conductor molests woman in Uttar Pradesh
column3: LUCKNOW: A 21-year-old woman was allegedly molested by the conductor of Uttar Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation (UPSRTC) bus on Thursday, while she was travelling from Firozabad to Lucknow. According to police, the woman is a resident of Mathura and boarded the bus for Lucknow. As the bus was packed, she had to sit next to the conductor. When the bus reached Alambagh bus station, the conductor allegedly started touching her inappropriately. When she objected, he started arguing with her. The woman got down from the bus at Alambagh and later lodged a complaint on Friday. SHO (Alambagh) Anand Kumar Shahi said, "The woman has given us the bus registration number and we are trying to track down the conductor." (The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

column2: How used became chic
column3: Pre-loved fashion has found a new market as shoppers look for smart and sustainable luxuryOn the eve of Karva Chauth this year, a young woman decided to get an Italian clutch for her mother-in-law. A few discreet calls later, not only did she find a coveted designer purse at a substantially lower price, but it came with a happy little note on how she was supporting sustainability. The latest entrant in feel-good commerce, is ‘pre-loved’, ‘gently-loved’ or ‘tried-and-treasured’ luxury products, euphemisms for being, essentially, second-hand. Companies that pride themselves on privacy — for both the buyer and seller — are creating a neat marketplace for those who have a glut of high-luxe bags, shoes and clothes and also those who covet them. Those in the business point to three areas that have prompted this change: the new trend in ‘sustainable living’, which has become the buzzword even among children; a growing exposure to the West, which has long loved ‘vintage fashion’ in all its stained and faded glory; and that abiding urge to acquire a designer product. As Mansi Poddar, who runs a lifestyle website and does pop-ups which include curated vintage clothing, says, “While a certain type of Indian woman may have been perfectly comfortable wearing a grandmother’s hand-me-down sari, she was not as comfortable buying a second-hand branded dress or accessory. Today, that has changed.” NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSSaudi's response on India's oil reserves 'undiplomatic': PradhanUnion minister for oil, petroleum and natural gas Dharmendra Pradhan on Friday termed Saudi Arabia's response on India's strategic oil reserves as 'undiplomatic' and said that India is conscious about its interest.PM Modi invites 50 Bangladeshi entrepreneurs to visit IndiaAddressing Bangladesh's 50th Independence Day anniversary at the National Parade Square, Modi said: "It is a happy coincidence that the 50th anniversary of Bangladesh's liberation and the milestone of the 75th year of India's independence have arrived together.Recently, a young mother received a request on her mommy WhatsApp chat group from someone looking around for a ‘pre-loved cycle’ for her five year-old’s birthday gift. “Maybe all those birthday party invites which ask for ‘blessings only’ will now turn into ‘second hand only’!” she joked. The mindset of people is changing, and people are now talking about buying pre-owned luxury products openly and confidently, says Monica Gupta, who runs triedandtreasured.com. When Gupta hosted her first exhibition in Mumbai a year ago, she felt that there was a slight social stigma attached to the idea. “By my second exhibition, I had women flocking to get my products. I remember I didn’t have my credit card machine set up, and there were people doing RTGS transactions there and then,” says Gupta, who gets clients from metros as well as Tier 2 cities Ahmedabad, Jaipur and Lucknow. “You begin to see the potential of a market which is aspirational but obviously not at exorbitant prices.” Now, many women who buy high-luxe products, are consciously keeping the packaging and invoices because they know that there is an avenue for resale, adds Jain. In fact, there is a buzzing market among collectors worldwide for high-end luxe items which may have gone out of circulation. So, an Italian python-skin purse may even fetch a higher price today than its original price. Or, a vintage designer collection from the seventies may be coveted for its sheer period beauty. When Poddar held a vintage pop-up in Mumbai last year, curated by the style queen Roohi Jaikishan for charity, it was a sellout. “These weren’t people who couldn’t afford new fashion, it was more people who knew that something they were buying was a 60s piece which you wouldn’t get again,” she says. Long before ‘pre-loved’ and ‘vintage’ popped up on Instagram, Indians have been veteran upcyclers, used to wearing hand-me-downs passed down from cousins, As Hanna Stromgren Khan, co-founder of VRTT vintage, says, “The Indian culture is fairly used to the whole idea of passing on. What’s new here is the whole transaction aspect of it.” VRTT vintage, describes itself as a company that “highlights the benefits and fun of passing on personal culture… our aim is not only to change the way we consume fashion, but also to put environment and future first…”. The way the pass-on process works is that it takes in branded items like shoes, bags, accessories or clothing whose original retail price was no less than Rs 15,000. The pieces are then authenticated, approved, and remain on a consignment basis for about 90 days. The seller gets 65% of the sale price, and 5% goes to charity. “Sustainability is on everyone’s radar,” says Stromgren Khan. “Today, everyone wants to be engaged in activities that are good for the environment.”

column2: Daylight robbery of work and most crucially creativity, is wrong: Vishal Dadlani in Lucknow
column3: Vocalist and music composer Vishal Dadlani, who is known for his numbers 'Swag Se Swagat', 'Desi Girl', 'Tu Meri', 'Saki Saki', among others was recently in the city. Starting his journey with an indie band to composing music in Bollywood, Vishal’s journey has been a blast according to him. Always very vocal about issues he feels strongly about, Dadlani in an online post recently called out to musicians remixing other composers songs warning them against legal action by him and Shekhar if any of their songs were remixed without the duo’s permission. "I have been made aware of some more remixes of our songs that are being made and produced without our, the original composers’, knowledge and consent. We will sue anyone who, without our specific consent, does that with an objective of releasing them, monetizing them or using them in any film other than the one for which the song was created," says Vishal. "We musicians put the cover versions out for free and we are fine by that, but remixes released even partly as someone else’s song will not be accepted. I shall certainly exercise my legal rights if needed, and even move courts against the films and the musicians, if it comes down to it. It’s not fair that anyone should be able to do this. And I’m sure that the courts will see this for what it is. Daylight robbery of work, credit, opportunity, and most crucially creativity, is wrong and should be stopped," he adds vehemently. Vishal Dadlani (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Vishal Dadlani (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Moving on to other topics, Vishal says it was in Kanpur in Uttar Pradesh, that his career as a musician actually kicked off and it was there that he tasted success for the first time. "I have been to UP several times. In fact, the first place our band won a contest was at IIT Kanpur back in 1995. So after starting and winning our first contest at Antaragni – the college’s fest – we made several friends and we were called to Delhi. We performed at IIT Delhi and won there too and after that we won at IIT Bombay too. The band then got famous and we started to make music regularly as we were offered many album deals. Then I became a professional musician and I give all the credit to this phase of my life to UP." Vishal, along with Shekhar, has composed hundreds of songs in all genres for Bollywood since the past 20 years including Nashe Si Chadh Gayi, Allah Ke Bande, Chammak Challo, Ishq Wala Love, among others. Sharing his equation with his partner Shekhar, and how the two started out together as composers, Vishal says, "Shekhar and I were friends and we knew each other because we lived within a distance of like one kilometre. We used to meet often and would have a light chat off and on about our professional lives. There was a studio in our locality and Shekhar used to do the advertising work of the studio and I knew the owner. So one fine day I was walking into the studio and he was coming out and he asked me ‘tu yahan kya kar raha hai’, and I asked him the same question. So he told me he was working on a film called Pyaar Me Kabhi Kabhi. Coincidently it was our first film and I told him that I am working on this film too. At that point in time, we were working separately, Vishal and Shekhar were two different entities. But then we both heard each other’s music and we liked the work. And the rest as they say is history...The title track of the movie was still left to be done so we decided to do it together and since then 20 years have passed." In all the talent hunt and reality shows on TV, contestants are always singing Bollywood compositions sung and composed by others. Talk about this and Vishal, a judge on a reality show, says that he would love for the contestants to sing their own composition rather than copy older singers and songs. "Copying other singers style can only make an artist learn music but will stop him or her to grow as a musician. I have never learned any music, I learned from listening to other people sing. So it took me ten long years to understand that to learn and to copy are two different things. And to try and sing consciously like my influences, that was a very big step for me as a musician. And these contestants are very new, they are still young and learning. So it is not a bad thing if they copy someone’s singing style whom they consider their influence. But I always try to make them understand that you can always learn by copying but you can never grow. You’ll end up being an ordinary singer. It is obvious because if we can access an original copy, why would we go for the copies? There is no rule that a contestant cannot sing his original composition. I will love it if a contestant sings his original composition. Infact, I will encourage the artist wholeheartedly, as that is the true measure of a talent. The brass tacks basic facts is that a reality show can popularize you but for a short time, but becoming a musician will actually make you successful. And for that you have to tell your story through your songs to the audience," says the Oh Womaniya singer. Vishal Dadlani with the contestants of the reality show he is judging on TV (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Vishal Dadlani with the contestants of the reality show he is judging on TV (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Being a regular on judging reality shows Vishal justifies the act by saying, "I listen to the songs made by others on a daily basis. Shekhar and I do that daily in the studio. The main reason of me judging reality shows is that I feel like we are seeing the future of India in terms of music. And I feel talent hunt shows nurture talent. Contestants come in raw and the vocal coaches in the show teach them a lot, and by the end of it, the artists develop. It’s a good place to look for and nurture new talent," he reasons. But mention to him that the talent hunt shows on TV are replete with drama and with most contestants having an emotional story to narrate, and Vishal agrees and says that as long as a contestant is not giving a false story, he is fine with that aspect being shown on TV. "See, today we are competing with the internet. It has everything on demand, so a TV show uses all the material it has to be entertaining for its audience. TV being a vehicle that can take these singers to the people, so I say if you are doing it, do it to win it. And as long as there are no false stories that are created, that is actually the story of the contestant and knowing the story creates a space in the audience’s heart, I see nothing wrong there. Reality shows shouldn’t manufacture the dramas, which is not something we do. But if the story is true and people empathize with it then there is nothing wrong. And people will connect with the contestants more if they will hear their stories and that will build a better understanding between the audience and the contestant. A person is nothing without his story. So the idea is to get to people’s hearts, to be like a family. So if we want to be in their lives, we should also allow them to be in our lives, right?" — With inputs from Saad Abbasi

column2: Ahead of SC verdict, Muslims want paramilitary deployed in Ayodhya
column3: FAIZABAD/LUCKNOW: Ahead of the Supreme Court’s verdict on the Ram Janmabhoomi-Babri Masjid title suit, “worried” Muslims in Ayodhya have asked the district administration to deploy central paramilitary forces in areas with dense population of their community. The demand was raised by representatives of the Muslim community during a meeting with the Faizabad administration. “We have full faith in the administration and are confident that it will ensure peace and harmony. But the deployment of central paramilitary forces will give more assurance to the community,” Jamiat Ulema Hind, Ayodhya unit general secretary Hafiz Irfaan told TOI. SSP Faizabad Ashish Tiwari told TOI, “Police have already been deployed in Muslim-dominated localities and central paramilitary forces will also be deployed soon. Civil police and some CRPF personnel are also keeping strict vigil in Muslim-dominated localities.” “We have asked Muslims not to panic and assured them that peace will not be disrupted in Ayodhya,” said DM Faizabad Anuj Kumar Jha. Meanwhile, UP CM Yogi Adityanath has asked his ministers to refrain from making any controversial statements on the Ayodhya verdict. Addressing ministers on Friday ahead of a cabinet meeting, the CM reportedly said that no one should make any “unwarranted comment” on the verdict. A source in the CM’s secretariat said, “RSS has been holding a series of meetings where it has been telling its cadre to refrain from provocative statements and actions after the verdict. In fact, when the CM went to Ayodhya for the Deepotsav, he met the seer community and asked them to refrain from saying anything controversial that could disturb peace.” BJP will hold meetings in the coming week to discuss what line the party would take on the verdict, keeping in view all possibilities.

column2: 2008 CRPF camp attack: 2 Pak nationals among 4 to hang
column3: RAMPUR: A local court in Rampur on Saturday awarded capital punishment to four men, including two Pakistani nationals, for the attack on a CRPF camp in Rampur in 2008 in which seven jawans of the paramilitary force and a civilian were killed. The four convicts include Imran Shahzad, a resident of Bhimhar in Pakistan-Occupied Kashmir (PoK); Mohammad Farooq, a resident of Kangriwala area in Pakistan’s Gujranwala; Sharif, a resident of Rampur; and Sabauddin, a resident of Bihar’s Madhubani. The remaining two of the six convicted on Friday – Jung Bahadur, a resident of Moradabad, and Faheem Ansari of Mumbai – were given life imprisonment and 10 years in jail, respectively. Two of those sentence on Saturday — Mohammed Sabauddin Ahmed and Faheem Ansari — were earlier acquitted in the 26/11 Mumbai terror case. According to sources, Faheem Ansari, a resident of Goregaon area of Mumbai, and Sabauddin Ahmed, a native of Bihar, were co-accused in the 26/11 terror case along with Pakistan terrorist Ajmal Kasab. However, a special court in Mumbai acquitted the duo in 2010 and their acquittal was later upheld by the Supreme Court. After a Mumbai court had acquitted Faheem and Sabauddin in 2010, both were transferred to jails of Lucknow and Bareilly in Uttar Pradesh. The court held Sabauddin guilty of attack on the CRPF camp and has been charged with murder and also under the Arms Act and the Explosive Act. However, Faheem was not found guilty in the attack but has been “found guilty for holding a fake Pakistani passport and also under the Arms Act”. “Pakistan nationals, Mohd Farooq and Imran Shehzad, were arrested from Lucknow in February 2008 and were lodged in Lucknow jail. They had undergone training in Pakistan,” said Singh. They are lodged in jails in Lucknow and Bareilly, ADG ATS Dhruva Kant Thakur said. The judgment pronounced by additional district and sessions judge Sanjeev Kumar said that all the four accused will hang till death under IPC’s sections 302 (murder), 149 (every member of unlawful assembly guilty of offence committed in prosecution of common object) and under 121 (waging war against government of India). On the intervening night of December 31, 2007 and January 1, 2008, terrorists had attacked the Rampur-based CRPF group centre, in which seven CRPF jawans and one civilian were killed, while some jawans and citizens had sustained serious injuries. Cases were registered against eight persons under various sections of the IPC, the Arms Act, Prevention of Damage to Public Property Act, Explosive Substances Act and the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act.

column2: Senior Congress leader wants to get me killed, says Ram Vilas Vedanti
