column3: KANPUR: Member of the Ramjanmabhoomi Nyas and former BJP MP Ram Vilas Vedanti has alleged that a senior Congress leader wants to get him killed. He was on his way to Auraiya when he took a halt in Kanpur and interacted with the media on Saturday. Vedanti said if anything unfortunate happened to him, the Congress leader should be held responsible for it. He also accused Congress and Pakistan of creating hurdles in the construction of Ram temple in Ayodhya. “Construction of Ram temple got delayed only due to hurdles created by Congress and Pakistan in regular hearing of the Ayodhya case in Supreme Court as they didn’t want the case to be settled,” said Vedanti and accused the Congress of doing divisive politics in the country since independence. “This is why people threw them (Congress) out of power in 2014,” he added. He also said the Sunni Waqf Board is getting funds from Pakistan and hiring costly lawyers to represent their case in Supreme Court. “I just wanted to question Sunni Waqf Board in this regard. While on one hand they cry that they are running short of funds to pay salary to their employees, on the other, they hire costly lawyers to represent their case in Supreme Court, which is not possible without financial support from Pakistan.” He also pleaded people not to raise provocative slogans on streets after the Supreme Court verdict, as it could disturb law and order. “Rather, it would be better if they indulge in puja and and other religious rituals within the confine of their homes,” Vedanti added.

column2: Grocery shop owner battered to death
column3: KANPUR: A 55-year-old grocery shop owner was allegedly battered to death by miscreants in Ghatampur area of the district on late Friday night. In order to conceal the crime, the miscreants dug up a pit and buried the victim's body. Police identified the deceased as Ram Bahadur Singh Rana, a resident of Kundauli village in Ghatampur. Police reached the spot, and after conducting preliminary investigations, shifted the body to the mortuary for postmortem examination. "Going by the preliminary findings, it appears that he died of serious injuries due to physical assault," said Circle Officer, Ghatampur, Ravi Kumar Singh. According to police, Rana used to run a grocery shop at Kundauli village crossing. "On Friday night, while he was asleep under a tin shade outside his shop, miscreants attacked him with blunt objects repeatedly till he succumbed to wounds. After confirming that he had died, the assailants dug up a pit in nearby fields and buried his body in it and escaped", said a police official. The incident came to light on early Saturday morning after his family members reached the shop, and on finding him missing, they informed the police control room. Police rushed to the spot and recovered his body from the pit. "His body has been shifted to the mortuary for postmortem examination. Further investigations are underway to arrest the suspects. We are exploring all possible angles", said SP (rural) Pradyumna Singh. The victim's daughter was to get married on November 29, the SP added.

column2: PF scam: 2 UP discom officials arrested
column3: LUCKNOW: A former top employee and a suspended general manager of a discom of Uttar Pradesh Power Corporation Limited (UPPCL) were on late Saturday arrested by the Yogi Adityanath government for violation in investment of more than Rs 2,200 crore of provident fund of corporation employees in Dewan Housing Finance Corporation Limited (DHFCL), a company whose promoters are under Enforcement Directorate (ED) probe for links with a firm of Iqbal Mirchi, a former aide of Dawood Ibrahim. The state government decided to recommend CBI probe late on Saturday evening. The government said the incident will be probed by DG (EOW) till CBI takes over charge.The Lucknow Police have slapped charges of criminal breach of trust, forgery and fraud of valuable security against the two suspended UPPCL employees — GM of Dakshinanchal Vidyut Vitaran Nigam P K Gupta and former director (finance) Sudhanshu Dwivedi. The FIR was registered following a political war of words that followed between Congress UP general secretary Priyanka Gandhi and UP government who traded barbs over the tenure of the alleged scam. The probe and subsequent arrest of the duo took place following a complaint by I M Kaushal, the chairman of trust of two employees’ funds: central provident fund (CPF) and general provident fund (GPF). Earlier, UP power minister Shrikant Sharma wrote on Twitter, “Investing employees provident fund money in DHFL is matter of serious concern. Stern action will be taken against those involved in it.” Later in the evening, Sharma wrote to CM Yogi Adityanath, seeking a CBI probe into investment of UPPCL employees provident funds in DHFCL. Sharma said that till CBI probe is initiated a high level inquiry be done in the case. The FIR states that though the decision to invest in any private firm or financial institution for a tenure of one to three years was first taken in February, 2014 but the sanction to invest in DHFL took place during the transition between then Samajwadi Party (SP) government and BJP government in March 2017. UPPCL chairman Alok Kumar said, “The investment of funds in DHFCL was gross violation of guidelines. The funds should have been deposited in government securities instead of fixed deposits of a private company.” The funds into DHFCL were invested in two ways. This included Rs 2631 crore from CPF and the other Rs 2267 crore from GPF was invested later. From the first tranche, Rs 1185 crore was returned to UPPCL while Rs 1491 crore was returned from the second tranche. “This still leaves the total balance amount of Rs 2,200 crore, which is a huge amount and will be recovered now. UPPCL will hand over provident fund matter to the Employees’ Provident Fund Organisation,” said an official The row had erupted in July when the trust employees had raised a banner of protest against the UPPCL and power department. “A sum of Rs 1,600 crore is still with DHFCL. The government should get back this money. We also need an assurance that in future money with GPF or CPF trust is not be invested in private firms,” said union general secretary Rajeev Kumar Singh. Earlier, Congress general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra targeted the government on the issue. “The UP BJP government invested the provident fund money of the state’s power corporation employees in a defaulting company like DHFL. Whose interest is being served through this investment of over Rs 2,000 crore which is the hard earned money of employees?” she said in a tweet.

column2: At AQI 422, it’s a health emergency in Lucknow
column3: LUCKNOW: The state capital remained shrouded in thick smog for the third consecutive day on Saturday and the air quality index (AQI) plummeted to a ‘severe’ 422 from ‘very poor’ 382 in 24 hours, but the authorities are yet to declare a public health emergency in the city. Track the pollution level in your cityThe spike in superfine particulate matter began around Diwali and increased almost three times in a week owing to fireworks, vehicular emission and conducive weather conditions, but no official health advisory or closure of schools like Delhi has been announced. Schools, both private and government, though were directed on Saturday to sprinkle water on their campuses to check pollution caused by dust. Vice-chairman of Lucknow Development Authority PN Singh has also ordered suspension of construction activities. From 155 on October 26, the AQI leaped by around 40 units a day in the past week to touch 422. The figure is nearly nine times higher than 50, the prescribed limit termed as ‘good air’ by the Central Pollution Control Board. Also, this is the second highest AQI this year after 436 on January 2. Times ViewCivic agencies are yet to take adequate measures to check air pollution despite the chief minister's directions. Besides garbage burning in open, construction activities and brick kilns without preventive measures continue unabated in the city. Sprinkling of water to prevent dust from polluting the atmosphere is limited to a few localities. Officers responsible for inaction should be booked for criminal negligence because this is a matter of public safety. Further, authorities should come up with a policy to tackle the problem in a planned manner ahead of the winter season, instead of reacting every year when pollution reaches alarming levels.Experts warn that the concentration of the microscopic and lethal PM 2.5 may breach the ‘hazardous’ 500 mark in the city in coming days if immediate measures are not taken. Exposure to such menacing levels of superfine pollutants can cause serious respiratory issues, including asthma, chronic bronchitis and allergic rhinitis, doctors maintained. Live air quality monitoring by CPCB suggests that the pollution levels in two areas of the city crossed 400 in the early hours of Saturday while a third inched closer to the ‘severe’ air quality bracket. The most polluted was the industrial hub of Talkatora with a PM 2.5 concentration of 410 microgram per cubic metre of air. It was followed by residential areas of Lalbagh and Aliganj with PM 2.5 concentrations of 402 and 393, respectively. The particulate matter concentration in these places was around seven times higher than the permissible limits of 60 microgram per cubic metre. While Talkatora was polluted because of industries, broken roads and garbage burning were the main culprits elsewhere, experts said. “We cannot control the weather as of now, but can take steps to check vehicular emission and smoke. There is an urgent need for formulation and strict implementation of a government policy on pollution control,” said environmentalist Venkatesh Dutta.

column2: Lucknow: Real estate sector pins hopes on first RERA conclave
column3: LUCKNOW: The first national RERA conclave is being organised in Lucknow on Sunday and Monday. The two-day event will see participation by 15 RERA units from across the country and will be addressed by chief minister Yogi Adityanath, minister of state (independent charge) for housing and urban affairs Hardeep Puri, developers and residents’ welfare associations. The theme of the conclave is ‘Transforming Realty with RERA’. On Sunday, RERA chairperson Rajive Kumar will hold a society meeting, followed by an experience sharing session by various state RERAs and a discussion chaired by Daya Shankar Mishra, secretary, ministry of housing and urban affairs. Day 2 will see presentations and discussions around the current real estate situation in the country. Two reports — one on best practices and another on key RERA judgments — will be launched, along with a book on real estate. The inaugural session will be addressed by Yogi Adityanath and Puri. Discussions through Monday have been divided into five sessions. These include ‘Addressing challenges and moving forward in real estate’ and ‘Reinvigorating real estate financing in India’.

column2: Refrain from statements on Ayodhya, CM Yogi Adityanath tells ministers
column3: LUCKNOW: With the Ayodhya verdict expected anytime now, chief minister Yogi Adityanath has asked his ministers to refrain from making any controversial statements. In a meeting held on Friday, the CM reportedly said that no minister should say anything about the verdict, irrespective of whose favour it comes in. A minister confirmed: “The CM has told us to abstain from making unnecessary comments on the issue.” A source in the CM’s secretariat said this direction was in line with a larger programme which BJP has started in light of the expected verdict. “RSS has been holding a series of meetings where it has been telling its cadre to refrain from statements and actions on the verdict. In fact, when the CM went to Ayodhya for the Deepotsav, he met the seers and asked them to refrain from saying anything controversial or something that could disturb peace,” the source said.  BJP will hold meetings with its members in the coming week to discuss what line the party would take in the face of the various possible verdicts.

column2: Manager of petrol pump found hanging
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 65-year-old man, working as a manager with a petrol pump in Morta, was found hanging from the ceiling fan of his room. A note found near the body said he was committing suicide as three transporters had not paid him Rs 20 lakh for fuel they had bought last year. Rampal, the deceased, had been staying in a room built on the premises of the petrol pump for the past several years. His family of three sons and wife lives in Muzaffarnagar. Rampal had been working at the pump for the past 20 years. On Saturday, when Rampal did not come out of his room till late, a few of his colleagues peeped inside and found his body hanging from the ceiling. Police were informed and the body was subsequently sent for an autopsy. In the note, he claimed the three transporters had not paid him Rs 20 lakh after buying fuel around a year ago. The three had allegedly threatened to kill him if he prodded them too much. The note mentions Somveer Tomar, his brother Pramod and a third relative. SP (city) Manish Kumar Mishra said police were yet to receive any written complaint so far. An FIR would be registered on the basis of the complaint, he said. Sources said the two transporters were believed to have been associated with a mainstream political party and had bought fuel around a year ago on credit. The manager was under extreme pressure on how to recover the money, police said. But police denied any knowledge about any political link. Rampal’s son Manoj said his father had never told anyone in the family about the alleged threats or problems he was facing.

column2: Lucknow: Retired colonel, kin duped of Rs 28.8 lakh
column3: LUCKNOW: A retired army officer lodged a case against a real estate company director and three others accusing them of duping him, his wife and daughter of Rs 28.80 lakh on the promise of selling them plots. Colonel Rajveer Singh Sangwan of Sector I, LDA colony, complained to Hazratganj police saying he, his wife Usha and daughter Nimisha had signed a deal with company's director Paresh Rastogi, his kin Piyush and Pankaj for plots in Kasimpur Viruha village in Mohanlalganj in 2013. "The accused showed us project map and claimed it was approved by government. They took us to the site, showed the plots after which we agreed and paid through cheques. They made us sign an agreement saying they would develop the land and give us plots in 30 months or else would pay Rs 50.99 lakh (for three plots)," said Sangwan. "Nearly 75 months have passed. When we verified, we found the company did not own the land shown to us. When we asked them to return the cash, they warned us of serious consequences and even issued life threats," Sangwan said in complaint. "The company duped us of a huge sum which I had saved," he said. SHO Hazratganj, Radha Raman Singh said an FIR has been registered against Paresh, Piyush and Pankaj under the charges of criminal breach of trust and dishonesty.

column2: Burning trash mounds mock CM Yogi Adityanath's directive
column3: LUCKNOW: An order from the chief minister to stop burning garbage notwithstanding, the practice - a major cause of air pollution - is continuing unabated in the state capital. The district administration and Lucknow Municipal Corporation (LMC), acting on the directive, had asked officials of all the eight zones in the city to conduct routine inspections to stem the problem. Zonal officials and those in charge of beats were warned of punitive measures if they failed to implement the order. However, burning garbage is still common in areas like Lalbagh, Latouche Road, New Hyderabad, Kaiserbagh and Daliganj, where residents complained to TOI about breathing distress, nasal congestion and headache. In Lalbagh, sanitation workers burn mounds of trash on the roadside, making children cough their way to school. "Our morning begins with breathing heavily polluted air. Garbage burning is rampant. There is no one to stop the sweepers from doing so. School-going children are inhaling poison every day," said resident Akansha Singh. As if toxic smoke from garbage were not enough, residents of Latouche Road rued that wires and cycle tubes were also frequently burnt. "The area is dotted with electronics and cycle repair shops. They junk everything on the road and the same is burnt by sweepers in the morning. It is a health emergency for senior citizens with low immunity and lung function," said Gautam Balamurli. Residents of Kaiserbagh are livid because complaints to the LMC about garbage burning have fallen on deaf ears. "Garbage mounds are set on fire at least three times a week. Thick, black smoke engulfs the neighbourhood. Every second person is complaining of headache or nasal congestion, but the LMC doesn't care," fumed Bhavna Tiwari. Civic officials insisted that the LMC had prohibited burning of garbage three years ago. It had also decided to penalise sanitation workers with a day's wage cut while a fine of Rs 500 was imposed on other offenders (commoners/non-employees). "We have penalised more than 20 people in and around the city. We are conducting regular drives and garbage burning will stop in the city very soon," said an LMC official without mentioning when and how.

column2: 15 cases of fraud in India against 'Bunty-Babli' arrested in London
column3: LUCKNOW: The husband-wife duo from Delhi arrested in London for a Rs 1.76-crore export fraud in Bulandshahr, UP, were never strangers to lies and deceit it seems.  The Economic Offences Wing (EOW) of UP Police has stumbled upon 15 cases registered against Vir Karan Awasthi (51) and Reetika Awasthi (49) across the country. The couple floated their export company, Bush Foods Overseas Private Limited, in 2013 after failing in real estate business. The EOW is inquiring into other possible fraudulent deals pulled off by the firm. There are also reports that the two conned nine banks in India out of a whopping Rs 650 crore . Director-general (EOW) Rajendra Pal Singh told TOI that of the 15 cases of fraud and dishonesty, four were registered in Bulandshahr alone. Two more have been reported in Hapur and one has been registered in Meerut. Outside UP, three cases are registered in Haridwar, two in Punjab and two in Delhi. Yet another case is recorded with EOW (Delhi). In all the 15 FIRs, Vir Karan and Reetika are named accused. Around 40 aides are also named in total. In five of these cases, investigation is pending; in two, chargesheet has been filed; and in three others, a final report was submitted by police of the state concerned.  EOW (UP Police) is awaiting deportation of the couple who was arrested from Mayfair in London on October 9. Vir Karan had fled to London soon after the FIR in Bulandshahr in 2015. Reetika joined him in 2016 after the Supreme Court allowed her to travel abroad, purportedly for medical treatment, for a surety bond of Rs 86 lakh. She never returned, prompting the EOW to approach Interpol for a red notice.

column2: Six UP cities among India’s most polluted
column3: LUCKNOW: As air pollution levels continued to deteriorate, six UP cities were among the top 10 most polluted places in the country on Saturday with Air Quality Index (AQI) in ‘severe category’ (400), an alarming situation as per the Central Pollution Control Board. Lucknow with AQI 422 was at the 11th spot. Track the pollution level in your cityGhaziabad was the most polluted city in UP and fourth most polluted in the country with AQI 453. Bulandshahr (446), Hapur (444), Greater Noida (438), Baghpat (435) and Noida (432) were the other most polluted cities. Hissar in Haryana was the most polluted city in the country. Overall, 13 cities in India — 7 from UP, 5 from Haryana and Patna — recorded severe air quality. “In west UP, sugarcane crushing and conducive weather conditions are the main reasons behind high pollution levels,” said director of air quality monitoring station at Lucknow University, Prof Dhruvsen Singh. Worried citizens have demanded swift action from the government to control the situation. “Every year, air quality begins to worsen from October. But the government wakes up only after the situation becomes alarming,” said Ghaziabad resident Bhawana Garwal. Noida resident Ankita Srivastava said the government should frame and implement a policy to control air pollution.

column2: Six UP cities among India’s most polluted
column3: LUCKNOW: As air pollution levels continued to deteriorate, six UP cities were among the top 10 most polluted places in the country on Saturday with Air Quality Index (AQI) in ‘severe category’ (400), an alarming situation as per the Central Pollution Control Board. Lucknow with AQI 422 was at the 11th spot. Track the pollution level in your cityGhaziabad was the most polluted city in UP and fourth most polluted in the country with AQI 453. Bulandshahr (446), Hapur (444), Greater Noida (438), Baghpat (435) and Noida (432) were the other most polluted cities. Hissar in Haryana was the most polluted city in the country. Overall, 13 cities in India — 7 from UP, 5 from Haryana and Patna — recorded severe air quality. “In west UP, sugarcane crushing and conducive weather conditions are the main reasons behind high pollution levels,” said director of air quality monitoring station at Lucknow University, Prof Dhruvsen Singh. Worried citizens have demanded swift action from the government to control the situation. “Every year, air quality begins to worsen from October. But the government wakes up only after the situation becomes alarming,” said Ghaziabad resident Bhawana Garwal. Noida resident Ankita Srivastava said the government should frame and implement a policy to control air pollution.

column2: Delhi's AQI in severe category despite mild showers
column3: NEW DELHI: Even mild showers failed to bring respite from the deteriorating quality of air in Delhi/NCR on Sunday morning as the AQI remained in "severe" category (401-500) in several areas of the city. At 9 AM on Sunday, the PM2.5 AQI was 499 in Delhi. The air quality hovered near the "severe plus" (Above 500) category for the entire night. Track the pollution level in your cityThe heavy smog reduced the visibility near Delhi airport to 300m. According to the Indian Meteorological Department, there will be a possibility of light rain and thunderstorms throughout the city. At AQI of 499, Fatehabad, Hisar air quality worse than Delhi’sThe mild spell has led to a marginal drop in the Air Quality Index (AQI) with readings at different places showing in 'severe category'. As of today morning, the AQI reading at Bawana is at 492, ITO crossing is at 487 and Ashok Vihar is at 482, all in 'severe' category. In Ghaziabad, Vasundhara at 486 and Indirapuram at 482 on Air Quality Index. As per Skymet, the Air Quality Index for Delhi, Noida, Ghaziabad, Gurugram, Faridabad shows severe to hazardous readings with PMs ranging from 400 to 709. An AQI between 0-50 is considered "good", 51-100 "satisfactory", 101-200 "moderate", 201-300 "poor", 301-400 "very poor", and 401-500 "severe". Above 500 is "severe-plus or emergency" category. Mild showers likely on SundayThe city received 0.3 mm rain in the past 24 hours which slightly lowered the hazardous level of air pollutants in the air. "Partly cloudy sky with possibility of very light rain or thundershowers. Strong surface winds during the day (speed 15-20 km). The maximum and minimum temperatures would be around 29 and 19 degree Celsius respectively," the weather forecast agency said. Relative humidity was 85 per cent at 8.30 am, said a MeT department official. The day is forecast to remain generally cloudy with light rain or drizzle expected later on. The maximum temperature will be around 28 degrees Celsius, he said. The air seed was around three knots at 8.30 am, the official said, adding the visibility was poor due to the smog. Some respite is expected from the heavy pollution, with strong surface winds forecast in daytime on Monday and Tuesday.

column2: Kanpur air quality improves slightly, AQI dips to 379
column3: KANPUR: The Air quality of the city slightly improved on Saturday as its index value was recorded as 379, placing the city under the 'very poor' category. On Friday, the index value of the air quality was 403 which was categorized in the 'severe' category. According to Nehru Nagar Center, PM 2.5 was around 189 which is slightly above the minimum limit. Similarly, O3 (Ozone) was recorded as 24 against 1 minimum while the NO2 (Nitrogen Oxide) value recorded at 5 pm was high at 63. The value of Sulphur Dioxide, which was recorded as 11, was also twice the minimum limit. Track the pollution level in your cityAccording to the center, 189 index value is unhealthy for residents of Kanpur. According to experts, with a decrease in night temperature, which was 16 degrees on Friday night, and increase in humidity, all gases are concentrating at the lower layer of the air and therefore morning time is more dangerous for the morning walkers. Noted environmentalist, Prof Mukesh Sharma, said that the government was not serious in controlling air pollution as it had woken up when the situation reached a critical stage. Sprinkling water over dust would reduce the pollution level, he added. Regional pollution control board officer Franklin, however, claimed that following steps taken by the authorities the air pollution has reduced to some extent and air quality index too improved. The former principal of GSVM medical college Dr. SK Katiyar said, "As humidity increases in winters and due to cold and humid conditions, all particulate matters (2.5 and 10) concentrate at the lower layer which is harmful to human beings". A senior doctor SN Shukla suggested that people should increase the intake of water as it acts as a detoxicant and reduces the effect of all foreign materials. "People should take Vitamin C and B Complex to increase their immunity. Fruits, especially Gooseberry (Amla), is a very good natural source of Vitamin C", he added.

column2: Rera authorities may seek powers to attach projects of errant builders
column3: NEW DELHI: It’s not just homebuyers who are troubled by builders’ non-compliance with orders passed by Real Estate Regulatory Authorities (Reras), even regulators are concerned at the stubborn attitude of builders. Fed up, the regulators are likely to seek more authority under the law to empower them to attach unsold inventories of builders to make them fall in line and find ways to complete projects. Real estate regulators from across states have gathered in Lucknow and sources said they would push for amendments in the Real Estate Regulation and Development Act (Rera) to give them more teeth, particularly to execute orders passed by them. They are also likely to flag emerging issues before the government including financing requirement for the sector, which is saddled with stuck projects across the country. “Our ultimate task is to see that stuck projects get completed and hence we have to look at liquidity issues,” said a regulator. On Sunday, housing secretary Durga Shankar Mishra hinted that the government would consider amendments in the law. “He said government is considering to give more power to regulators so that they can take bold steps,” an official statement by UP Rera said. A couple of Rera chiefs TOI spoke to said though the law had made an impact across states, there were some challenges to take it ahead. They said some legal issues needed to be resolved for effective functioning of regulators. “This is the first time that there is a concerted effort to identify issues, discuss them and make recommendations to the government. The main focus is how to strengthen the system,” one of them said.

column2: 2007 maintenance law finds no takers among Vrindavan’s abandoned mothers
column3: MATHURA/VRINDAVAN: Abandoned and neglected older women are all too common in the crowded lanes of Vrindavan-Mathura. But oddly enough, none has sought legal redress under the law to protect parents from such shoddy treatment, perhaps indicating just how helpless and vulnerable these women are. Officials said there are no cases before the tribunal in the district under the Maintenance and Welfare of Parents and Senior Citizens Act 2007 seeking relief by way of maintenance or action against errant children. “The tribunal in Mathura was set-up many years ago but no elderly person has so far filed a case or sought relief under the Maintenance Act,” said district social welfare officer Karunesh Tripathi. Tripathi shared that a mediation facility is available in Mathura too. He claimed authorities in district and in Lucknow have from time to time taken measures to spread the message about the provisions of the law and the redressal it provides. Besides making children accountable to provide maintenance to elderly, the law entails three months imprisonment or a fine of Rs 5,000 or both where it is found that a parent was abandoned by adult children. The ministry of social justice and empowerment is currently reviewing a draft amendment bill that proposes to enhance the jail term to six months and the fine too. Nodal officer for monitoring the shelters for women in distress in Mathura, Anurag Shyam Rastogi, said last year they organised an interaction with the elderly women in one of the government run-shelter homes. “We found most mothers were reluctant to explore the legal route against their children,” Rastogi added. Vrindavan is home to thousands of destitute women and even a growing number of men left to fend for themselves. Many are above 60 and women in their eighties and even nineties can be spotted surviving on charity of pilgrims and trusts that abound here. Though women come from across states, there are many from Mathura and its surroundings too. Elderly women with their heads covered and sandalwood paste smeared on forehead can be spotted lining up to get their Rs 7 to Rs 10 for a few hours of singing in bhajan ashrams. In their hearts most carry painful memories of abandonment, neglect and even abuse by adult children - mostly sons and their wives. However, none of them have chosen the legal recourse to punish their families. Abha Upadhyaya the social protection officer with HelpAge India in Mathura points that most elderly women say they do not want to beg for their rights. “In almost 50% of the cases of elderly women, we find they are either abandoned by family or victims of some kind of emotional or physical abuse. However, these mothers step back refusing to punish their children,” Upadhyaya said. Shyama Devi still shudders at the memory of that day when her daughter-in-law brought her from their comfortable home in Etah, Uttar Pradesh and left her at a privately-run ashram for women in distress – or mostly widows. Over two years later, she has yet to reconcile to the “dhokha” (betrayal) at the hands of her own kin. The women originally came in large numbers from West Bengal but now are from everywhere. TOI came across women from Bihar, Jharkhand, UP, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Assam, Tripura, Punjab, Delhi and even Nepal. Shyama Devi’s story is not a stray case. In the same home, a man came in to leave his mother, Rama Bai. Recently he had taken her home for a few days to Sagar in Madhya Pradesh only to bring her back again. Rama Bai’s file records discord with daughter-in-law. Her son claims he works as a labourer and his wife was paralysed. Whatever be the case, it is clear she fit into the family scheme any more.

column2: Hospitals see 30% rise in patient footfall as Lucknow gasps for good air
column3: LUCKNOW: For five days Munshipulia resident Suresh Kumar suffered from breathlessness and chest tightness. It was only after he visited a pulmonologist that the 36-year-old realised that smog was the culprit. “I don’t smoke and never had these problems before. Hence, I was confused. The doctor said pollutants in the air that I inhale on my way to work were to blame. He advised me to wear a mask or take a few days off,” the private company employee told TOI. TimesViewThe anti-pollution measures announced by the administration — ban on burning garbage in the open, suspension of construction activities and sprinkling of water on dusty roads — should ideally have been launched right after Diwali when pollution levels started rising. In its reality check, TOI found that these measures are often not enforced strictly. After announcing such measures, the administration should ensure that they are implemented strictly. The government should collect feedback from the public and take lax officials to task.Kumar is not the only victim of the city’s deteriorating air quality. Hospital OPDs are swamped with people complaining of allergies, skin and eye irritation, breathing distress, chest congestion and cough. Those with underlying conditions such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and cardiac ailments are worst sufferers. For five days Munshipulia resident Suresh Kumar suffered from breathlessness and chest tightness.Doctors at KGMU maintained that the number of patients with respiratory problems had jumped 30% in a week. “If we were attending to 250 daily seven days ago, the number is now 325 a day,” said head of respiratory medicine professor Suryakant. The cardiology wing of KGMU is also seeing more patients — 280 a day against 250 earlier. “These are mostly people with weak heart who have acquired respiratory complications,” said associate professor (cardiology) Askhay Pradhan. The patient footfall has similarly gone up at SPM Civil Hospital and Balrampur hospital. Many are complaining of skin rashes and throat infection. A week ago, Indira Gandhi Eye Hospital witnessed 80 patients a day with dry eyes and conjunctivitis. Today, the headcount is higher by 25%. The poison in the air is affecting people irrespective of age. Fourth grader Raj Khare, who has asthma, is experiencing rapid breathing, and chest and neck tightness at least thrice a week. The nine-year-old from Talkatora puts his inhaler into his school bag before books. “We have requested the principal to allow him to skip the morning assembly. Despite wearing a mask, he feels uncomfortable,” mother Anupama said. On Friday, 35-year-old Rubina Khan had to be hospitalised. “I have chronic bronchitis, but the bad air triggered an attack while I was shopping with my daughter,” she said. “Doctors have told us not to allow her outdoors till air quality improves,” said husband Istiyaq Khan. Madiaon resident Ajay Singh had a heart surgery six months ago. “I am working from home because the air outside makes my heart pound faster,” said the 26-year-old employee of a networking company in Aliganj. Anchal of Dubagga, a teacher at a private school who is five months pregnant, said she had been advised to wear a mask. “Pollutants in the air can affect the growth and mental development of my baby.”

column2: Gang duping job-seekers, making money via Bitcoin busted in Lucknow
column3: LUCKNOW: With the arrest of three persons, the Uttar Pradesh special task force (STF) on Sunday unearthed a Bihar-based gang which used to post offers for overseas jobs on the internet to dupe gullible aspirants and conduct transactions in bitcoins to avoid police radar. A police team arrested Rakesh Kumar Singh, Bittu Yadav and Pradeep Deo (all from Bihar) from Chinhat and recovered 16 ATM cards, two Aadhaar cards, two PAN cards, a driving license and Rs 21,300 cash from them. A police team arrested Rakesh Kumar Singh, Bittu Yadav and Pradeep Deo (all from Bihar) from Chinhat and recovered 16 ATM cards, two Aadhaar cards, two PAN cards, a driving license and Rs 21,300 cash from them.SSP (STF) Rajeev Mishra said, “After getting information that a gang duping jobseekers was active in Kushinagar and Lucknow, a team zeroed in on the culprits and arrested them. The gang members had duped people not only in India but also Indians living in the US, UK, Australia and Canada.” Explaining the modus operandi of the gang, the SSP said the gang worked on a three-tier system comprising of a scammer, bitcoin vendor and pickers. “The scammer, who is the main handler, roped in bitcoin vendor and pickers and gave them their commission after executing an online fraud. The scammer posted advertisements for jobs asking people to contact him. After an aspirant was trapped, the picker contacted him and asked him to transfer money in a bank account for registration purpose,” the SSP said. He said pickers used to open multiple bank accounts to avoid police scanner and after getting the amount from aspirants, they deducted their commission and transferred the remaining amount to a bitcoin vendor who converted the money in cryptocurrency and transferred it to the scammer’s wallet. According to police, the arrested men were pickers and had disclosed the names of some other pickers active in UP. They have also named a Moradabad-based bitcoin vendor who is on the run. Police said they have got the list of bank accounts and transactions made in them.

column2: ‘Government must empower RERA to revive real estate sector’
column3: LUCKNOW: The only way the real estate sector will start looking up is if old, pending projects get completed, said Parveen Jain, vice-chairman of the National Real Estate Development Council (NAREDCO). He added that the Real Estate (Regulation and Development) Act, 2016, needs to be empowered further to take stronger decisions. Speaking to TOI on the sidelines of the first RERA conclave in Lucknow, Jain said that despite RERA, people have no confidence in new projects and are investing only in ready to move into units. The Lucknow conclave, he said, should throw up concrete results and firm commitments from the government or else it would be a waste. NAREDCO is an apex real estate body which works under the Union ministry of housing and urban affairs. “There are some 5-7 lakh unfinished units and it is imperative that they are delivered before the real estate sector can look up. RERA is toothless in this matter. Among the first things it should be empowered to do is to ensure that as a builder taking on completion of an underconstruction project, one should not be saddled with retrospective liability of that project,” Jain said. Pushing for completion of projects over starting new ones, Jain said that penalising developers for delayed projects should be a secondary concern for the government. He added that current central government schemes for revival of the real estate sector would not achieve much because they are narrow in their outlook. Jain said that as per the Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman a fund of Rs 20,000-30,000 crore had been set up to help developers. But, he said, the money was not reaching the end users. “The condition for availing the fund was that projects should not come under nonperforming asset (NPA), but at present most projects fall under this category,” he said. At present, UP has unsold units worth about Rs 1,43,000 crore, of which the UP Housing and Development Board has around 9,500 units. Despite the availability of ready to move into units, Jain said that high levels of unemployment and an uncertainty among the business class is the key reason for slowdown in the sector. “Even now, most of those buying property are looking to invest. However, investors are generally missing from the markets. This, despite the fact, that now is the best time to invest in property due to slowdown,” Jain said. He explained that property rates were at least 30% lesser than they were at peak time in 2012. Add to that an average of 5% inflation each year since then, he said, and one would realise that a good deal could be had at as much as 50% lesser than its actual value.

column2: Swine flu claims 6th victim in Lucknow
column3: LUCKNOW: The city has recorded its first swine flu death since August with a 51-year-old man succumbing to the highly contagious disease caused by the H1N1 virus. Although Daliganj resident Manoj Kumar breathed his last at King George’s Medical University (KGMU) on October 19, his death was logged in the chief medical officer’s audit only on Saturday. With this, the swine flu toll in the city since January rose to six. TimesViewSwine flu reared its ugly head, while Lucknow is barely able to cope with a dengue outbreak. The spread of the two viruses can be contained through efficient planning and coordinated efforts of health department and civic agencies. Had LMC and the department launched fogging drives in a planned manner, the dengue outbreak – now on the verge of breaking the 2016 record – could have been prevented. Swine flu has affected nearly 50 people and claimed one life in the city over the past two months, but the authorities are yet to launch awareness drives or any preventive measures in public places.A woman from Aliganj, Ranjana Pathak (66), detected with H1N1 infection, also died at KGMU on October 19. However, doctors have listed the cause of her death as multi-organ failure due to diabetes, hepatitis C and renal failure. Late hospital reports delayed confirmation of death: CMO Chief medical officer Narendra Agarwal said Kumar was admitted to the isolation ward of the emergency trauma medicine unit of KGMU with breathing difficulties and chest congestion on October 16. He was put on ventilator support on October 19, but did not make it. On why his office took 15 days to confirm the cause of death as swine flu, Agarwal said: “Usually, a death audit is completed in three days, but the hospital records arrived late and then there were (festive) holidays.” Speaking on Pathak’s case, Agarwal said the audit team found that she died of renal failure and hepatitis C complications. “Her brain and heart stopped functioning,” he added. Associate professor of medicine D Himanshu reiterated that Pathak was admitted with respiratory problems and died of multiple complications arising out of failed kidneys and liver. The swine flu season, according to the health department, begins around August and lasts till March. Out of 550 cases this year, 511 were reported in the first season (January-March) and 39 since August. As many as 250 people had tested positive in February, followed by 214 in March. The patient count was much less at 27 in January and 30 in April.

column2: Thieves steal gold, cash from temple in Lucknow
column3: LUCKNOW: Unidentified persons broke into a Kali temple in Indiranagar between Saturday night and Sunday morning, and decamped with gold and silver jewellery of the goddess, besides Rs 40,000 in cash. According to the FIR lodged by office-bearers of Ma Kalyani Kalibari in Khurramnagar, the intruders broke two locks to the grille gate to gain entry. “They took ornaments that the goddess wore around her neck and took the cash from the donation box,” the complaint said. The theft has angered residents, some of whom claimed police were on patrol in the area on Saturday night and yet couldn’t check the crime. “If a temple is not safe, do you think the house of a common man is?” said Suyash Mishra. Prashant Tewari said thieves had targeted several temples in Indiranagar and other areas of trans-Gomti. “Policing is lax as ever,” he added. Police spokesperson Ashish Diwedi said subinspector Vinod Yadav had been assigned the case.

column2: Lucknow police fails to challan driver of 'hanging car'
column3: LUCKNOW: A motorist and his friend had a lucky escape when their luxury sedan leaped off the flyover near Janeshwar Mishra Park and got caught in a tree in the small hours of Sunday. What is more bizarre though is that police failed to register a case or even challan Amir Kamal, a property dealer from Gokhale Marg, and his friend Arib Hussain for speeding at a time the Road Safety Month campaign is underway. Gomtinagar SHO Amit Dubey insisted that a case could not be registered because no one filed a complaint. Asked if the duo were drunk and speeding, Dubey said both were gone by the time police reached the scene and hence, nothing could be ascertained. Lawyers, however, maintained that police couldn't afford to be so lenient and nonchalant in cases of reckless driving. Senior advocate Nitin Mathur said the facts that the sedan jumped a flyover and landed on a tree were indicative of speeding. "Even if no one lodged a case or no commuter suffered injuries, police are bound to challan the driver. The action would have been a deterrent for all motorists," he said. Criminal lawyer Alok Singh agreed that the onus was on police because the car could have run over a passer-by. "Cops should have conducted a technical inspection of the vehicle first and then lodged a case based on the report," Singh said, adding that medical examination of the driver could have revealed if he were under the influence of alcohol, which is a bigger offence.

column2: Lucknow: 'Breathing PM2.5 for a year may cause lung cancer'
column3: LUCKNOW: It is no secret that prolonged exposure to particle pollution and toxic fumes can cause a host of respiratory and cardiovascular diseases. Experts have now stepped up their warning to say that only a year of continuous inhaling of the microscopic and lethal pollutants can lead to lung cancer, besides increasing chances of a heart attack. Currently, superfine particulate matter PM2.5 is nearly seven times higher than the permissible limit of 60 microgram per cubic metre of air. Track the pollution level in your city "These particles are so small that they can penetrate deep into our lungs and constant exposure for just about a year may lead to lung cancer," said head of respiratory medicine at KGMU professor Suryakant. The professor explained that PM2.5, which has an aerodynamic diameter of less than 2.5 micron, can even enter the blood stream by penetrating the lung membrane, thereby increasing chances of a heart attack by exerting pressure on arteries. "The PM 10 is less hazardous than PM 2.5, but causes respiratory tract infections and asthma," he added. Associate professor of medicine at KGMU D Himanshu said nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and sulphur dioxide (SO2) present in air caused skin allergies and eye irritation. "These gases produce acid after reacting with moisture present in the atmosphere, which in turn burns the skin," Himanshu said, adding that inhalation of ozone damaged the nervous system. Dust particles, on the other hand, triggered dryness in the eyes. "An increased level of NO2 and SO2 can also lead to conjunctivitis and bacterial infections," warned ophthalmologist Dr Siddharth Srivastava.

column2: BJP MLA without helmet fined in Kanpur
column3: KANPUR: BJP MLA, who was elected from the city's Govind Nagar assembly constituency in the bypoll held on October 21, was challaned on Sunday for riding a motorcycle without a helmet. The MLA, Surendra Maithani, accepted his mistake and promised that he would not flout traffic rules again. Maithani, who is also the district president of BJP, is a first time MLA. He was riding a bike along with his supporters and party workers in his constituency to wish people on the occasion of Chhath. His pictures riding a two-wheeler went viral after which the traffic police challaned him for flouting the rules. Talking to TOI, Maithani said, "I forgot to wear the helmet as I was in a hurry to meet people on the occasion of Chhath. Being a citizen of this country I am also bound to obey laws and rules like other people. I accept my mistake and promise that this will not happen again. I have paid the fine for driving the bike without a helmet."

column2: Tractor trolley hits bike, one dies in Lucknow
column3: LUCKNOW: A 24-year-old man was crushed to death by a tractor-trolley in Sarojini Nagar early on Sunday morning. Police said the victim, Ankit Pal of Asoha in Unnao, who worked in a factory in Nadarganj area, was returning home on his motorcycle after night shift duty when the incident took place. He was not wearing helmet. As Ankit reached Sadullakheda locality, a tractor-trolley hit his motorcycle from behind. Ankit was flung in the air and landed a few metres away suffering serious injuries. The commuters chased the tractor-trolley driver, whom the police later identified as Ashutosh Shukla, managed to flee the scene abandoning the vehicle on the spot. Ankit was rushed to the hospital where he was declared brought dead. An FIR has been lodged.

column2: Ahead of Ayodhya verdict, police step up vigil in Noida and Ghaziabad
column3: GHAZIABAD: Ahead of the Ayodhya verdict, the Ghaziabad administration and police have intensified patrolling. The district has been divided into 10 zones and each is being monitored by a super zonal magistrate, who is being assisted by 16 zonal magistrates and 58 sector magistrates. Additional DM (city) Shailendra Kumar Singh and additional DM (administration) Jitendra Kumar Singh have been the charge of city and rural areas, respectively. Hearing in the Ayodhya case is complete and a verdict is expected later this month. To ensure that law and order is maintained and peace isn’t disturbed, district magistrate Ajay Shankar Pandey has directed the super zonal magistrate and zonal magistrates to conduct regular patrolling and participate in peace committee meetings. Police are also keeping tabs on social media and officials have been directed to take action in case of provocative and objectionable posts. Sector magistrates have been asked to coordinate with local police stations and keep watch on the activities of locals. As many as 14 officials in the city area and 11 in the rural zone have been kept in reserve and would be asked to pitch in in case of emergency. Likewise, circle officers and station house officers have been asked to conduct peace meetings in their respective areas. On Friday, DM Pandey and SSP Sudhir Kumar Singh had held a meeting of members of social and religious organisations. The senior officials had urged them to maintain peace and take the SC verdict in a positive manner. In Noida too, police and administrative officials have been holding peace meetings to ensure law and order. Sector 24 station officer Ramphal Singh said a meeting was held in Morna and residents were asked to maintain peace and harmony.

column2: Ghaziabad: Principal booked for student’s death in 2017
column3: GHAZIABAD: The principal of Vidyavati Mukand Lal Girls’ College, two students and a hostel warden have been booked for murder and criminal conspiracy in connection with the death of a 20-year-old BCA student in her hostel room in 2017. A case was registered at Sihani Gate police station on Friday following a directive by a local court on October 21. College principal Indrani, two of the BCA student’s roommates then — Swati Panwar and Isha — and a hostel warden have been named as accused in the complaint. Pushpanjali Chaudhary was found hanging from the ceiling fan of her hostel room on September 7, 2017. A note, purportedly written by Pushpanjali, mentioned that she did not want to be a burden on her poor family. However, Parvinder Kumar Nagar, who represented Pushpanjali’s father in court, contended that the writing on the note matched that of one of the roommates. BL Chaudhary, Pushpanjali’s father, had approached police, suspecting that her roommates may have had a role in the death. But the cops apparently refused to register an FIR, which prompted him to move court. Chaudhary, a resident of Noida Sector 93 and an auto-rickshaw driver, said he had received a call from her daughter a few hours before her death and she sounded quite happy. “She told me she would come home a couple of days later. Around noon, I got a call from the college management and was told that Pushpanjali was very sick. My wife and I reached the college, but was told to rush to MMG District Hospital as Pushpanjali had died,” he wrote. “The principal told us my daughter had committed suicide. When I reached her hostel room, we noticed that the ceiling was quite high and nobody could reach it without a ladder. A note was also shown to us, but the writing on it was not my daughter’s,” he added. Principal Indrani refuted the allegations. She said Pushpanjali had shut the door of her room after telling her friends that she was going to change her clothes. “When she did not come out after some time, her friends started knocking on the door. They did not get any response. Some students broke open the door and found Pushpanjali hanging from the ceiling. By then, I had also reached the hostel,” said Indrani.

column2: Lucknow: 80-plus Hindu professor to host his 50th majlis this year
column3: LUCKNOW: When professor PS Gupta began teaching chemistry at Shia PG College more than half a century ago, it was not just his teaching skills that were noticed and praised by students and colleagues. The professor held a majlis (religious congregation) on the campus in 1970 and earned the sobriquet 'Majlis-wale Guptaji'. The tradition has been continuing ever since. An octogenarian today, the retired teacher holds on to his special title by organising the college majlis, where the tragedy of Karbala is recalled with pathos on the eve of the last day of Muharram every year. He may be old and frail, but the sermons he organises about the martyrs keep people riveted to their seats. This year, the majlis will be held on Tuesday, November 5. "I had faith in Imam Husain (Prophet Muhammad's grandson). Shia Muslims and Hindus have a lot of cultural similarities, which is why I was drawn to the history of Karbala. I wanted to organise a majlis and when I ran the idea by my colleagues at college, they were more than happy to hear it," said the resident of Rajajipuram. "I made all arrangements for the majlis - from getting the sound system to readying the campus for the solemn event. It was well-attended the first time and many people come even today. They adore me as Majlis-wale Guptaji," he added. For a few years now, Gupta's eldest son has been sharing the majlis responsibility with his ageing father. The congregation, which was initially presided over by Limca record-holding cleric Maulana Mirza Mohammar Athar, was later taken over by his brother Maulana Mirza Mohammad Ashfaq. For the past couple of years, Maulana Athar's son Maulana Mirza Yasoob Abbas has been delivering the sermon at the majlis. "I remember my father telling us that professor Gupta popped the idea (about he organising a majlis) in the staff room one day and everyone agreed. Thus began a tradition," said Maulana Yasoob Abbas. "There was one time when Diwali and the last day of Muharram fell on the same day. The professor gave the solemn ceremony priority over Diwali celebrations at home, which he attended after the sermon," recalled the cleric. Posters, banners and pamphlets for the majlis continue to be printed in the name of professor Gupta till date. A few of his Hindu friends answer his clarion call to attend the congregation as well.

column2: Lucknow air 'very poor' despite drop in pollution level
column3: LUCKNOW: Pollution level in the state capital continued to touch the alarming mark of 400 for the second consecutive day on Sunday. According to data released by Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB), the air quality of the city figured in 'very poor' category with Air Quality Index (AQI) of 400. This was the second most polluted day in the post-monsoon period after Saturday, when AQI was 422-the highest for this season. Track the pollution level in your cityDespite a fall in pollution level by 22 units as compared to a day before and shifting of the air quality from 'severe' to 'very poor' category, the situation remained worrisome as Lucknow figured among the 27 most polluted cities of the country. These cities had AQI of 400 or more.  The first three days of November have not been so polluted in the past three years. In 2017 and 2018, AQI remained below the danger mark of 400 from November 1 to 3. Pollution level was highest in the morning hours, with PM 2.5 concentration recorded to be more then six times the permissible limit.

column2: I don’t see myself playing a naag or a bhoot: Iqbal Khan
column3: Even though he has been to Lucknow several times earlier, this time it was different for actor Iqbal Khan. The 'Fun2shh... Dudes in the 10th Century' fame actor was in the city to shoot for the film 'Indoo Ki Jawani' which features Kiara Advani and Aditya Seal. Iqbal, who has also been seen in the show Tumhari Pakhi, says he always tries to explore the city in whatever time he gets from his late nights shoots. Taking time out for us, Iqbal talked about his favourite food in Lucknow, his absence from TV serials, trends on TV and a lot more. You have been to Lucknow earlier also to promote your TV shows, but this time you are shooting for film here. How does it feel?I think that last time I came to Lucknow was several years ago to promote my TV show Tumhari Paakhi. It must be some five years back. I wasn’t able to explore the city at all then but this time while shooting for Indoo Ki Jawani and staying in Lucknow for almost half a month, I was able to see quite a bit of Lucknow though there is still so much left to explore about this city. However, this time although I am staying here for such a long time, I wasn’t able to know the pulse of the city. I was shooting for my scenes till late in the night till early morning. But yes, I went to Dadamiyan ki Mazar, which was a really serene place. I spent time there with the kids of the near-by place and it was really a well-spent evening. Also, I was really happy to see that the metro has finally paved its way in Lucknow. So what all did you explore in Lucknow?My connect with Lucknow is primarily with the food. I have this school friend of mine Ishanveer who is from Lucknow. He had taken me to this very regular looking place in old Lucknow and he made me eat Nihari there with sheermaal. Being a complete foodie, that is my major connect with Lucknow. Lucknow mein jaise nihari milte hai waise kahin bhi nahi taste kari. The whole taste, the tenderness of the meat and the sheermaal in Lucknow is very different from the ones served anywhere in India. When you talk about sheermaal, everywhere in India where I have eaten it, it is same from both the sides. But Lucknow mein aise bilkul nahi tha.Yahan pe sheermaal ek side se tandoori tha and doosri side se ekdum roti type ka tha. I found it amazing! Iqbal Khan at the Gomti River Front (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Iqbal Khan at the Gomti River Front (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) We haven’t seen you much on television these days?There is a phase which television is going through where the makers have not been experimenting much with good content. Even if they have experimented with something, it has gone wrong. Most of the broadcasters today think that Indian audience needs spoon feeding of concepts like daayans, bhoots and makkhis. But the best part is that even today top shows on television are neither mythological or folklore stories. They are regular family dramas. Never say never but I somehow don’t see myself playing a naag or a bhoot. I have not done any such kind of stuff before and God has been really kind to me that I have got shows which have not been typical drama types shows that we have on the small screen today. Television has seen it best phase when shows like Shanti, Hum Log, Kyunki... were made. People used to start watching TV from 8 pm and sit till midnight. But ab kahan aisa hota hai. What about mythological or historical shows, are you not open to them as well?Well, to be frank, I was offered to play Lord Shiva and I did my homework for that and I was excited to play one but at the last minute I didn’t do it for the only reason that such shows require a lot of time even in the making. But TV today, after a month or so, it doesn’t give you that much of time for such a show. I feel on television, even today, romance, relationships, family these things always work. There are so many good shows which are approved for their uniqueness but by the time they go on air woh ek dum badal chuke hote hain and mostly for the worst. Is it the reason, why you have been blamed for a show’s shut down after you left being unsatisfied because of its storyline? It is very easy for the makers to say that actor chala gaya iss wajah se show band ho gaya. I don’t believe television actors have that kind of power. There are so many shows which have worked wonderfully even after the main lead’s exit. So yes I was blamed for leaving two of my shows after I was not satisfied with the storyline, which was not what was originally narrated and promised to me. But I have done a show like Karam Apna Apna long time back which I left after sometime, but even after that it worked for two years. So it is because the story was going downhill that the show couldn’t garner TRPs, not because I left it.

column2: A tragedy play 'Gao Mein Kuch Bura Hone Wala Hai' staged in Lucknow
column3: A play titled 'Gao Mein Kuch Bura Hone Wala Hai' was staged at the Valmiki auditorium of the Sangeet Natak Akademi. Based on Gabriel Garcia Marquez’s play of the same name, the dramatization by the artists on stage won them a thunderous applause from the audience at regular intervals. The tragedy by Gabriel had the audience glued to their seats until the culmination of the play. A scene from the play (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) A scene from the play (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) The guests of honour at the play were theatre veteran Surya Mohan Kulshreshtha, scientist Ravi Sinha, theatre critic and director Rajesh Kumar and poetess Saroj Singh. The highlight of the play was the artists in the play who were a group of housewives, aged between 30 to 80 years, who performed the roles of the men as well. (L) Anisha and Hansika (R) Aparna Bhargava and Mini Bajpae (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Anisha and Hansika (R) Aparna Bhargava and Mini Bajpae (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) The plot of the play revolved around how a superstition eventually converts into a rumour and transforms into a tragedy. — Saad Abbasi Baijanti, Amit Singh and Komal Singh (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Baijanti, Amit Singh and Komal Singh (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Dr Surya Kant Tripathi (R) Gopal Sinha (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Dr Surya Kant Tripathi (R) Gopal Sinha (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L-R) Reena, Ankur and Upasna (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L-R) Reena, Ankur and Upasna (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Shubham Tiwari (R) Surya Mohan (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Shubham Tiwari (R) Surya Mohan (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

column2: New portal, app soon for property buyers
column3: LUCKNOW: The Centre is set to launch a new web portal and a mobile application to facilitate purchase of ready-to-move-in properties. Union minister for housing and urban affairs Hardeep Puri on Monday said the first of its kind project, to be launched in India in collaboration with CREDAI and NAREDCO, would be operational as early as mid-January 2020. Addressing the first annual RERA conclave in Lucknow on Monday, Puri said the two national bodies of real estate developers in the country – NAREDCO and CREDAI – would ensure completion of all formalities for purchase of any units through this e-commerce website, aimed at bringing transparency in the sector. Vice-chairman of NAREDCO Parveen Jain said only certified projects would be listed on the website. “The website will offer details of all projects along with a video experience for buyers to assess a property. Only those properties, which have received occupancy certificates, will be listed on the website. One will have to pay a refundable fee of Rs 25,000 to register for a property. We will ensure that all formalities are completed. This will also fix responsibility of the builder,” he said.

column2: UP: Graft charges on suspended GM, ex-finance director of PCL
column3: LUCKNOW: The Economic Offences Wing (EOW) of UP Police will slap charges under the Prevention of Corruption Act against suspended general manager PK Gupta and former finance director Sudhanshu Dwivedi of UP Power Corporation Limited (UPPCL). The EOW on Sunday had taken over the case of violation of investment of over Rs 2,200 crore of provident fund of UPPCL employees in a tainted company, Dewan Housing Finance Corporation Limited (DHFL), and registered a case against suspended general manager PK Gupta and former director (finance) Sudhanshu Dwivedi. Director general of EOW Rajendra Pal Singh said that all relevant documents pertaining to the accused have been prepared. They have been sent to the managing director of UPPCL for his assent before lodging an FIR under corruption charges against the duo. The Act is being slapped on the basis of the FIR registered by IM Kaushal, the secretary of the trust. The DG also said that EOW will seek remand of the accused for further questioning. On Monday, an 11-member team of EOW also raided the second-floor office of Power Sector Employees’ Trust located in Shakti Bhawan. The team was led by DIG (EOW) Heera Lal along with an SP and other inspectors. The team stayed on the premises from 11am to 4pm. The team recovered 16 bundles of documents relating to the investments made into DHFL. Some documents are dated to 2000, when the trust was formed. Investigation officer of the case Dinesh Singh also visited Lucknow jail to take statements of the accused.

column2: Uttar Pradesh fares better than Haryana and Punjab in stubble burning: Study
column3: LUCKNOW: As Delhi is struggling to breathe cleaner air with Sunday’s AQI slipping to worst-ever figure at 494, a study by Union agriculture ministry has said that among the national capital’s neighbours, only Uttar Pradesh has done better with fewer incidents of stubble burning — one of the biggest contributors to air pollution — this year as compared to 2018. Track the pollution level in your cityThe study comes at a time when UP government has booked 158 farmers for burning paddy straw, in violation of the National Green Tribunal (NGT) norms. It also comes at a time when Yogi government has asked its prabhari mantris (ministers in charge of districts) to visit around and photo-bomb farms where residue burning is taking place and share the pictures with nodal officers of agriculture department or district magistrates. The report has found that UP recorded 1,428 incidents of stubble burning in the paddy harvest season in October that coincides with Diwali festivities as compared to 2,649 incidents for the corresponding month in 2018. Haryana and Punjab were worse than UP during the same duration. The study, which has been done by Consortium for Research on Agroecosystem, Monitoring and Modelling from Space (CREAMS) Laboratories Division of Agricultural Physics, ICAR, has said that Punjab reported 18.5% increase with 22,421 firing incidents as compared to 18,922 such incidents in 2019 Haryana was a shade better than Punjab but recorded a minor increase of 2.6 % stubble fires at 4,186 as compared to 4,294 incidents in 2018. The UP government officials have formed a CMO WhatsApp group, where each visiting IAS and prabhari minister has been asked to take photographs of the violating farmer whose field is on fire and share that on WhatsApp goup. “Total 488 notices under the Air and Pollution Control Act of 1981 have been slapped on farmers across 11 UP districts. While 158 FIRs have been registered, overall 150 farmers have been booked and the chargesheet will be submitted in the court of law,” said a UP agriculture department official. UP food and civil supplies minister Ranvendra Pratap Singh said that he visited about 35 districts recently and took around 53 photographs where he discovered minor instances of stubble burning but insisted them to opt for organic farming. “I am an organic farmer in Fatehpur. And I use decomposer with cow urine to take care of stubble burning. I have been suggesting farmers in UP during my visits to practice the same and the results are fewer number of fire incidents,” a farmer said. The UP government has also been running a programme called Million Farmer School since 2017 where each farmer from a village is asked to attend an educational institution on farming for a six-hour class along with ‘Vaigyani ki baat, kisaano ke saath’ monthly events where agriculture scientists hold talks with farmers.

column2: 17-year-old girl found dead on rail tracks in Auraiya district
column3: KANPUR: A 17-year-old girl, student of class XII at Shyama Inter College, was found dead under suspicious circumstances on the Delhi-Howrah rail track in the Dibiyapur area of Auraiya district on Monday. Police said that the girl, identified as Puja Yadav, daughter of Mohan Yadav, a resident of Ranapur in Dibiyapur town, had gone to attend her coaching classes, The local sources told the police that the girl wasrun over by a train. “We have received information from locals about a dead body lying on rail tracks. We rushed to the spot and identified the victim on the basis of ID card and the Aadhar card recovered from her school bag lying close to the body,” said inspector GRP, Auraiya, Avadhesh Pathak. The body has been shifted to mortuary and investigations are underway to ascertain the actual cause of her death, the inspector added. The incident came close on the heels of November 1 incident where a girl, a student of high school at Saraswati Vidhya Mandir, was found dead on the rail tracks in the same area under mysterious circumstances. She had also left her home to attend coaching classes near Sahayal Road when the incident occurred.

column2: Kanpur’s air bad again, AQI at 454
column3: KANPUR: A day after Air Quality Index (AQI) dipped to 287, the situation worsened again in the city on Monday with the AQI at 454. Track the pollution level in your cityThe AQI recorded by Nehru Nagar centre of Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) at 8pm on Monday was 454 and the air quality was termed as ‘Hazardous’. The levels of PM2.5, NO2 and SO2 had also increased manifold. The air quality had deteriorated during the morning time and continued to remain the same almost throughout the day. At noon, AQI was recorded 451, at 4pm it was 444 and by 8 pm it reached 454. According to a report by CPCB, the levels of PM2.5, Nitrogen Dioxide and Sulphur Dioxide had increased manifold. The dip in the air quality on Sunday was attributed to less traffic on roads since it was a Sunday. But on Monday, the city sky was again covered with a thick blanket of smog and dust. City witnessed a cloudy day with no sunshine due to dust and smoke. According to regional pollution control board officials, gases and smoke have enveloped the city. Burning of garbage and dust from roads added to the pollution levels while weak wind velocity added to the troubles. As per the experts improvement in wind velocity and rains might improve the situation otherwise the city’s climatic conditions could worsen in approaching winter season. Regional pollution control board officer Dr S B Franklin said that serious efforts should be made by the city denizens to reduce pollution or the problems would increase with the lowering of temperature in winters. Central Pollution control board’s observatory has recorded an average PM2.5 as 444. The minimum PM2.5 in last twenty-four hours was 307 while the maximum was at 500. Nitrogen dioxide was recorded as 39 with a minimum 32 and maximum 116 and Sulphur Dioxide was recorded as 17 with minimum 9 and maximum 3. Quantity of Ozone was found as 24. Many people could be seen wearing masks or covering their face with cloth to protect from inhaling dust and smoke. The medical stores witnessed a rise in the sale of masks. Many people faced difficulty in breathing and irritation in eyes.

column2: Jhansi cops organize Diwali Mela for senior citizens, 500 elderlies attend
column3: JHANSI: Police organized a Diwali Mela for senior citizens on Sunday which was inaugurated by ADG Kanpur Zone, Prem Prakash, in the presence of divisional commissioner Shubhash Chandra Sharma, DIG Jhansi range Shubhash Singh Baghel, DM Shiv Sahay Awasthi and SSP OP Singh. A series of cultural programmes were organized on the occasion which was attended by around 500 senior citizens from all over the district. A free medical check-up camp and stalls for bank assistance and police assistance were also installed for the assistance of senior citizens. DM Jhansi Shiv Sahay Awasthi announced that special medical cards would be issued to the senior citizens so that they did not have to wait in queues for long hours for getting treatment both in the government and the private hospitals. The fair’s brainchild, DIG Jhansi range Subhash Singh, said, “This is the second such fair which is being organized for the senior citizens with the motto ‘Bring them under one platform and address their day-to-day problems’ related to their health and security, especially for those who live alone”. He said the fair has been organized by ‘Savera’, the police cell for senior citizens, created by him with equal participation by police and volunteers from the civil society to help those who are in need. “I have created a group of police personnel, including an inspector, a woman constable and two constables at every police station in the district. They have made a list of all senior citizens of that area whom they often visit to inquire about their well being. In the past year, the cell had been able to provide succour to many senior citizens in need”, Baghel further said.

column2: UP artist’s paintings on Guru Nanak’s life to come alive in Kartarpur Sahib
column3: LUCKNOW: Pilgrims visiting the Kartarpur Sahib Gurdwara in Pakistan through the Kartarpur corridor will not only be able to offer prayers at the historic gurdwara but also get a chance to see an exhibition on the life of Guru Nanak Dev. Being coordinated by the Delhi Sikh Gurdwara Management Committee, the exhibition will showcase the work of 25 different artists from India including Hari Singh from Uttar Pradesh. The Kartarpur corridor connects Dera Baba Nanak Sahib in Gurdaspur of Indian Punjab with Darbar Sahib in Kartarpur in Narowal district of Pakistan’s Punjab, The corridor will be inaugurated for pilgrims on November 9 as part of the 550th birth anniversary of Guru Nanak Dev. “The committee got paintings made on Guru Nanak Dev’s life events and teachings. A set of 28-30 paintings tracing the guru’s life in Sri Nankana Sahib, enlightenment and turning points would be showcased in the corridor for pilgrims,” said Manjinder Singh Sirsa, president Delhi Sikh Gurudwara Management Committee. Some of the entries which have made it to the exhibition are creations of Hari Singh, an artist from UP’s Sitapur district. “I have made 14 paintings for the collection which are a property of the committee. The experience I gathered in making them was extremely enriching and satisfying. I felt I was among the chosen ones for a divine task like this,” said Singh, who has made the signature piece. “Kartarpur Sahib is of special significance to everyone who reveres Guru Nanak Dev. He spent the last 18 years of his life here. He practised farming to cultivate his food and gave the message that everyone must work hard for survival and benefit all. My painting has tried to bring in all these elements in a single frame,” Singh said.

column2: Nine UP cities among 10 most polluted in country
column3: LUCKNOW: The battle with hazardous air is far from over for Uttar Pradesh cities which entered another traumatising week with ‘severe’ air quality on Monday. Track the pollution level in your cityAccording to Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB), nine cities from the state figured in the top 10 most polluted cities of the country. With AQI 440, Baghpat and Ghaziabad shared the slot of second most polluted in the country after Jind in Haryana which topped with AQI 448. Hapur stood third with AQI 436, followed by Lucknow AQI 435, Moradabad AQI 434, Noida AQI 430, Greater Noida AQI 428 and Kanpur AQI 427. The ninth most polluted city was Sirsa (426) in Haryana, while Meerut was at 10th position with AQI 424. Barring Kanpur and Lucknow located in central UP, the other six most polluted cities of UP are in the west bordering Haryana and Delhi. “With the start of stubble burning in Haryana and fall in temperatures and low wind velocity, the pollution levels will continue to remain severe in UP cities,” said environmentalist Venkatesh Dutta. Similar conditions are likely to continue till Thursday as there will be no change in weather conditions.
