column2: Lucknow: Poor roads still a worry; water sprinkling plan fails to take off
column3: LUCKNOW: Civic agencies have so far failed to implement the state government’s order to sprinkle water on broken roads to prevent dust from polluting the atmosphere. Track the pollution level in your cityThe government had directed Lucknow Municipal Corporation (LMC) and UP Public Works Department (UPPWD) to repair all roads by October 31. However, both have missed the deadline and now a ban has been enforced on repair and construction of roads in view of rising air pollution. According to a survey by Uttar Pradesh Pollution Control Board (UPPCB), dust raised from broken roads contributed around 87% to total air pollution in the city. Hence, orders were issued to sprinklewater on broken roads to settle the dust. A TOI reality check found that water sprinkling has been limited to main roads and posh areas. There are many internal roads where residents complained that no water sprinkling has been done. Some prominent areas like Gomtinagar, Jankipuram, Jankipuram Extension, Hazratganj, Lajpatnagar and Mahanagar have tattered roads and residents have been complaining about respiratory, skin and eye problems due to dust which enters their homes and settles in layers. The road from Kisan Bazar in Vibhuti Khand to Vinay Khand is full of potholes. “I have dust allergy and cannot cross this stretch without a mask. Even after that, I have breathing trouble and irritation in eyes,” said Kapil Verma of Vibhuti Khand. Several roads in Jankipuram are also full of potholes and both locals and commuters complain about dust causing problems. Kartik Srivastava of sector C said, “Dust regularly enters our house. I am worried about its impact on my children’s health. I have purchased dust masks but they are not enough.”

column2: Lucknow pollution: Shortage of masks hits fight against toxic air
column3: LUCKNOW: Shrouded in toxic haze, the city is bearing the brunt of acute shortage of anti-pollution masks N95 and N90 which can filter 90-95% of pollutants in the air. Left high and dry, people are forced to buy ordinary masks which cannot filter PM10 and PM 2.5, the deadly superfine particles whose concentration has been found to be very high in the city air. Track the pollution level in your cityMedical stores in Chowk, Hazratganj, Lalbagh, Kaiserbagh and Aminabad have already exhausted their stock and distributors said the fresh supply is expected only after few days. Veeru Pajapati, a bronchitis patient, has been shuttling between medical stores in search of N95 mask but in vain. “I have been experiencing chest discomfort and shortness of breath... Despite running from pillar to post, I have not found a single N95 mask,” Prajapati said. The demand for air filtration masks has gone up, said Vikash Amal Sinha, a Lalbagh-based distributor. “We sold only 250 masks of N95 and N90 a day last week. Now, there is a jump of 50% in demand.” He said: “The supply has been affected since most of the companies are in Delhi, where air pollution has reached its hazardous level... Since the demand for anti-pollution masks has hit the roof in the national capital, companies are giving priority to local distributors.” Ravi Bharti, a medical store owner in Hazratganj, said: “We have sold 60 pieces of N90 masks in just three days. Our order for 200 more masks may take at least a week to arrive.” “We had a stock of 400 pieces as demand remains low throughout the year since they cost about three times more than reusable anti-dust masks. But in the past three days, all masks have been sold off,” said Yatin Malik, a distributor in Aminabad. Unable to find them in stores, people have started buying these masks online. “Since my father is asthmatic, we ordered it online after we failed to get it from local medical stores,” Nikhil Singh, a resident of Hazratganj.

column2: A November morning in Lucknow with January-like feel
column3: LUCKNOW: November morning on Monday appeared like that of January, when dense smog enveloped the city, leading to drop in visibility to around 100 metres. The situation, however, may slightly improve in the coming days with the state weather office predicting rise in wind velocity from Thursday. Usually dense fog engulfs city towards December end and in January. But, for the past five days, Lucknow has been witnessing shallow fog in the morning due to low temperatures. The fog turns into dense smog after combing with pollutants. State met director JP Gupta said that conditions are becoming favourable for change in the wind pattern in the state from moisture laden westerlies blowing at present to dry north-westerly from Thursday.  The wind speed is also expected to rise above 15km per hour, helping in diluting the density of smog by dispersing pollutants. But till then shallow to moderate fog is expected in the morning hours and night, with maximum and minimum temperatures expected to be around 29-31 and 18-20 degrees Celsius, respectively.

column2: Uttar Pradesh beats slowdown, springs hope for real estate sector
column3: LUCKNOW: The stock of unsold inventory in Noida, Greater Noida and Ghaziabad has come down by 26% since the third quarter of 2017 despite slowdown, according to a report released by ANAROCK and NAREDCO during the first national RERA conclave in Lucknow on Monday. In sharp contrast, Gurugram’s unsold inventory went up by 7% and that of Delhi by 20%. The report titled ‘Addressing Challenges and Progressing Ahead in Real Estate’ says that from 1,31,150 units in the third quarter of 2017, the combined inventory of these three NCR cities has come down to 97,270 in the third quarter of 2019. The highest pending stock was disposed of in Greater Noida where the unsold inventory figures fell by 27% from 66,570 units to 48,350 units. During the same period, unsold stock came down by 24% in Noida and Ghaziabad. There are 19,480 unsold units in Noida and 29,440 units in Ghaziabad. The report says the sale of these units was made possible despite slowdown due to restrictions imposed on the launch of new projects in these areas. Giving a comparison with other areas where new constructions continued unabated, the report states that unsold housing inventory went up by about 7% in Gurugram which has the highest stock of unsold units at 55,900, up from 52,460 in 2017-end. Delhi’s inventory also went up by 20% during this period, from 10,770 units to 12,960. Chairman of ANAROCK Property Consultants Anuj Puri said, “UP cities falling in NCR managed to reduce their stock by restricting launch of new projects and focusing on completion of pending ones. In Gurugram, over 2,030 units were launched in the third quarter of 2019 while only 1,610 units were collectively started in Noida, Greater Noida and Ghaziabad. Two years back as well, Gurugram saw supply of 3,520 new units while these three cities launched just 1,220 units in the same quarter.” The report praises the UP government for ensuring that RERA rules favour aggrieved homebuyers, particularly in Noida and Greater Noida. It adds that RERA policies have been diluted in other states. “Nearly 76% of total 17,077 complaints filed with UP RERA till September 2019 relate to promoters and projects in Noida, Greater Noida and Ghaziabad. However, UP RERA has disposed of more cases (over 10,000) since its inception than any other state with active RERA rules in place,” the report says. According to the report, another reason for the slowdown in real estate sector is that the residential units are now accounting for 84% of total inventory against 16% of commercial units. “Builders have been making the wrong product. While they are focusing on luxury and high-end projects, the demand is actually for lower income groups and economically weaker sections,” the report adds.

column2: Centre to launch e-comm portal for realty trade soon
column3: LUCKNOW: The Centre will start an e-commerce portal that brings the national real estate industry on a single platform, Union minister for housing and urban affairs Hardeep Singh Puri said on Monday. The portal will be an aggregator, aimed at organising an industry that is massive but also region-oriented. It will bring together inventory, rates and resources across India on a common site. Puri was speaking at the first national Rera conclave, an event that in itself marked significant progress in turning real estate into an organised industry overseen by the watchdog, Rera, which was formed in 2016. Puri said the conclave would be turned into an annual event. The host, UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath, hinted at likely financial sops for developers in the state in the near future. Noida, one of the most fertile grounds for the industry in the country, is also currently among its biggest troublespots, with realtors going bankrupt and thousands of flats running up to a decade or more behind schedule, symbolised by the Jaypee and Amrapali crisis. “We will make an announcement in a week, which will reinstate the trust of buyers and builders back in the industry,” the CM announced, adding over one lakh flats in Noida and Greater Noida had been handed over since he took over as CM.

column2: DHFL fiasco: UP refuses to bail out UPPCL
column3: LUCKNOW: The UP government on Monday said it had nothing to do with the money from the provident fund of UP Power Corporation Limited (UPPCL) employees that was invested by the UP Power Employees’ Trust in the tainted Dewan Housing and Finance Corporation Limited (DHFL). “It is the responsibility of the trust and its chairman to ensure that the money of power sector employees is taken care of properly,” UP energy minister Shrikant Sharma told TOI. The minister’s statement came on a day when UPPCL chairman Alok Kumar, who also heads the trust, proposed at an emergency meeting of the UPPCL board of directors that the corporation meet the shortfall in paying the PF and gratuity to the retiring employees. Over Rs 4,000 crore has been invested by the trust in DHFL. While less than 50% of this amount has been recovered, a whopping Rs 2,268 crore is still with DHFL.

column2: Ghaziabad: Couple held for killing tenant, burying his body in basement
column3: GHAZIABAD: The owner of a house accused of killing his 30-year-old tenant and burying the body 6ft under the basement last month was arrested along with his wife and daughter from Sahibabad railway station on Monday. Police said Munna Kumar and his wife Sulekha murdered Pankaj, a 30-year-old law student staying in their house for the past few months, because he was in a relationship with their daughter Ankita. Munna allegedly brainwashed 19-year-old Ankita to believe that Pankaj was cheating on her and included her in the plan to murder the tenant. Apart from studying law, Pankaj ran a cybercafe in the area and gave tuitions to local children. Police sources said that in April this year, Munna had admitted his four children in Pankaj’s coaching centre. Pankaj and Ankita had apparently developed a liking for each other between May and June, when her parents had gone to their hometown in Bihar’s Nalanda. The two started talking over the phone and meeting each other. A few weeks later, Pankaj took a room on rent in Munna’s three-storey house. One day, sources said, Munna caught his daughter talking to Pankaj over the phone, and things started to turn sour since then. Pankaj was asked to vacate the room on the pretext that it would be sold off. Circle officer (Sahibabad) RK Mishra said, “Munna raised questions on Pankaj’s character and persuaded Anikta into believing that he was cheating on her. He told his daughter that the law student had lied to her about his age and showed her fake documents. After a while, Ankita believed her father and became a part of his plan.” On October 9, Ankita allegedly lured Pankaj to her house, saying she was alone and her parents had left for some work. “However, her parents were hiding inside the bathroom. When Pankaj reached the house around 10 am, Ankita and her parents smothered him to death, buried the body under the basement and plastered the floor with cement. At that time, Mukesh’s three other children were in school,” Mishra added. Pankaj’s family is from Ballia. His father Narender Singh said he had last spoken to his son on October 8. When Pankaj was reported missing, his father suspected Munna of murdering his son, and it was only after he insisted that the cops agreed to dig a portion of the cemented floor that “looked different”. On October 14, police were finally able to dig out Pankaj’s decomposed body from the basement. On a complaint by Narender, an FIR was lodged against the entire family of Munna, including his four children, under Section 302 (murder) of the IPC. The accused had been absconding since then. After fleeing Sahibabad, Munna stayed with her sister-in-law in Patna for some time, police said. They planned to go to Nalanda, his hometown, but went to a friend’s house instead. Later, they hid in Delhi’s Ghazipur for a few days. On Monday, the three were caught from Sahibabad railway station when they were trying to flee the city again. Narender had earlier alleged that Munna wanted to buy the cyber café that Pankaj ran in the area and murdered his son as he refused to sell it to the landlord.

column2: 6 bullets fired as two groups clash in society
column3: GHAZIABAD: As many as six bullets were fired in a clash between two groups of residents of a high-rise apartment in Raj Nagar Extension on Saturday evening. The two groups later filed counter-FIRs against each other. The clash took place around 7 pm on Saturday at River Heights society. One of the FIRs was registered on a complaint by Subodh Tyagi, president of the Apartment Owners’ Association (AOA), against a resident, Sunil Kumar, under sections 307 (attempt to murder) 323 (voluntarily causing hurt), 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace) and 506 (criminal intimidation) of the IPC. Tyagi alleged that Kumar had been abusing and intimidating RWA members and guards for a long time. The AOA chief said Kumar had clashed with the society’s guards on Saturday and even fired gunshots in the air. Subsequently, a call was made to police by one of the guards. Although the reason behind the clash was not immediately clear, Tyagi claimed that Kumar had threatened to file false cases against the RWA members. It was alleged that Kumar had been nursing grudges against the members after losing the society elections last year. He had even tried to disrupt the poll process, the AOA chief claimed. Kumar, on the other hand, filed an FIR against three unidentified persons under IPC sections 352 (assault or criminal force otherwise than on grave provocation), 323 (voluntarily causing hurt), 392 (robbery) and 506 (criminal intimidation) the same evening. SHO (Sihani Gate) Umesh Bahadur Singh said an investigation had been initiated into the two complaints.

column2: Lucknow’s present ‘smoggy’; future foggy
column3: LUCKNOW: If you have schoolgoing children, chances are they inhaled smoke from 45 cigarettes on their way to school and back on Monday. Track the pollution level in your cityThis may sound bizarre but it is true, considering that the city’s air quality crossed into the ‘very severe’ category according to the definition of the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB). Air quality in this category is hazardous for people to breathe in. Concentration of PM2.5 in many localities of the city in the morning hours and Zafternoon—when children go to school and come back home—was between 400 and 591 micrograms per cubic metre of air. According to a research by the University of California, one cigarette means inhaling 22 micrograms PM2.5 per cubic metre of air. Since children were exposed to an average PM2.5 concentration of 500 mcg/cubic metre of air twice in the day, it means they were forced to inhale around 45 cigarettes. The hourly data of poll tion level recorded by CPCB monitoring stations in four localities—Gomtinagar, Lalbagh, Aliganj and Talkatora—showed that PM2.5 concentration varied between 200 and 591mcg/cubic metre of air throughout the day, depending on weather conditions such as wind speed and temperature. The concentration was, on an average, more than eight times the permissible limit of 60 mcg/cubic metre of air, set by the National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS). Gomtinagar was the worst hit, where PM2.5 level was 591 mcg/cubic metre of air between 12midnight and 1am and then for seven consecutive hours from 3am to 9am. It dropped to 236 mcg around noon but crossed 500 after two hours of relief at 2pm. “My son complained about irritation in eyes and breathlessness the moment he returned home from school in Gomtinagar on a bicycle. We have been reading about pollutions but on Monday, we felt its choking impact,” said Nidhi Pandey, whose son studies in CMS Gomtinagar. In Lalbagh, PM2.5 concentration was 333 mcg/cubic metre of air at noon which gradually rose to 511 at 6am. Thereafter, it swung between 450 and 500 till evening. “Traffic jam during school hours is an everyday affair but on Monday, stuck in Lalbagh, I could not breathe. My son also complained of coughing,” said Amrita Dixit. After picking her son from school, she said she felt pain and heaviness in her chest. Talkatora area, which houses some small-scale industries, saw PM2.5 rising from 276 mcg/cubic metre of air at midnight to 466 12noon and beyond 523.8 by evening. “My morning walks are always pleasant but today after a mere 2km, I felt breathless. While going to office, visibility due to smog reduced all of a sudden around 11.30am,” said Alok Dixit, a banker in Talkatora. Aliganj witnessed comparatively low pollution levels in comparison to other localities. PM2.5 level at midnight was 176 mcg/cubic metre of air but rose to 314 mcg around 8am before dropping by a few points and rising again in the evening.

column2: With AQI 435, Monday second most polluted day in Lucknow this year
column3: LUCKNOW: The steady rise in air pollution level post-Diwali made Monday the second most polluted day of the city this year, with Air Quality Index touching 435 (severe category). Lucknow’s air was also the fourth most polluted in the country and third most contaminated in the state. Track the pollution level in your cityThe air quality in the first three days of November has been hazardous in the state capital. From 382 on November 1, AQI increased by 55 units on Monday. The city is just one unit away from breaking its own record of the most polluted day of the year. Times ViewThis is one Times View with which almost every one agrees with — it’s high time the district administration came up with a roadmap to counter the effects of pollution. It’s common knowledge that pollution levels rise during winter every year and the levels have only been increasing each year. Given they know what’s causing the problem, it shouldn’t be hard for the administration to figure out a solution.On January 3, the city battled severe air pollution when AQI soared to 436. Gomtinagar most polluted in cityThroughout the day, the city struggled with toxic air as PM2.5 concentration reached as high as 591. As per the live air quality monitoring conducted by Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB), Gomtinagar was the most polluted with PM2.5 concentration of 5,591 micrograms during the day, followed by Lalbagh, Talkatora and Aliganj with concentrations of 511.08, 461.65 and 317 micrograms respectively. “The levels will increase further and may touch 500 in coming days, if the administration doesn’t take measures to keep a tab on pollution emitting sources,” said prof Dhruvsen Singh, director, Lucknow University air quality monitoring station.

column2: Humour over Lucknow’s hazy skyline cracks netizens up
column3: LUCKNOW: With thick soupy smog enveloping the state capital, the issue of air quality has also blanketed the social media. Be it Twitter, Facebook, Instagram or Snapchat, concerns over breathable air by Lucknowites have taken the microblogging sites with a storm. Track the pollution level in your cityFrom #HowsTheJosh to #HowsTheSmoke, from #MuskuraiyeApLucknowMe-Hai to #GhabraiyeApLucknowMeHai, various hashtags along with hazy pictures of Nawabi-era monuments have been among the top trends on social media pages. Last night, with nearly zero visibility in #Lucknow, I realised my driver is a daredevil #Fog #Smog #India #Winter https://t.co/eJgCJrxxeR— Karan Sanjay Shah (@karanshah2405) 1481514562000One Instagram post with the hashtag #smogoverlucknow posted by handle @dramnanaqvi, creatively played with the image of Indian superhero Shaktiman, with the caption ‘Ab to is smog ko Shaktiman hi kheench ke kahin door brahmand me chhod sakega’ (Only Shaktiman will be able to leave this smog in a far away universe). The post received 63 likes and a number of shares. Gard o ghubar #Lucknowpollution #Shaam #iphonephotography https://t.co/ydKZNIi9KG— Seemi Khan Kazmi (@seemi13) 1572704056000A Twitter user with handle @karanshah2405 posted a latenight video of driving in smog with the caption ‘Last night, with zero visibility in Lucknow, I realised my driver is a daredevil’. A number of people also posted pictures of their areas at early morning and afternoon, showing the dense smog enveloping the city gradually during the day. Give me some sunshine give me some rain, give me AQI of less than one hundred ten. #Lucknow #smog https://t.co/GFMyptDgWL— Sunny Vaish (@sunny_dude) 1510577657000Another resident @SeeemiKhan contrasted the air quality by sharing a picture of Rumi Darwaza during the 1990s and in 2019, and a picture of Teele Wali Masjid engulfed in toxic air, with the caption ‘Gard O Ghubar’. While a few vented their anger on their FB and IG stories blaming those burning crackers contributing to air pollution during Diwali, a number of residents shared alternatives to stay safe in this coarse weather. “Guess that ‘one cracker’ did the wonders,” said Reema Mahajan on her post, while Savnit Gurnani shared pictures of some indoor plants to deal with bad air quality. Darvesh Yadavendra trolled UP Minister Sunil Bharala for his comment on air pollution, by sharing a screenshot of the AQI (air quality index) exceeding the 400 mark, with the caption, “Yagya hi karva do”. Another user @Sunny-Vaish shared, “Give me some sunshine, give me some rain, give me AQI less than one hundred and ten”.

column2: Lucknow: Official vehicle hits nurse's car, driver flees with her purse
column3: LUCKNOW: A 41-year-old nurse had a harrowing time on Sunday night after her car was hit by a speeding official vehicle of a state construction agency on Lohia Path. When she protested, the erring driver misbehaved with her and allegedly decamped with her purse containing Rs 18,000 and some important documents. According to the FIR lodged by the nurse, Sunita Mishra, she was returning from SSP camp office in Hazratganj, where she had gone to lodge a complaint against her neighbour in connection with a dispute, when a speeding four-wheeler hit her car on Lohia Path around 7.30pm. She along with her son chased the vehicle in the car and intercepted it near Lohia Crossing. She also called a home guard standing nearby, who advised her to take the matter to the Gomtinagar police station. The woman sat along with the driver and asked him to drive to the police station. However, the complainant in her FIR said, the driver after driving for few minutes, called five of his aides who forced the woman to alight from the car, They then misbehaved with her stating that the vehicle belonged to the motorcade of a minister. They also took away her purse, which had cash and important identification documents like PAN and Aadhar cards.

column2: Dengue case count breaks 2016 official record in Lucknow
column3: LUCKNOW: With 36 fresh dengue cases reported in city on Monday, the tally for this year touched 1,097, breaking 2016’s record when 1,089 dengue cases were reported. In fact, the number of cases in October (652) alone this year was higher than the total number of cases reported in the entire year for every year since 2007, barring 2016. Besides, the seven dengue deaths of this year were all in October. This was the highest after 2016 when 18 deaths were reported. However, chief medical officer Narendra Agarwal said that 2016 still holds the record for maximum number of dengue cases. TimesViewChief medical officer insists that number of dengue cases reported this year so far has not broken the record of 2016. The figure quoted in records is a misprint and would be corrected soon. Even if this is true, more than 1,000 cases of dengue caused by mosquitoes in a year does not augur well for the city aspiring to become Smart. The spike in cases shows that civic agencies have not been able to perform their job to take preventive measures and maintain cleanliness required to provide healthy environment to citizens.He said the actual number of cases in 2016 was 2,172 with 18 deaths. The data in official records, he said, was misprinted and will be corrected soon. “There is no need to panic as we are taking measures to control dengue. In the upcoming days, the numbers will come down,” said the CMO. Among the fresh cases is an 11-year-old boy from Hazratganj, who is critical and undergoing treatment at Civil hospital. Two men aged 28 and 31 years are admitted in private hospitals in Aliganj and Indiranagar, respectively. Another critical patient is a 22-year-old woman undergoing treatment in a private hospital in Banthra. The 29 new patients are residents of Husainabad, Aishbagh, Malihabad, Daliganj, Keshavnagar, Ruchi Khand, Balaganj, Bangla Bazaar, Alambagh, Rajni Khand, Chandannagar, Hazratganj, Salehnagar, Indiranagar, Adilnagar, LDA Colony, Wazirganj, Banthara, Singarnagar, Krishnanagar , Vikasnagar, Talkatora, Rajajipuram, Deva Road, Aliganj and Chinhat. The health department teams found larvae of the Aedes aegypti mosquito, which carries the dengue virus, at 31 places out of 2,553 sites scanned. The areas inspected were Hussainabad, Jodha Kheda, Singarnagar, Bahadur Kheda and New Haiderganj.

column2: Kanpurites enjoyed this hatt ke party
column3: Diwali might be over but Kanpurites are still in a festive mood. A social club organised a post-Diwali party for its members, recently. In order to give a festive look to the party the venue was beautifully decorated with jhalars, LED lights and cut-outs of diyas. (L) Beenu Gandhi and Lucky Gandhi (R) Divya Dixit and Neelu Gupta (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Beenu Gandhi and Lucky Gandhi (R) Divya Dixit and Neelu Gupta (BCCL/ IB Singh) While the ladies chose colourful Indian dressing for the occasion most men came dressed in kurta and pyjamas. Simmi Oberai, was seen exchanging pleasantries with the guests. Placards of firecracker turned out to be the attraction among the guests as they were seen clicking pictures holding them. (L) Gurmeet Singh and Meetu Singh (R) Mala and Sudha (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Gurmeet Singh and Meetu Singh (R) Mala and Sudha (BCCL/ IB Singh) A number of games kept everyone entertained during the do. Palak bagged a gift hamper for winning the antakshari whereas Beenu Gandhi and Lucky Gandhi won in stray styling. Later, Kanchan Tiwari enthralled the guests with her dance performance on the song In Aankhon Ki Masti from the film Umrao Jaan. Also present were Rajnikant, Divya, Twinkle, Meetu, Meenu, Gurmeet Singh, Rajeev Malhotra and Bhawana Malhotra. (L) Palak (C) Reetu and Sudha (R) Simmi Oberai and Twinkle (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Palak (C) Reetu and Sudha (R) Simmi Oberai and Twinkle (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Rajeev and Bhawana Malhotra (R) Roma and Seema (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Rajeev and Bhawana Malhotra (R) Roma and Seema (BCCL/ IB Singh)

column2: Ajay Devgn’s back in Lucknow for Maidaan
column3: After completing the Mumbai schedule of Boney Kapoor’s 'Maidaan', Ajay Devgn reached Lucknow on Monday afternoon to begin the second leg of the shooting here in the city. The shooting for the film began in Sitapur from Tuesday. Before coming to Lucknow, Devgn, along with son Yug, visited the Ajmer Sharif Dargah in Ajmer, Rajasthan, and after offering prayers there, headed to Lucknow. This is Ajay’s second film shoot in Lucknow after Raid and this time too the actor will be shooting in and around the city for more than a month. For Boney Kapoor, this is his third film shoot in Uttar Pradesh after Tevar and Mom that he has shot in Agra and Noida, respectively, earlier. "I have shot two films in UP, one in Agra and one in Noida, this time I am bringing my film to Lucknow. Jab bhi yahan aata hoon achha lagta hai." Boney said to us in an earlier interview. Amit Sharma, Director of the film Maidaan, posted a picture online from his Lucknow visit (BCCL) Amit Sharma, Director of the film Maidaan, posted a picture online from his Lucknow visit (BCCL) Boney adds, "Idhar ka khana aur idhar ke log, dono hi manpasand hain. Idhar ka mahaul bhi badhiya hai. UP is where I belong to, I was born in Meerut, so whenever I come here, I’m reminded of my childhood. I do think about spending some more time in Lucknow, but work beckons back in Mumbai. But now, thankfully I will be coming here for a longer stay to shoot my next film." Maidaan is a film about football coach Syed Abdul Rahim who responsible for India winning the gold medal in the Jakarta Asian Games in the 1963. He also helped India reach the semi-finals in the 1956 Melbourne Olympics. The film is being directed by Amit Ravindranath Sharma, who’s also directed the superhit 'Badhaai Ho' and 'Tevar'. The film also stars South Indian actress Keerthy Suresh, Boman Irani and Gajraj Rao. Other actors include football players who are undergoing training for the film.

column2: Amethi farmer gets free liver transplant at KGMU
column3: LUCKNOW: The department of surgical gastroenterology at King George’s Medical University (KGMU) played good Samaritan on Tuesday and conducted a free liver transplant on a poor farmer from Amethi. Gyanendra Pratap Singh, 41, was suffering from liver cirrhosis and prognosis wasn’t favourable without a transplant. While his wife Vandana, 39, decided to donate the organ, the department helped the patient in applying and procuring financial assistance under the chief minister’s Asadhya Rog Yojana. Normally, a liver transplant costs around Rs 30 lakh at a private hospital while the expenses at KGMU is around Rs 8 lakh, said head of department professor Abhijit Chandra who led the team of surgeons comprising Dr Vivek Gupta, Dr Vishal Gupta and Dr Pradeep Joshi. After a 12-hour operation, both donor and recipient are doing fine, Chandra added. This was the eighth liver transplant at KGMU since March 2017.

column2: Amethi DM late for hearing, faces HC ire
column3: LUCKNOW: Lucknow bench of Allahabad high court on Tuesday severely reprimanded the district magistrate of Amethi, Prashant Sharma, for not appearing before the court in time to attend proceedings of a case. The officer was let off only after he tendered a written apology to the court. In January this year, hearing a petition filed by Ram Pratap Singh of Amethi, the court had directed the officials to ensure that the petitioner’s work was done within six months and asked the district magistrate to ensure compliance of the order. The court had summoned the DM on Tuesday in connection with a contempt petition in the same case. When the DM did not appear before the court for hearing at 12.30 pm and no explanation was given on his behalf, justice CD Singh expressed displeasure over the officer’s behaviour and directed the state authorities to ensure his presence in the court at 3.30 pm. When the officer did not appear even at 3.30pm, the state counsel sought 15 minutes more. The officer finally appeared after some time. Expressing displeasure over the DM’s behaviour, justice Singh directed him to stay in the court. Later, the officer tendered an unconditional apology to the court after which he was allowed to leave.

column2: Above 400, Lucknow AQI ‘severe’ for 4 days in a row
column3: LUCKNOW: Moderate winds helped clear the cloak of smog a bit, but the city’s air quality index (AQI) continued to stay above 400 or in ‘severe’ category for the fourth consecutive day and was the second highest in the country on Tuesday. Track the pollution level in your cityHaze followed by smog in the aftermath of Diwali celebrations has been shrouding the city for the past eight days, making breathing difficult for healthy citizens, not to mention the ailing or the elderly. The Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) recorded an AQI of 416 in Lucknow on Tuesday. Experts explained that though winds cleared the morning sky, the average AQI for 24 hours (5am to 5am) was high because of severe concentration of PM 2.5 on Monday evening and till the small hours of Tuesday. “The air was clearer by (Tuesday) afternoon, thanks to moderate winds and rise in temperature,” said professor Dhruvsen Singh, director of Lucknow University’s weather and pollution monitoring cell. According to CPCB’s real-time monitoring station, Talkatora was the most polluted with a PM 2.5 concentration of 445.05 microgram per cubic metre of air at midnight. The level dropped thereafter and remained in the 300-400 range till noon. Thereafter, it plummeted to 246.6 microgram per cubic metre around 2pm. In Lalbagh, the PM 2.5 concentration was again highest (374 microgram per cubic metre) at midnight. In the morning, it came down to 300 microgram per cubic metre of air and gradually dropped to 198.59 microgram per cubic metre of air by afternoon. Gomtinagar too recorded highest concentration of superfine particulate matter (309 microgram per cubic metre) around Monday midnight.

column2: UP: All construction norms up in smoke
column3: LUCKNOW: As the state capital continues to cough through pollution, some private and government agencies are brazenly flouting the government order to halt all construction activities. A TOI realty check found construction norms being violated in prominent localities like Mahanagar, Aliganj, Niralanagar, Gomtinagar, Jankipuram and Aishbagh. At many under-construction units, building material was not covered with green nets to prevent dust from polluting the air. Track the pollution level in your cityIn view of the deteriorating air quality, the state government had directed the Lucknow Development Authority (LDA) to ensure that no construction takes place in the city. However, the LDA has failed to implement the order. In Mahanagar, construction work of a three-storey housing unit was in progress. The contractor, Mahesh Patel claimed to be unaware of any government order. Tarun Verma, a resident of Mahanagar Sec-C, said, “Initially, they didn’t even put a green net to prevent dust from mixing in the air. Since my father has a breathing problem, I took up the issue with the contractor and a small green net was placed. However, it has failed to prevent the dust from coming outside.” Similar situation was found in Aliganj, where locals have been gasping under “eye-burning pollution”. Shikhar Saxena, a resident, said, “Forget about stopping the construction work, the site near my house is not even following the NGT norms. The entire locality gets walloped with dust causing redness in our eyes and breathing problems.” LDA vice-chairman P N Singh said, “We have issued notices to 90 construction sites to stop construction work. Our zonal officials are regular drives to ensure that no construction work takes place in the city till the pollution level improves.”

column2: UP: If you’re older than 60 years, take extra pollution cover
column3: LUCKNOW: Ram Manohar Mishra, 78, has been feeling breathless for the past four days, ever since he collected his pension from the bank, barely 2km from his Thakurganj residence. Track the pollution level in your city“My throat burns and I have difficulty breathing even if I go out on the terrace. The doctor says it is severe pollution that is causing my wheezing. I have been advised rest and venturing out is a strict no-no,” the retired government teacher told TOI. Mishra is not the only senior citizen who’s been extra susceptible to the poison in the air. If hospital and clinic registers are any indication, the number of elderly patients has leaped by 50-65% since Diwali. Most have complaints like chest congestion, high blood pressure and aggravation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), an umbrella term used to describe progressive lung diseases, including emphysema (damaged lung air sacs), chronic bronchitis, and refractory (non-reversible) asthma. Also, there’s a 35% increase in bacterial infection cases among the elderly, including conjunctivitis and dry eye syndrome. “If we were attending to 50 elderly patients a day eight-nine days ago, the number is now 100,” said head of respiratory medicine at KGMU professor Suryakant. “Around 65% patients have chronic respiratory problems aggravated by high pollution levels,” he added. Chest specialist Kalayan Malik, who runs a private hospital in Thakuraganj, said he was attending to 35-40 elderly patients a day. “The number was 15-20 a week earlier. Only an hour or two of exposure to pollutants is complication underlying ailments,” Malik said. Similarly, at Balrampur Hospital, SPM Civil Hospital and Ram Manohar Lohia Institute of Medical Sciences, the number of elderly patients in the pulmonary OPD has jumped from around 25 a day to 50. Narhi resident Sarju Prasad, 60, had to be rushed to the emergency after he had an attack of breathlessness on Tuesday afternoon. The COPD patient was at his electrical appliances store when he suddenly ran out of breath. “I was uneasy since morning and had an attack around 3pm. My son took me to hospital, where I received oxygen support,” he said. Harishchanda Singh, 75, of Chapatioan said merely a 30-minute park visit on Friday made his eyes burn. “I went to the ophthalmologist a day after and was told I had conjunctivitis. I have been advised to stay indoors,” he added.

column2: Industrial corridors along state e-ways soon
column3: LUCKNOW: To give a boost to its one district-one product scheme, the government has decided to develop industrial corridors along all expressways in the state. Principal secretary MSME Navneet Sehgal has said that directions have been issued to all divisional commissioners and district magistrates to identify land along all existing and upcoming expressways for the industrial corridor. The land for these parks will be identified in a 5km radius from the expressway. All expressways will be covered under this policy, said an official. “Where we are able to get more than 5-acre land of the gram sabha, we will establish mini industrial complexes. In these areas, 50% of the land will be reserved for MSME units,” Sehgal said. The land will be made available free of cost to the directorate of industry for development of these corridors.

column2: Jan Sangh, BJP saved nation from another Partition: CM Yogi Adityanath
column3: LUCKNOW: Chief minister Yogi Adityanath on Tuesday said that the country would have been witness to another Partition if the leaders of Jan Sangh and BJP had not staunchly opposed the appeasement policy of the Congress regimes at the Centre. “Jan Sangh and later the BJP were conceptualised to make Bharat as one country. The two organisations stood for democratic values which bind the country into one nation,” Yogi said at the book launch of ‘Amit Shah and March of BJP’ written by Anirban Ganguly and Shivanad Dwivedi, in Lucknow. “For BJP, the Constitution drafted by BR Ambedkar is more important than any other thing,” the CM said. BJP has reached a turning point under the leadership of PM Narendra Modi and party chief Amit Shah, the CM said. Amit Shah started his political career by pasting posters for daughter of Vallabhbhai Patel’s daughter Maniben in Mehsana and went on to become the BJP chief. This is possible only in BJP which does not believe in nepotism,” Yogi said. Comparing Shah with Adi Shankaracharya and Chanakya, the CM said it was the appeasement policy of the Congress that compelled Shah and senior BJP leaders to come up with the concept of ‘Congress-Mukt Bharat’. Yogi said when the Opposition alliance in UP and other states worried some BJP functionaries, Shah told them that the party would beat all odds and register a win. “And that’s exactly what happened in UP, where SP-BSP fought against us, but we emerged victorious in Lok Sabha polls,” he said. Yogi said that even the programmes of Modi were executed by Shah and ensured that the philosophy of `Sabka Saath Sabka Vikas’. Quoting PM Narendra Modi, Yogi said that the government should not work for any particular caste or community. “He (Modi) ensured that the people’s welfare schemes were taken down at the grassroots level,” he said. Yogi also blamed the Congress for introducing Article 370 that gave special status to Jammu and Kashmir. “Modi and Shah scrapped it because for them the country is more important than politics and every country has backed their decision,” he said.

column2: Power employees on a short fuse, want PCL chairman to step down
column3: LUCKNOW: Enraged over the alleged Rs 2,200-crore PF scam involving investment of their hard-earned money in tainted Dewan Housing and Finance Corporation Limited (DHFL), power employees staged a protest at Shakti Bhawan, the UPPCL headquarters, on Tuesday. Under the aegis of UP Rajgya Vidyut Karamchari Sangharsh Samiti, the protesters demanded that the state government should take the guarantee of the money invested by the UP state power sector employee trust in various unscheduled financial institutions including DHFL, PNB Housing Ltd and LIC Housing Limited. Samiti convener Shailendra Dubey said that UPPCL chairman Alok Kumar, who also happens to be the chairperson of the trust, should own the responsibility of the anomaly and step down. The union also demanded that Kumar be arrested for the alleged scam as he could influence the ongoing inquiry by the economic and offence wing. “More than Rs 3,000 crore was invested in DHFL during the tenure of Kumar and he should be held responsible for this,’’ Dubey said. Angry power employees started gathering at the UPPCL headquarters in the afternoon before taking out a foot march around the two buildings housing the offices of corporation chairman and energy minister Srikant Sharma. Raising slogans against the management, the employees said the state government cannot shy away from its responsibility of ensuring public welfare. The agitation came a day after the government removed UPPCL managing director Aparna U and posted her as secretary in the irrigation department. Employees said that just removal of Aparna U would not assuage the anger of the affected staff. “The entire UPPCL management needs to take responsibility and step down,’’ Union general secretary Rajeev Singh said. Employees wondered as to how the UPPCL could not keep an eye on the investment of their PF in unscheduled financial institutions. “They know about the quantum of payments made to the contractors but they claim of remaining in dark when it comes to investments in companies like DHFL,’’ said an agitator.

column2: UP cadre IPS officer is new LPAI chief
column3: LUCKNOW: Uttar Pradesh cadre IPS officer Aditya Mishra, who is heading state CID wing as ADG, has been appointed the chairman of Land Ports Authority of India (LPAI). LPAI is the nodal agency for clearing and managing facilities for cross-border movement of passengers and goods at designated points along the international borders. The move comes at a time when LPAI will also look after the crucial Kartarpur corridor amid strained ties between India and Pakistan. The 1989-batch IPS officer, who returned to his parent cadre in 2017 after a successful stint with BSF in Punjab, will assume charge with LPAI in Delhi for a five-year tenure. Mishra, a post-graduate in economics, has also served with SSB and at Hyderabad Police Academy.

column2: UP may hold special assembly session on Constitution Day
column3: LUCKNOW: Having set a record of convening the assembly non-stop for 48 hours to lay the road map for development, the Yogi Adityanath government is set to achieve another milestone by holding a special session on November 26, celebrated as Constitution Day, for the first time. The chief minister is likely to convene a meeting with Speaker Hridaya Narain Dixit and parliamentary affairs minister Suresh Khanna on November 8 to finalise details. Highly placed sources in the government told TOI that the chief minister wanted to convene the special session as a tribute to leaders who deliberated in the constituent assembly to promulgate the Constitution of India. Also known as Samvidhan Divas, it is celebrated in India on November 26 every year to commemorate the adoption of the Constitution of India. On November 26, 1949, the constituent assembly adopted the Constitution and it came into effect on January 26, 1950. Yogi is likely to invite governor Anandiben Patel to inaugurate the special assembly session after which tributes will be paid to freedom heroes and architects of the nation. In the recent past, the Yogi government had convened a special session of the House for 48 hours (October 2-3) to pay tribute to Mahatma Gandhi. Since opposition had boycotted the October special session, it is to be seen if they attend the one this time.

column2: UP: Construction work will draw Rs 1 lakh fine till air clears
column3: LUCKNOW: UP chief secretary RK Tiwari on Tuesday directed the officials concerned to ensure no construction activities are carried out till the air quality improves and impose a fine of Rs 1 lakh on those found violating the ban orders. Track the pollution level in your cityExpressing concern over spike in air pollution level, particularly in Ghaziabad, Greater Noida and Noida, which have been figuring among top polluted places in the country for last one week, he directed all divisional commissioners and district magistrates in the state to ensure compliance of the November 2 Supreme Court order on air pollution control. “In case of non-compliance, local administration and municipal corporation will be held responsible. Steps should also be taken at every level including gram panchayat, gram pradhan and lekhpal to stop burning of agricultural waste in the state,” he added. The chief secretary also directed officers to ensure measures to check dengue, availability of dengue ward, medicines and other facilities in government hospitals. “A joint team of additional CMOs and officers of local civic body will be formed to ensure that the staff and units work efficiently to prevent dengue in affected areas,” he said.

column2: UP: Construction work will draw Rs 1 lakh fine till air clears
column3: LUCKNOW: UP chief secretary RK Tiwari on Tuesday directed the officials concerned to ensure no construction activities are carried out till the air quality improves and impose a fine of Rs 1 lakh on those found violating the ban orders. Track the pollution level in your cityExpressing concern over spike in air pollution level, particularly in Ghaziabad, Greater Noida and Noida, which have been figuring among top polluted places in the country for last one week, he directed all divisional commissioners and district magistrates in the state to ensure compliance of the November 2 Supreme Court order on air pollution control. “In case of non-compliance, local administration and municipal corporation will be held responsible. Steps should also be taken at every level including gram panchayat, gram pradhan and lekhpal to stop burning of agricultural waste in the state,” he added. The chief secretary also directed officers to ensure measures to check dengue, availability of dengue ward, medicines and other facilities in government hospitals. “A joint team of additional CMOs and officers of local civic body will be formed to ensure that the staff and units work efficiently to prevent dengue in affected areas,” he said.

column2: Traditional games & yoga to make schoolkids fitter
column3: LUCKNOW: Seeking to promote a culture of fitness among kids, Uttar Pradesh schools will celebrate the Fit India Week in November (18-23) with traditional games and yoga sessions. The schools would observe the ‘Fit India Week’ in November third week. Following suggestions from the Sports Authority of India (SAI), the week would begin with ‘Magical Monday’ and conclude with ‘Sportier Saturday’. UP state project director (education) VK Anand has instructed basic shiksha adhikaris of all districts to organise a host of activities during the week. The initiative would begin with ‘Magical Monday’, wherein schools have been directed to organise indigenous or traditional sports. Schools will also assess the physical fitness of their staff and organise a three-minute yoga protocol. Next on ‘Tempting Tuesday’, sport teachers would interact with parents and educate them about healthier lifestyles. The sports teacher-parent meeting would be followed by 30-minute fitness session. The day’s activities will conclude with a four-minute yoga session. On ‘Winner’s Wednesday’, schools’ staff would compete with students in traditional games, followed by a five-minute yoga protocol. On Thursday, games testing students ability to work in teams would be organised. The day’s schedule would also include a six-minute yoga session. Next on ‘Friday Fitness Quiz’, a Khelo India quiz will be organised for all. Friday’s yoga protocol would be of seven minutes. The week will end on Saturday and schools have been directed to organise fun activities for students, teachers and parents. Also, a fitness assessment report card will be handed over to everyone. The last yoga protocol of the week will be eight minutes long. The idea is to encourage students to include physical activity and sports in their everyday lives, said an official.

column2: Meerut: Crime branch to probe cop’s suspicious death
column3: MEERUT: Over a month after a 35-year-old police constable was found dead at his home in Meerut under suspicious circumstances, members of his family and scores of locals held a protest at police headquarters here, alleging that it was a murder and suspected the role of his wife in it. Deepak Singh Raghav, who was posted at Lucknow Police Lines, was found hanging at his home in Meerut’s Shradhapuri area on October 2. On Tuesday, Raghav’s kin held a protest at the office of additional director general (ADG) (Meerut zone) Prashant Kumar demanding an FIR in the case. The family members in their complaint alleged that local police was not registering FIR. Speaking to TOI, the Meerut ADG said, “The family met me, and on their request, we will get the investigation done by crime branch.” A constable of 2015 batch, Raghav is now survived by his wife and a one-year-old daughter. Initially, it was claimed that Raghav took the extreme step due to domestic dispute. But now, the aggrieved family is claiming it to be a murder. They are suspecting the role of Raghav’s wife into his death. So far, it was treated to be a case suicide and no FIR was registered.

column2: UP: Gang lifts 8 high-end vehicles, but leaves behind super car
column3: LUCKNOW: In a wee-hour operation à la Hollywood action heist film Gone In 60 Seconds, a gang of vehicle thieves stole eight expensive cars valued at more than a crore from a resale showroom on Faizabad Road, opposite Badshahnagar Metro station, on Tuesday. Ironically, the cars were lifted from a place 700 metre from the trans-Gomti ASP’s office and at a time cops were busy checking vehicles at 93 points under Operation Midnight. In a face-saver, police claim to have identified four suspects from surveillance camera footage and are not ruling out an insider role. There were 17 cars parked inside the walled compound, but the gang whisked away six with automatic transmission — a BMW X3, an Audi Q3, a Toyota Fortuner, a Ford Endeavour and two Toyota Innova Crystas — besides two Hyundai i20s that had manual transmission. What is baffling investigators is that the thieves left behind a fleet of other high-end cars. Employee on leave under police scannerWhat is baffling investigators is that the thieves left behind a fleet of other high-end cars, including an Audi Q7, a Mercedes, two more BMWs, a Skoda Superb, a Honda Accord, a Chevrolet Cruze, a Renault SUV and another Fortuner, which were more expensive than the Innova and i20s despite having access to the keys. In fact, they moved the Q7 (ex-showroom price Rs 80 lakh) out of their way to take some of the other cars. According to police, the gang first scaled the 8ft boundary wall to enter the resale showroom premises, and then broke open locks to the main gate and office door. Keys of all the second-hand cars were inside an almirah locker while the almirah key was inside the drawer of the office table. “The intruders took all the keys, but later left behind nine inside the compound. The most expensive car in the lot was an Audi Q7, but they just moved it out of the way to steal the BMW X3 and Endeavour parked behind. The i20s were whisked away first, followed by the Fortuner, Crystas and Q3. The X3 and Endeavour were the last to go,” a policeman said. A 28-year-old employee who has not returned to work since he went home to Varanasi for Diwali is under police scanner. His last location was traced to Chandauli. He had worked at the used car showroom for around three months. Mahanagar circle officer Sonam Kumar said they were examining CCTV camera footage and the break-in seemed to have taken place around 1am. “The gang may have taken multiple routes to reach target,” he maintained. Trans-Gomti ASP Rajesh Srivastava said registration plates of the stolen cars had been put under surveillance. “They have not crossed any toll plaza on the outskirts of Lucknow. We have a list of suspects provided by the business partners. The digital video recorder, initially reported as missing, was found dumped in a duct inside the compound. Footage shows four suspects,” the officer added.

column2: Former UPPCL MD arrested in over Rs 2,000 crore PF scam
column3: LUCKNOW: Former managing director of Uttar Pradesh Power Corporation Limited (UPPCL) AP Mishra was arrested by the economic offences wing (EOW) of UP Police on Tuesday evening in connection with the scam involving investment of over Rs 2,200 crore of the corporation employees’ provident fund in the tainted Dewan Housing and Finance Corporation Limited (DHFL). Mishra has been arrested under the charges of criminal breach of trust, dishonesty, forgery of valuable security, forgery for the purpose of cheating and using a genuine document as a forged one. He has been locked up at the Hazratganj police station. Confirming Mishra’s arrest to TOI, director general of EOW Rajinder Pal Singh said, “The EOW is verifying all the documents seized from the (UPPCL) office of the period when Mishra served as MD. Tampering has been witnessed, which is being cross-checked.” Mishra’s arrest comes two days after general manager (finance) P K Gupta and former director (finance) Sudhanshu Dwivedi were arrested. The state government has already recommended a CBI inquiry into the case. “We will now seek remand of Gupta and Dwivedi, so that they can be confronted with Mishra,” Singh added. The EOW on Sunday began investigating the violation in investment of over Rs 4,000 crore by UP Power Sector Employees’ Trust in DHFL. Of this amount, Rs 2,268 crore has got trapped following a Mumbai high court order restricting the company from releasing money to its creditors. Sleuths from EOW swooped down on Mishra at 3.30amMishra took over the reins of UPPCL as MD in May 2012, soon after SP stormed to power with absolute majority. In fact, he was the first engineering cadre official to become MD of UPPCL and was given extension thrice in the Akhilesh Yadav regime. He tendered his resignation on March 23, 2017, after the BJP came to power. On Tuesday around 3.30am, Lucknow police along with a 10-member team of EOW swooped down on Mishra’s Aliganj residence and picked him up for questioning. He was taken to EOW office and questioned for several hours. Mishra is accused of giving his nod to the investment of employees’ provident fund money in DHFL in March 2017, EOW sources said. They said that it had come to the fore that Mishra was one of the key members of the board of trustees which, on March 22, 2017, gave its assent to invest in companies, including DHFL, from where higher returns were expected. Interestingly, Mishra resigned on March 23 but was issued a transfer order on March 24. Hence, his role in the investment decision could not be ruled out, a senior EOW official told TOI. Even as SP and BJP continued to trade charges over which government was responsible for the diversion of the PF money, BSP chief Mayawati lashed out at the saffron party and said that having failed in stemming corruption, it should not play a blame game. Putting out a tweet, she said: “When BJP was unable to stop the more than Rs 2,200 (sic) PF scam that involved money of thousands of engineers and workers of the power department, what is the point of playing a blame game. The government should first think about the welfare of the workers.”

column2: A Diwali dhamaka for these girls in Lucknow
column3: A well-known girls’ school in Lucknow recently hosted a Diali party for their students. A fun-filled evening of dance, music, games and prizes started with the dancing extravaganza titled Diwali Dance Dhamaka organized by the alumni association of the girls’ college. (L) Bhavna Gupta (R) Ila kapoor and Ishita Basu (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Bhavna Gupta (R) Ila kapoor and Ishita Basu (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) The musical score by DJ Moni was an instant hit with the young crowd. Songs like Closer, Bachna Ae Haseeno with recent hits like Ghungroo and the Jawani song made the girls ask for an encore. Diwali being the theme of the party, we spotted most girls dressed in Indian attire. Ila Kapoor and Ishita made the evening more happening with their hosting skills. (L) Karishma Sharma and Vageesha Pandey (R) Ritika Rai (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Karishma Sharma and Vageesha Pandey (R) Ritika Rai (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Mahi Srivastava and Anushika Shukla (R) Monii (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Mahi Srivastava and Anushika Shukla (R) Monii (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) The most awaited part of the evening was the giving away of titles. Shambhavi Pandey was crowned the Diwali Queen while Lavanya Dhakrey bagged the title of Diwali Princess. Last but not the least, Surabhi Garg stood as the Best Dancer. The Lucky Draw Hamper was won by Sanvi Sharma of Class III.
