column2: Ayodhya on tenterhooks: Some shift out, others stocking up on ration
column3: AYODHYA: In Ayodhya these days, the air is thick with apprehension and anxiety. With the temple verdict expected any day now, the town’s residents are making whatever preparations they can — some are hoarding food and essentials, while others have quietly begun shifting women and children out to places they feel are safe. Some are even cancelling weddings or moving venues outside the district. A middle-aged tailor in Syedwada, a neighbourhood with a considerable number of Muslim families living alongside temples and Hindu households, said, “They (locals residents) talk among themselves and say that Syedwada will be targeted this time. It is worrisome.” The man, who didn’t want to give out his name, added, “They are saying there will be trouble if the judgment is not in favour of the Ram temple. What will we do in such a situation if not send our families away?” Many in the community had done the same when in November last year VHP and Shiv Sena members descended on the town. Some distance away, Ghanshyam Gupta, whose family has been selling ladoos outside the famous Hanuman Garhi temple for three generations, said, “We have made suitable arrangements and are stocking rice and lentils at home.” Umar Farooq, a litigant in the Ramjanmabhoomi-Babri Masjid dispute, said he’s seen it all — the violence in 1990, the demolition of Babri Masjid in 1992 and the arson that followed, the tension around the high court judgment of 2010, and when the Shiv Sena marched into Ayodhya in November last year. “Through all this, Ayodhya residents never had problems with one another. Trouble starts when a mob comes from outside. That’s when there is chaos for us,” he added. The district administration, meanwhile, is holding peace gatherings with community leaders and is even forming WhatsApp groups for real-time communication and deployment of additional forces in the event of an emergency. District magistrate Anuj K Jha told TOI that a number of meetings in October and November with Hindu mahants and Muslim imams had been held to address worries and give assurances of safety. “We have assured Muslims that a survey of all sensitive areas, including minority-dominant ones and those with mixed populations, has already been done and we will be deploying forces ahead of the verdict. There is no need for people to panic. Our focus is peace and protection in the whole of Ayodhya,” Jha said. However, apprehension is still running deep. In October, the Muslim community’s nervousness became apparent when a meeting was called at the house of Haji Mahboob, another litigant in the dispute, to get their concerns addressed. “Security was beefed up in Ayodhya in 2010 when the high court was to pronounce a judgment. Things will be fine if there is a similar bandobast in place. But people are scared. Many haven’t been able to forget 1992.” He has a point. Syed Khalique Ahmed’s son was to get married in December. But feeling that the situation is “not conducive” for a celebration, Ahmed not just changed the venue of the wedding from Faizabad to Lucknow but also got his son married in early November itself. Hotel owners in Ayodhya echoed Ahmed’s sentiment. Pawan Singh, manager of the Birla Dharmashala, meters away from Hanuman Garhi, said, “People have cancelled bookings for venues and rooms, not just for November and December but until February next year. Whoever is saying normal life in Ayodhya has not been disrupted is not telling the truth.”

column2: Slowdown signal: Top companies cold to IIT hiring season
column3: MUMBAI: In yet another indication of the economic slowdown, some of the leading firms that visit the IITs every year are likely to stay away during the placement season starting December. Some of the sought-after ‘Day One’ firms, which typically offer hefty packages, have either declined requests from placement cells of the institutes or are yet to confirm their interest. The placement cells at these institutes have doubled their efforts to reach out to newer firms to get adequate recruiters. Quantitative investment management firm, World-Quant, which usually offers one of the highest domestic packages at over Rs 40 lakh, will be visiting IIT-Bombay but is yet to confirm at other IITs. Tower Research and Graviton Research and other firms with lucrative offers have not given any positive indication yet. At some of the IITs, USbased cloud data management company Rubrik, which offers US profiles to students, has not confirmed its presence this year. “We have lost a few companies which regularly visited us, but we are compensating for this by exploring newer avenues,” a student representative from IIT-Kharagpur said. “Some of them have met their requirements from the pre-placement offers. We have increased the total number of companies visiting us this season to beat the ongoing slowdown.” The first phase of placements across IITs commences on December 1 every year and goes on for two to three weeks. Many IITs have seen a slight increase in their pre-placement offers from the previous year, while some like the ones in Kanpur and Kharagpur have seen almost similar number of offers. In a press statement, IIT-Hyderabad said that the number of PPOs has almost doubled compared to the previous year. Gartner, Graviton, World-Quant, Rubrik are not visiting the IIT-Kanpur campus, while Tower Research is yet to confirm, said a student. “The automobile sector is severely hit,” one of the overall placement co-ordinators from the institute said. “In other core sectors, fewer roles are being offered, but there is no freeze. In some other firms, newer roles are added. We are expecting a marginal drop in the hiring with some of the leading ones staying away from our campus.” An official from the IITBombay placement office confirmed that a few ‘Day One’ organisations had declined to participate in the placement process. At IIT-Bombay, 163 pre-placement offers were made till November 5, compared to 141 last year. A student representative from IIT-Delhi said many firms from the core sectors which visited last year had refused to come this year.

column2: Air quality improves but AQI ‘hazardous’ in Kanpur
column3: KANPUR: The city on Wednesday witnessed improved air quality and bright sunshine in the first half of the day though the sunshine dipped in the afternoon. The Air Quality Index (AQI), which was 311 at 12 noon, was labelled as 'hazardous' for intake. But as the day progressed, the air quality kept on improving. Though it improved to 251 at 10 pm, still it was rated as 'very unhealthy'. There was no relief from the dusty atmosphere as the dust continued to wrap the atmosphere, especially in areas where roads are damaged and need urgent repairs like a road between Kidwai Nagar crossing and Transport Nagar. Track the pollution level in your cityResidents got some relief from smog and haze and the weather was clear with better visibility. The day temperature came down to 29.4 degrees while the minimum temperature fell to just 16 degrees. This was for the first time since the month of November started that the night temperature fell to 16 degrees Celsius. The minimum temperature on the previous night was 18.8 degrees while on Sunday night it was 19.8 degrees Celsius. The temperature fell and the smog disappeared due to icy winds blowing in the city. The district administration has warned people not to burn garbage on roads as a fine of Rs 50,000 would be slapped on a person found burning garbage.

column2: CSAW: Students exhibit hacking talent at IIT-Kanpur
column3: KANPUR: Cyber Security Competitive event— CSAW (Cyber Security Awareness Worldwide), organised in cooperation with New York University and other centres, commenced at IIT-Kanpur on Wednesday evening. IIT-K director Prof Abhay Karandikar inaugurated the event. On the occasion, the institute also signed MoUs with Data Security Council of India (DSCI) and Schneider Electric India. The keynote speech was delivered by senior cyber security consultant -Asia Pacific, Schneider Electric, Dinesh Gianchandani. Head of the department, computer science and engineering Prof Sandeep Shukla said that every year in the first week of November CSAW competition is conducted in cooperation with New York University, Mexico, Israel, France, Tunisia and other countries at the same time. The participants from India come to IIT-Kanpur and first preliminary tests are conducted in August and September. The finalists of this competition come to IIT-K to take part in 36-hour long continued hacking titled ‘Capture The Flag (CTF)’. “The participants earn the points for hacking the target given to them. In an applied research event, teams present their research before the judges while in Embedded Security Challenge teams hack the Embedded Security System. This time the students had to hack the RFID system. Every year different hacking challenges are offered to the participating teams. Faculties from IIT-Ropar, IIT-Bhilai, IISc and other institutes judge these events”, said Prof Shukla. “An Industrial Hacking workshop has also been organised for industrial experts”, he added. Before the event director, IIT-K signed two MoUs. “The IIT-K signed a MoU with Data Security Council. The institute will be partner in the Centre of Excellence for Cyber Security to be set up in Noida. The council has even been granted funds by ministry of electronics and telecommunications for the project,” said Prof Shukla. Meanwhile, hacking contest will commence from Thursday morning and will continue till mid-day Friday. Teams from various institutes and universities will take part in the event. An industrial security workshop for industry engineers and academics will also be held on Friday. Also an Industrial Control System hacking contest will take place on Friday. Teams from IIT-Kharagpur, IIT-Gandhinagar, IIT-Madras, IIT-Dharwad, IIIT-Allahabad, Cochin University of Technology will compete in applied research competition, and embedded security challenge.

column2: Six KMC workers, one local fined for burning garbage
column3: KANPUR: Even after a prohibition on burning of waste in open, Kanpur Municipal Corporation workers as well as local residents continue the practice and ended up being penalised. Recently, in an order, the district administration has prohibited burning of waste and announced a fine on any such activity in view of deteriorating air quality in the city. On receiving a complaint from locals on WhatsApp number issued by the KMC recently, it carried out an investigation and fined 11 persons including 10 KMC employees and a local resident. KMC had issued a WhatsApp no 8601805555 for registering complaint regarding any such activities like burning garbage. Municipal commissioner Akshay Tripathi supervised the complaint cell. Around 225 complaints were made to the cell between October 28 and November 5. However, the KMC imposed a fine acting on the complaint for the first time, said an official. “I have specifically directed that there shall be a complete prohibition on burning of waste in open anywhere across the city. For each such incident, violators shall be liable to pay fine. Of the 225 complaints, we have zeroed in on 11 persons including nagar nigam and contractual employees, besides a city residents and fined them. We have deducted one day salary of six nagar nigam employees, fined three other nagar nigam employees of Rs 200 and Rs 1,000, and recommended an outsourcing company to remove a cotractual employee and fined a city resident of Rs 500,” said Tripathi.

column2: Section 144 imposed in Kanpur ahead of Ayodhya verdict
column3: KANPUR: District administration on Wednesday promulgated Section 144 of CrPC to maintain law and order in the city ahead of Supreme Court judgement in the Ayodhya case. ADM (finance and revenue) Virendra Pandey in his order stated that in view of Kartik Purnima/Guru Nanak’s birth anniversary, the Barawafat festival and the Supreme Court’s judgement on Ayodhya issue, Section 144 of CrPC has been promulgated in the city. He said following the imposition of Section 144 CrPC, five or more than five persons would not be allowed to assemble at any public place nor they can take out any procession without the permission of the district administration. Marriage functions and carrying of dead bodies for cremation/burial will, however, be exempted from this provision. No one will be allowed to raise slogans, give a fiery speech, spread rumour or indulge in any activity which might hurt the feelings of any community. Further, the use of loudspeakers will remain prohibited from 10 pm to 6 am. No person will be allowed to carry a firearm, place hurdles on public roads or encourage anyone to do so, the ADM said. Meanwhile, at a communal harmony meeting held here on Wednesday, SSP Anant Deo appealed to the people of the city to maintain law and order city after the judgment in Ayodhya case. “It is the duty of the people to comply with the Apex Court’s order and refrain from expressing their joy or sorrow over the judgment”, he said. He asked them to keep a tab on social media and desist from posting rumour or any sensitive message. Police have raised four IT cells to keep a tab on social media. Police have also identified as many as 204 sensitive spots in the city where the special force will be deployed, he said. He has appealed to senior members of both the communities to help police in maintaining law and order in the city after the verdict.

column2: Two get 10-year jail term for abducting, exploiting minor
column3: KANPUR: Additional district and sessions judge (V) Sanjay Kumar Verma on Wednesday sentenced accused Ghulam Jilani of Gangaghat and Farhan of Tiwaripur to ten years rigorous imprisonment along with a fine of Rs 22,000 on each for enticing, kidnapping and physically exploiting a minor girl. According to additional district government counsel (ADGC) Pradeep Bajai, the court in its order observed that 50% of the fine amount (Rs 22,000) be given to the victim as damages. The ADGC stated that a complaint was filed by the victim’s father on July 14, 2010, against two persons--Ghulam Jilani and Farhan--alleging that they had enticed his daughter and alter kidnapped her at around midnight. The victim in her statement stated that she knew Farhan because he was studying with her in the same school and the same class and she would often help him financially. She told the court that on July 14, 2010, Farhan had asked her to help him and when she went to Farhan, who was standing near a car, Ghulam Jilani dragged her inside the car and placed a medicated handkerchief on her mouth after which she lost her senses. When she regained consciousness, she found herself in Unnao. Later, Farhan took her to Aligarh. She said that was kept in a house where both Farhan and Jilani physically exploited her for two months and used to threaten her. On the point of the sentence, the defence counsel pleaded that Jilani, a 64-year-old man, had not played any role in the incident and Farhan was minor at the time of the commission of the crime. Since he was the only earning member of his family, therefore, the court should take a lenient soft view, he pleaded. Countering the defence counsel's arguments, the prosecution claimed that as the accused had not only kidnapped and physically exploited the girl in a very calculated manner for more than two months, therefore, they deserve exemplary punishment. (The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

column2: Reconsider Tipu Jayanti ban, HC tells Karnataka govt
column3: BENGALURU: The Karnataka high court on Wednesday directed the BS Yediyurappa government to reconsider its decision to ban the annual celebration of Tipu Jayanti at an administrative level, even as it refused to stay the July 30 government order (GO) cancelling the Jayanti. Hearing a PIL seeking to scrap the GO, a division bench headed by chief justice Abhay Shreeniwas Oka noted that since the issue involved was a policy matter, the court did not want to pass a stay order. Citing the November 8, 2016, order passed by the then Congress government supporting Tipu Jayanti celebrations and the fact that the cancellation order was issued within a day’s time by the present BJP government, the bench directed the state to reconsider the GO. The court gave two months’ time to the government for the same. The court also directed the government to submit information on other birth anniversary celebrations conducted at the government level. Since the advocate general had told the court that others were free to celebrate Tipu Jayanti on November 10, the court directed authorities to take all precautionary measures to ensure law and order. Lucknow-based Bilal Ali Shah who claims to be a descendant of Tipu Sultan, along with Tipu Sultan United Front and Tipu Rashtreeya Seva Sangha challenged this cancellation order. The petitioners argued that the cancellation was discriminatory since 25 other Jayantis were being celebrated in the state. They argued Tipu Jayanti was cancelled because he was a Muslim. The court said the PIL warranted a detailed hearing and posted the matter to January.

column2: Ex-UPPCL MD quit on March 23, 2017, ‘signed’ note day later
column3: LUCKNOW: Even as a political row erupted over Uttar Pradesh Power Corporation Ltd (UPPCL) provident fund investment violations, then UPPCL MD A P Mishra, under whose tenure the decision to invest Rs 2,268 crore in tainted DHFL was taken and the money transferred, is in the eye of the storm on how he sanctioned the investment a day after his resignation during the transition of Samajwadi Party and BJP governments in March 2017. Mishra was arrested on Tuesday. Mishra submitted his resignation on March 23 that year, a day before the UPPCL Trust finally authorised the move to invest in DHFL. But what has baffled the EOW probing the scam is that the minutes of the trust meeting to invest in DHFL was prepared on March 17 and that Mishra’s signature is there on the March 24 meeting note. CM Yogi Adityanath took oath on March 19, blurring the lines on whom to fix responsibility. TOI is in possession of both the communications — Mishra’s resignation letter signed by then UP power additional chief secretary Sanjay Aggarwal as well as the March 24 minutes of the meeting note of UPPCL Trust that resolved to invest in DHFL. The March 24 decision by UPPCL trustees has been signed by five people — then UPPCL chairman Sanjay Aggarwal, trust secretary and general manager (finance and accounts) P K Gupta, director (finance) Sudhanshu Dwivedi, director (accounts) Satya Prakash Pandey and Mishra. “The trustees passed the following resolution: Board of trustees agreed to consider investment proposals as per government notification dated March 2, 2015, in securities with higher security and high interest rates other than term deposits of nationalised banks and ‘Triple A’ rated companies. As per prevailing practice, further investment in securities will be decided by secretary (trust) on case-to-case basis, with the consent/approval of director (finance), UPPCL, and trustees,” said the March 24 note. Sources in EOW though have said they are checking the possibilty of over-writing on one of the meeting notes and that if the March 24 meeting actually took place on March 22. Mishra has been shown as “special invitee’ in the March 24 meeting. TOI is also in possession of the March 17 note in which DHFL is shown to be providing higher rate of interest (ROI) as compared to other nationalised banks and hence the decision to invest Rs 2,268 crore.

column2: Shia Board’s secret deal: Build temple, shun claim on other disputed shrines
column3: LUCKNOW: With the mediation hotline shut and Ayodhya verdict day drawing closer, TOI accesses a letter by the Shia Waqf Board to the SC-appointed committee led by Justice FMI Kalifulla, offering a secret deal to solve the decades-old dispute. Striking a hard bargain with the mediation panel, Shia Waqf Board chairman Wasim Rizvi while consenting to construction of the Ram temple at the disputed site in Ayodhya put a rider that Hindus would have to shun their claims over other disputed shrines all over the country under a 1931 British-era Act. The letter followed discussions in March before Lok Sabha polls. The mediation committee had made a last-ditch attempt to resolve the Ayodhya imbroglio by talking to all stakeholders on directions of the apex court, but failed to hammer out a consensus due to the stringent stand of both Hindu and Muslim representatives, who questioned the integrity of some members and finally decided to abide by the Supreme Court judgment. Rizvi’s letter dated March 26, 2019, in possession with TOI reveals the Shia Waqf Board claimed to be the key litigant and custodian of the disputed property and extended a three-pronged offer. First, the Ram temple can built in the disputed site with consent of all litigants and a Babri mosque won’t be resurrected anywhere in India. Second, Hindus cannot lay claim on any other place of worship in the country and strictly adhere to the Places of Worship (Special Provisions) Act, 1931. Third, it demanded a promise from the mediation panel on “repair, renovation, and beautification of all mosques in Ayodhya at the expense of the state exchequer”. The Shia Board chief played hard ball, unlike his public posturing when he declared the dispute site be handed over to Hindus .

column2: SC verdict on Ayodhya: Fringe turns dove, fans out with peace tidings
column3: LUCKNOW: The Sangh Pariwar—VHP, Bajrang Dal and RSS—have fanned out into every block and village in Ayodhya district even as the country waits with bated breath for the Supreme Court verdict on the dispute. RSS, VHP and Bajrang Dal volunteers are talking to people, making an appeal to maintain peace and harmony at this crucial juncture. Recommended By Colombia                                      (function(){                       var adContainer = '';                       var randomNumber = Math.random();                       var isIndia = (window.geoinfo && window.geoinfo.CountryCode === 'IN') && (window.location.href.indexOf('outsideindia') === -1 );                       //console.log(isIndia && randomNumber  While vitriolic slogans had vitiated the atmosphere in 1992, when the Babri Masjid was pulled down, the fringe is now maintaining silence to the extent that cheerleaders of the VHP-Bajrang Dal-RSS have been strictly told to not make any statement regarding the Ram Mandir. Even BJP spokespersons have been told to either stay away from TV shows on the Ayodya verdict or play down the emotive issue if they did. Over a dozen scheduled programmes of the VHP-RSS-Bajrang Dal, to be held in November, have been postponed for an indefinite period and thousands of letters and appeals are being issued for peace and harmony. Chief minister Yogi Adityanath called a special meeting of his ministers and asked them to avoid mentioning Ram temple in their discussions. Sharad Sharma, spokesman of VHP in Ayodhya, said all programmes of the Sangh Pariwar have been postponed till an indefinite period and organisations and office-bearers have been told to maintain peace and propagate it through letters, appeals in media and through man-to-man contact by visiting villages and other places. Sharma said that Durga Vahini was to meet in Ayodhya for a training programme, “pracharaks” of various organisations of the RSS were to meet in Haridwar and Varanasi and a similar programme was to be held in Lucknow, but all these have been put off by now.

column2: Sangh curbs on cadre ahead of Ayodhya verdict: No sweets, crackers on D-day
column3: AYODHYA/LUCKNOW: Ahead of the Ayodhya verdict, Vishwa Hindu Parishad (VHP) and Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS) have enforced a slew of curbs on its cadre, including a ban on distribution of sweets even if the judgment is in favour of the temple. Senior RSS and VHP functionaries told TOI there should not be any celebration that can potentially disturb harmony. “Cadres have been told to refrain from distribution of sweets, bursting crackers or taking out processions,” said a senior RSS functionary. The development comes a day after minority affairs minister Mukhtar Abbas Naqvi hosted a meeting with Muslim and Hindu representatives and social organisations in Delhi, and appealed for calm after the Supreme Court verdict. The meeting which was attended by senior RSS functionaries, including Krishna Gopal and Ram Lal, called for a consensus on “no celebration or aggression” after the verdict. The hardline Sangh outfit, Vishwa Hindu Parishad, issued an appeal to members to maintain harmony in the run-up to the verdict. VHP vice-president Champat Rai said, “The verdict should not be a trigger for a Hindu-Muslim face-off, but an acceptance of the court verdict.” In a letter issued to VHP workers, Rai said this verdict won’t be any community’s victory. Expecting the verdict to be declared before November 15, he advised the cadre not to create an atmosphere of frenzy. State spokesman of VHP Sharad Sharma said, “All proposed programmes and activities by various outfits ahead of the verdict have been cancelled. Whether the verdict is in favour of Hindus or Muslims, both communities must present an example of harmony and brotherhood now. We all have to take care that no incident strains the cordial relations between Hindus and Muslims,” said Sharma. VHP national spokesperson Vinod Bansal said cadre and seers may continue their ‘anushtans’ (ritual prayers) for the Ram Temple wherever they are but they should not go overboard. “We are keeping a wait and watch approach. Any course of action would be taken after consultation with seers after the SC verdict is delivered,” he said, while speaking to TOI. VHP camps involving ‘Trishul Diksha Karyakram’ (trident training programmes) are already on hold. The camps were aimed at providing training to around 10,000 cadre and prepare them in case the court verdict comes in favour of the temple. Another VHP functionary in Ayodhya said no call has been given to cadres across India to reach the temple town once the SC verdict is delivered.

column2: UP: Banda power staff wear helmets, fearing injury from crumbling roof
column3: LUCKNOW/JHANSI: Fearing injury from the dilapidated ceiling of their office, employees in Banda district office of the UP Power Corporation Limited have started wearing helmets to their workplace. Located in Peeli Kothi area, the part of the building in shambles is the metre reading lab of the electricity department. The move, which was also seen as a protest against the apathy of the authorities towards their pending demand for a repair, caught attention of authorities when pictures of the employees wearing helmets went viral on social media. Soon, officials ordered an immediate repair of the building. However, they said the work would take about a week. “Our request for repair is pending since June 2017. Skipping office is not an option so we decided to take precautions,” said one of the employees. The photographs of the office speak volumes about the poor working condition. Remains of the rotting wooden false ceiling hangs over their head along with electrical wires. “The damp walls in the office have developed fungus... In monsoon, water droplets also trickle down from them,” rued another employee. One of the employees shared that a couple of months ago, a female visitor had a miraculous escape. “A huge chunk of the false ceiling fell upon her along with some debris. Thankfully, her injury was not deep,” claimed a clerk. When contacted, Keshav Kumar Bharadwaj, chief engineer, Dakshinanchal Vidyut Vitran Nigam Ltd, Banda, said, “The matter has come to my notice. The ceiling is made of a tin shade with a plyboard false ceiling which has decayed. We are taking immediate action, it will be repaired within a week”.

column2: Air improves, but graded plan curbs remain in place
column3: NOIDA: Crosswinds blowing into NCR cities reduced pollution levels in Noida and Greater Noida on Wednesday and the air quality improved to “poor”. In Greater Noida, the AQI dropped by about 100 notches to 247 compared to 346 on Tuesday. In Noida, the level saw a drop from 335 to 237. Air in both cities was in the “very poor” category on Tuesday. Track the pollution level in your cityOn Wednesday, Ghaziabad recorded an AQI of 294, also in the “poor” category. On Tuesday, the AQI was 346 (very poor). Officials said all existing GRAP restrictions continue to be in place and the the regional office of Uttar Pradesh Pollution Control Board (UPPCB) has sent out an alert saying that there should be no leaf burning at any place. The UPPCB has directed Noida and Greater Noida authorities to be vigilant of horticulture waste. “We ask all the authorities to collect horticulture waste and send them for composting. At no cost should leaves be set on fire. Every year around this time when trees shed leaves, people start setting them on fire. But we do not want any such reports this year,” said Anil Singh, the regional officer, UPPCB, Noida. Leaves are usually removed from the streets during sweeping by civic workers and then dumped in secluded spots. Horticulture waste can be seen along the approach road to Okhla bird sanctuary and many other spots and after some time, they are set on fire. “Burning of leaves and horticulture waste is punishable under National Green Tribunal (NGT) norms. Besides, we are going to keep a vigil on all leaves being picked up and piled up at various spots across the city. Burning leaves can lead to emission of toxic gases and we want to prevent it,” Singh said. He added that the air quality has improved overnight with a change in wind direction and speed. “In addition, with the clouds shifting, there has also been sunlight that has helped in dispersing the pollutants,” he said. On Wednesday, Noida and Greater Noida mostly saw clear sky. But Thursday might be a hazy day, as temperatures are likely to decrease overnight. Delhiites also breathed easy on Wednesday with the AQI improving significantly to 214 (“poor”). The last time Delhi recorded a reading below 214 was on October 10 when the AQI was 211. October 19 was an exception when the AQI had drastically fallen to 161 primarily due to a spell of rain. The Met department predicts a similar spell in the capital on Thursday, with good wind speeds accompanying it. It is likely to further improve Delhi’s air quality.

column2: UPPCL’s ex-chief signed PF order a day after quitting
column3: LUCKNOW: Even as a political row erupted over Uttar Pradesh Power Corporation Ltd (UPPCL) provident fund investment violations, then UPPCL MD A P Mishra, during whose tenure the decision to invest Rs 2,268 crore in tainted DHFL was taken and the money transferred, is in the eye of the storm on how he sanctioned the investment a day after his resignation during the transition of Samajwadi Party and BJP governments in March 2017. Mishra was arrested on Tuesday. Mishra submitted his resignation on March 23 that year, a day before the UPPCL Trust finally authorised the move to invest in DHFL. But what has baffled the EOW probing the scam is that the minutes of the trust meeting to invest in DHFL was prepared on March 17 and that Mishra’s signature is there on the March 24 meeting note. CM Yogi Adityanath took oath on March 19, blurring the lines on whom to fix responsibility. TOI is in possession of both the communications — Mishra’s resignation letter signed by then UP power additional chief secretary Sanjay Aggarwal as well as the March 24 minutes of the meeting note of UPPCL Trust that resolved to invest in DHFL. The March 24 decision by UPPCL trustees has been signed by five people — then UPPCL chairman Sanjay Aggarwal, trust secretary and general manager (finance and accounts) P K Gupta, director (finance) Sudhanshu Dwivedi, director (accounts) Satya Prakash Pandey and Mishra.

column2: Five of a gang held for stealing vehicles
column3: GHAZIABAD: Five persons were arrested from Itwar Pusta area in Khoda around 10.45pm on Tuesday for allegedly stealing around 80 vehicles from Delhi, NCR, Haryana and Punjab. Sixteen motorcycles and two scooters have been seized. Among those arrested, Shahnawaz, Asif, Sushil Kumar and Vishal belong to Ghazipur in Delhi, and Rehan is from Bijnor. They have several cases lodged against them in Delhi, Ghaziabad and Noida. SP (city) Manish Kumar Mishra said, “They conducted a recce of some areas, identified targets and then stole vehicles at night. Later, they replaced the original chassis and registration numbers and prepared fake papers for the vehicles.”

column2: Hindon gets 2nd flight, most seats sold for the week
column3: GHAZIABAD: “Mundgod to Hubballi by road, on to Hyderabad, a flight to Delhi and then an overnight bus to Dharamsala,” Lobshany Gyaltsan, a Buddhist monk, went over the route he used to take to get to the hill town where the Dalai Lama lives. Starting Wednesday, things will be simple: “One flight to Hindon and a bus ride to Dharamsala,” he said. What used to be a journey spanning at least three days will now take just a day. It has been nearly nine months since Hindon airport was launched. The idea was to take some pressure off Delhi’s Indira Gandhi International Airport. The Hindon airport started functioning last month, when Heritage Airlines started a six-day flight service to Pithoragarh in Uttarakhand. But that ended up being a false start after flight operations were suspended twice. After a hiatus, the Hindon display board lit up again on Wednesday: “OG115”. For now, the new Star Air flights to and from Hubballi will be the only one operating out of the airport. Just as the display board said the incoming flight was on time, the terminal broke out in a flurry of activity – officials from Star Air and the Airports Authority of India wrapped up a quick inaugural ceremony. At 3.45pm, the first flight on the route touched down at Hindon. “I will be seeing my husband after many months. But more than me, it is my three-year-old whose excitement knows no bounds,” said Nisha, who came to Hindon from Nagina, more than 150 km away, as she waited in line for baggage check. The Heritage Airlines flight, a nine-seater, did not allow any check-in baggage. Star Air does. And on the first day, there were no glitches. Lobshany, meanwhile, waited with 30 other monks, all on their way back to their monastery at Mundgod, about 50 km from Hubballi in Karnataka. “Return journeys were tiring as well. We would take a flight to Mumbai, Goa or Bengaluru and then travel by road,” said Geshelopsangh Tseten, another monk who was part of the contingent. In fact, a lot of what the Star Air flight service has to offer makes things easier – a bigger aircraft (the 50-seater Embraer), a bigger fleet (two now, to be scaled up to five by the end of the year) and baggage check-in facilities. “I have to commute to Hubballi at least once a month. I will be spared the rush of the Delhi airport and can save a lot of time,” said Sarvesh Choudhary, a project engineer with a Karnataka-based MNC. The response has been good, the airline said. “We are booked right through the week,” said Simran Singh Tiwana, CEO of Star Air. But could it run into the same problems that Heritage did? “We will not face the same snags. We are already operating on seven routes in the country. Our performance has been on a par with the major players and, unlike Heritage, we have two planes in the fleet and we intend to add three more by the end of the financial year.” The Hubballi-Hindon flights will operate thrice a week – on Wednesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays. On Wednesday and Thursday, the flight will leave Hubballi at 1.05pm and land in Hindon at 3.45pm. It will leave for a return journey to Hubballi at 4.10pm and reach at 6.50pm. On Saturdays, the flight will leave Hubballi at 11.50am and arrive at 2.30pm. It will leave Hindon at 3pm and reach Hubballi at 5.40pm.

column2: Lucknowites party in all-white
column3: After a hectic week at work, this was how these Lucknowites decided to unwind. An all-white theme party was recently organised by a city club. The ambience, music, food and drinks were just perfect and the guests made the most of it. Everyone was dressed stylishly in white for the do. (L) Goldy and Rimple Taneja (R) Swati Bansal (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Goldy and Rimple Taneja (R) Swati Bansal (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) The party got more interesting with some fun-filled games like Nike-Nike Shots, where the lady who drank maximum soft drink shots in the given time was the winner. Lavee Agarwal emerged as the winner by drinking maximum shots. (L) Tanisha and Darshan Singh (R) Niti Agarwal (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Tanisha and Darshan Singh (R) Niti Agarwal (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Another interesting game was Takatwar Pati in which the husband had to pick up his wife in his arms for maximum time. Sanjay emerged as the winner for holding his wife Alka in his arms. — Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui Akanksha and Abhishek (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Akanksha and Abhishek (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

column2: Lucknow Mahotsav to be postponed again this year?
column3: The much-awaited annual event Lucknow Mahotsav, that is held from November 25 to December 5 in the city, may be postponed this year. In anticipation of the effect of the Ayodhya case verdict, considering the law and order situation, the administration is mulling over postponing the Mahotsav this year to next year in January. Two years ago too the Mahotsav had been postponed to January in view of the Civic polls held in the state, despite it being a calendar event. This year too, the mega-fair may be postponed to January to avoid any untoward incident during the ten-day festival in view of the law and order situation that prevails after the Ayodhya Ram Temple case verdict is out. The Lucknow Mahotsav, which is a 10-day carnival like event, also has celebrity performances every day apart from mushaira, kavi sammelan, vintage car rally, kite flying competition, tonga race and a host of activities planned for each day. This year singers Jassi and Badshah were expected to perform apart from former contestants of Indian Idol and other reality shows. "Nothing is finalised yet but I have been told to think of an alternate date in case the Mahotsav is postponed," says Anupam Srivastava, Regional Tourist Officer, Lucknow division and member of the Lucknow Mahotsav Samiti. "There is no confirmation that has been given to me, but if the law and order situation gets affected due to the Ayodhya case verdict, then the mahotsav may be shifted to a later date by a day or two or maybe by several weeks or even months. But one thing is for sure that if it gets postponed to a later date, we will surely not have it in extreme winters and have it instead in mid-January," adds Srivastava. Meanwhile, according to sources, the Mahotsav may now be organised from January 13, 2020 at the Awadh Shilp Gram, near the Ekana Stadium on Shaheed Path instead of Smriti Upvan Aashiyana, its usual venue.

column2: Kanpur: Court to hear dengue-related case on day-to-day basis
column3: KANPUR: Civil judge, senior division, Kanpur Nagar, on Wednesday heard the review petition for execution of the direction issued by the Permanent Lok Adalat of Kanpur in 2016 and while fixing November 13 as the next date of hearing, stated that it would hear the case on day-to day-basis as the city is again gripped with dengue. Praveen Fighter, advocate, had filed a complaint before the Permanent Lok Adalat in 2016 when the city was reeling under dengue fever. Impleading district magistrate, municipal commissioner and general manager Jal Kal as the opposite parties in the suit, he requested the Lok Adalat to issue specific directions to the opposite parties to remove the garbage, clear choked drains and maintain hygiene as dengue had acquired an epidemic form in the city. After two years of long hearing of the case, Lok Adalat directed the opposite parties to maintain cleanliness in the city and do regular fogging and sprinkle pesticides in order to control dengue. The complainant-advocate had filed an execution in the court of district judge Kanpur Nagar who transferred the petition to the court of civil judge senior division. The then civil judge had dismissed the execution. Following current dengue menace in the city, the advocate moved an application in the court of the civil judge for review of its old order. The court issued notices to the opposite parties and fixed November 6 as the date of hearing. The court has sought the report of the ‘munsarim’ (reader report) and summoned the original file of the case, said the complainant-advocate. Kanpur Municipal Corporation (KMC) stated in its written submission that it was working hard and taking all necessary measures to control dengue in the city in compliance of the court order and therefore the review application be dismissed. Following the objections filed by the complainant against the defendant’s plea, the court while fixing November 13 as the next date of hearing.

column2: Man gets 7-year jail for bid to kill brother
column3: KANPUR: Additional district and sessions judge of Kanpur Nagar, Pawan Kumar Srivastava, on Thursday convicted one Budhu Singh for committing attempt to murder of his brother and punished him with 10 years rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs 15,000. The presiding judge in his order also observed that Rs 10,000 from the fine amount be given to the victim as damages. On the point of sentence, the defence counsel pleaded that the accused belonged to a low income group and is the only earning member of his family. Therefore, a lenient view should be adopted. On the other hand, the prosecution urged for maximum punishment as the accused had attempted to kill his brother. However, the judge observed there were not adequate grounds for maximum punishment. The period which accused had spent in the jail would be adjusted in the punishment period. According to additional district government counsel Pradeep Kumar Sahu, complainant of the case was Deepa Singh, wife of Narendra Singh, a resident of Deepapur village under Narwal police station who presently resides in Kanpur. Deepa stated that on May 21, 2016 she along with her husband Narendra Singh had gone to Deepapur to let out agricultural land. Budhu Singh, brother of Narendra Singh, strongly objected and soon the matter turned into a tiff. Annoyed Budhu Singh opened fire from a country-made pistol with an intention to kill him. The bullet hit his left palm and fingers and plunged into abdomen. An injured Narendra was admitted in LLR hospital for treatment.

column2: Man killed in dispute over tying buffalo in vacant plot
column3: KANPUR: A farmer was beaten to death on Thursday morning allegedly by his neighbour and his three aides, following a dispute over tying of buffalo in a vacant plot near their house in Chaubeypur area of the district. Hari Babu, a resident of Wajidpur area under the limits of Chaubeypur police station of the district used to grow vegetables and sell them in nearby markets. “As per his family members, they had an old dispute with their neighbour Pardeep Rathore over tying of buffalo at a vacant plot near their house. Earlier also on several occasions the two groups had clashed with each other over the same issue,” said a police officer. He added, early on Thursday morning, while Hari Babu was on way to nearby market on a motorcycle to sell vegetables, he was brutally attacked with ‘lathis’ allegedly by his neighbour Pradeep Rathore and his three aides. All the accused fled after the crime, said police. On being informed, police rushed to the spot and admitted unconscious Hari Babu with serious injuries to Lala Lajpat Rai hospital, where he succumbed to wounds later. Police shifted the body to mortuary for postmortem examination. Heavy deployment of police has been made in the village following the incident to avoid any kind of backlash. The accused are absconding, said Inspector Chaubeypur Rakesh Maurya, adding that an FIR under relevant sections of Indian Penal Code has been lodged against Pradeep and three others. “In the complaint, Hari Babu’s family members accused Pradeep and his aides of killing him over tying of a cattle at a vacant plot. Police teams have been formed to nab Pradeep and his aides. Investigations are continuing,” Maurya added.

column2: 2 contractors fined for violating NGT norms
column3: KANPUR: Two contractors were fined for violating rules and regulations of National Green Tribunal Act on Wednesday. Municipal commissioner Akshay Tripathi imposed a fine of Rs 50,000 against them. The contractors were of PWD and railway.According to Municipal corporation sources municipal commissioner make a visit of city on Wednesday and observed that building material was lying on the road at two places. In the first incident he found that bricks were piled on the road near a nursing home on Nine number crossing and Chapera pulia. On enquiry zonal Engineer apprised him that M/s Infra Built Ltd a contactor firm of Railway had placed those bricks for construction .Annoyed municipal commissioner ordered to impose a fine of Rs 50,000 from contractor and realize that. Thereafter he observed that Railway contractor was constructing railway boundary wall without covering the area . Tripathi in a swift action directed to zonal engineer to impose a fine of Rs 50,000 on contractor for violation of NGT rules. Meanwhile Kanpur Municipal corporation on the basis of whatsap and messages imposed a fine of Rs 8100 against four persons for burning the garbage in open air and realized the fine amount from them.

column2: Five shops gutted in major fire on Musanagar road
column3: KANPUR: Five shops were gutted in a major fire in Ghatampur area on Musanagar road on Wednesday night. Property worth lakhs was destroyed in the blaze. Locals said the fire was spotted around 3 am at roadside shops and in no time, goods and furniture inside the shops were reduced to ashes. “We came out and found five shops in area near Community Health Centre on Musanagar road were on fire,” said Anees Ahmed who owns a tailoring shop and a local resident. Several fire tenders rushed to the spot and with the help of local residents who had already started pouring buckets of water on the fire, they manage to douse the blaze after nearly two hours. Anees further said on late Wednesday night, he was woken up by a powerful cylinder blast alerting him about the mishap. “I came rushing to the spot. I tried to bring out some of the items but in vain. I saw my entire shop burn right in front of my eyes,” said he. Police said, the area consisted of tailoring shop, hair cutting salon, auto-parts, paan masala and gas welding shops. “We are probing into the origin of fire. It looks like fire originated following a short circuit,” said Ghatampur police station incharge.

column2: Get secy probed in UPPCL scam: Minister to Yogi
column3: LUCKNOW: Energy minister Shrikant Sharma has writen to CM Yogi Adityanath, demanding a CBI probe against UPPCL chairman Alok Kumar, who’s also principal secretary, energy, for his alleged complicity in the Rs 2,268-crore provident fund investment scam. The minister sent the letter on Tuesday, demanding a probe into the role of the entire UPPCL brass. No action has been taken yet against Alok Kumar a week after the scam came into the open. In his letter, accessed by TOI, the energy minister lamented that when Alok Kumar ordered an inquiry into the scam in August, he (Sharma) was not kept in the loop. He also said he was kept in the dark when the bureaucrat, who was also director, finance, allowed transfer of funds to the tainted firm, DHFL. Sharma also questioned the lack of periodic meetings of office-bearers of UP Power Employees Trust in the last 30 months, when they should have been held every quarter.

column2: Mayawati mulls withdrawing 1995 guest house case against Mulayam Singh Yadav
column3: LUCKNOW: Despite snapping ties with Samajwadi Party at the close of 2019 Lok Sabha polls, BSP chief Mayawati is learnt to have told party members that she is considering withdrawing cases filed against SP patriarch Mulayam Singh Yadav in the infamous 1995 State Guest House incident. Sources in BSP said, Mayawati made this revelation during a meeting with party workers in Lucknow on Wednesday. "While addressing the simmering discontent among cadre over calling off the alliance with SP, Mayawati told partymen that she may appear strong-headed, but she in fact made several concessions for SP. She recalled Akhilesh Yadav's request to her to withdraw the 24-year-old case against his father in the run-up to the Lok Sabha polls. She said she had asked party's Rajya Sabha MP Satish Mishra to look into the matter," said a BSP member. The Guest House incident has been a sore point with Mayawati and she would often raise the issue during her alliance with SP. When the alliance was announced, she said the tie-up took place "despite" the Guest House incident and elaborated that Akhilesh was not in politics when it happened. In 1995, when Mayawati threatened to end her alliance with SP, which meant unseating Mulayam Singh from the CM's post, scores of SP workers gheraoed the State Guest House on Meera Bai Marg, where Mayawati was closeted in a meeting. Mayawati had to lock herself in a room to escape the wrath of SP workers and she later alleged they were trying to kill her. Then BJP MLA Brahma Dutt Dwivedi had rescued her, she claimed.

column2: Ayodhya verdict: 24x7 control rooms, two choppers on standby, DMs put on night shift
column3: LUCKNOW: Chief minister Yogi Adityanath reviewed law and order in the state ahead of the Ayodhya verdict likely to be delivered next week and directed all senior officers to stay overnight in their respective districts and ensure no untoward incident takes place. CM Yogi interacted with police officials and district magistrates via video conferencing on Thursday night and told them to review security of all religious sites, ensure flag march, foot patrolling are carried out routinely and establish connect with communities and groups while keeping a close watch on social media groups to identify mischief makers. The CM said that one control room should be established in each district and be functional 24x7. He ordered that a helicopter each be kept on standby in Ayodhya and Lucknow. Along with holding peace committee meetings, police and district officials should establish contact with various sects, religious leaders, intellectuals, social workers, the CM said. UP DGP, chief secretary, home secretary and other senior officials were also present in the meeting. “While the Ayodhya verdict is expected, festivals like Kartik Purnima, Barawafat and Prakash Parv are coming up and CM wanted to ensure peace in the state. Major stress was on security arrangements for Ayodhya verdict while security for the festivals was discussed,” said a government spokesperson. The CM asked officials to ensure Barawafat processions are peaceful and festivals do not become a shield for unlawful behaviour and directed them to have a traffic plan in place before hand along with a proper route chart. He also asked police to ensure that trade and community establishments are properly secured and told officials to ensure Dial-112 is working properly. CM Yogi especially mentioned that rumour mongering, especially on social media, be checked immediately and action initiated against anyone making hate speeches or inciting violence. Asking to shift all homeless people to night shelters, the CM said that footpaths, roads, platforms, crossing should be secured. Identify of those accessing night shelters should also be checked. While reviewing Indo-Nepal border security, the CM said movement of all illegal immigrants should be stopped immediately and officials should monitor electronic media and internet. A senior official said, the CM has asked for special security measures to be put in place in Ayodhya, where the panchkosi parikrama is under way and lakhs of devotees are expected to arrive on November 11 and 12 to celebrate Kartik Purnima. “In case there is heavy traffic on the routes in and out of Ayodhya, police should set up barricades,” he said.

column2: Ayodhya verdict effect: Mahotsava to be held in January
column3: LUCKNOW: People of Lucknow are in for a disappointment this year as the much awaited Lucknow Mahotsava will not be held this November. The district administration has deferred the cultural extravaganza to January. The decision was announced by district magistrate Abhishek Prakash in a meeting with Lucknow Mahotsava committee on Thursday. The step was taken keeping in mind the Ayodhya verdict, which is expected any day before November 17. All resources and manpower have been deployed to maintain law and order ahead of the verdict. Hence, the administration would not be able to spare officers and police personnel required for management and security of Mahotsava. “The 10-day event has been postponed from November 25 to the third week of January. A number of events were lined up as part of the festival. We will reconsider the schedule and the theme for 2020,” said Anupam Srivastava, secretary of Lucknow Mahotsava Committee. He added that as a result now, the city will see two Lucknow Mahotsavas next year—one in January and the other on regular dates in November. “We will organise Mahotsava again in November 2020, as per the traditional dates from November 25 to December 5,” he added. In 2017 too, Lucknow Mahotsava was deferred to January because of municipal elections in November.

column2: Ghaziabad: Cop who swindled Rs 70 lakh from thieves surrenders in court
column3: GHAZIABAD: A former SHO of Loni police station, who had been evading arrest for allegedly pocketing Rs 70 lakh recovered from thieves, surrendered before a Meerut court on Thursday. Laxmi Singh Chauhan was with constable Dheeraj Bhardwaj, also an accused in the case. Both were remanded in 14 days’ judicial custody. Inspector Chauhan and six other cops — Maharajpur chowki in-charge Naveen Kumar Pachauri and constables Bachchu Singh, Faraz Khan, Dheeraj, Saurabh Sharma and Sachin Kumar — had been booked under the Prevention of Corruption Act and IPC Section 409 (criminal breach of trust by public servant) for allegedly siphoning off over Rs 70 lakh. A reward of Rs 25,000 was recently announced on her arrest. In April this year, CMS Info Systems Ltd had registered an FIR against some of its employees for stealing money that was meant to be feeded in to 20 ATMs across the city. Chauhan, who was investigating the case, had arrested Rajeev Sachan, part of the team that was to load the cash, and Aamir, another accused, on September 24. Records filed by the SHO and her associates showed they had managed to seize Rs 45.8 lakh. When the Sahibabad circle officer questioned Chauhan and her colleagues, it turned out that they had actually recovered Rs 60 lakh from Aamir and Rs 55 lakh from Rajeev. The difference between what the records showed and the actual money seized was about Rs 70 lakh. On Thursday, Chauhan declined to talk to the media, saying she would speak in court. Police said they would appeal for her custody in court.

column2: Lucknow pollution levels rebound, brace for ‘toxic’ weekend
column3: LUCKNOW: Pollution level in the city increased by around 30 units on Thursday after a day’s relief. Lucknow was the third most polluted city in the country with Air Quality Index at 366 (very poor). Track the pollution level in your cityOn Wednesday, it was after a week that the city’s AQI had dropped below 350. Before that it had been upwards of 400, in the ‘severe’ category for four consecutive days from November 2-5. Pollution levels have been increasing in the city since October-end and reached an all-time high on November 4 with AQI of 435. “This increasing trend will continue, turning the air worse by Sunday as the climatic conditions are favourable for a spike in concentration of pollutants. Low temperatures, wind velocity and high humidity will deteriorate the air quality,” said Prof Dhruvsen Singh, director of the weather and pollution monitoring cell at Lucknow University. According to live air monitoring conducted by the Central Pollution Control Board, the values in all four localities of Lucknow—Gomtinagar, Lalbagh, Talkatora and Aliganj—were recorded above 300 in the morning and evening hours.

column2: Lucknow and Kanpur third most polluted cities in country
column3: LUCKNOW: Air quality in UP cities deteriorated again on Thursday, with Moradabad recording the highest pollution level in the country at Air Quality Index (AQI) of 435. Lucknow and Kanpur continued to be equally polluted with AQI 336, sharing the third place in the list of the most polluted cities of the country. Track the pollution level in your cityThis was for the third consecutive day that the two UP cities took the top slots on the list. Pollution levels in four UP cities shifted to ‘very poor’ from ‘poor’ category with their AQI. These were: Baghpat (352), Noida (328), Ghaziabad (325) and Greater Noida (318).
