Quick Response teams (QRT) comprising central and district police have also been made to keep vigil around .

column2: Yogi Adityanath calls emergency meet, UP-Nepal border sealed
column3: LUCKNOW: As the Supreme Court registrar announced that the much-awaited verdict on the Ayodhya issue in its list for Saturday, UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath convened an unscheduled emergency meeting of his core team to review the state's preparations, with the verdict coinciding with the large-scale congregation of pilgrims in Ayodhya for Panchkosi Parikrama. Yogi summoned additional chief secretary Awanish Awasthi late on Friday night along with director general of police OP Singh, acting chief secretary RK Tewari and other top officers dealing with law and order, intelligence bureau, state intelligence and other key departments. Immediately after the meeting lasting for over an hour, Awasthi told TOI that apart from Section 144 imposed all over the state, the UP-Nepal border has been sealed and no one without proper identity would be allowed to move along the sensitive border. Live updates: SC verdict on Ayodhya caseAwasthi said that railway forces have been directed to take safety and security of railway passengers inside trains and railway stations. Complete coverage: Ayodhya verdictSpecial security arrangements have been made for pilgrims in Ayodhya and more buses deployed around the temple town if anyone wanted to go back to their home, the government buses would be available. In yet another major decision Awasthi said social media has been put under scanner and nearly 70 persons have already been booked in the last few days and anyone posting communal stuff to vitiate the atmosphere would not be spared. Yogi called over a dozen commissioners to take direct feedback of the ground situation and also issue necessary directives.

column2: AQI dips, but Lucknow still breathes 'very poor' air
column3: LUCKNOW: Lucknow was the fourth most polluted city in the country on Friday according to the data released by the Central Pollution Control Board. Air quality continued to be 'very poor' for the second consecutive day with AQI at 342. A fall in pollution level by 24 units compared to Thursday did not bring any relief from poor air. Track the pollution level in your cityCPCB conducted live air quality monitoring at four locations: Talkatora, Lalbagh, Gomtinagar and Aliganj. PM2.5 concentration was found to be more than four times the permissible limit. With PM2.5 concentration of 295 micrograms per cubic metre of air, Talkatora had the worst air quality. This was followed by Aliganj, Lalbagh, Gomtinagar with concentration of 267, 265 and 186.5g/m3, respectively. Pollution level has been rising in the city since October-end. It reached an all-time high on November 4 with AQI at 435. Environmentalist Venkatesh Dutta said, "The situation will remain the same until immediate measures are not taken to control pollution. Favourable weather conditions like low temperatures, wind velocity and high humidity will make the situation worse in the coming days."

column2: Ghaziabad bans sale of loose petrol, acid ahead of Ayodhya verdict
column3: GHAZIABAD: Ahead of the Ayodhya verdict, Ghaziabad administration has banned the sale of loose petrol, acid and other inflammable substances. The administration has already imposed Section 144 of the IPC in the district and set up a round-the-clock monitoring station. Earlier, a high-level meeting chaired by Meerut divisional commissioner Anita Meshram took place, where IG Meerut zone, district magistrate and others officials were present. “We have already imposed Section 144 of the IPC, which bars any kind of assembly in the district. We have now banned the sale of loose petrol, acid and inflammable substances. Anyone found to be in violation of the rule would immediately invite action under suitable sections of the IPC,” said an official from the administration. “A 24x7 monitoring station under ADM finance has been set up in the collectorate and officials have been deputed to monitor the situation,” he added. “Objectionable content, in form of videos and messages on social networking sites, will be monitored. We urge residents not to send or forward any such content. A harsh punishment would be meted out to anyone found to be indulging in it,” he said. Meerut divisional commissioner Anita Meshram has directed officials to keep a tab on religious places, gaushalas and some other communally sensitive places in the district. “We have also sought support from prominent residents from different communities to help us create an amiable environment in the district,” said the official. The district magistrate, meanwhile, has divided the district into ten zones for monitoring. In the zones, 10 super zonal magistrates, 16 zonal magistrates and 58 sector magistrates have been ordered to ensure peace.

column2: Ghaziabad: Protests after student dies in crash
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 20-year-old student was killed and two others were injured when the auto-rickshaw they were travelling in had a head-on collision with a roadways bus in Masuri area on Thursday. On Friday, the student’s relatives, friends and some students from his college held a protest and blocked NH9 in Masuri demanding that the administration built a foot over bridge or an underpass in the area. More than 50 people have been booked. Police said the deceased, Gaurav Singhal, a third-year BCA student at Sunder Deep College in Ghaziabad, was from Bulandshahr. “He was going to his house in Masuri area when he met with the accident,” a police officer said. Gaurav’s brother Vipul told TOI that around 1.30pm on Thursday, Gaurav took an auto from the college gate. “Around 2 pm, I got a call from one of his friends and he told me Gaurav was injured in an accident. We reached the hospital where Gaurav’s friend and police had taken him. There, the doctors asked us to take him to another hospital. We took him to Sarvodaya hospital but the doctors declared him dead at 10pm,” he said. “Accidents have become a regular thing on the stretch and no one is ready to take responsibility. The traffic police and other authorities are not taking any steps. We blocked the highway for over three hours and demanded justice for Gaurav,” said a student who took part in the protest. Naresh Kumar Singh, SHO, Masuri police station, said the driver of bus has been arrested and the bus seized. “An FIR has been lodged against the driver under IPC sections 279 (rash driving), 338 (causing grievous hurt by act of endangering life), 427 (mischief causing damage to the amount of Rs 50) and 304 A (causing death by negligence),” he added. “We’ve booked around 50 people, including students, under Section 147 (rioting) of IPC and under relevant sections of the National Highways Act,” Singh said. A police officer said: “Police are trying to identify the students who were involved in the protest and action would be taken against them soon.”

column2: Ghaziabad: Duo broke into 50 flats in six months, held
column3: GHAZIABAD: Two men were arrested on Friday for allegedly breaking into houses in several societies. Police said the two men had broken into at least 50 houses in the city over the past six months and decamped with jewellery, cash and electronic items. Police claimed that with their arrest, they have solved over a dozen theft cases in Ghaziabad. The arrested men include Kamil, the gang leader from Sambhar town in Jaipur, and Rajesh Dubey, a resident of Delhi. Four others are absconding. On October 7, they had stolen cash and jewellery worth Rs 40 lakh from a businessman’s house. Police claimed to have recovered jewellery worth Rs 20 lakh and Rs 5 lakh cash from the two. Umesh Bahadur Singh, the SHO of Sihani Gate police station, said, “We had leads from CCTV footage in one of the crime scenes in which the two were seen scouting the houses. They would stroll in societies and if guards stopped them, they would tell fake names. They broke into locked houses within 20-25 minutes where they would only steal items like cash, jewellery, watches, etc. that were easier to carry in their bags,” said Singh, adding that they would also carry weapons along with them, but never used them in any of the theft cases. The SHO said that the case has thrown light on the lapses in security of highrises and the police department will issue an advisory to residents welfare associations (RWAs) and apartment owners associations (AOAs) to strengthen the security in order to avoid such cases.

column2: Litigants: Don't see the Ayodhya ruling as victory or defeat
column3: Lucknow: On the eve of the verdict, both Hindu and Muslim litigants in the Ayodhya title suit reiterated on Friday they will accept the SC verdict and expressed hope peace will prevail in the country. "My happiness knows no bound since I heard the judgment would be pronounced on Saturday morning. Whatever the court decides will be welcome. Whoever is born in India will accept the apex court's decision," said Mahant Dhinendra Das of the Nirmohi Akhara, which is a party in the case. Ayodhya verdict: An unprecedented move by judges"We will welcome the verdict whichever way it goes," said chairperson of UP Sunni Central Waqf Board, Zufar Farooqui. Live updates: SC verdict on Ayodhya caseTriloki Nath Pandey, who represents Ram Lalla Virajman (Friend of Lord Ram) in the court, told TOI: "We had been waiting for this day and kept tab on news on the case." He added: "We were expecting the verdict around November 14-15, but are happy that it would be pronounced on November 9." Ayodhya case: Meet the five judges who pronounced judgment todayIqbal Ansari, son of the oldest litigant from the Muslim side, Late Hashim Ansari, shared the same sentiment. "News of the SC verdict on Saturday is welcome. Whatever is decided by the apex court will be accepted by all parties and all people. We are not scared of anything. We will stay at home and follow the verdict in detail since morning." Complete coverage: Ayodhya verdictIn 2010, the Allahabad high court had divided 2.77 acres of the disputed land into three parts, with Nirmohi Akhara, Ram Lalla Virajman and the UP Sunni Central Waqf Board each getting the right to one-third of the land. The three sides then challenged the high court order in the SC.

column2: Some fun time for these fuchchas in Lucknow
column3: A fresher's party at a private girls’ college was nothing less than fun and frolic for these girls. The highlight of the event was the fashion show where the freshers walked the ramp in saris. Bagging the title of Miss Fresher from the Under Graduate team was Pankhudi while Archana won the title from among the PG students. By Saad Abbasi Anam Jahan and Jyoti Pandey (R) Archana Verma (BCCL/ Vishu Jaiswal) Anam Jahan and Jyoti Pandey (R) Archana Verma (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Deepti Joshi (R) Seema Khan and Tanu Bora (BCCL/ Vishu Jaiswal) Deepti Joshi (R) Seema Khan and Tanu Bora (BCCL/ Vishu Jaiswal) Pankhuri Shukla (R) Faizi Yunus (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Pankhuri Shukla (R) Faizi Yunus (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Zainab Khan (L) and Amber Zabeen (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Zainab Khan (L) and Amber Zabeen (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Dr K Bazmi Yunus (L) and AS Khan (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Dr K Bazmi Yunus (L) and AS Khan (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

column2: Ayodhya verdict: Lucknow chooses to remain home, stays glued to television, cellphones
column3: LUCKNOW: City streets and markets wore a deserted look on Saturday as people preferred to stay indoors during the day apprehending law and order problem in view of Supreme Court verdict in Ayodhya case. Curfew-like situation prevailed in Aashiana, Daliganj, Sitapur road, Aliganj and Gomtinagar where people remained glued to television sets and phones for news. Though the state administration ordered closure of schools and colleges till Monday, very few people visited city malls or market during day hours. The number of metro riders also plummeted with 45,000 commuters on board as compared to average daily footfall of 75,000. Many shops remained closed in areas like Alambagh, Hazratganj, Chowk and Aminabad, while vegetable prices went up during the day. Mohammad Salim, a wholesaler at Ahibaranpur, said: “After news broke out last night that the Supreme Court will pronounce its judgment today, many people indulged in panic buying as they felt they would face cash crunch and won’t be able to visit the market due to heightened security. Onion prices went up from Rs 80 to Rs 100 per kg while tomato price doubled to Rs 120 per kg.” (Inputs from Shagun Verma and Akshata Mishra)

column2: Every Indian considers Ram an ancestor: Yogi Adityanath
column3: LUCKNOW: Reacting to the Supreme Court verdict on the Ayodhya issue, chief minister Yogi Adityanath said that he has complete faith that a grand temple dedicated to Lord Ram will be built at his birthplace. He welcomed the verdict, saying that a 492-year-old dispute had been ended in a peaceful manner, strengthening India’s democracy. In a blog on his official portal, Yogi wrote, “Due to political interests, some outfits had, under a conspiracy, turned Ayodhya into a very sensitive issue. However, Ayodhya was solely a matter of faith. Everyone Indian who believes in a supreme power, irrespective of their faith, considers Ram to be their ancestor.” The CM added that this verdict was not about anybody’s victory or defeat but just the reiteration of truth and justice. Addressing himself as a yogi and an ascetic, he wrote, “An ascetic’s life is dedicated to the welfare of the people. From a political perspective, I have adopted a nationalist ideology and followed the policy of development. When I took over as CM of UP, the situation of Ayodhya, which had become untouchable because of narrow politics over the years, pricked my heart. I took an oath to bring back Ayodhya’s glory and develop Ram Janmabhoomi on priority. That is why we started Deepotsav.” Ram has been a central figure in the religious and cultural diversity of India, the CM wrote, adding that he was reminded of his ‘guru’ Mahant Avaidyanath, who had played an important role in the Ramjanmabhoomi movement. “He used to say that Lord Ram’s virtues of justice, equality, discipline and sacrifice should be the ideals for every political leader,” wrote Yogi, adding that he was following the same. Earlier in the day, addressing the media, he had said, the (proposed) Ram temple would be a “national temple” which will spread the fame of India to all corners of this world. “It will also fulfil Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s determination to make India ‘Ek Bharat, Shreshta Bharat’”, he had said.

column2: ‘Gorakshpeeth epicentre of temple movement’
column3: LUCKNOW: Even though senior BJP leaders refrained from taking any credit for the success of Ram temple movement, the party pointed out that Gorakshpeeth has had deep links with Ramjanmabhoomi movement and CM Yogi Adityanath, the peethadheeshwar and head priest of Gorakhnath Temple, visited the temple town 18 times in last two-and-a-half years. The party pointed out that Samajwadi Party president Akhilesh Yadav was CM from 2012 to 2017 but he did not visit Ram Lalla even once. “Since 1992, when the disputed structure was brought down, all leaders refrained from visiting Ram Lalla. Mulayam Singh Yadav, Mayawati, Rahul Gandhi and Priyanka Gandhi Vadra never visited Ram Lalla,” said a BJP functionary. Sources in Gorakhnath Math said all major events related to Ramjanmabhoomi movement have had some link or with Gorakshpeeth. “The agitation itself started under the leadership of Mahant Digvijay Nath. On the intervening night of December 22-23, 1949, when idol of Ram Lalla appeared at the site, then Mahant Digvijay Nath was singing bhajans with other seers,” claimed a source. Digvijay Nath was appointed Hindu Mahasabha general secretary and won election from Gorakhpur Lok Sabha seat in 1967, he added. Subsequently, in 1986 when then Faizabad DM gave orders to open the locks of the disputed site to allow Hindus to offer prayers there, Mahant Avaidyanath was present at the site to open the lock. Thereafter, under the leadership of Avaidyanath, Gorakhnath Temple became the centre of the Ramjanmabhoomi agitation, he said. “And now, when the apex court order has cleared the way for the construction of Ram temple, Yogi Adityanath, the current Mahant of temple, is the chief minister of UP. He became associated with the movement soon after taking over the reins of Gorakshpeeth. Now, when the judgment has come, he is the chief minister and the task of getting the temple constructed will rest on his shoulders,” he said.

column2: Uttar Pradesh: 37 held for inflammatory posts & triggering panic after verdict
column3: LUCKNOW: As many as 37 people were arrested over Friday and Saturday in UP over incidents related to the SC verdict on Ayodhya. Crimes included posting inflammatory comments, creating panic by giving wrong information to UP 112 and “celebrating” the verdict. Seven people were arrested in three separate incidents of minor law and order issues in Meerut alone. Two were arrested in GB Nagar, followed by one each in Lucknow, Sitapur, Gorakhpur, Banda, Hathras, Lakhimpur Kheri, Kasganj, Fatehpur, Kaushambi, Bareilly, Moradabad, Muzaffarnagar and Shamli. Many others were detained. In Lucknow, Ramesh Pal (25) of Rakabganj was arrested for circulating a message about the formation of Ram temple after the verdict. The arrest was made under charges of spreading enmity between two groups and deliberate and malicious act intended to outrage against a religion or class. In Sitapur, Pushpendra (30), under Kamplapur police station, was arrested for making an objectionable post on Facebook. In Gorakhpur, Shakeel (32) was arrested for posting an objectionable audio. He also operated a WhatsApp group known as ‘Power Junction’. In GB Nagar, Amit Jani of Nav Nirman Sena was arrested for bursting fire crackers while Deepak Chaudhary was arrested for giving wrong information about gathering of a group to UP 112. UP Police’s social media cell also reported 2,426 posts on Twitter, 865 on Facebook and 69 videos on YouTube. In 17 cases, UP 112 dispatched a police response vehicle to address a complaint but found that it was a hoax call. As a result, preventive action was taken against callers.

column2: Ayodhya verdict: Sunni, Shia waqf boards won’t file review plea
column3: LUCKNOW: The UP Sunni Waqf Board, a key litigant in the Ayodhya case, welcomed the Supreme Court’s verdict and said it will not file a review or curative petition. The Shia Central Waqf Board, another party in the case, also hailed the judgment, but said the five acres allocated to the Sunni board should have been given to it. However, the Shia board clarified it would not go in for an appeal. The Sunni board’s chairman Zufar Faruqi said, “Any statement in this regard by an individual, lawyer or organisation which mentions that UP Sunni Central Waqf Board will go for a review is not our line.” Faruqi was referring to the reaction of Sunni board counsel Zafaryab Jilani earlier in the day, saying the verdict has contradictions. “We will seek a review,” Jilani had said. But he later clarified that he had reacted as AIMPLB secretary and not as the Sunni board counsel. Faruqi said Muslim outfits, in general, had agreed earlier that they would welcome whatever verdict SC pronounced. However, Shia board chief Wasim Rizvi questioned the granting of land to Sunni board, saying Babri Masjid was built by Mir Baqi, a Shia.

column2: ‘Hats off to all the people who are part of the Bigg Boss house’ Tinaa Dattaa
column3: Tinaa Dattaa in Lucknow (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Yashi Agarwal Actress Tinaa Dattaa, who started her acting career from the age of 5 in the Bengali film 'Chokher Bali' along with Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, and gained fame with her television stint in the serial 'Uttaran', was in Lucknow recently. In a freewheeling chat with us, Tina spoke at length about her love for Lucknow, her television and filmy career, and more.  “Lucknow is such a beautiful city, I absolutely love it. One of the major reasons for loving this city so much is food. I’m a hardcore foodie and Lucknow offers the best biryani and mutton keema parantha. Dastarkhwan happens to be one of my favourite places in the city with mouth-watering food. Also, I like shopping and the chikankari work here is so beautiful. There’s nothing like a chikan sari or a suit or a kurta, they’re all just so pretty. She adds, “Every time I’m in Lucknow I go to Seva Chikan and purchase so many suits and saris that I land up getting overloaded with luggage while flying back to Mumbai.”  Tinaa’s first project was a Bengali serial called 'Sister Nivedita' starring Moon Moon Sen but due to some reason it didn’t take off. “I did a lot of work in the Bengali industry at the start of my career. It’s fun being a part of your own regional cinema. And now, of late, Bengali movies have been doing outstandingly well at the Box Office. Right from the way they are shot to the concept, its mind-blowing. If given an opportunity, I’d love to be a part of Bengali films.” Tinaa seems very happy with the way things have lined up for her, specially her career as she managed to try out various types of roles and didn’t stick to one character. Speaking about the same, Tinaa says, “I don’t think you can plan your career move specially when you’re doing a daily soap. You never know about the time frame of a television serial. You’re so committed to your own show that you can’t exactly plan ahead as you don’t know how long the show will get aired. The show can run for a year, six years, some shows have been going on for more than eight years now. So its uncertain. As for me, I’m very happy with the way my career has shaped up. I wanted to do something different after 'Uttaran' and so I worked in a mythological show after which I did a non-fiction series. So I guess it’s safe to say that I did manage to experiment. Currently, also I’m looking forward to a different kind of role, say a negative character onscreen or something like that.” Rumour mills were abuzz with reports that Tinaa would be entering the Bigg Boss house this year, hearing which the actress has a good laugh. “This rumour was everywhere. I don’t mind being a part of 'Bigg Boss' sometime later but not as of now. I don’t think I’m in the right frame of mind to enter that house. You need to have immense patience and maturity to be able to handle that place considering one’s stranded in a house with 15 different strangers. It’s not easy. Hats off to all the people who are part of the house.” Rumoured to be once married to supervising producer Mahesh Kumar Jaiswal from her debut show 'Koi Aane Ko Hai', the actress says, “I have rubbished these rumours several times before also. There is no truth in my marriage rumours.” So is she looking to get married anytime soon? “I personally feel that there’s a lot of insecurity when you settle down with an actor. Having said that, many actors and actresses have had successful marriages too, but I want someone from outside the industry. I think it’ll be better. I don’t want any ego clashes or insecurity issues marrying someone from the same industry. You see Shilpa Shetty Kundra or Madhuri Dixit Nene, they are so happily married. They settled with people from outside the industry. Even I would love to do something like that.” — Yashi Agarwal

column2: Sunni Waqf Board won't file review plea, Shias follow suit
column3: LUCKNOW: The UP Sunni Waqf Board, a key Muslim litigant, welcomed the Supreme Court judgment on Ayodhya title suit and announced it will not file a review or curative petition against the order. UP Shia Central Waqf Board, another party to the case, also hailed the decision, while stating that the 5 acre land allocated to Sunni Board should have been given to it, but clarified it would not go in for appeal. Welcoming Saturday's verdict, UP Sunni Central Waqf Board chairman, Zufar Faruqi, said if someone else files a review petition, it would not be in Board's name. "Any statement in this regard by an individual, lawyer or organisation which mentions that UP Sunni Central Waqf Board will go for a review is not our line," he said. Faruqi was referring to the reaction of Board's counsel Zafaryab Jilani, saying, "The Ayodhya verdict has contradictions. We will seek a review." Jilani later clarified the press conference was organised by All India Muslim Personal Law Board and he reacted as its secretary and not as counsel for Sunni Waqf Board. Faruqi, however, said Muslim organisations, in general, already agreed to welcome the court order, whatever it may be, and "it won't be right" if they change the stand. He further said the Board had not demanded the 5 acre land granted to it as alternate site for a mosque, but added it "respects the court's decision". "I will be calling a meeting of the Board soon and finalise our stand," said Faruqi. Faruqi also thanked the court for upholding the Places of Worship Act, 1991. "By mentioning it in the judgment, the court has strengthened the Act. We are grateful to them for setting aside as 'erroneous' the 2010 observation of an Allahabad high court judge, which diluted the provision of Places of Worship Act," he said. Shia Central Waqf Board president Wasim Rizvi also welcomed the verdict, saying they were always in favour of a Ram temple at Ramjanmabhoomi, but questioned the granting of 5 acre land to Sunni Waqf Board. He said the Babri Mosque was built by Mir Baqi, who was a Shia. "Instead of giving it to Sunni Waqf Board, the land should have been given to us. However, the Board will not file a review petition. We do not want an alternative site in lieu of an encroachment on temple site. Shia community has several legal mosques," he said.

column2: Ghaziabad: Toddler steps out of home, run over by auto
column3: GHAZIABAD: A one-and-a-half-year-old girl was allegedly crushed to death by an autorickshaw in Vijay Nagar on Friday night. Police said the deceased has been identified as Diya. Her father works as a daily wage labourer. On Friday, when the child’s family was having dinner, Diya somehow managed to get out of the house and she got hit by the auto-rickshaw. Vedprakash, her father told TOI that there was a wedding in the neighbourhood and the auto-rickshaw was carrying tents for the event. “Around 9.30pm, a passerby raised the alarm after seeing the accident and we went outside the house to see what had happened. We took her to a nearby hospital but doctors declared her brought dead,” said the father. Police have sent the body for an autopsy and reports are awaited. Shyamvir Singh, SHO, Vijay Nagar police station, said an FIR has been registered against the auto-rickshaw driver under IPC sections 279 (rash driving), 338 (causing grievous hurt by act of endangering life), 427 (mischief causing damage to the amount of Rs 50) and 304 A (causing death by negligence). Vedprakash said if the driver is not held soon, he will protest outside the SSP office.

column2: Strict vigil in Ghaziabad, posts monitored
column3: GHAZIABAD: The city did not report any unrest or untoward incident on Saturday as vigil was stepped up in the entire district, especially in sensitive areas, in light of the Supreme Court’s verdict on the Ram Janmabhoomi-Babri Masjid title suit. With the administration imposing Section 144 of CrPC late Friday night, more than 5,000 personnel from police, home guard and Provincial Armed Constabulary (PAC) were deployed to ensure there was no breach in peace. Besides, four ‘highly sensitive’ and 58 ‘sensitive’ areas had been identified by police and the sale of loose petrol, acid and other inflammable substances had been banned. As per the state government orders, educational institutions remained closed. A senior police officer said that about a 100 ‘suspicious’ persons, who have been involved in riots and other community fights in the past, are under surveillance. Besides, a team of 50 personnel from the cyber cell also monitored content circulated on social media platforms. Cops said they kept an eye on about 800 accounts for any inflammatory posts. SSP Sudhir Kumar Singh said, “I think Ghaziabad police have managed everything very well. The situation in the district is normal and residents are busy with their day-to-day work.” District magistrate Ajay Shankar Pandey, who visited sensitive areas in the district with the SSP, said, “The day passed off peacefully. We will keep the same level of preparedness for the next few days.” Meanwhile, many stretches in the city wore a deserted look. “There was less traffic because it was the second Saturday (of the month). All government offices and schools were closed,” said an official. City Imam K Z Bukhari said his community had accepted the verdict with grace. “I met many people from my community and was pleasantly surprised that there was no unrest in their minds,” he said, adding, “I am relieved that this contentious issue has reached its logical end and after today, it will no longer be a bone of contention between the two communities.” He added that for in the coming days, similar maturity and vigil would need to be maintained. Mahant Narayan Giri said the Supreme Court decision had been received well by both the communities. “The past is behind us and the matter should cease to exist for the communities as a whole,” he said.

column2: How the Lord fought & won Ayodhya suit
column3: LUCKNOW: With the Supreme Court declaring the makeshift temple’s presiding deity, Ram Lalla Virajman, as owner of the disputed land in Ayodhya, the 70-year-old title suit created legal history on Saturday with the Lord himself being a party to the case and winning it. And it was Ram Lalla’s ‘next friend’ Triloki Nath Pandey, who represented the Lord in court and finally won the protracted battle after the apex court rejected the claims of key litigants, Nirmohi Akhara and Sunni Central Waqf Board. Talking to TOI, 75-year-old Pandey calls it the end of Ram’s second vanavas (exile). “The Lord will now be able to move to a majestic temple from its present tarpaulin abode. It’s the victory of Ram Lalla Virajman, but the best thing is that no one has lost,” he said. Pandey has been pursuing the case in court on Ram Lalla’s behalf since 2010. He was allotted one-third of the disputed site at Ayodhya — sanctum sanctorum — by the Allahabad High Court on September 30 in that year, but he challenged the decision in Supreme Court. Under Indian law, a deity is an individual entity and like a firm or a trust can contest its own case. The deity (Ram Lalla Virajman) is a perpetual minor and needed a ‘next friend’ to represent itself in court. Pandey is the third ‘next friend’ of Ram Lalla. Earlier, retired judge Deoki Nandan Agarwal (1986-1996) and historian Thakur Prasad Verma (1996-2009) represented the infant God in courts. Agarwal, an advocate who later became a judge in Allahabad High Court, was a resident of the Sangam city and later the vice-president of the Vishwa Hindu Parishad (VHP). After retirement, he extensively researched documents and filed a petition in Allahabad High Court in 1989, claiming the land belonged to Ram Lalla and he was his ‘next friend’. The court accepted his petition. He also challenged the status of Nirmohi Akhara in the title suit, but died in April 2002. Agarwal was succeeded by BHU professor Thakur Prasad Verma in court. Later, because of his age and failing health, he withdrew in 2008 and Triloki Nath Pandey, a VHP office-bearer, took over as ‘next friend’ of Ram Lalla. “I am happy that Ram Lalla will finally get his due. I am also happy the decision took place in my lifetime. The verdict is clear and to the point and the bench left no room for any ambiguity. At the same time, it has been able to strike a balance between religious and national interest,” Pandey said. Pandey, however, expressed concern about the possibility of Nirmohi Akhara filing a review petition. “I would urge them to join hands with us and take forward the task of temple construction,” he said.

column2: In peaceful Kashi, namaz and prayers go hand in hand
column3: LUCKNOW: Vitriolic slogans that reverberated in Ayodhya after the Babri Masjid demolition did not find echo 27 years later at Kashi’s disputed site, where the Gyanvapi mosque shares its premises with the Vishwanath temple. The ancient city was visibly calm with Muslims offering afternoon namaaz at Gyanvapi mosque, while thousands of pilgrims, mostly from South India and Maharashtra, queuing up to offer prayers at the adjacent temple amid tight security. The day passed off peacefully in all 10 districts of Varanasi zone, including Azamgarh and Mau. A massive security cover was in place at the Kashi Vishwanath-Gyanvapi complex. ADG Varanasi zone, Brij Bhushan, said security arrangements will continue in coming days. Varanasi DM Kaushal Raj Sharma said there would be no change in schedule of Kashi Ganga Mahotsava and fair, and arrangements have been made for Barawafat, Guru Nanak Jayanti and Dev Deepawali. Though many residents had stocked up groceries and other essentials on Friday in anticipation of a shutdown, markets remained open and everyday activities went on uninterrupted on Saturday.

column2: Ayodhya verdict: BJP on temple run, UP satraps to rethink plan
column3: LUCKNOW: The Supreme Court verdict on Saturday paving the way for the construction of a Ram temple on the disputed site might now have regional parties in UP - Samajwadi party (SP) and Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP) - going back to the drawing board to rethink their strategies ahead of the 2022 Assembly elections even as BJP moves towards the state polls with a clear advantage. The Opposition, mainly SP, will have to fight the effects of acts like jailing the Kanchi Kamakoti Shankaracharya in 1990, when Mulayam Singh Yadav was chief minister, and then the firing on karsevaks in Ayodhya, also under Mulayam's chief ministership. BJP had been taunted by the Opposition in the past for the delay in mandir construction with slogans like "Mandir wahin banayenge, tarikh nahi batayenge (We will build a Ram temple but won't give you a date by when it will be built)" and "Ram Lalla tirpal mein, sare neta maal mein (Ram Lalla lives under a tent, leaders live in comfort)". Now, the Opposition has run out of ammunition on this issue and will have to rethink not only how to plan its own moves ahead of the state elections but also how to counter BJP. The slogan "Modi hai to mumkin hai" will now reverberate stronger, emphasising how "injustice" has been meted out to Hindus for the last 500 years and how the temple dream will finally be fulfilled. Political observers say that BJP and other right-wing groups may be restraining themselves from making a big noise or celebrating for now, but in the heat and dust of elections this issue could help it get traction and take the wind out of the Opposition's sails.

column2: Ayodhya verdict: Love binds transgender Hindus and Muslims
column3: LUCKNOW: While the nation was glued to the television for the verdict, Sandhya Naik was busy teaching her foster son Rizwan how to cook dal. Unfazed by the excitement all around, the mother-son duo prepared lunch for their 15-member family and indulged in chitchat about how they would celebrate the upcoming Gurpurab. Sandhya, 45, is a Hindu Brahmin. Rizwan, 23, is Muslim by birth. But, they are among several members of the transgender community in Alambagh who bond beyond religious boundaries and often under one roof. "We believe in humanity and one god. Ram, Rahim, Waheguru and Jesus are all same for us," said Sandhya. "Those among us who practise Islam know every Hindu ritual while Hindus keep roza every year. We live in harmony. There is no room for discord here," added Rizwan. Sonali, a trans-woman, summed it up: "Our relationship is thicker than blood. If you study all religions in detail, you will find they preach nothing but peace and love."

column2: ATMs across Lucknow run out of cash
column3: LUCKNOW: Several ATMs in the city ran dry on Saturday, courtesy panic withdrawal all through Friday night by people apprehensive of a law and order situation after the Ayodhya verdict. Of the 9,650 ATMs, those in Lalbagh, Mahanagar, Narhi, Aliganj, Niralanagar, Hazratganj, Jankipuram Extension, Gomtinagar, Indiranagar and parts of Old City were dry by morning. Standing outside a closed Aliganj ATM, Gaurav Tandon rued, "Banks won't refill cash on Sunday, which means long queues on Monday."

column2: ‘This time I wish to explore Lucknow more’ Viineet Kumar
column3: Actor Viineet Kumar of 'Mukkabaaz' fame, started shooting for the Lucknow leg of his untitled film, directed by Susi Ganeshan, near Lucknow University from Wednesday. The film, a Hindi remake of a Tamil film 'Tiruttu Payale 2', commenced shooting from Gai ghat in Varanasi last week. The crime thriller has actor Viineet Kumar and Urvashi Rautela, Miss Diva 2015- Miss Universe India, known for films like 'Kaabil' and Great 'Grand Masti', in the main lead. During the three-week schedule in Lucknow, the film will be canned across various locations in the city including old Lucknow. Hailing from Varanasi, Viineet, who has been to the city several times before, and was here last time to shoot for 'Kargil Girl', was feeling nostalgic shooting this time. Reminiscing his days in the city as a basketball player, Viineet, who was last seen in 'Saand Ki Aankh', says, “It always feels good to be back in Lucknow but this time it is more of a nostalgic one.” Director Susi Ganeshan (in red T-shirt) explaining the shot to Viineet (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)  Director Susi Ganeshan (in red T-shirt) explaining the shot to Viineet (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Viineet goes on to add, “I am staying at a famous hotel near Hanuman Setu and when I look out of the window of my room, I can see the KD Singh Babu Stadium and its basketball court where, as a kid, I came and stayed at and alsoplayed the game. At that time, I was told by my player friends that this is the hotel where all the big players stay and it was like a dream back then. Today, life has come a full circle, though a bit differently.” He adds, “I also had the famous mattha outside the stadium. For me, it was like refreshing my memories!” Fans gathered at the shoot location to get themselves clicked with the 'Saand Ki Aankh' actor (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)  Fans gathered at the shoot location to get themselves clicked with the 'Saand Ki Aankh' actor (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Talking about the film, Viineet says, “Not only the 80 percent of the movie is being shot in Lucknow during its three-week schedule here, the story also revolves around the city itself. Most of the scenes are to be canned on roads at various locations in the city." He adds, “This time I wish to explore the city more and also the lajawaab Lakhnawi food!” — Abhishek.Shukla2@timesgroup.com

column2: Ready to give up claim, Sunni board wrote to SC in March
column3: LUCKNOW: The Sunni Central Waqf Board, which was a key litigant in the Ayodhya title suit, had offered a settlement formula to resolve the issue in its letter to Supreme Court in March this year, stating it was ready to relinquish its claim over the disputed site in larger interest of national harmony in lieu of a mosque at an alternative site. TOI is in possession of a copy of the settlement offer, which was sent to the Supreme Court after the mediation process was initiated by the court-appointed Justice Kalifulla-led mediation panel. TOI had reported on October 17 that the panel had informed the SC that the Muslim parties were willing to give up their claim on the disputed site if some conditions were met, including construction of a mosque at an alternative site. Para 5 of the Sunni Central Waqf Board’s settlement offer states, “Sunni Waqf Board, first and main plaintiff, has no objection in relinquishing all rights, interests and claims over the land and is entering into this settlement in larger interest of harmony. The board confirms there’s no bar on acquisition of the land by the central government under Section 51 (1-A of Waqf Act, 1995, or any other law). The board may build a mosque at another suitable place, keeping in view requirements of local Muslims.” Para 14 clearly says, “The court may also consider using the settlement as the foundation for its order and decree under Article 142 of Constitution and do justice by bringing a comprehensive, effective and harmonious end to the dispute.” For relinquishing its claim, the Sunni Waqf Board put riders, including allowing namaz at ASI-controlled mosques.

column2: Mentally ill man ends life after killing wife in Kanpur
column3: KANPUR: A 35-year-old mentally challenged son of a retired BSF inspector bludgeoned his wife to death, critically injured their two minor sons in Pukhrayan town area of Kanpur Dehat district on late Saturday night, and later threw himself in front of a speeding vehicle on the highway. Police identified the deceased as Deepak Yadav, resident of ward no. 17 of Gandhi Nagar locality in Pukhrayan, and his wife Rashmi, 29. The injured sons, Honey and Mayank, are undergoing treatment at Lala Lajpat Rai hospital in Kanpur. The bodies of the man and his wife have been sent for the postmortem examination. “As per Deepak’s father, Ram Bihari, who had retired as an inspector from BSF, his son had joined the merchant navy in 2010, but after serving for two years, he returned to his native place when he developed some psychic illness in 2012”, the police said. “On late Saturday night, while all the family members were asleep, Deepak barged into the room where his wife Rashmi and their two sons were sleeping. He first killed his wife and injured his two minor sons by attacking them repeatedly with an iron rod. Later, he reached the highway and committed suicide by jumping in front of a speeding vehicle,” the police further said. The deceased’s father Ram Bihari reached the highway and came across the badly crushed body of his son lying in a pool of blood. He then informed the police. After a preliminary investigation, it seems that Deepak was depressed and could have taken the extreme step out of mental agony, the police said. ASP Kanpur Dehat, Anup Kumar said that Rashmi died at the spot while Deepak was killed after being run over by a speeding vehicle. Their sons are recuperating at Lala Lajpat Rai hospital in Kanpur, the ASP added.

column2: UP: Children spot two hand grenades at Ganga banks
column3: KANPUR: Some children, who had gone to collect coins offered by devotees in Ganga on Sunday afternoon, stumbled upon two hand grenades in Farrukhabad district. A senior police official said the hand grenades were recovered from the Panchal Ghat at the banks of Ganga in Dheemarpur village under Kotwali police station of the district. “Some children, who had gone to the banks of the river to collect coins, spotted two grenades kept inside a polythene bag and alerted other people, who then informed the police control room,” said Circle Officer (City Kotwali) Manni Lal Gaur. The anti-sabotage squad seized the grenades and handed them over to Kotwali police station. Police suspect that following movement of security forces in the area, some anti-social elements might have dumped the grenades in the river. Police have launched an investigation to track down those involved in dumping the grenades, but no arrests have been made so far. “Search operations are being carried out in the area. We are in the process of diffusing the grenades,” the CO further said.

column2: ‘Nagar Kirtan’ taken out on eve of ‘Prakash Parva’
column3: KANPUR: A grand ‘Nagar Kirtan’ was taken out on the eve of the 550th ‘Prakash Parva’ of Guru Nanak Dev Ji Maharaj in the city on Sunday. Hundreds of Sikh devotees, besides people from other communities, including men, women and children, drawn from different parts of the city, participated in the ‘Nagar Kirtan’ which was welcomed near Sangeet Talkies crossing by Sikh religious leaders. It was organized by various Gurdwara committees of the city. Hundreds of people en route made beelines to pay obeisance to Guru Granth Sahib. Sikh men, attired in Khalsa dress, displaying swords in their hands, led the procession which was followed by ‘Panj Pyaras’ and band parties. School children were reciting ‘Gurbani’ and ‘Bhajans’. Showing utmost respect and honour to Guru Granth Sahib, the Sikh ‘sewadars’ cleaned the road from where the procession had to pass. The devotees and Sikh youths, chanting slogans “Vahe Guru Ji Ka Khalsa Vahe Guru Ji Ki Fateh”, “Jo Bholey So Nihal Sat Sri Akal” en route, played ‘gatka’, displayed martial art and other feats. The district administration had made elaborate security arrangements for the ‘Nagar Kirtan’ which was escorted by a contingent of police and PAC personnel.

column2: Ghaziabad: SHO among three cops booked for taking Rs 14 lakh bribe
column3: GHAZIABAD: The station house officer (SHO) of Indirapuram police station and two sub-inspectors have been suspended for allegedly taking around Rs 14 lakh to release 13 gamblers arrested from a hotel on the intervening night of October 22 and 23. Deepak Sharma, the SHO, Sandeep Singh, the chowki in-charge of Shipra Sun City, and sub-inspector Sachin Kumar of Vaishali outpost were sent to the police lines after an internal inquiry found them guilty of taking bribe. All three are untraceable at the moment. Keshav Kumar Mishra, assistant superintendent of police who conducted the inquiry, said the cops had received a tip-off that gambling was going on in a couple of rooms in hotel Grand Inn in Sector 4 of Vaishali. “Sub-inspectors Sandeep and Sachin conducted raids at the hotel and arrested four persons from rooms 109 and 209. During investigation, it came to light that the cops had pocketed the money that was being used in the gambling and also taken a bribe to let the accused persons go. It was revealed that around Rs 14 lakh had been swindled in the entire case,” Mishra said. The officer further said the involvement of the Indirapuram SHO was also confirmed in the probe. “During the probe, it was revealed that the SHO of Indirapuram police station, Deepak Sharma, had shared a part of the money recovered from the gamblers. The cops had seized Rs 4 lakh from the accused persons and took some money as bribe. A report on the entire case has been sent to the SSP for further probe,” he added. Ghaziabad SSP Sudhir Kumar Singh said the SHO and two other cops are absconding. “They might have sensed that an FIR would be lodged against them. We are yet to trace them, but they would be caught soon,” he added.

column2: Lucknow breathes easy as low temperature pulls AQI down
column3: LUCKNOW: After coughing through pollution for 15 days, the state capital breathed a sigh of relief on Sunday, with the overall Air Quality Index (AQI) improving significantly to 237. However, the air quality was still in the ‘poor’ category, according to the data released by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB). The city’s AQI registered a drop of 77 units compared to Saturday, when air quality index stood at 312. Last time the city recorded a reading below 200 was on October 26 — a day before Diwali — when the AQI was 155. Thereafter, the air quality deteriorated and AQI soared to 435 on November 4, the highest post-monsoon season. For five consecutive days from November 2, the state capital’s air quality remained ‘severe’ before dropping to ‘very poor’ category. Track the pollution level in your city“The pollution level has dropped due to high temperature and low humidity,” said state met director J P Gupta. However, the relief is expected to be short-lived. “The air quality will deteriorate once again as the minimum temperature is expected to drop in coming days, leading to fog and formation of smog in teh city,” Gupta said. According to the live air quality monitoring conducted by the CPCB, PM2.5 concentration in all the four localities monitored in the city was above 200 micrograms per cubic metre of air, around four times higher than the permissible limits of 60 set by the National Ambient Air Quality Standards. (NAAQs). The most polluted location was Talkatora with PM2.5 concentration reaching 257.6. This was followed by Gomtinagar, Lalbagh and Aliganj with pollution levels settling at 227, 216, and 201 respectively.

column2: UP: Tractor rams buffalo, farmer gives chase but gets crushed
column3: LUCKNOW: A 32-year-old man, chasing a tractor-trolley that injured a buffalo belonging to his friend, was killed when the same heavy vehicle knocked him off the bike he was riding pillion on in Maal on Sunday evening. The unnamed driver of the tractor, who is on the run, has been booked for rash driving and causing death by negligence. Deceased Ramesh Kumar was a resident of Gagan Barauli village, on the outskirts of the state capital, and a farmer by profession. He was having dinner at home around 8.30pm, when he overheard an argument between some villagers, including his friend Sarvesh, and the driver of a tractor carrying stubble, police said. Ramesh learnt that the heavy vehicle, returning from a field, had hit and injured a buffalo that belonged to Sarvesh. While the villagers were demanding compensation from the driver, he stepped on the pedal and escaped. Sarvesh gunned the engine of his bike and followed the tractor with Ramesh riding pillion. The two overtook the tractor a little distance away from their village. But, while Sarvesh slowed down in front of the heavy vehicle, it hit his bike from behind. Sarvesh sustained minor injuries, but Ramesh hit his helmet-less head hard on the road. The tractor driver escaped with his vehicle. He was rushed to the community health centre in Maal, but declared brought dead. Sarvesh’s mother Kalavati lodged an FIR, where she categorically mentioned that the tractor-trolley belonged to the husband of the gram pradhan of neighbouring Mannbhauna village. Maal SHO Shailendra Singh said the tractor driver had been booked for rash driving, causing death by negligence, endangering lives of others and damaging a motorcycle. “We are looking for him,” the officer added.

column2: How a two-room memorial school turned into a 225-acre Lucknow University
column3: In the summer of 1862, first viceroy of British India Charles John Canning breathed his last in London. Around 4,500 miles away, a bunch of loyal taluqdars in Awadh decided to donate eight anna (half a rupee) from their annual income to start an academic institution in his memory. Two years later, Canning High School was born. What began as a cradle with 200-odd students in two rooms of a haveli in the narrow lanes of Khayaliganj, Aminabad, is today one of the oldest residential universities of the country. The University of Lucknow, which formally became a varsity in 1920, sprawls over 225 acre in Hasanganj and has over 1.5 lakh students across its campuses and affiliated colleges. As the university steps into its centenary year on November 25, here’s looking back in pride at its interesting genesis. According to a document from 1906, attributed to Mohammed Tasadduqi Khan — the Raja of Jehangirabad Oudh (now Barabanki district), the taluqdars wanted to build a college in honour of Lord Canning on a plot of land in Kaiserbagh that the viceroy had once gifted them. First academic session began in July 1921They managed to open a school (instead) at Aminuddaulah Palace in present-day Aminabad on May 1, 1864. There were 200 students on the rolls till Class X,” historian Yogesh Praveen told TOI. In 1866, the high school was elevated to Canning College. In the early days, the college had no building of its own and had an almost peripatetic existence, shifting from one place to another, including Lal Baradari where Lalit Kala Academy is housed at present. It got a building of its own in Kaiserbagh (currently, Rai Umanath Bali Auditorium and Bhatkhandey Music Institute), but the growing demand for space prompted another relocation. In 1878, Canning College finally had a permanent address in Badshah Bagh, Hasanganj, where it stands even today. The foundation stone of the new building was laid by Sir John Lawrence on November 13, 1867, but it took around 11 years to be ready. The main building was patterned in Indo-Saracenic style with high ceiling and wooden stairways. It was formally inaugurated by Sir George EW Couper, then lieutenant-governor of northwestern provinces and chief commissioner of Oudh on November 15, 1878. Canning College remained a recognised institution under Calcutta University for 20 years from 1867 till it came under the jurisdiction of Allahabad University in 1888. The University of Lucknow Bill was introduced in the Legislative Council on August 12, 1920. It was referred to a select committee that passed it after amendments on October 8, 1920. Canning College was merged with Isabella Thoburn College and King George’s Medical College to form the university. GN Chakravarti, then pro-vice-chancellor of Banaras Hindu University (BHU), was made the first vice-chancellor of University of Lucknow on December 16, 1920. The academic session began in July 1921 and the first convocation was held in October 1922.

column2: ‘Mathura, Kashi not on agenda, temple tribute to martyrs’
column3: LUCKNOW: Senior BJP leader Vinay Katiyar, one of the prominent faces of Ramjanmabhoomi movement, said the construction of a grand Ram temple in Ayodhya would be a tribute to over 3.50 lakh martyrs who laid their lives in the 78 wars fought over the shrine since 1450 when the existing temple was demolished and Babri Masjid built on its ruins. In an exclusive chat with TOI, Katiyar, the founder-president of Bajrang Dal and Hindu Jagran Manch, who was famous for his firebrand speeches, said his dream has almost come true as he had struggled throughout his life to see the Ram temple becoming a reality in Ayodhya. Katiyar, one of the prominent faces of Ram temple movement in the 90s, however, said there was no talk of claiming the disputed shrines in Kashi and Mathura now and he would work with the the Union and state governments as well as the trust that would be formed for construction of Ram temple . When asked to comment on the Supreme Court directing the government to give five acre land for a mosque in Ayodhya, the former member of Parliament, who once said he would not allow construction of a new mosque in Ayodhya, said that since it was an order of the highest court of the land, he would not like to comment on it. Katiyar said he wholeheartedly welcomes the apex court’s decision and would appeal all citizens to take it in good spirit.

column2: PF scam probe: EOW to send notice to senior IAS officer
column3: LUCKNOW: Taking probe ahead into irregularities in investment of UP Power Corporation Limited employees' provident fund in tainted firm Dewan Housing and Finance Corporation Limited (DHFL), UP Police's economic offences wing (EOW) is sending a notice to Union agriculture secretary Sanjay Agarwal, the former chairman of UP Power Corporation Limited (UPPCL), for recording his statement. EOW director general, R P Singh, told TOI on Sunday, "Our probe is under way. We need to take statement of all members of the trust, including an IAS, who was chairman of the trust, when funds were invested in DHFL." "The documents seized from the office at Shakti Bhawan reveal discrepancy on the date of meeting of the trust. The meeting was held on March 22, 2017, but was shown to have taken place on March 24. The meeting note bears signature of all trust members," Singh added. The EOW found that the note that allowed employees' PF money to be invested in triple A rated companies bore signatures of Sanjay Agarwal, then UPPCL MD A P Mishra, general manager finance P K Gupta, director finance Sudhanshu Dwivedi and director personnel and administration, S P Pandey. While Mishra, Gupta and Dwivedi have been arrested, Pandey had died in 2017. According to sources privy to investigation, EOW has also zeroed in on 14 UP-based brokerage firms which initiated contract between UPPCL and DHFL for investment of fund in 2016. A senior EOW official said directors of all these firms would be quizzed. However, when EOW tried to trace the firms, five of them based in Meerut, Ghaziabad and Delhi were found to be non-existent on ground. On Sunday, UPPCL MD AP Mishra was sent to the jail. "From Monday onwards, officials of DHFL and the brokerage firms will be questioned," DG EOW said. EOW is also looking for Abhinav Gupta, son of PK Gupta. Abhinav, who runs a real estate firm, is on the run since his father's arrest. Meanwhile, DHFL issued a statement saying it is committed to return the invested money along with interest to UPPCL power sector employee trust. It claimed to have returned principal amount of Rs 1,864 crore and paid Rs 208 crore in interest on the total Rs 4,132 crore deposit. The firm said it was refunding maturity amount with interest in past, but was forced to stop payments following Mumbai high court order .
