column2: From a banker to an actor, the journey has been an exciting one: Mukul Chadda
column3: Mukul Chadda, who has featured in films like 'Ek Main Aur Ekk Tu', 'I Me Aur Main', among others, was in Lucknow some time back. While on his second visit to Lucknow, this foodie decided to try out the famous delicacies here and further recalled his last visit. He said, "I came to Lucknow for a few days during peak summers once. I went around Hazratganj eating street food. It was fantastic. We had the famous basket chaat and of course biryani and galawati kebabs. It was just so good. We hope to make the best of today as well by trying out other delicacies in the city." Married to Rasika Dugal, ask him if the two discuss work at home and pat comes the reply, "Yes! Since Rasika and I, both are from the same field such discussions are bound to happen. Whenever we are in a dilemma regarding a project, we discuss it with each other." Mukul Chadda in Lucknow (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Mukul Chadda in Lucknow (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Not many know that Mukul is an MBA from IIM Ahmedabad and it was after working in a bank in New York that he decided to take his passion for acting forward. "I wasn’t happy doing what I was doing. Theatre is something I was always inclined towards. Even while in New York I’d take part-time classes at Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute. We did shows and we would rehearse on weekends. I just never thought of it as a career then. When I quit my job and came to India, I took a sabbatical. During my sabbatical I did theatre. The plan was to try it out for a year or two and see what happens next. Karte karte, I did it for longer and after I did a bunch of advertisements and other stuff I realized that it was paying the bills so I could continue doing it. I sort of accidentally stayed on this course and then at some point I realized that I’m a full-time actor now. From a banker to an actor, the journey has been an exciting one!" said Mukul. - Yashi Agarwal

column2: VHP decides to construct Ram temple through crowd-funding
column3: LUCKNOW/NEW DELHI: VHP has decided to seek contributions for the proposed Ram Mandir and has also decided to explore ways to enlist the involvement of Ram bhakts in its construction, potentially setting the stage for yet another mass mobilisation for the Ayodhya temple. “Ram bhakts (devotees) from across the country will be approached for contribution to the construction of the Ram temple. The Ayodhya movement was associated with the faith and sentiments of scores of Hindus and they will have to do their bit, including ‘kar seva’, whenever the project begins,” said Vinod Bansal, national spokesperson of VHP, the Sangh affiliate which spearheaded the campaign for the construction of the temple. “A formal plan will be out soon,” Bansal told TOI. Besides, VHP has decided to suggest that the trust that is to be formed within three months should facilitate the symbolic participation of “bhakts” in the construction of what has been imagined as a “grand Ram temple”. Devotees from all 718 districts of the country will be invited in delegations to stay for at least a week and help in construction work, said the VHP functionary, an indication that another round of “kar seva” could be in the works. “Kar seva”, or voluntary work, formed an important part of the VHP-led “Mandir” movement with lakhs reaching Ayodhya in 1990, and again in 1992, the second round resulting in the demolition of Babri Masjid. VHP functionaries in Delhi confirmed the crowd-funding plan. “There is no ambiguity about the plan that funds will be pooled in directly from Hindu devotees of Lord Ram spread across the globe. The process to seek contributions will start soon for which teams will be constituted to ensure that it is done smoothly,” VHP working president Alok Kumar told TOI. He said VHP has pledged only to use contributions from people for temple construction. VHP’s statements come amid reinforced indications that it will have a significant representation in the temple trust. The Supreme Court had, in its verdict on Saturday, denied any role for VHP-promoted Ramjanmabhoomi Nyas in temple construction. However, sources said the government, which will have the final say in the matter, appears inclined to include in the trust Mahant Nritya Gopal Das, who headed the Nyas, as well as some of the key Hindu seers aligned with VHP. The decision to pool funds is in sync with what Mahatma Gandhi had suggested when he offered his support for the reconstruction of the Somnath temple. Gandhi gave his consent to the move to revive the temple, which had been attacked and plundered repeatedly by invaders, but told the prime movers — Sardar Patel and K M Munshi —that they should not take money from the government. “For a temple dedicated to Lord Ram, funds must come from the public. Taxpayer money should not have any role in the project. We shall start the fund collection once the trust takes over,” Kumar said. “Some people may contribute shilas (sandstone), while others may donate money. We leave everything to people,” he added. VHP sources in Ayodhya said they expect the construction to begin around Makar Sankranti in January or Ram Navami in April next year. “The ball is in the court of the government which has to take a call on the issue,” said a senior VHP functionary. VHP functionaries said enlisting popular support for the construction of the temple will be a respectful gesture to the devotees, who have waited “generations” to see it happen. “We shall urge the trust to allow the visit of delegations from each district of the country to hand out a brick for the construction,” Kumar said. He said over 60% of the temple has already been carved but construction will start after complying with the norms. “We have to abide by the norm as the temple will be dedicated to ‘Maryada Purushottam’.”

column2: Kanpur: One arrested for farmer’s murder
column3: KANPUR: Police on Monday arrested one person in connection with the murder of a farmer, who was beaten to death on November 7 morning allegedly by his neighbour and his three aides following a dispute over tying of a buffalo at a vacant plot near their house in Chaubeypur area of the district. The deceased Hari Babu, a resident of the Wajidpur area under Chaubeypur police station of the district, used to grow vegetables and sell them in the nearby market. Police have identified the accused as Pratap, a resident Wajidpur. Confessing his crime, he told the police that he had an old dispute with his neighbour Hari Babu over tying of buffalo at a vacant plot near their house. He said as a result of the dispute he had attacked Hari Babu with a wooden log on the morning of November 7 while he was on way to the nearby market on a motorcycle to sell vegetables. Following the attack, Hari Babu succumbed to injuries at Lala Lajpat Rai hospital, said station house officer Chaubeypur Rakesh Kumar Maurya. “Pratap, who was arrested from his house on Monday has been booked under relevant sections, including section 304 of IPC and sent to jail, the SHO added.

column2: Lawyer, policeman injured in clash in Kanpur
column3: KANPUR: An advocate and a policeman got injured after two groups clashed in the Shivli area of Kalyanpur in the city on late Sunday night. The clash took place allegedly over a road rage incident in which the car of Prateesh Mishra, advocate, was hit by the mobile car of Kalyanpur police station. As per the advocate, the policeman, who was on the wheels of the mobile car, had abused and manhandled him. Later, people from the advocate side joined the fight. The policeman too sought police help by dialing the control room following which a police team was rushed to the spot to control the situation, but it deteriorated further and more police force was requisitioned. The injured advocate and the constable were taken to a hospital and police force deployed in the area and the hospital. “We have recorded their statements and brought the two vehicles to the police station. However, we have not yet received complaint from the two sides. Security measures in the area have been stepped up to normalise the situation. Investigations are on in this regard,” said inspector Kalyanpur Ashwini Pandey.

column2: Ordnance factory employee’s body found hanging from tree
column3: KANPUR: A 44-year-old employee of the Ordnance factory, who had been missing from his house since Saturday, was found hanging from a tree in the premises of the factory in Armapur, on Monday. The deceased, Ravi Shankar, native of neighbouring Khaga town in Fatehpur district, was employed as an engraver at the Ordnance factory Armapur. He used to live with his wife Puja and two children at residential block of the factory in Armapur Estate. Police said that as per Ravi’s wife, he left the house on Saturday and went missing thereafter. Puja then apprised her family members following which they launched a search. Ravi Shankar was found hanging from a tree in the factory premises on Monday morning, said the police. Later, a police team from Armapur police station along with forensic experts reached the campus for further probe. The body was sent to mortuary. Circle officer, Nazirabad, Gitanjali Singh, said, “No external injuries were found on the body and no suicide note has been recovered from the spot. As per the investigations, it seems to be a suicide. However, we aer waiting for autopsy report to ascertain the cause of death."

column2: Kanpur: Seven-year rigorous imprisonment to man for attempt to murder
column3: KANPUR: Additional district and sessions judge (I) Kanpur Nagar Mohd Riyaz on Monday convicted accused Gaurav Pratap Singh under section 307 of IPC (attempt to murder) and sentenced him to seven years rigorous imprisonment along with a fine of Rs. 10,000. The judge in his order observed that out of the fine amount a sum of Rs 8,000 would be given to Pankaj who had suffered injury when the accused fired at him. According to additional district government counsel (ADGC) Rajendra Prasad Uttam, Pankaj had some dispute with Gaurav Pratap Singh and Honey Bhatia which led to heated arguments and scuffle at HAL gate at around 9 pm on April 11, 2010. Honey, Shivam Kataria and Gaurav thrashed Navneet and Pankaj and while they were trying to escape, Honey opened fire injuring Pankaj on his shoulder. Later, Pankaj lodged a report with the Chakeri police, the prosecution told the court. Since Shivam and Honey were minors their file was separated and they are being tried in the juvenile justice board, the ADGC said.

column2: Kanpur decked up for 550th birth anniversary of Guru Nanak
column3: KANPUR: Beautifully decked up city is set to celebrate the 550th birth anniversary of Guru Nanak Devji Maharaj on Tuesday. 'Langars' would be held at all Gurudwaras in the city. A large number of people had gathered to prepare a grand 'langar' to be held at the Motijheel where people of all faiths would relish it after paying obeisance to Guru Granth Sahib. All prominent city crossings have been decorated with lights as this year the Sikh community is celebrating the 550th birth anniversary of Guru Nanak Devji. Sikh religious leaders have requested the people to reach Motijheel in large numbers to get served with 'Langar Parshad' and seek blessings of the Guru. A 'Kirtan' held at Motijheel on Monday continued till late night where hundreds of devouts paid obeisance to Guru Granth Sahib. Around 80 tableaux were part of the 'Nagar Kirtan' (procession) taken out on Sunday. Men, women and children participated in the event. The festivities which commenced on Sunday would continue till Tuesday. Members of the Sikh community will keep their establishments closed on Sunday.

column2: Inflammatory social media posts: Arrest count now 93 in UP
column3: LUCKNOW: Altogether 16 persons were arrested across the state on Monday for trying to vitiate communal harmony on social media through objectionable posts, taking the total number of such arrests to 93 since the Ayodhya verdict on Saturday. The arrests have been made for objectionable posts on WhatsApp, Twitter, Facebook and Instagram, and giving wrong information to UP 112, police said. Four persons were arrested in Hardoi, two in Bijnore, one each in Sitapur, Rae Bareili, Shamli, Kaushambi, Banda, Ambedkarnagar, Bareilly, Banda, Noida and Mainpuri. In Hardoi, one Yogesh Mishra was arrested under the charges of spreading enmity between groups, whereas Shahid Husain of Bilgram was arrested under charges of spreading enmity and deliberate and malicious act intending outrage against a religion or class. Two others — Amit Srivastava and Mohammed Sayyed — were arrested from Shahabad and Behta on charges of spreading enmity and malicious act intended to outrage a specific class. They all had posted content on Facebook. Similarly, in Sitapur a person identified as Shibu Kumar, who worked as a teacher, was arrested for posting inflammatory content on Twitter in Mehmoodabad police station area. UP Police’s social media cell also reported 2,555 inflammatory posts on social media taking the count to 10,000 in the last three days.

column2: Kalyan Singh to visit Ayodhya soon, says dream fulfilled
column3: LUCKNOW: Former UP chief minister and an accused in Babri mosque demolition case, Kalyan Singh, on Monday said Ram Temple in Ayodhya was not a political issue, but was intrinsically linked to the country’s cultural tenets. Kalyan was speaking to reporters, two days after Supreme Court verdict on Ayodhya. “I am a Ram Bhakt and have been dreaming about the temple for decades. I will soon go to Ayodhya,’’ said Kalyan, under whose regime the Babri mosque was demolished by a frenzied mob of karsewaks in 1992. Singh said the apex court judgment should not be seen as a victory or loss for anyone. “The government will form a trust which will build a grand temple,’’ he said. Kalyan said the construction of a Ram Temple will pave way for further development of the temple town. “It’s time Ayodhya’s development is put on fast track and chief minister Yogi Adityanath is committed to this.” Responding to a query on the Babri demolition chargesheet against him and other senior BJP leaders, Singh it was for the CBI to answer. “As many as 39 witnesses have been examined. Now, the investigation agency will take it forward,’’ he said. In September, CBI moved high court to prosecute Kalyan Singh after his gubernatorial term in Rajasthan ended. Singh, enjoyed immunity from trial while he held the constitutional post.

column2: Ayodhya verdict: AIMPLB meet on November 17 to decide on review plea
column3: LUCKNOW: All India Muslim Personal Law Board (AIMPLB) on Monday said it will take a decision on filing a petition in Supreme Court seeking review of the Ayodhya verdict, after its working committee meeting next week. The board called a special meeting of all 51 working committee members, including Hyderabad MP Asaduddin Owaisi at Lucknow’s Darul Uloom Nadwatul Ulama on November 17. AIMPLB officials said it will also decide on which of the other five Muslim litigants can file the review plea, if the board decides to embark on that path. According to the board, an umbrella body of all Muslim sects, the Sunni Central Waqf Board is only “one part” of the Muslim side in the case. The waqf board has already clarified it won’t review the verdict. “The AIMPLB decided in its last meeting on October 12 that it will meet after the SC verdict to discuss the judgment at length and decide the way forward, both legally and practically. The legal committee, Jamiat Ulama-e-Hind and Jamaat-e-Islami will participate in the meeting,” said board spokesperson and secretary, Maulana Khalid Saifullah Rahmani. Counsel in the title suit and convener of AIMPLB’s Babri Masjid Action Committee, Zafaryab Jilani, said, the Sunni Waqf Board is only a part of the Muslim side, opening a window for other litigants to seek review of the verdict, if such a decision is taken. “This can be done through litigants, Jamiat Ulama-e-Hind, Iqbal Ansari, Mohammad Umar, Misbahuddin and Maulana Fazlur Rahman. Defendants in the case Haji Mahboob and two sons of Haji Abdul Ahad and Maulana Hazbullah can also be approached,” he said. Though AIMPLB is not a party in the case, it has been providing financial and legal assistance to litigants. “It will also be explored if AIMPLB can file a review petition,” Jilani added. “I won’t agree to filing a review if asked. For 70 years, we kept providing documents to court, but faith won over facts. The review will also bear the same result so what is the point,” said litigant Iqbal Ansari.

column2: Golden advice from a General: Failure is a challenge, accept it
column3: LUCKNOW: General Bipin Rawat, the Chief of Army Staff and chief guest at Babasaheb Bhimrao Ambedkar University’s (BBAU) eighth convocation, wore a poet’s hat on Monday to teach students how to deal with failures. “Asafalta ek chunauti hai, Isko sweekar karo tum, Kahan khamiya reh gayi, Inpar vichar karo tum, Mehnat aur lagan ke saath aagey badhey chalo, Phir kabhi peechhey mat dekho, Aur har nayi choti pe parcham leharaye chalo, leharaye chalo (Failure is a challenge, accept it; reflect on your shortcomings and move ahead; Never look back),” Rawat read out these lines from a poem that he said inspired him during tough times. Deviating from the usual practice of asking politicians or academics to grace its degree day, BBAU this year invited the army chief. The spirit of nationalism peaked as soon as he entered the convocation hall. Students shouted, ‘Jai hind, Sir; Bharat Mata ki jai’ and saluted him. General Rawat returned the gesture. “The presence of the man who commands the Indian Army was inspiring. The poem was a bonus. We will now remember this day not for the gold medal we won, but for the golden advice he gave,” said MSc (Zoology) topper Astha Singh. As many as 1,626 students were conferred degrees on Monday and 251 from 2017-18 and 2018-19 batches received gold medals.

column2: Gold medallist violates dress code, barred at convocation
column3: LUCKNOW: A 2018-batch Dalit student, who topped in MA (Sociology) and was to be conferred three gold medals, was not allowed to attend the convocation at BBAU on Monday for violating the dress code. BBAU’s alleged high-handedness against Kranti Kumar — currently pursuing his MPhil at JNU — coincided with a clash between JNU students and police in Delhi following a protest over a host of issues, including dress code. Kumar arrived at the venue in formal wear instead of the mandatory kurta-pyjama. He wanted to advocate for freedom of choice and pay a tribute to Ambdedkar who always dressed in formal clothes on special occasions. The alumnus was seated among gold medallists in the front rows at the convocation, which was attended by Chief of Army Staff General Bipin Rawat. He said he was first asked to leave by a faculty member and later forcibly removed from the venue by police. He was allegedly detained at the proctor’s office till the end of the function. “I am not a criminal and yet was kept under detention (at the proctor’s office) for around six hours. This despite me requesting the vice-chancellor (Sanjay Singh) and others to allow me to wear formal clothes in a tribute to Ambedkar and for an individual’s freedom of choice,” said Kumar who hails from Andhra Pradesh. “India thrives in its diversity. Imposing dress code on students is unfair. I am more comfortable in formal wear. I had sought prior permission for myself and for those underprivileged students who cannot afford the convocation ensemble,” he said, adding that the vice-chancellor didn’t reply to his request. BBAU officials denied allegations of harassment and high-handedness, stating that they only followed rules. “The convocation dress code is cleared by the academic council. Hence, it is binding on all students. We did not allow on stage any student who was not following the dress code,” spokesperson Rachna Gangwar said. She denied that Kumar was detained at the proctor’s office.

column2: In a first, Lucknow University registrar gets additional charge as VC
column3: LUCKNOW: Registrar of Lucknow University SK Shukla was given additional charge as its vice-chancellor on Monday because the governor, who is also the chancellor of state varsities, failed to find a suitable successor to incumbent SP Singh whose three-year term ended on the same day. “The term of current VC... expired on November 11 (Monday) and appointment of a regular incumbent is taking some time... Using the power given to chancellor under Section 12 (10) of the UP State Universities Act, 1973, I have directed the registrar, SK Shukla, to discharge additional responsibility of VC for next six months or till further orders,” Governor Anandiben Patel said in her order. This is the first time that a registrar, who is a Provincial Civil Services officer, has been given additional charge in the absence of a regular vice-chancellor. Some senior teachers objected to the appointment, saying the post was academic and the registrar was only the head of the clerical unit. They said the tradition was to appoint a teacher — pro-VC or senior-most professor — to the chair. Raj Bhawan officials, however, insisted that under the said section of the Act, the chancellor could appoint a suitable person to the vice-chancellor’s office for a term not exceeding six months. These special circumstances include the situation “when a vacancy in the office occurs, and cannot be conveniently and expeditiously filled in accordance with norms”. A section of teachers contested the claim, citing Section 12 (11) of the Act. It states that if there is no regular VC, the pro-VC will discharge duties and in case there is no pro-VC, then the senior-most professor will be given charge. Raj Bhawan officials countered the argument. They said the role of pro-VC or senior-most professor came into play only in two scenarios. One, if the chancellor is not able to appoint any suitable person, regular or acting, to the post. Two, if the said person is not able to assume office within stipulated time.

column2: UP Cabinet sets madrassa funds code, scraps Buddha project
column3: LUCKNOW: In the first meeting after the Ayodhya judgment, the Cabinet on Monday approved the expenditure burden under new guidelines of the Madrassa Modernization Scheme. As per this, the Centre will contribute 60% of the funds while the remaining 40% will be borne by the state government. The scheme has been renamed as the Scheme for Providing Education in Madrassa. There are 7,442 madrassas identified under the scheme and the total cost of running them will be Rs 213 crore. In another important decision, the cabinet approved cancellation of an MoU between the government and the Maitreya Trust, which was entrusted with development of projects under the Integrated Buddha Circuit in Kushinagar. A government spokesperson said that even though the agreement was signed in 2003 and land was allocated in 2014, the trust did not even start work till 2017. DM Kushinagar, A K Singh said the MoU was signed when Mulayam Singh Yadav was the chief minister of the state. “It was signed in 2003 and amended in 2014 under the Akhilesh Yadav government. In 2014, 195- acre land was made available to the trust by cultural department. However, the trust did not carry out any work till 2017,” said an official. The Cabinet also cleared Uttar Pradesh Municipality Rules -2019 and an amendment to the State University Act, 1973, for setting up of the Raja Mahendra Pratap Singh State University in Aligarh. Under the new Uttar Pradesh Municipality Rules-2019, tax was collected in municipality and nagar panchayat under municipal corporation bylaws. The two bodies will now have separate rules, draft for which will be released in a month. It proposes to divide properties under four classes, which will be further divided into 12 categories. The Cabinet also approved the awarding of the 765 KV transmission line in Meerut and 400 KV transmission line at Sindhauli to Power Grid Corporation of India for a proposal of Rs 115 crore. The work will be completed by 2021. Power Grid has also been awarded work for 765 KV and 400 KV transmission lines at Rampur and Sambhal. Besides, the Cabinet cleared an amendment to the State University Act, 1973, for setting up of the Raja Mahendra Pratap Singh State University in Aligarh. E-stamp rules have also been revised and now, stamps of a value of more than Rs 15,000 can also be sold.

column2: Crowdfunding for 57 years gave birth to elite Lucknow varsity
column3: LUCKNOW: Long before the term ‘crowdfunding’ became popular in the early 21st century, the practice of funding a project by raising small amounts of money from a large number of people was witnessed during the establishment of a school that graduated into a college and then became a university of indisputable repute. In 1864, voluntary deduction of eight anna (half a rupee) from the annual income of taluqdars gave birth to Canning High School in Aminabad. It took 57 more years of generous donation of cash, land and even war bonds (debt securities issued by a government to finance military operations and other expenditure in times of war) to turn the two-room school into the first campus of University of Lucknow (LU). Dated March 21, 1921, the minutes of the first annual meeting of LU court gives a detailed account of how funding was rustled up. In our e-age parlance, how the varsity came into being through ‘crowdfunding’. “The total sum promised in subscription up to 19th March, 1921, as reported by the Commissioner of Lucknow and the secretary of Lucknow University funds committee amounts to Rs 29,60,459, inclusive of the two donations announced by His Excellency, The Governor, at the ceremony of the laying of the foundation stone. Of this sum, Rs 1,70,225 has been received in war bonds,” the minutes read. This oldest surviving LU document further states: “Cash collections up to date (March 19) amount to Rs 12.88 lakh… Of this, Rs 2.43 lakh has been placed in a fixed deposit. The balance is either in the Imperial Bank or in the district treasuries.” The statement of finance was issued by LU’s first honorary treasurer EAH Blunt. The fascinating story of ‘crowdfunding’ even before the term’s etymological origin also unfolds in the first journal of LU published in September 1922. It says the idea of starting a university was mooted by Raja Sir Mohammad Ali Khan, Khan Bahadur, Knight Commander (KCIE) of Mahmudabad, who contributed an article to The Pioneer, urging the foundation of the University of Lucknow. In 1919, governor of United Provinces Sir Harcourt Spencer Butler played catalyst and proposed the funding scheme for the new varsity. A general meeting of the British Indian Association in connection with the proposed university was held in Kaiserbagh on February 4, 1920. It was announced that an advance of nearly Rs 11 lakh for the establishment of LU had been pooled in. The sum included contributions from the Maharaja of Balarampur (Rs 3 lakh), Raja of Mahmudabad (Rs 1 lakh), Raja of Jehangirabad (Rs 1 lakh), Rani of Mahomadi (Rs 1 lakh), Raja of Utranla (Rs 1.10 lakh) and Sir Harman Singh (Rs 50,000). All those who made donations of Rs 25,000 and above were made lifetime members of the LU court, says the journal. Sir Butler appealed for another Rs 50 lakh. The event was covered by esteemed national dailies. According to newspaper reports on February 6, 1920, the taluqdars expressed their gratefulness to Butler for accepting their request to establish “a university for the benefit of the people of Oudh”.

column2: UP: Bricks with ‘Sri Ram’ inscriptions to form foundation of Ram temple
column3: LUCKNOW: Over 2 lakh bricks (shilas) inscribed with ‘Sri Ram’ in various languages collected over three decades from across country, will form the foundation of the Ram Temple at Ayodhya, according to VHP’s janmabhoomi blueprint. The bricks, which carry sentimental value, will also be used to erect a memorial wall to cement the contribution of those involved in the Ram temple movement. Chief architect of the temple whose grandfather was also involved in renovation of Gujarat’s Somnath temple, Chandrakantbhai Sompura told TOI the foundation will be laid with the bricks. “The shilas will be used for the foundation and cemented and a marble chaukath will be placed on it,” Sompura told TOI from Ahmedabad. The bricks which carry inscriptions of Lord Ram in various languages, including Gujarati, Bengali, Tamil, Telugu and other languages were collected from villages and homes across India in 1989. Some bricks were sent from as far as Canada and China too. ‘In 1989, over 50,000 bricks used in shilanyas on Rajiv Gandhi’s nod’For 30 years, the bricks have being laying at VHP’s temple workshop in Ayodhya in the shape of a temple, symbolising the proposed Ram temple and is revered by pilgrims. “In 1989, when the Central government decided that the ‘shilanyas’ (foundation ceremony) will be undertaken 25-30 feet away from the janmasthan, VHP members collected bricks from across the country,” said VHP Avadhprant chief, Sharad Sharma. “At least 2.75 lakh bricks were workshop in trucks. On Nobrought to the VHP temple vember 9, 1989, on the day of shilanyas, around 50,000 shilas were used in the ceremony. The remaining 2.25 lakh bricks will be ploughed into the temple’s foundation and erecting a memorial,” Sharma told TOI. The ceremony was performed with permission of then Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and a 10-foot long and 12-foot wide floor was built with 50,000 bricks. The ground-breaking ceremony was attended by Ashok Singhal, Acharya Giriraj Kishore, Paramhans Ram Chandra Das, Mahant Nritya Gopal Das and Mahant Avaidnath.

column2: Lucknow: Liquor smuggler held for harassing girl, attacking dad
column3: LUCKNOW: A 27-year-old youth with links to liquor mafia was arrested on Monday for allegedly harassing, stalking and bullying a woman and roughing up her father in Sarojininagar. The accused, Shivam Awasthi, was arrested almost a week after the girl’s father filed a complaint last Monday. In an FIR lodged on November 6, the girl’s father alleged that Awasthi used to stalk his daughter whenever she stepped out of home. “She told me about his antics, so I escorted her when she went out on November 6. However, when he saw me he was not bothered. He came close to my daughter and started taking her pictures. When I intervened, he roughed me up. When passersby tried to intervene, he fled from the spot. We then decided to approach the police,” said the complainant. He also said that Awasthi has been stalking his daughter since the past one month. “Initially, she ignored his advances thinking that he would eventually give up if she didn’t entertain him. However, her disinterest only encouraged Shivam. He became possessive of her and often used to click her photographs whenever she went out,” the girl’s father said. He also said that the girl was so frustrated that she stopped going out. Station house officer of Sarojininagar police station Pramendra Kumar Singh said Shivam was arrested under charges of voyeurism, outraging modesty of a woman, criminal intimidation and provoke breach of peace.

column2: Lucknow: Six lakh diyas to add to Dev Deepawali radiance
column3: LUCKNOW: Days after Lord Ram's hometown Ayodhya glowed from the lights of 4.1 lakh diyas during Deepotsav, it's time for 'Lakshmanpuri' to get lit up. Lucknow would celebrate Dev Deepawali, to be observed on Tuesday, by lighting 6 lakh oil lamps on the banks of Gomti at Mankameshwar ghat. Dev Deepawali is celebrated on Kartik Purnima. Traditionally celebrated in Varanasi, Mankameshwar temple will be leading the initiative with help from school and college students. Over 5,000 diyas will also be lit at Kudiya Ghat. "Of the six lakh diyas, four lakh will be donated by devotees and rest by school and college students. We are not trying to create a record with the event like the one created during Deepotsav. We will light these earthen lamps as part of Kartik Purnima or Dev Deepawali celebrations. The celebrations will be followed by the traditional Gomti aarti," said head priest of Mankameshwar temple Mahant Divyagiri. Around 3,000 devotees and volunteers are expected to attend the celebrations at Mankameshwar Ghat, where every individual will have to light 100 oil lamps. "Apart from the new ones, we'll also be using recycled earthen lamps which were lit up during Diwali. Last year, we lit three lakh diyas," the priestess said.

column2: Lucknow: Speeding truck hits bike, kills 22-year-old
column3: LUCKNOW: Reckless driving by a truck driver claimed the life of a 22-year-old man in Chinhat on Monday. Station house officer, Chinhat, Sachin Singh said Vivek of Kanpur Dehat was going on a two-wheeler with his friend Surya (23), who was riding pillion, when their vehicle was hit by a speeding truck in Kapda Koti area in Chinhat around 4.45pm. Passersby managed to stop the truck and handed over the driver to the police. The SHO said Vivek was in the city in search of a job and was staying in a locality on Dewa Road with his friend Surya. "Vivek's identity was ascertained on the basis of his Aadhaar card which was recovered by the police. Vivek's family has been informed about the incident," he said. The duo were rushed to RML Hospital where Vivek was declared brought dead while Surya is undergoing treatment.

column3: LUCKNOW: Reckless driving by a truck driver claimed the life of a 22-year-old man in Chinhat on Monday. column2: Ghaziabad: Man stabs wife to death, tries to kill self
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 25-year-old man allegedly stabbed his wife to death and then attempted suicide by injuring himself with the same knife in Kotwali’s Balupura area on Monday afternoon. The injured couple was taken to MMG District hospital by locals where doctors declared the woman dead and referred the man to GTB hospital in Delhi. Police said the case was found to be related to dowry harassment. The woman Pooja (23) was a resident of Kallpura area. She married Vikas, an auto-rickshaw driver and a resident of Gukhna, on December 14, 2015, said police. Pooja’s father Surendra Kumar, an e-rickshaw driver, alleged that soon after the marriage, Vikas started demanding a motorcycle and Rs 30,000 from him and when he could not fulfil his demands, the latter started torturing his daughter. “Vikas quarrelled a lot with Pooja over dowry. When the dispute between them increased, I complained about it in the arbitration cell in October 2016. However, soon after that he and Pooja reached a compromise and decided to live away from his parents. On their request, I arranged a rented accommodation for them in Balupura. For the past 18 months till around Raksha Bandhan this year, they had been living together,” said Pooja’s father, adding that after Vikas again started demanding dowry, his daughter started living with her family. Fed up of her husband’s behaviour, she finally filed a divorce case at a local court on October 9, said Kumar. The grieving father disclosed that after the court hearing in the case on Monday Pooja’s lawyer had suggested her to collect her belongings from Vikas’s house for which she had went to Balupura along with her father Omvati. However, as soon as Pooja entered the room, Vikas closed the door, shutting out Omvati. He then stabbed Pooja on her shoulder, waist and throat around 10-15 times before stabbing himself in the stomach and throat with the same knife, said police. Hearing Pooja’s cries Omvati shouted for help after which locals gathered outside the room. The owner of the building, where Vikas lived along with other tenants, then broke opened the door and found the couple lying in a pool of blood. “An FIR will soon be lodged in the case,” said the SHO of Kotwali, Laxman Singh.

column2: Name new mosque after Kalam, not Babar: VHP
column3: LUCKNOW: Functionaries of the Vishwa Hindu Parishad (VHP) on Monday said they want BJP president and Union home minister Amit Shah as a member of the trust that will decide on the planning and construction of the Ram temple. VHP also said it would request the Centre to not allow the new mosque-which is to be built on a 5-acre alternative land-to be named Babri Masjid after Babar.  "Babar was an aakranta (attacker) from a foreign country. We will approach the government to not allow this. There are a lot of good Muslims in India. Their contributions to India's peace and development are huge...such as Vir Abdul Hamid, Ashfaqullah Khan and former President APJ Abdul Kalam. The new mosque should be named after any of them," said VHP spokesperson Sharad Sharma, who looks after the Ram Janmabhoomi Nyas karyashala, where engraved stones for the Ram temple have been kept. One of the Muslim petitioners, meanwhile, said naming the mosque was not important. The primary issue was of consensus on whether or not to accept the land for the mosque.  " Masjid koi Babar ki mohtaaj nahi. Babar ek baadshah tha. (A mosque doesn't depend on any ruler or his popularity)," said Iqbal Ansari, one of the lead petitioners in the title suit case. "The land is yet to be acquired and there will be a meeting (of the Sunni Waqf Board) on this. I can certainly assure this country that we will live with Hindus without any fuss and with dignity. We will not allow peace to be disturbed," said Ansari.

column2: Babri demolition anniversary will be a closed-door affair this time for VHP
column3: LUCKNOW: For the first time in 27 years, the anniversary of the Babri Masjid demolition on December 6 will be a low-key affair for the Vishwa Hindu Parishad. The Sangh outfit has been observing the anniversary as “Shaurya Diwas” and organises yagnas and special prayers for the Ram temple every year. It also pays tributes to kar sevaks who were killed in police firing in 1990 during the then Mulayam Singh Yadav regime. However, VHP has changed its plans in the wake of Supreme Court’s verdict on Ayodhya. “This time, all programmes will be a closed-door affair and there won’t be any public display,” VHP national general secretary Milind Parande told TOI. VHP had suspended all programmes and training camps ahead of the SC verdict, and all activities will remain suspended till further orders from the central leadership. “Despite the SC ruling in favour of a Ram temple, we have been instructed not to celebrate and maintain communal harmony,” VHP’s Awadh prant general secretary Bholendra said. Sources in VHP said it will not mount pressure on the government for the formation of a trust for the construction of the Ram temple. “The ball is now in the Centre’s court. It has to decide when the trust would be formed and when the construction of Ram temple would start,” said a senior VHP functionary.

column2: Muslim community mulls rejecting offer of alternative site for mosque in Ayodhya
column3: NEW DELHI: With prominent voices joining in, a view is gaining ground within the Muslim community that it should not accept land for building a new mosque anywhere else in Ayodhya. In order to articulate the sentiments of its members and the community, the All India Muslim Personal Law Board will on Sunday spell out its view on the offer of 5 acres of land for a new mosque as per the Supreme Court judgement in the Ram Mandir- Babri Masjid case. The Board at a special meeting of its working committee on Sunday in Lucknow will also decide whether it is in favour of filing a review petition against the judgement or not. While the AIMPLB meeting is being seen among Muslim organisations as critical to put forth a public statement, the fact remains that the decision whether or not to accept the land is going to be the prerogative of the UP Central Sunni Waqf Board. UPCSWB on the day of the judgement issued a statement welcoming the SC verdict and made it cleat that it was not going to file a review petition. UPCSWB was also one of the petitioners in the case. However, the community voices over the way forward have started growing with Jamiat Ulama -i- Hind president Arshad Madani saying, “While it is up to the UPCSWB to take the land or not in my view they should not take it. The reason is that the case was about Babri Masjid and that it existed on the site that was under dispute. It was never about seeking an alternate site. We don’t need five acres land like a compensation. We have lost the case and we accept the top court’s verdict with dignity. However, building a mosque elsewhere does not make any sense to me,” Madani said. A prominent member of the All India Muslim Personal Law Board, Kamal Faruqui, said, “There is a sentiment within the community that the land should not be accepted. I also feel if a new mosque is built at an alternate site it will be a reminder of Babri Masjid and the associated developments ever since it was demolished. Therefore a new mosque should not be built at an alternate site.” Jamaat -e- Islami Hind national secretary Malik Mohtashim Khan too said that there was a sentiment within the community that 5 acres of land should not be accepted by those at the helm of affairs.

column2: A raja’s idea to bridge religious gap shaped Lucknow University
column3: LUCKNOW: Among the many inspirations behind setting up of LU was one more beautiful than the others. At a time when divisions based on religion were creeping into Indian society, the idea of Lucknow University was thought of to promote communal amity. This led to the Ganga-Jamuni tehzeeb of Lucknow later playing a significant role in Hindu-Muslim unity during the freedom struggle. It was in 1920 that then Raja of Mahmudabad thought of establishing a university free of communal affiliations. By that time, the Muhammadan Anglo-Oriental College in Aligarh had been transformed into Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) for imparting education to Muslims youth while before that, in 1916, the Banaras Hindu University (BHU) had been established in Varanasi. “My grandfather Raja Sir Mohammad Ali Mohammad Khan (Khan Bahadur, KCIE) of Mahmudabad was the founding vice-chancellor of AMU. However, after serving for some time, he became disillusioned with the concept of having educational institutions on communal names and affiliations. A Muslim university was being run by one system, while a Hindu university had its own set-up. This division, he felt, would later reflect in Indian society. He realised that the university should be a place of equality in opportunities. It gave rise to a desire for an institution free from cultural or religious influences,” said 75-year-old Raja Amir Mohammad Amir Khan, a descendant of Raja of Mahmudabad, narrating how LU was born. ‘Raja Saheb’ then decided to moot the idea of a university in the heart of the state—Lucknow, as it was known for its Ganga-Jamuni tehzeeb—where students from all faiths and cultures could get quality education under one roof. With this thought, the Raja contributed an article to a prominent daily newspaper, urging the foundation of a university at Lucknow. The request by him also finds a mention in the first journal of Lucknow University published in 1922. Khan then approached his friend Sir Spencer Harcourt Butler, the first governor of United Provinces of Agra and Oudh, to establish a university in Lucknow, the de facto capital of the United Provinces. The idea simultaneously also got support from other taluqdars of the region and together, they all laid the foundation of LU. “The idea of promoting Muslim and Hindu cultures together also found reflection in the efforts of Raja Saheb and Taluqdar friends in courses at LU. They ensured Persian, Arabic and Sanskrit courses under one roof at LU. This allowed students from humble backgrounds or those not from an English-speaking school to get an opportunity to attain higher education in their own language,” he said.

column2: UP: Path lab issues wrong dengue report, health department cancels licence
column3: LUCKNOW: Health department on Tuesday cancelled the registration of a private pathology in Keshavnagar for issuing false dengue positive reports. The action came after a health department team conducted surprise inspection and found that though the reports given by the pathology mentioned that dengue test was done through ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay), no equipment used for the test was present in the lab. The staff was also found to be unaware of how to use ELISA method for testing samples. The four-member team headed by pathologist Dr Rajesh conducted inspection at around 5 pm after finding discrepancies in dengue positive reports issued by the pathology. “The anomalies in the reports were detected during an audit of patients who died due to dengue in the city. The pathology had issued dengue positive report to a 34-year-old woman who recently died due to high fever,” said Dr KP Tripathi, in charge of vector-borne disease control unit. Chief medical officer Narendra Agarwal said, “An FIR will be lodged against the pathology for endangering public health as the centre may have issued fake reports to other patients as well. If a report is incorrect, it may lead to wrong treatment and death of a patient.”

column2: 70 years on, Jat king who gave land for AMU gets university in his name
column3: LUCKNOW: Jat king and freedom fighter Raja Mahendra Pratap Singh, who leased 3.04 acre land to set up Aligarh Muslim University in 1929 at Rs 2 per year, is set to get a university in his own name close to the institution that he helped set up. In October this year, while campaigning for byelections in Aligarh’s Iglas assembly seat, CM Yogi Adityanath had announced that his government would set up a university in Singh’s name, who despite having made great contributions to AMU, was not being recognised for it. On Monday, UP cabinet cleared the proposal to set up a state university in Aligarh, named after the Jat freedom fighter. “He had given land for the purpose (of establishing the university) but his name has not been mentioned on any plaque,” the CM had said during his election campaign when promising to set up a university in Singh’s name. Singh was an alumnus of the Mohammedan Anglo Oriental College which went on to become AMU. Singh has become a bone of contention between AMU and BJP over the past few years. Not only was there a demand to rename the university after him when a portrait of Pakistan’s founder Mohammad Ali Jinnah was found hanging on the AMU campus in 2018, but the local BJP wing had also demanded that the university commemorate Singh on his birth anniversary on December 1, 2014. AMU had instead settled on a seminar to honour Singh, with sources saying that the university had more than a 100 donors and it would be impossible to honour each of them on their birth anniversaries. Meanwhile, AMU acknowledges Singh’s contributions on its website. In a programme to celebrate Singh’s birth anniversary in 2016, a person the university refers to as a “freedom fighter and social reformist”, then AMU vice-chancellor Lt General Zameeruddin Shah had said: “Raja Pratap was a proud AMU alumnus, who urged the students to follow footsteps of Sir Syed Ahmad Khan and to join the ‘Freedom Movement.’ His family was closely associated with Sir Syed Ahmad Khan, the founder of the institution, and they also donated land where AMU’s City School is situated…We have always acknowledged that the Raja did lease 3.04 acres of land to AMU in 1929 at a rate of Rs. 2 per annum and we are proud of his contribution.”

column2: GST assessees low, Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath sets stiffer target for 2020
column3: LUCKNOW: Expressing dissatisfaction with the low number of tax assessees in state, chief minister Yogi Adityanath directed the commercial tax department to increase registration of traders to at least 25 lakh and set a target of Rs 1 lakh crore tax collection in the next financial year. He instructed the officials to curb tax theft in pan masala and iron trade, especially in areas neighbouring Nepal and take strict action against tax evaders. Addressing zonal additional commissioners in a review meeting on Tuesday, Yogi expressed displeasure over just 14 lakh traders being registered with the department. He told them to meet the Rs 77,640.10 crore tax collection target for current financial year. He told officials to work in tandem with trader welfare boards and ensure they work in such a way that traders find them to be friendly and not see them as oppressor. The CM asked officials to inform traders about the Rs 10 lakh insurance cover for those registered under GST and the proposed pension scheme for them in future. Proposing measures to increase tax collections, Yogi said, “Felicitate 10 traders of each district who pay the highest GST. Also felicitate the highest tax-paying traders in state on GST Day.” He told the officers to monitor GST collection at district level and stressed on the need to decentralise collection system. Yogi said each zonal additional commissioner must hold a fortnightly review and send report to him. “Deploy good officers in field and monitor their work. If it is unsatisfactory, call them back. This will create a positive image of the department among traders and registration and revenue will increase,” he said.

column3: LUCKNOW: Expressing dissatisfaction with the low number of tax assessees in state, chief minister Yogi Adityanath directed the commercial tax department to increase registration of traders to at least 25 lakh and set a target of Rs 1 lakh crore tax collection in the next financial year.
