This will create a positive image of the department among traders and registration and revenue will increase,” he said.

column2: Sikh gurus saved India, religion from being destroyed: Yogi Adityanath
column3: LUCKNOW: Days after the Supreme Court ruled in favour of giving the disputed land at Ayodhya for a temple, chief minister Yogi Adityanath praised Sikhism founder Guru Nanak Dev as “courageous” for giving Mughal ruler Babar the title of ‘Jabar’ or atrocious. Speaking at a celebration to mark Guru Nanak’s 550th birth anniversary at DAV College in Lucknow, the CM said that when people were reeling under the atrocities of Babar and the country was facing foreign invasions with “religion and truth being destroyed”, Guru Nanak Dev had paved the way for the welfare of humanity through his divine light. “A large section of society was afraid regarding issues of religion, truth and respect for sisters and daughters. Anarchists were a threat to the nation and religion. When the country and religion came under threat, Sikh gurus never bowed or turned back. The sacred tradition of the sacrifice of Sikh gurus is written in golden words in the history of India and every Indian expresses gratitude towards this,” the CM said. Yogi also expressed hope that like Katarpur, Indian Sikhs would soon be able to visit Nankana Sahib as well, the birth place of Guru Nanak in Pakistan. “Woh din door nahi jab Nankana Sahib me bhi hum sab is prakar se jaane me safal honge (The day is not far when we'll be able to visit Nankana Sahib as well).” Thanking Prime Minister Narendra Modi for the opening of the Kartarpur corridor, connecting the Sikh shrine of Dera Baba Nanak in India to Darbar Sahib in Pakistan on the occasion of Guru Nanak’s birth anniversary, Yogi said: “It is because of the grace of Guru Nanak Dev that both opening of the Kartarpur corridor and the final Ayodhya verdict on Ram Janmabhoomi happened on the same day.” The SC verdict on November 9 that settled the dispute mentions in its 1,045-page judgement that Guru Nanak had visited Ayodhya for Ram Janmabhoomi ‘darshan’ in 1510-11 AD. This ‘evidence’ had helped strengthen the claim for the temple, it said. Yogi added that no one could forget the contribution of Sikhs in the Indian freedom movement. Schools should organise competitions to teach students about it, he said. As part of the 550th year celebrations, the CM mentioned that work was underway to develop various religious sites associated with Sikhism in the state.

column2: Delhi-NCR breathes ‘severe’ air again, today may be worse
column3: NEW DELHI: A noxious haze hung over Delhi-NCR on Tuesday as air quality plunged into the “severe” zone again after eight days of relative respite, with experts pointing to a rise in pollution from farm fires and unfavourable weather conditions while warning that pollution could get worse on Wednesday and Thursday. Track the pollution level in your cityThe average AQI in Delhi on Tuesday was 425, a sharp drop from Monday’s 360 (“very poor”). The air was just as toxic in other NCR cities with Ghaziabad recording 453, Noida 440, Faridabad 406, Greater Noida 436 and Gurugram 402 — all in the “severe” category. The 24-hour average PM2.5 and PM10 levels had reached “severe plus” levels, five times above the safe standards, according to CPCB’s data. While Delhi-NCR’s average PM2.5 was 332.8 micrograms per cubic metre at 8pm, the average PM10 concentration was 479.2 micrograms per cubic metre. The “emergency” benchmarks for these pollutants under the Graded Response Action Plan (GRAP) are 300 and 500 micrograms/ cubic metre, respectively, while the safe levels are 60 and 100 micrograms/cubic metre. Air quality unlikely to improve before FridayAccording to SAFAR, no sudden recovery is expected under the present conditions at least for the next two days and AQI is likely to deteriorate further into the severe category. Decrease in temperature, low surface winds and northwest direction of wind, which was bringing in stubble burning emissions from Punjab and Haryana were causing the dip in air quality air, it said. A dip in wind speed and temperature makes the air colder and denser, leading to accumulation of pollutants, a met official said. “The condition may slightly improve by November 15. The effective stubble fire counts have shown a decreasing trend and were recorded at 740 on November 11, but the transport level wind direction is forecast to be highly favourable for plume intrusion for the next two days. The sky is likely to be partly cloudy for the next two days under the influence of an approaching western disturbance but no rain is expected,” a SAFAR report stated. A decreasing trend in the mixing depth and ventilation coefficient is also forecasted for the next two days which will cause the city air to foul up further, the SAFAR report added. Earlier, as pre-emptive steps ahead of the “severe” days, the Supreme Courtmandated Environment Pollution (Prevention and Control) Authority on Monday had said dirty fuel-based industries in Delhi and its suburbs will remain shut till November 14 morning. It also extended the ban on hot-mix plants and stone-crushers in Delhi-NCR till the morning of November 14. This order was based on the Central Pollution Control Board-led graded response action plan task force which reviewed the likely weather conditions in the next 48 hours at a meeting earlier in the day. The maximum and minimum temperatures on Tuesday were 28 degree Celsius, one point below normal for this time of the year, and 11.7 degree Celsius, two notches below normal and the season’s lowest so far. Partly cloudy sky along with shallow fog in the morning hours is expected on Wednesday. The maximum and minimum temperatures would be around 29 and 14 degree Celsius, respectively.

column2: New Ayodhya: Saryu cruise, Ram corridor, five-star hotel
column3: LUCKNOW: A cruise on the Saryu, a five-star hotel and heritage hotels, a Ram Corridor. As the Supreme Court verdict on Ram Janmabhoomi dispute on Saturday cleared the way for construction of Ram temple in Ayodhya, UP government has planned a slew of development projects for the temple town. State culture and tourism departments have plans to invite all states to replicate their respective prominent religious places in Ayodhya and also have their own state residential buildings like ‘Karnataka Bhawan’ or ‘Rajasthan Bhawan’. Sources in the government said rail, air and road connectivity will be developed while creating a “new Ayodhya”, a new township along with construction of the Ram temple to develop the town as among the world’s best pilgrim destinations and attract tourists from world over. Much before the pronouncement by the Supreme Court, chief minister Yogi Adityanath had begun working on renovating and beautifying the town and had approved a Rs 400 crore for this. Principal secretary, tourism and culture, Jitendra Kumar said there was already a surge of investors from India and abroad evincing interest in building big hotels, hospitals, resorts and providing hospitality and service centres in Ayodhya. “Investors have also shown interest in building modern inns and other places to serve pilgrims from outside and saints residing in Ayodhya,” said Kumar. “Culture and tourism departments have drawn up a plan which includes a 13-km long corridor from the Ram temple site to the place where Ram statue is being installed on the banks of Saryu." Along the corridor, life and times of Lord Ram would be recreated. Other religious sites would also be depicted along the corridor, he said, adding that the proposed project could be named after Lord Ram. The state government is also considering inviting all state governments to set up guest houses on the pattern of those in Delhi and also build models of main religious sites and temples like Somnath in Gujarat and Balaji Mandir in Tirupati. These would be built in Ayodhya, so that tourists visiting the temple will have a glimpse of religious places from across India. ‘Plan for international airport already approved’Rail, road and air traffic routes would be strengthened and expanded to cater to the growing pilgrim and tourist influx. A bus station to accommodate 3,000 to 4,000 buses at a time is being finalised and work on this would start soon once the chief minister approves the plan. Plan for an international airport is already approved for this city,” said Kumar. “The cruise planned on the Saryu, on the lines of Varanasi, will provide a panoramic view of all the attraction, including the Ram temple, Ram corridor and Ram statue.

column2: Soon, council to push development in Ayodhya, Yogi Adityanath to head
column3: LUCKNOW: Even before the Supreme Court-directed trust is to be formed by the Centre to facilitate construction of Ram temple in Ayodhya, the UP government is all set to constitute a similar body - the Ayodhya Development Council or Ayodhya Vikas Parishad. The government will move a Bill, which has been drafted and readied, soon for the constitution of this council. The draft will be taken up for approval in the next meeting of the state sabinet. The council would be headed by chief minister Yogi Adityanath and a special secretary-rank officer would be its chief executive officer while some official and private members could be nominated. Sources told TOI that the new council would be the umbrella body for carrying out development and beautification plans of the temple city. The council will not be involved in the building of the Ram Mandir and would be limited for the development of the city. At present, development work to the tune of hundreds of crores of rupees have already taken off in Ayodhya and bigger projects are on the cards as the state government has finalised plans to spruce up Ayodhya on par with any top pilgrim and tourist destination of the world.

column2: Lucknow: Fake buyers dupe three with 'payment' links
column3: LUCKNOW: Cyber criminals posing as prospective buyers on online sale and purchase portals are fleecing people by asking them to click on links sent to them for payments. Three such incidents have been reported at the Lucknow cyber cell over the past week. Sameer Mishra of SGPGI area on Sunday informed police he was duped of Rs 29,000 when a 'buyer' on such a site offered to pay him for an item through a link. "I shared the QR code of my payment app through social media messaging interface. However, he sent a link and said I will get the money by clicking it. When I clicked the link and fed my virtual payment address (VPA) pin, Rs 29,000 was deducted from my account," said Mishra. Similarly, businessman Yogendra Pratap was duped of Rs 20,000 while Anjali Joshi was duped of Rs 12,500 when she decided to sell her refrigerator last week. Sub-inspector, cyber cell, Rahul Rathore said: "We are investigating the cases."

column2: Students attack teacher in school in Rae Bareli
column3: LUCKNOW: A group of boys at a private school attacked their lady teacher when she intervened to resolve a dispute between them. The incident occurred at Gandhi Sewa Niketan, a private boys’ school run by an NGO working for orphaned children, in Rae Bareli on Monday. The victim, Mamta Dubey, lodged an FIR against unidentified children on Tuesday. The district administration ordered a probe after a video of the incident went viral on social media. In the FIR, Dubey stated that she was teaching students of class IX when two groups of boys started abusing each other. “When I tried to stop them, they first threatened me and then one of them attacked me with a chair,” Dubey, who suffered minor injuries, said in her FIR. SP Rae Bareli Swapnil Mamgain told TOI that the incident will be probed by citymagistrate and ASP rank officer. “A case under the charges of criminal intimidation, voluntarily causing hurt, provoking breach of peace, and cr iminal assault has been lodged against unidentified children,” said Mamgain. City magistrate will record the statements of the victim as well as the aattackers on Wednesday, SP said.

column2: Farm fires bring air quality back to ‘severe’ category
column3: NOIDA/GHAZIABAD: As the AQI in Noida, Greater Noida and Ghaziabad shot up to more than 400 on Tuesday, the Uttar Pradesh Pollution Control Board (UPPCB) said the pollution levels would be in “severe” range for the next 24 hours. On Tuesday, the AQI in Noida was recorded at 438, in Greater Noida, it was at 436 and in Ghaziabad, it was 451. Track the pollution level in your cityAccording to UPPCB, the spike in the AQI levels is because of an increase in the incidents of stubble burning in Punjab and Haryana. “There has been a 25% addition in the PM 2.5 category of pollutants from stubble burning over the past 24 hours. In addition to this, there is negligible wind movement. Because of the combination, the AQI has once again shot back to the ‘severe’ category,” said Utsav Sharma, environment engineer, UPPCB, Greater Noida and Ghaziabad. According to SAFAR, no sudden recovery is expected under the present conditions at least for the next two days and the AQI is likely to deteriorate further into the severe category. Decrease in temperature, low surface winds and northwest direction of wind, which was bringing in stubble burning emissions from Punjab and Haryana were causing the dip in air quality air, it said. A dip in wind speed and temperature makes the air colder and denser, leading to accumulation of pollutants, a met official said. “The condition may slightly improve by November 15. The effective stubble fire counts have shown a decreasing trend and were recorded at 740 on November 11, but the transport level wind direction is forecasted to be highly favourable for plume intrusion for the next two days. The sky is likely to be partly cloudy for the next two days under the influence of an approaching western disturbance but no rain is expected,” a SAFAR report stated. A decreasing trend in the mixing depth and ventilation coefficient is also the forecast for the next two days, which will cause the city air to foul up further, the report added. Earlier, as pre-emptive steps ahead of the “severe” days, the Supreme Court-mandated Environment Pollution (Prevention and Control) Authority on Monday had said dirty fuel-based industries in Delhi and its suburbs will remain shut till November 14 morning. It also extended the ban on hot-mix plants and stone-crushers in Delhi-NCR till the morning of November 14. This order was based on the Central Pollution Control Board-led graded response action plan task force which reviewed the likely weather conditions in the next 48 hours at a meeting earlier in the day. In Delhi, the maximum and minimum temperatures on Tuesday were 28 degree Celsius, one point below normal for this time of the year, and 11.7 degree Celsius, two notches below normal and the season’s lowest so far. Partly cloudy sky along with shallow fog in the morning hours is expected on Wednesday. The maximum and minimum temperatures would be around 29 and 14 degree Celsius, respectively. On Monday, the AQI in Greater Noida was 364, in Ghaziabad, it was 384 and in Noida, it was 376. The AQI had shot up from Sunday when it was in the “very poor” range. “The air quality will be in the ‘poor’ range after the weather conditions change. But for now, as long as there is no increase in wind movement, we are not certain about any radical shift. But we are continuously making an effort to be vigilant about ground level pollution control, to help keep a check on the PM 10 and PM 2.5 levels,” Sharma added.

column2: Delhi-Meerut Expressway work on, NHAI fined Rs 26 lakh
column3: NOIDA/GHAZIABAD: The UPPCB on Tuesday slapped a fine of Rs 26 lakh on the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) for violating the blanket ban on construction activities. The violation was detected on a stretch of the Delhi-Meerut Expressway ahead of ABES College near Vijay Nagar area in Ghaziabad. The Uttar Pradesh Pollution Control Board’s regional officer for Ghaziabad, who is also the environmental engineer for Greater Noida, Utsav Sharma, said construction was going on at a plot in Indirapuram and action would be taken against those responsible. On Tuesday, minor constructions could be seen at various places in Noida and Ghaziabad. “Construction work can be both polluting and non polluting. If someone is doing some work inside a building, we don’t have much of a problem. But no one is allowed to conduct any construction on the outside and the fine in such cases can be of Rs 1 lakh,” Sharma said. He added that the department has imposed penalties to the tune of Rs 53 lakh for violations related to construction and demolition activities since October 15 when the graded response action plan (GRAP) came into effect. On Monday, in Jewar, Sharma lodged complaints against 10 farmers for stubble burning. In Ghaziabad’s Raj Nagar Extension, a machine was found levelling the ground and digging up earth at a plot between Gaur Cascade and Classic Residency societies on Tuesday. Locals alleged that the work had been going on for the past three-four days. Building constructions were in progress at Raj Nagar and Lohia Nagar. Kumar said teams were conducting inspections and taking action against violators. Reports of violation came in from both Noida and Ghaziabad in the past 24 hours. Some residents have also reported about crackers being burst late on Monday. “If people are carrying out repairs in the houses, causing pollution, it is a violation. The complaints have all been forwarded to the Noida Authority,” said the regional officer, UPPCB, Gautam Budh Nagar, Anil Singh. Fines for construction work, be it private houses, builder projects or government activities, is Rs 1 lakh. The ban on construction activities was imposed by the Supreme Court on October 25.

column2: Ghaziabad: Bus with private firm staff rams tractor on NH-9
column3: GHAZIABAD: Nearly two dozen employees of a private textile company were injured after the bus they were travelling in collided with a tractor in Vijay Nagar area on NH-9 on Tuesday morning. According to police, around 8am, the bus driver lost control of the vehicle and hit the tractor carrying material for the construction of a road. The bus used to ferry employees of a private cloth manufacturing company from their home to office in Sector 63. Shyamvir Singh, the SHO of Vijay Nagar police station, said when the cops got information about the accident, a team reached the spot and took the injured to a nearby hospital. Most of the passengers were discharged in an hour after receiving first-aid. However, three people, who were critically injured, were referred to Safdarjung Hospital in Delhi. “Initial investigation revealed that the speed of the bus was over 60km/hr. The driver lost control and descended the bus on the kuchcha road adjacent to the main road and hit the tractor,” said the SHO. However, the company’s spokesperson said that the tractor had suddenly come in front of the bus. “The bus driver has also suffered some injuries, but he is fine now. The driver told us that the tractor suddenly came in his way. While the bus driver tried his best to avoid the collision, the tractor turned turtle in front of the bus,” he added. As a result of the accident, the highway witnessed a massive traffic jam for around three hours. Police took three hours to remove the bus and the tractor from the road. “The cops have created some diversions around 200 metre before the accident spot. Police diverted the vehicles approaching from Hapur to another adjacent road towards Delhi,” Singh said. A commuter stranded in traffic said she got late in reaching her office. “I was stuck in traffic till about 9am and reached around three hours later,” said Akansha Srivastava, who works with a private bank in Connaught Place.

column2: Till waste plant is built, Ghaziabad municipal corporation to hire segregator
column3: GHAZIABAD: The Ghaziabad Municipal Corporation (GMC) plans to install a waste segregator in Morta to separate dry and wet garbage. Officials said till the waste-to-energy plant becomes functional in Galand, this initiative will help the civic body in separating the waste and disposing them properly. This proposal will be discussed on Wednesday during a meeting to shortlist projects under the infrastructure funds and the 14th Finance Commission. The budget allocation under both heads is around Rs 150 crore, officials said. GMC additional commissioner Pramod Kumar said that the segregator will not be bought, but taken on rent for the time being. “It is a pilot project. The machine is capable of segregating around 300-400 tonnes of garbage per day. We plan to install it in Morta. While wet waste will be used for producing manure, dry waste like paper, plastic and rubber will be disposed of accordingly,” he said. According to Kumar, a similar machine has been installed in Ghazipur in Delhi and has given good results. “With the help of different agencies, the civic body has been preparing organic compost in the vegetable market and flower compost in Sai Upvan. Moreover, liquid compost is being produced in Vijay Nagar and Mohana Nagar from waste,” he added.

column2: Varanasi to bid adieu to turtle sanctuary
column3: LUCKNOW: Three decades after it was declared India’s first and so far only protected area dedicated to the conservation of freshwater turtle species, Varanasi’s Turtle Wildlife Sanctuary is being denotified by the UP government in preparation for a possible “relocation” to the Allahabad-Mirzapur stretch of the Ganga. The prod to denotify the sanctuary first came two years ago, when the Union ministry of environment and forests wrote to the state government that the ghats were under threat. Amid opposition to the move from conservationists, it emerged that the Centre’s 1,620km national waterways project was to pass through the turtle habitat. Sources said the Wildlife Institute of India (WII) had conducted a feasibility study and found the Allahabad-Mirzapur stretch of the river suitable for the relocation of the sanctuary. The proposal was “reviewed and approved in principle” during a recent meeting of the state wildlife board, chaired by CM Yogi Adityanath. The sanctuary, spanning the 7km stretch from Ramnagar Fort to the Malviya railroad bridge, was notified as the country’s first freshwater turtle sanctuary under the Ganga Action Plan in 1989. The idea of a sanctuary was married to the concept of releasing four carnivorous species of turtles for organic cleaning of the Ganga. Since Kathawa (Aspederites gangeticus), Sundari Kachua (Lissemys punctata), Dhond (Kachuga dhongoka) and Pacheda (Pangshuratecta) are carnivorous turtles, it was expected that they would feed on half-burnt corpses floating in the waters of the Ganga. Turtle eggs were secured from the Chambal river, hatched at the Sarnath breeding centre and released in the river. The state government subsequently banned sand mining in the area to save the nesting turtles, leading to sand accumulation and increased sedimentation that seemed to create a new set of challenges. Flagging this as a threat to the ghats, the environment ministry wrote to the state government in 2017 seeking a remedy. Since a wildlife sanctuary can only be denotified, Turtle Wildlife Sanctuary will have to be reborn as a new habitat as and when it is shifted.

column2: Muslim litigant ready to file Ayodhya review petition in SC with AIMPLB support
column3: LUCKNOW: Days after the Supreme Court verdict on Ayodhya, Mohammad Umar, son of one of the first Muslim litigants, announced on Wednesday he was ready to file a petition after a nod from the All-India Muslim Personal Law Board (AIPLBM). Talking to TOI from Ayodhya, Umar said alternate land for the mosque outside the acquired 67 acres may not be acceptable. “I am ready to move a review plea, if asked by AIMPLB, which will have to legally back me. We were fighting for Babri mosque, not a piece of land,” said Umar, whose father Mohammad Farooq was one of the first six Muslim litigants in the Ram Janmabhoomi-Babri Masjid dispute, along with Hashim Ansari. When asked about his stand on the five acres allotted for the mosque at an alternative site, Umar asked, “Why should the mosque be built away from the site of the demolished Babri masjid? Why should we go somewhere else to offer prayers? Land for the mosque should be given within the acquired site and not beyond,” he said. After the demolition of the Babri masjid, the then Congress government of Prime Minister P V Narasimha Rao passed the “Acquisition of Certain Areas at Ayodhya Act” to acquire 67 acres around the 2.77-acre disputed site where the Babri masjid had stood. Another key litigant, the UP Sunni Central Waqf Board, has already announced it won’t go for a review petition and will decide whether to accept the five acres of land soon. AIMPLB member and Babri Masjid Action Committee convenor Zafaryab Jilani had earlier told TOI the board would take a call on the review petition at its November 17 meeting in Nadwatul Ulama.

column2: Swimiming pool at Green Park complex
column3: KANPUR: Green Park sports complex will soon be equipped with a swimming pool for which Kanpur Municipal Corporation (KMC) has sanctioned Rs 1 crore. Swimming would be 19th discipline of Green Park where coaching and training facilities will be available for sportspersons. Talking to TOI, Ajay Kumar Sethi, regional sports officer, said that he was leaving no stone unturned to make the stadium the best sports complex of the country. After swimming pool, squash court, modern gym and up-gradation of badminton hall are in the pipeline which would add another feather in Green Park’s cap, he said. There was a great demand for a swimming pool because sometimes players also need water therapy and swimming provides the best water therapy, he further said. The 25-metre long all-weather pool, equipped with water filter plant would be constructed in four phases at the old hostel building site which is in a dilapidated state, Sethi said. The pool would see construction in the first phase while in the second phase it would be equipped with a water filter plant.

column2: UP: Harassed by driver, woman jumps off 3-wheeler, injured
column3: LUCKNOW: In another case of sexual harassment in public transport, a 21-year-old graduation student was injured when she was forced to jump from a moving three-wheeler after being harassed by the driver. The driver also did not stop the vehicle at her destination in Bakshi Ka Talab on Wednesday. According to the FIR, the Hassanganj resident left home around 10am and boarded a tempo for her college in BKT. She was left alone in the 6-seater vehicle after other commuters alighted. After driving for some time, the driver asked her to remove the scarf with which she had covered her face and share her mobile phone number. The woman refused and asked the driver to stop the vehicle. However, he accelerated and increased the volume of the music system, playing obscene songs. The woman repetitively asked the driver to stop the vehicle but her requests went unheeded. Finally, when the vehicle went past her stop, she jumped out to protect herself from the harassment. “I always take the same route for college but such an incident has never occurred,” the woman told TOI. While the vehicle sped away, the woman, who suffered limb and back injuries, was helped by passers-by to reach a nearby private hospital from where she was discharged after first aid. “I recently joined college after a month’s leave because my father passed away due to cancer...Now, I might have to discontinue because my mother and sisters are scared about my safety,” she added. SHO BKT Amarnath Verma said, “We are trying to identify the driver through CCTV footage.” (The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

column2: Smriti Smriti chides DM for shoving slain BJP man’s brother
column3: LUCKNOW: Union minister Smriti Irani on Wednesday chided Amethi district magistrate on twitter after a video showing him roughing up the brother of a slain BJP worker went viral on social media. Irani represents Amethi in Lok Sabha. Amethi DM Prashant Sharma, a 2012 batch IAS officer, entered into a verbal duel with Sunil Singh, a PCS trainee officer, brother of BJP worker Vijay Kumar Singh alias Sonu, who was shot dead in Amethi on Tuesday over extortion. Sunil was protesting against the delay in post-mortem and nabbing Sonu’s killers. In the two-and-half minute video, Sharma is seen shoving Sunil and lecturing protesters on not to over-react and seek instant results. “Is zile ka sabse varishth adhikari yahan khada hai. Kya aapko pata hai us aadmi ke paas katta hai ke nahi? (The district’s most senior officer is standing here. Can you show if that man has a firearm?” asks Sharma.  Irani tagged the DM in her tweet saying, “Vinaysheel evam samvedansheel banein hum, yahi prayaas hona chahiye. Janata ke hum sevak hain, shaasak nahi @DmAmethi. (We should always try to be humble and caring. We are here to serve people not to rule.)” This was the second controversy involving Sharma in last one week. Sharma had come late for hearing before the Lucknbow bench of Allahabad high court. Despite repeated attempts, Amethi SP Khyati Garg did not respond to calls and messages to confirm if the district police has received any complaint against Sharma. The Amethi Police has registered a case of murder against three unidentified people in Gauriganj. Sonu Singh, owner of a brick kiln, was shot dead allegedly over extortion demand of Rs 2 lakh barely 500 m away from the SP’s office in Amthi at around 7pm on Tuesday. Sonu’s father Shivnayak Singh is also a local leader of BJP. Sonu’s brother Arpit Kumar Singh had accused Chandrashekhar Kesarwani, Shubham Tiwari and three unidentified persons in the complaint filed at Gauriganj police station after which an FIR was lodged.

column2: Seized documents put former PCL boss AP Mishra in dock
column3: LUCKNOW: The findings of probe in violation of government rules while investing employees’ provident fund reveal that Uttar Pradesh Power Corporation Limited managing director, A P Mishra, played a key role in it as money was put in financial institutions other than scheduled commercial banks for the first time in December 2016. The scrutiny of documents seized from UPPCL headquarters at Shakti Bhawan on November 4 by UP Police’s Economic Offences Wing till now has revealed that bending of rules in PF investment started under Mishra in December 2016. Officials privy to the probe said prior to investment of UPPCL employees’ PF in DHFL in March 2017, the UP power sector employees trust and UPPCL authorities had invested Rs 50 crore from contributory provident fund and Rs 50 crore from general provident fund in PNB Housing and LIC. EOW officials on Wednesday said they have traced the money trail of four of the 14 brokerage firms that secured the deal between UPPCL and DHFL. The officials said DHFL has agreed to co-operate and disclose the commission percentage given to brokerage firms. “Transactions have also taken place between these four brokerage firms and UPPCL officials and are being probed,” said a senior official. EOW had started investigation of the anomalies on November 3 and has so far arrested Mishra, UPPCL director (finance) Sudhanshu Dwivedi and general manager (finance) PK Gupta. EOW sleuths continued the questioning of Gupta’s son Abhinav on Wednesday. He was served notice to explain his role in the negotiations with DHFL. Meanwhile, the laptops and CPUs seized from the residences of the arrested officials have been sent to Forensic Science Lab for data recovery.

column2: 75% infant deaths take place in the first month of birth in UP
column3: LUCKNOW: Over 75% infant mortality cases in UP clock deaths in the first 28 days itself. The tragedy is compounded by the fact that majority deaths are linked to preventable causes and at least 41 of 1000 babies die before celebrating their first birthday. An internal assessment by the state health department found pre-term births accounted for about 44% deaths and these are linked to poor health and anaemia in expectant mothers. Neonatal infections (20%) picked up from labour rooms or caused by lack of basic hygiene by lower-rung health staff and parents was the next big reason. Acknowledging the need to spread awareness on factors that lead to neonatal deaths, National Health Mission would observe Neonatal Awareness Week between November 14 and 21. Mission director, NHM, UP Pankaj Kumar said, “the most crucial time to connect with a newborn is the first 28 days when the infant is vulnerable to different life-threatening diseases.” Experts agree. “If the baby survives in this period, UP’s infant mortality rate can be halved,” said Dr Vishwajeet Kumar, social entrepreneur and founder, Community Empowerment Lab dedicated to saving newborns.

column2: Don’t burn crop stubble, convert it into biofuel: CM Yogi Adityanath
column3: LUCKNOW: With air quality over north India deteriorating once again, chief minister Yogi Adityanath has appealed to farmers to not burn crop residue but instead use it to increase soil productivity. The CM announced that the government was exploring the opportunity to convert crop residue into fuel and at some point in future, could even purchase it from farmers. “Crop stubble can be converted to biofuel. We are already in talks with companies like Indian Oil and Bharat Petroleum and are setting up a unit each in Sitapur and Gorakhpur for this. Once these are up and running and successful, we will strive to have one or two such units in each district. In coming days we can then purchase crop residue from farmers,” the CM said. Farm fires in rice producing states of UP, Haryana and Punjab have been identified as a major cause of air pollution. Several cities in UP where air pollution is being monitored have shown extremely high levels of harmful particulate matter. Addressing farmers during the launch of an e-portal for sugarcane growers on Wednesday, Yogi said burning stubble decreases the productivity of soil and adversely impacts environment. “I appeal to all farmers that stubble should not be burnt. Instead, if you crush it and use it while turning the soil, it will turn into compost. Use it for anything else but don’t burn it. Burning releases dangerous gases,” he said. He added that with the government promoting sugarcane production and opening more sugar mills in UP, sugarcane leaves would also be generated as “waste” but instead of being burnt, they could be used for maintaining moisture in the soil for the next sugarcane crop.

column2: Lucknow as noisy as vacuum cleaner near you: Experts
column3: LUCKNOW: It is not just the air of Lucknow that is unfit for breathing, even noise pollution levels in the city are alarmingly high, posing a risk to health of people. Track the pollution level in your cityA study by the Indian Institute of Toxicology Research (IITR) has found that day and night noise levels across Lucknow are 24-40% higher than the permissible limit set by National Ambient Air Quality Standard (NAAQS). These noise levels are equivalent to a vacuum cleaner running constantly near you. Prolonged exposure to such noise can damage ear drums and cause hypertension in people, said experts. Primary reasons for high noise levels were vehicular movement and construction activities, they added. Aliganj was the noisiest place during the day with 69.5 decibels, 25% higher than permissible limit. Indiranagar, with 64.8 decibels, was the noisiest at night. This was 44% higher than permissible limit. Aliganj recorded 62.8 decibels at night while Indiranagar recorded 67.4 decibels during the day. Noise level in Gomtinagar was 68.7 decibels during day and 60.1 decibels at night. For Vikasnagar, it was 65.9 decibels in the day and 58.9 decibels at night. Among commercial areas, Charbagh was the noisiest both during the day and night with 77.2 decibels and 68.9 decibels, respectively. Chowk was the second noisiest during the day and Aminabad at night.

column2: Gomtinagar gasped in worst October air
column3: LUCKNOW: People living in Gomtinagar and Charbagh breathed in the most polluted air in October in the city, reveals the post-monsoon ambient air quality assessment report released by the Indian Institute of Toxicology Research (IITR) on Wednesday. Track the pollution level in your cityThe main reason for pollution was found to be dust raised by plying of vehicles on broken roads, open garbage burning and vehicular emissions. In the survey, air pollution levels in October were monitored at nine locations—four residential ones being Aliganj, Vikasnagar, Indiranagar and Gomtinagar, four commercial ones being Charbagh, Alambagh, Aminabad and Chowk and one industrial area being Amausi. Among residential areas, Gomtinagar had the highest average PM10 concentration at 165.4micrograms per cubic metre of air (g/m3), almost double the permissible limit of 100g/m3. This was followed by Indiranagar, Vikasnagar and Aliganj. Gomtinagar also topped in PM2.5 concentration with 93.6g/m3 followed by Indiranagar, Aliganj and Vikasnagar. All values were above the permissible limit of 60g/m3. Among commercial areas, Charbagh recorded the highest PM10 concentration of 197.4g/m3, followed by Aminabad, Alambagh and Chowk. Similarly, PM2.5 concentration was highest in Charbagh with 109.6g/m3 followed by Chowk and Alambagh. Citing a study by UP Pollution Control Board last year which cited broken roads, open garbage burning and vehicular emissions as main sources of air pollutants in the city, experts said that unless these activities are not corrected with seriousness, no improvement in conditions could be expected. The areas found most polluted in the report are those where either vehicular load is high or many stretches are lying broken or garbage is burnt in the open. Dust particles released by construction activities have been the major factor of air pollution in expanding Gomtinagar where a number of residential, government and commercial construction projects are underway. Charbagh, on the other hand, witnesses heavy vehicular load daily. Similar factors in various degrees can be found in other residential and commercial areas. “The weather also plays an important role in air pollution. For example, wind speed can blow away pollutants hanging in the atmosphere and rains can clear the air, but the real solution would be to reduce the source of pollution,” said senior scientist SC Barman who led the IITR team.

column2: Digital signatures on Lucknow University marksheets to cut fakes
column3: LUCKNOW: To check fake documents, the Lucknow University has decided that all marksheets uploaded on its website will now bear digital signatures. Moreover, students will get only three years after passing out to get their marksheets corrected after which a go ahead will be required from the examination controller and the vice-chancellor. The decisions were taken during the examination committee meeting on Wednesday. It examination committee decided that marksheets will be made available to students within 10 days of declaration of results. The practice of giving physical copy of the marksheet to students and uploading of documents online will continue. However, the online version will have digital signatures. The students will be given 10 days to apply for corrections, if any, after which marksheets with digital signatures will be uploaded on the website. If the students are not able to get corrections done within 10 days for some reason, they can get special permission by applying within three years of passing out. However, if any request is allowed after three years, the candidate will have to seek the approval of controller of examination and vice-chancellor who will have to mention, in writing, the circumstances under which approval is being given. “In the name of corrections, many marksheets keep on lying in university’s examination cell for years. Tabulation charts are taken out for correction but not put back which increases risk of misuse like making of fake marksheets,” said officiating vice-chancellor SK Shukla.

column2: Why Sanskrit, Persian will forever illuminate Lucknow University
column3: LUCKNOW: Envisioned as a centre of multi-culturalism, Lucknow University has been a place to learn languages since its inception. Besides science and humanities subjects, Latin, Greek, Sanskrit and Persian were among the first 28 departments set up in 1921, when LU it began its journey. These departments were clubbed under different faculties. With time, many new departments were added. The departments of Latin and Greek, though, had to shut after just a year due to a fall in popularity. However, it is a bond signed with the founding fathers that has ensured that the departments of Sanskrit, Arabic and Persian continue to impart knowledge despite a decline in demand. According to the bond—the Taluq-e-Daran-e-Awadh—signed in 1922, the university will have to run traditional courses in Persian, Arabic and Sanskrit till the time it exists. It was signed at the time when land for constructing the university was donated by Sir Mohammad Ali Mohammad Khan, the then Raja of Mahmudabad estate. The sentiment behind the bond was that these subjects reflected the Ganga-Jamuni tehzeeb enshrined in Lucknow’s culture. “This is the reason why teaching in classical Sanskrit, Arabic and Persian in the traditional manner using unabridged books still continues in LU,” said Ayodhya Das Shri Vishnu, former head of the department of oriental studies in Sanskrit. “By teaching these subjects, we are keeping our traditions alive and connect the past with the present,” said Prof Syed Arshad Ali Jafari, a faculty of oriental studies in Arabic and Persian and an alumnus of LU. The Taluq-e-Daran-e-Awadh also arranged for some waqf properties to fund these departments. As a result, no fee was charged from the students. This, however, changed in 2007, when then vice-chancellor RP Singh issued directions to charge fees to deter non-serious candidates from taking admission. “In 2007, the fee was increased from a meagre Rs 350 to Rs 3,000,” which became the main reason for the drop in the number of applications,” said Das. LU alumnus and Ram Manohar Lohia Avadh University VC Manoj Dixit said, “These courses are very unique to India and LU was the first, at least in North India, to start them. Insufficient work on syllabus, not updating it, and not making the courses job-oriented can be seen as reasons for the dip in demand.”

column2: Ayodhya Muslim litigant ready to file review plea
column3: LUCKNOW: Days after the Supreme Court verdict on Ayodhya, murmurs are getting louder among Muslims to seek review of the judgment. On Wednesday, Mohammad Umar, son of one of the first Muslim litigants, announced he was ready to file a petition after a nod from All-India Muslim Personal Law Board (AIPLBM), an apex body of the community. Talking to TOI from Ayodhya, Umar said alternate land for the mosque outside the acquired 67 acre may not be acceptable. "I am ready to move a review plea, if asked by AIMPLB, which will have to legally back me. We were fighting for Babri mosque, not a piece of land," said Umar, whose father Mohammad Farooq was one of the first six Muslim litigants in the Ram Janmabhoomi-Babri Masjid dispute, along with Hashim Ansari. When asked about his stand on the 5-acre land allotted for the mosque as an alternative site, Umar asked, "Why should the mosque be built away from the site of the demolished Babri Masjid? Why should we go somewhere else to offer prayers? Land for the mosque should be given within the acquired site and not beyond," he said. After the Babri demolition, then Congress government under Prime Minister P V Narasimha Rao passed the 'Acquisition of Certain Areas at Ayodhya Act' to acquire 67 acre around the 2.77 acre disputed site where Babri Masjid once stood. Another key litigant, UP Sunni Central Waqf Board, has already announced it would won't go for a review petition and would decide on accepting the 5-acre land soon. AIMPLB member and convener of Babri Masjid Action Committee, Zafaryab Jilani, had earlier told TOI the Board will take a call on the review petition in its November 17 meeting in Nadwatul Ulama, Lucknow. He also said the board can explore the option of seeking a review through five Muslim litigants and three other Muslim defendants in the Ayodhya case. Jamiat Ulama-e-Hind (JuH), which is also a party in the case, will be meeting in Delhi on Thursday on the issue. "A final call will be taken by the governing council meeting of JuH on Thursday on twin issues of review and alternate 5-acre land," said JuH's state chief, Maulana Ashhad Rashidi.

column2: Lucknow: Man dials 'toll free' number to cancel food order, loses 4 lakh
column3: LUCKNOW: A man trying to cancel an order made through a food delivery app by using a toll free number was duped of Rs 4 lakh in Virat Khand area of Gomtinagar on Wednesday. It was later found that the toll free number was fake. The victim, who did not wish to be named, said he ordered food through a food delivery app but when the company did not deliver as per his expectation, he searched the customer care number on the internet. He said his call was received by a man who introduced himself as the company's representative and asked him to install an app and login to his savings bank account. "As soon as I entered my bank details in the app, I received a one-time password (OTP). The caller asked me to enter the OTP to get the refund. However, within minutes Rs 4 lakh was debited from my bank account," he said. Police said the app, which the cyber fraudster asked the victim to install, allowed remote access of mobile phone to him. Getting access to his phone, the scammer withdrew money from the account. SHO, Gomtinagar, Amit Kumar Dubey said: "We are taking the help of cyber cell to trace the miscreant."

column2: Lucknow: Rising chill & fog to push pollution in coming week
column3: LUCKNOW: As air pollution levels continued to increase in the city on Wednesday, the Air Quality Index (AQI) jumped to 354, up by 53 points from 301 on Tuesday, data from the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) showed. T rack the pollution level in your cityThe situation will aggravate in the coming week with state Met office predicting a drop in temperatures and formation of moderate fog. For four consecutive days from November 2-5, the state capital’s air quality remained ‘severe’ before dropping to ‘very poor’ category. On November 10 and 11, the pollution levels were below 300 before soaring again on Tuesday. According to the live air quality monitoring at four localities in the city conducted by CPCB, PM2.5 concentration on Wednesday was above or touching 350 micrograms per cubic metre of air ( g/m3), around five times higher than the permissible limits of 60 g/m3 set by the National Ambient Air Quality Standards. Environmentalist Venkatesh Dutta said, “Immediate measures are needed as with fall in temperature, there is a spike in pollution by around 50 units every day. The situation will become worse once fog begins.”

column2: Look into farmers’ issues, Ghaziabad district magistrate says in meeting
column3: GHAZIABAD: The district magistrate on Wednesday held a meeting with agitating farmers from Modinagar and discussed with them some of their grievances related to construction of roads and low height of underpasses along the Delhi-Meerut expressway. The DM directed the National Highways Authority of India officials to look into the farmers’ problems on a priority basis. Subdivisional district magistrate, Modinagar, Saumya Pandey, has been made the nodal officer to listen to the farmers’ grievances and coordinate with NHAI officials to look for a solution. DM Ajay Shankar Pandey said: “I have directed NHAI officials and district administration officials to accelerate the construction of the Delhi-Meerut road and told them that all problems and difficulties being faced by farmers, whose land have been acquired by the administration, should be looked into.” The NHAI officials submitted a list of connecting roads and underpasses that have been constructed by the authority to the farmers. Later, Pandey directed the farmers’ representative to provide a list of places where they wanted additional connecting roads so that a feasibility survey could be conducted. NHAI project director RP Singh said the underpasses have been built according to the set standards and their height cannot be changed. Regarding pending compensations to farmers whose land has been acquired for the Eastern Peripheral Expressway, the DM has directed the NHAI to look into the matter with the next 15 days.

column2: Ghaziabad green-lights projects worth Rs 148 crore, sets aside Rs 28 crore for roads & drains
column3: GHAZIABAD: Projects worth Rs 148 crore were sanctioned at the infrastructure fund and 14th finance commission meeting of the Ghaziabad Municipal Corporation (GMC) at the district collectorate on Wednesday. The biggest allotment was made to the infrastructure fund – Rs 28 crore for the construction of roads and drains by the public works department. An additional Rs 8.5 crore has been allotted for other construction works. Rs 2.76 crore has been given to the streetlight wing. The health department has been allotted Rs 14.07 crore for buying 50 small loaders for door-to-door collection, 2,000 biometric watches for sanitation workers and field officers, water sprinklers and composting machines, among other equipment. Rs 6.37 crore will be spent on the construction of an RCC stormwater drain from Prahlad Garhi to Vaishali Canal and Rs 3.96 crore on building a drain from Nandgram to Sai Enclave. Horticulture department has been allocated Rs 2.79 crore for buying park equipment. A sum of Rs 96 lakh will be spent on the installation of new deep wells while Rs 33 lakh has been kept aside for reboring works. Around Rs 5.5 crore will be spent on strengthening waterworks.

column2: Air emergency in Delhi-NCR, schools shut till Friday
column3: NEW DELHI: Air quality in Delhi-NCR plunged deeper into the “severe” zone on Wednesday, staying in the worst category on the AQI scale for the second straight day, which prompted the authorities to take “air emergency” action. Schools in Delhi and adjoining cities were ordered shut till Friday while CM Arvind Kejriwal said he would consider extending the odd-even scheme beyond November 15.Track the pollution level in your city“In view of deteriorating air quality because of pollution due to stubble burning, the Delhi government has decided to close schools tomorrow and day after,” deputy CM Manish Sisodia tweeted.Similar announcements were made in Noida, Gurugram, Ghaziabad and Faridabad after the Environment Pollution (Prevention and Control) Authority wrote to NCR states recommending the move and advised people to avoid outdoor exposure and work from home wherever feasible.The average air quality index in Delhi on Wednesday was 456 — the third highest so far this season — deteriorating from Tuesday’s 425.No respite today, ‘severe’ air may improve to ‘very poor’ after 2 daysAir quality remained severe in NCR towns as well. It was 470 in Noida, 446 in Faridabad, 467 in Ghaziabad, 462 in Greater Noida and 447 in Gurugram. A toxic smog hung over much of north India with cloudy skies over Punjab, Haryana and west Uttar Pradesh as well as calm winds ahead of an approaching western disturbance trapping pollutants close to the ground.In NCR, the 24-hour average PM2.5 and PM10 concentrations in the air crossed severe plus levels — five times above the safe standards on Wednesday — according to CPCB’s central control room data. While the average PM2.5 was 348.2 micrograms per cubic metre at 9pm, the average PM10 concentration was 506.6 micrograms per cubic metre. The “emergency” benchmark for these pollutants under GRAP is 300 and 500 micrograms per cubic metre, respectively, while the safe standards are 60 and 100 micrograms per cubic metre.The CPCB-led task force met to review the situation and recommended the shutting down of schools for the next two days. It also extended the ban on hot-mix plants and stone-crushers in Delhi-NCR till November 15. The apex court had on November 4 banned construction and demolition activities in the region till further orders.All coal and other fuelbased industries, which have not shifted to natural gas or agro-residue, will remain shut in Faridabad, Gurugram, Ghaziabad, Noida, Bahadurgarh, Bhiwadi, Greater Noida, Sonepat and Panipat till November 15, it said. In Delhi, industries which have not yet shifted to piped natural gas, will not operate during the period.“Low surface winds, low mixing depth and contribution from farm fires due to northwesterly winds resulted in the severe plus category, which is likely to continue till Thursday,” an India Meteorological Department official said. “Strong winds are expected from November 15, which will bring down the air pollution levels to the very poor category,” he added.Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal said in view of the situation, the odd-even road rationing scheme could be extended beyond November 15.“If the need arises, we will extend the odd-even scheme,” Kejriwal said in response to media queries on whether the initiative aimed at curbing vehicular pollution will be extended. The scheme, implemented from November 4, is to end on November 15.Earlier on November 1, the Delhi government had ordered closure of all schools till November 5 after the EPCA declared a public health emergency in Delhi-NCR due to a harmful spike in pollution after Diwali. According to SAFAR, the AQI is likely to deteriorate during Wednesday night and stay in the severe category on Thursday.“The air quality condition is likely to marginally improve by November 15 but reasonable improvement to ‘very poor’ is expected only by November 16. The stubble fire counts has shown decreasing trend (480 counts on November 12). Hence, a decline in biomass share in Delhi’s air quality is estimated as 13% for November 14 in spite of favourable transport level wind trajectory,” it said.The approaching fresh Western Disturbance exists as a cyclonic circulation over Afghanistan and neighbourhood and is likely to affect northwest India in the next two days, which is likely to increase wind speed at Delhi by November 15, the report stated.

column2: Man consumes poison near police outpost in Ghatampur, critical
column3: KANPUR: A 35-year-old man tried to commit suicide by consuming some poisonous substance outside police outpost in Patara area of Ghatampur against alleged police inaction on Wednesday. The man, identified as Girja Shankar Tiwari of Patara, is said to be in a critical condition. His family claimed that he was under depressed after his neighbours grabbed his land. Inspector Ghatampur RB Singh said, “Earlier, on November 5, Girja and his wife Namrata attempted suicide at ‘tehsil diwas’ at Phoolbagh on November 5. Police had inspected the site after receiving instructions from senior officials, but their allegations wherein they had accused his neighbour of grabbing their land, were found to be false.” “On Wednesday evening, he consumed some poisonous substance and reached the police out-post. He was rushed to a nearby CHC from where he was referred to Lala Lajpat Rai hospital,” he added.

column2: UP: Man gets 10-year imprisonment for physically exploiting daughter
column3: KANPUR: Special judge POCSO court Vijay Raje Sisodia on Thursday convicted a man for physically exploiting his daughter and punished him with 10 years rigorous imprisonment along with a fine of Rs. 22,000. The case has been decided in just one month and three days of hearing. The presiding judge in her order also directed to give 50% of fine amount, i.e., Rs 11,000, to the survivor. The judge in her order further observed that since the accused was being punished under section 3/4 of POCSO Act, therefore, there was no need to punish him under section 376 of IPC. According to special prosecutor Ganga Prasad Yadav, the case has been decided in just one month and three days of hearing. During this period, the prosecution had presented as many as eight witnesses in the court. The police had filed chargesheet on October 10, 2019. He informed TOI that the survivor herself had lodged the first information report (FIR) with the police. The survivor, a resident of a locality under Bithoor police area, in her report had stated that her mother had died in her childhood and her father was exploiting her. He played music in high volume and forcefully stuffed her mouth with cloth before exploiting her under threat to kill her. One day she left the home and went to her maternal aunty at Rawatpur to stay with her, the special prosecutor apprised the court during the trial.

column2: 7.63 lakh to use first corridor of Kanpur Metro by 2024: RITES
column3: KANPUR: Around 7.63 lakh passengers will use the first corridor route of Kanpur Metro between IIT-K and Naubasta by 2024, according to the detailed project report of RITES Ltd. In its report, Rail India Technological and Economic Service (RITES) said Metro would prove to be a useful transport system in future and would be the first choice of Kanpur (west and south) residents. In its report, RITES assumed that by 2031, passenger load would increase to 8.55 lakh and the train would make 7-8 trips to cover the entire route to and fro. In next 10 years, passenger load will be 9.33 lakh and number of trips will go up to 9-10. When Metro will enter the city from Motijheel station in underground tunnel, it will pass close to two heritage sites, Subedar Ka Talab cemetery and Memorial Well Garden. Archeological Survey of India (ASI) had sought explanation from KDA before releasing no objection certificate. KDA had apprised ASI that Subedar Ka Talab site was around 270 metres away from Metro route while Memorial Well Garden was about 180 metres away.

column2: Ghaziabad sees three houses on average getting burgled every day
column3: GHAZIABAD: Be wary about how you lock your house as there are chances that you might be the next target for thieves on the prowl in Ghaziabad. Over the last few years, the district has witnessed a rising number of thefts. According to police data, while 492 cases were reported in 2015 the figure increased to 760 in 2018. However, in 2019, the number skyrocketed. Between January and October this year, 975 cases of theft have already been reported, meaning more than three cases (on average) every day. The police said that this year, they have arrested 55 thieves from the district and sent them to jail. Officials said around 30% of the theft cases were lodged by residents of highrise apartments while the rest of them came from independent houses, colonies and factories. Around 20% of cases were lodged against the house helps or other staffers, the cops said. In the 2,383 cases of theft that were reported between 2015 and 2018, assets worth over Rs 1 crore were stolen. “A number of crimes can be avoided if residents are vigilant and proactive about them. People should install CCTV cameras around their houses and when they go out, they should properly lock their homes,” a senior cop said. In 2018, former SP (city) Shlok Kumar had issued guidelines to apartment owners associations (AOAs) and RWAs to strengthen their security mechanism. Besides, residents also have the option to install anti-theft devices in their flats. Sudhir Kumar Singh, senior superintendent of police (SSP) Ghaziabad, told TOI that the cases of theft have gone down in the last two months as police have arrested several criminals. “Nowadays, it is very easy to enter any house on the pretext being a worker, a house help and more. So police verification is very important for these things. The police verification forms can be filed online,” Singh said. Police said that patrolling, especially during the night has been enhanced, but AOAs and RWAs should come forward and plug the gaps in their society’s security. “I have formed a team at every police station to keep an eye on suspicious persons. The teams also check the vendors and workers who work in highrises,” he added. Among the prominent theft cases in Ghaziabad is the one that took place in August. Four persons, including the driver of a businessman, were arrested for allegedly stealing cash and jewellery worth Rs 1.2 crore from his Kavi Nagar house. The family was out for dinner when the incident took place. Along with cash and jewellery, a licensed pistol of the businessman’s brother was also stolen. ADG (Meerut zone) Prashant Kumar said it was the biggest recovery in the zone in the past two years.

column2: NCR: Three ‘severe’ air days in a row again
column3: For the second time this season, Noida, Greater Noida and Ghaziabad have recorded “severe” pollution levels for at least three days in a row. The last time this happened was after Diwali, when all three cities had recorded AQI around the “severe” levels for almost a week. Track the pollution level in your cityOn Thursday, Noida recorded an AQI of 486. While Greater Noida was at 467, Ghaziabad was at 486. On Wednesday, Noida’s AQI was at 470 and on November 12, it was at 438. In Greater Noida, AQI was 462 and 436 on November 13 and 12 respectively. In Ghaziabad, the AQI was 467 and 451 on November 13 and 12, respectively. In Noida, Rs 3.53 lakh was collected in fines from people who were found violating pollution norms. While carrying out inspections, Noida Authority officials pulled up people who were found violating guidelines laid down by the Environment Pollution (Prevention and Control) Authority. On Thursday, 42 stretches across Noida were cleared of dust with help of machines. An increase in wind speed is forecast by Saturday which is likely to increase ventilation and improve the air quality towards “very poor”, a SAFAR report stated, adding that the air may clear further by Sunday. A Met official said the wind speed on Thursday was very low, 5-6km per hour, which was not allowing dispersion of pollutants.“Partly cloudy sky, too, is adding to the low visibility which was 600-800 metres in Delhi on Thursday. From Friday evening, however, wind speed is expected to pick up. On November 16-17, 20-25km per hour surface winds are expected and the air quality will improve,” the official told TOI. According to the SAFAR experts, the effective stubble fire counts estimated as per satellites are only 69 on November 13 under dense cloudy conditions when satellite capability to detect is questionable. “Considering the PM2.5 deficit, fire emissions appear to be higher and fresh biomass contribution is around 13%. However, due to lack of dispersion and very low mixing height, the sustainable cumulative impact of stubble intrusion on Thursday is estimated to be more than 30%.” According to Met officials, due to an approaching fresh western disturbance and induced cyclonic circulation over southwest Rajasthan, which has started to affect northwest India, scattered rainfall is expected over Punjab. “This is likely to lead to very low fire count during the next two days. The stubble transport level wind direction is not so favourable for intrusion of the crop burning emission into Delhi. Therefore, stubble contribution is estimated to reduce significantly by tomorrow to around 5%,” he said. Earlier on Wednesday, the SC-appointed Environment Pollution (Prevention and Control) Authority wrote to the NCR states, and ordered schools to be shut on Thursday and Friday, and advised people to avoid outdoor exposure and work from home wherever feasible.

column2: NHAI, railways flout graded plan, fined
column3: GHAZIABAD: A private builder and one of the contractors of the National Highway Authority of India (NHAI) were fined Rs 1.01 crore each by the Uttar Pradesh Pollution Control Board (UPPCB) for carrying out construction work despite a blanket ban on such activities by the Supreme Court. The NHAI was also fined Rs 1 lakh for violating the ban. Indian Railways has been fined Rs 11 lakh for carrying out construction work on a railway bridge in Indirapuram. UPPCB is also considering legal action against NHAI. “The penalties have not deterred NHAI from carrying out construction work. On two occasions in the past, we had imposed penalties of Rs 90 lakh and Rs 26 lakh on NHAI but it did not stop its work. We are now exploring ways to prosecute the highway authority,” said UPPCB regional officer Utsav Sharma. During a joint inspection by Sharma and additional district magistrate (city) Shailendra Kumar Singh on Thursday, construction activity was found taking place near Kanawani Pusta road by NHAI’s contractor APCO. A fine of Rs 1 crore was imposed on the infrastructure company for violating the norms of the Graded Response Action Plan (GRAP), while Rs 1 lakh was levied for not following the SC directive on construction. Nine persons working at the site were also detained. The joint team also fined the real estate developer, Apex Group, for carrying out construction work at its project, The Kremlin, in Siddharth Vihar. The district administration on Thursday held an emergency meeting on pollution owing to severe AQI levels of 486. DM Ajay Shankar Pandey ordered an emergency water sprinkling station at the collectorate. ADM (city) Singh has been directed to monitor the station’s activity.

column2: Alternative land not acceptable for mosque in Ayodhya: Jamiat Ulama-e-Hind
column3: LUCKNOW: Jamiat Ulama-e-Hind (JuH), a key Muslim litigant in the Ayodhya title suit, has decided not to accept the 5-acre alternative land for building a mosque as mandated by the Supreme Court. After its working committee meeting in Delhi on Thursday, the Jamiat Ulama-e-Hind said that nothing would be acceptable as an “alternative” to a mosque, be it money or land. In another big decision, JuH did not rule out the possibility of going for a review of the Supreme Court verdict. A five-member fact-finding committee to be headed by its president, Arshad Madani, would seek legal opinion on the issue. Ayodhya verdict: Complete coverage“Two crucial decisions were taken in the working committee meeting. One pertained to the five-acre alternative land for a mosque and the other possibility of filing a review plea. The working committee unanimously decided there can be no ‘badal’ (alternative) of a mosque for anything in the world. Neither money nor land,” said UP chief of JuH, Maulana Ashhad Rashidi, who was present in the meeting. ‘Won’t be right for any Muslim outfit to accept a barter’It won’t be right for any other Muslim organisation to accept a barter,” he said. On the question of the review petition, Maulana Rashidi told TOI, “A committee of five members headed by Arshad Madani will in a couple of days go through court documents and seek legal opinion from JuH’s own lawyers and other Supreme Court lawyers to get a perspective before taking the next step.” Founded in 1919, Jamiat Ulama-e-Hind is one of the most influential and financially sustainable Muslim organisations in the country that completed 100 years in India. It was an active member of the Khilafat movement and freedom struggle, while also opposing Partition. Read this story in Bengali

column2: Lucknow: Missing girl found rotting in thickets
column3: LUCKNOW: The decomposed body of a 10-year-old girl missing for a week was found in the bushes around 200 meters from her home in Gosainganj on Thursday. The body was infested with maggots and her left foot was missing. The parents of the girl had last seen her playing outside their home on November 8. Though family members and neighbours had alleged sexual assault, the autopsy report did not confirm it. The report, however, said that the cause of death was strangulation. The father of the girl owns a meat shop while her three elder brothers are daily wagers. According to police, locals found the body on agricultural land around 7am, but were not able to identify it as it was decomposed. As they knew that a girl was missing from a house in the neighbourhood, they informed the girl’s family. The elder brother (22) of the girl identified the body from her red dress and her height. The left foot of the girl seemed to be eaten away by an animal. The family then informed the police which sent the body for postmortem examination and started scanning the area for evidence and quizzed locals. The elder brother of the girl said, “We do not have enmity with anyone in the village who could have possibly done this to take revenge. I had found an old knife near the body and informed police about it”. In the police complaint on Saturday, the girl’s mother had said that she had seen her playing outside her home around 9am. “Later, locals told us that they saw her crying near a house outside the village. They also said they saw her going towards her house,” said Gosainganj sub-inspector Rajendra Verma. SSP Lucknow Kalanidhi Naithani said, “The postmortem examination report states that the girl died about a week ago due to strangulation. Evidence of sexual assault was not found in the report.”

column2: Who hacked Amethi Police’s handle? Ball in Twitter court
column3: LUCKNOW: Even five days after Amethi Police’s Twitter account was hacked and a warning posted from its handle to a journalist for her tweet on Ayodhya issue, Uttar Pradesh police have failed to trace the culprit. On November 8, the columnist, had tweeted, “Tomorrow is a big day for India. The Babri Masjid, a monument of faith for Indian Muslims was demolished on 6th Dec 1992 by those in power today. It changed my life and a generation of Muslims who were ‘othered’ overnight. I hope my country does not disappoint me tomorrow.” Tomorrow is a big day for India. The Babri Masjid, a monument of faith for Indian muslims was demolished on 6th Dec… https://t.co/4zjR4L9n8O— Rana Ayyub (@RanaAyyub) 1573235936000The tweet was posted around 11.30pm. Hours later, Amethi police, replied to the tweet from its official twitter handle, “You have made a political comment. Delete it immediately, otherwise legal action will be taken against you.” By November 9 morning, both the tweets were deleted (TOI has screen shots of both tweets), while Amethi police had blocked the journalist. When TOI spoke to SP Amethi, Khyati Garg, on November 9, she said the official account of Amethi police was accessed by somebody who posted a warning to a journalist over her tweet. Garg also told TOI that an FIR was lodged under IT Act in the case. When TOI again called up Garg on Thursday for update in the case, the officer said it had been established that the account was hacked and police have sought information from twitter about the login and other details of the person who posted the tweet. Police is yet to get a response from twitter, she said. However, the investigation officer of the case registered at Gauriganj police station, Parshuram Ojha, told TOI that he was not even aware of any such case having been allotted to him. Ojha was initially hesitant to talk to TOI.

column2: Deputy chief minister Dinesh Sharma to monitor UP Board exams on phone
column3: LUCKNOW: After a crackdown on the copying menace in the past two academic sessions in UP Board examination, the government is set to develop a digital system to monitor the process. Under the new system, deputy chief minister Dinesh Sharma will watch the examination process on his smartphone and issue instructions as needed. Sharma, who also has the charge of secondary as well as higher education ministries, would not need to inspect the examination control room of UP Secondary Education Board March 2020 onwards. Through an app, the control room will take live feed from all 8,700 examination centres in the state and that will be streamed on the smartphone of the minister. If any copying attempt is made, immediate action will follow. No state has developed such e-monitoring or a control room for every examination centre through internet and CCTV cameras to check copying, Sharma said. With over 70 lakh students taking the exams in classes X and XII, UPSEB is among the world's largest examination bodies. However, copying mafia and mass copying have tainted the image of the state's board examination. To check the menace, the government has mandated CCTV cameras with internet connection for all examination centres. Any centre not having the facilities would be denied permission for the exams, Sharma said. With the new system in place, the minister hoped that UP Board exams would be free of the copying menace.

column2: BJP eyes GenNext, cuts age cap by 20 years of Uttar Pradesh district chiefs
column3: LUCKNOW: As BJP prepares for its next big internal election exercise for mandal and district presidents in Uttar Pradesh, the party has put a cap on the age of candidates who have applied for the posts this year. While the district chiefs, known as zila adhyaksh, cannot be older than 50 years, which is down by 20 years from the earlier 70, mandal chiefs cannot be older than 40 years. The age bar for internal selection comes for the first time in last two decades in any state for the BJP. BJP has received more than 10,000 forms for 1,915 mandal president posts while the elections for district presidents will begin on November 20. The move comes ahead of UP elections due in 2022. "Seeing the overwhelming response to our membership drive, we have increased 'sangathanamak' (organisational) works. The blocks are further divided into 27,779 sectors which, too, will have party posts to encourage people joining us. And to lead such people, we need younger people to handle the reach of our central schemes and assist our ministers in implementation of such schemes which requires foot patrolling," said UP BJP general secretary Govind Narayan Shukla. The party has also made fields like caste, current responsibility, education and past record mandatory for declaration by members to ensure a comprehensive background check and equal representation of every community in UP. The party said it will also put thrust on increasing women representation. At present, there are only two women district presidents - in Auraiya and Kanpur. For its internal elections, BJP has introduced posts of district presidents in several towns in BSP pocket boroughs of Lalganj and Macchlishahr in Jaunpur.

column2: Cops ran up food bills of Rs 17 lakh, never paid up: Eatery owners
column3: GHAZIABAD: The image of the authoritarian cop throwing his weight around while those around scramble to appease him is an all too familiar one. In Ghaziabad, a group of eatery owners decided to put an end to this narrative of “extortion”. “Around Diwali, the station house officer of every police station in the district held meetings with the owners of restaurants and hotels, telling them that encroachment and parking violations would lead to strong action. Just a day after that, eatery owners started getting calls from police officers in every police station, ordering more than 100 packs of sweets and the same number of dry fruit packs,” said Anil Kumar Gupta, the president of the Association of Food Operators in Ghaziabad. There are 17 police stations in Ghaziabad. The Association of Food Operators alleged every police officer ran up bills of Rs 1-1.5 lakh. Initially, Gupta said, the police officers said that they would pay the bills but when they were asked for the money later, they threw their weight around and threatened them about encroachment and parking. “Then they came with families and friends for lunch and dinner, and never paid those bills either,” he added. For most eatery owners, they said, the sequence of events is not unfamiliar. “Restaurant and hotel owners are harassed by police at every level all the time. They often ask that the food they order be provided free of cost or at half price,” Gupta said. What is not familiar, though, is the scale. And eatery owners decided to resist it this time. The Association of Food Operations has more than 150 members in Ghaziabad. Gupta wrote a letter to the SSP, Ghaziabad, complaining about the harassment he and his colleagues have been subjected to – the letter went viral. It was not just the police, though, he said. “The fire officer did the same, threatening to obstruct the fire NOC for restaurants and hotels should anyone press for payment of dues,” Gupta added. The association has planned to go meet the SSP about this. “If the SSP fails to do anything, I will take the complaint to police in Lucknow and the UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath, asking them to get our bills paid,” Gupta added. But the SSP, Sudhir Kumar Singh, on his part, has already taken note of the complaints. “An investigation will be conducted by a senior officer. We are yet to receive the letter (of complaint) but I have already asked all station house officers to pay up the money immediately or else action will be taken,” he said. Taking the onus of redress upon himself, he added, “The vendors can send bills directly to my office, with the name of the police officer. The bill will be paid by the concerned officer and I will initiate action against the officer.” In fact, from now on, eatery owners can get in touch with the SSP directly in case they face this kind of harassment again. “I have issued a notice to this effect. I will also call the association members and ask for evidence against the errant officers. Otherwise, the officers may end up taking action against them,” he added.
