column2: Government fund sought for Hindon flights to three UP cities
column3: GHAZIABAD: The district administration plans to seek Viability Gap Funding (VGF) from the UP government for starting flights from Hindon to Prayagraj, Lucknow and Varanasi airports as these routes do not fall under the regional connectivity scheme (RCS). The district magistrate has sought a proposal from Indigo, Heritage Aviation and Star Air in this regard. Currently, the Star Air flights to and from Hubballi in Karnataka are the only ones operating out of Hindon airport. Under the RCS scheme, a certain amount of VGF, or financial support, is provided to participating carriers to meet the gap, if any, between the cost of operations and expected revenues on the routes. District magistrate Ajay Shankar Pandey said the Airport Authority of India (AAI) has informed the administration that if any airline wants to start flights to these places, it will have to seek permission from Hindon Air Force base and Delhi International Airport Limited (DIAL). If the state government agrees to provide 100% VGF, these routes could be included in the next round of bidding, he added. Pandey said, “The airports of Lucknow, Allahabad (Prayagraj) and Varanasi do not fall under the purview of the regional connectivity scheme, Udan (Ude Desh ka Aam Nagrik), so only commercial flights could be allowed to operate at these places. During a meeting, I sought a proposal from Indigo, Heritage Aviation and Star Air for the flight service to the three UP districts.” “Afterwards, I will write to the state government for 100% VGF. In the next step, permission from Hindon Air Force base and DIAL will be required by the airline,” he added. The Hindon airport started functioning last month, when Heritage Airlines started a six-day flight service to Pithoragarh in Uttarakhand. But flight operations were suspended twice. They will now resume from November 16. Pandey said the airlines had informed that a periodical inspection of the aircraft has been completed and flights can be operated without any interruption for the next four months. Heritage Aviation officials have also been asked to explore the feasibility of starting services to Gulbarga in Karnataka and Jamnagar in Gujarat. The proposal is in the preliminary stage, the DM said.

column2: Mukkabaaz Viineet Kumar gets sporty with college kids in Lucknow
column3: Actor Viineet Kumar of 'Mukkabaaz' fame, who is shooting in Lucknow for an untitled Hindi film, had some fun moments when he played cricket with the students of a college where he was shooting. Viineet had got some time between shots and spotted a few students of the college playing cricket. With time at hand, the 'Saand Ki Aankh' actor decided to join them for a game. The youngsters were delighted to have a Bollywood star playing with them and happily let Viineet take the bat and call the shots, literally. Sharing his experience of playing with the kids, Viineet says, "It was a great experience playing cricket, especially with the students." Viineet playing cricket with college kids during a break from his shooting schedule (BCCL)  Viineet playing cricket with college kids during a break from his shooting schedule (BCCL)  Viineet adds, “The place where we are shooting in Lucknow has a management college and I saw students playing there. I would see them play everyday and would want to play but there was just no time between the shots. In fact, the students would also invite me to join them in the game but time hi nahi milta tha. But then yesterday, I got some time and went to play a few shots. It was nice spending time with them." The Gold and Gangs of Wasseypur actor himself happens to be a national level basketball player and has a lot of interest in sports. "Cricket is not just a game, it's a passion. People are very emotional about cricket and even I am very fond of cricket. I used to play cricket before I started playing basketball. My brother introduced me to basketball otherwise I was always a cricket person. No doubt, I have a special connection with the game," he says as he heads off for another shot. Viineet Kumar even hurt himself during the game (BCCL) Viineet Kumar even hurt himself during the game (BCCL) Viineet is shooting in Lucknow for the Hindi remake of the hit Tamil film Tiruttu Payale 2 which is being directed by Susi Ganeshan. The film also stars Uravashi Rautela, Miss Diva 2015- Miss Universe India, opposite him.

column2: A dog’s day all the way in Lucknow
column3: Labradors, Golden Retrievers, Miniature Pinchers, Rampur Hound and various other breeds of dogs participated in the 83rd, 84th & 85th Championship dog show, organized by the Oudh Kennel Club in the city, recently. Nearly dogs from all across the country participated in the two-day show held at the Reserve Police Lines in Mahanagar. Judged by T Preetham, Radzuik Sviattana and Tatasiana, who came all the way from Belarus with Gauri Nagalkor, the pooches put their best foot forward at the Labrador, Rottweiler and German Shepherd speciality show. (L) Dinkar Pratap Singh flaunts the trophy won by his lab Luke on day 1 (R) CUDDLESOME: Jini with Vishhna, the American Cocker Spaniel (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Dinkar Pratap Singh flaunts the trophy won by his lab Luke on day 1 (R) CUDDLESOME: Jini with Vishhna, the American Cocker Spaniel (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) KK Trivedi, Vice Chairman Kennel Club of India (KCI) and CV Sudarshan, Secretary of KCI, who came from Chennai, especially for the show, graced the event which was ably managed by Shashank Trivedi, the show Secretary and Alop Ghosh. Satya Narayan Sabat, DIG, UP Police, who was the Chief Guest of the show, said, “There should be cohabitation in maintaining peace between pets and humans.’’ (L) My dog’s the best: Dipika Srivastava with Nexa, a German Shepherd (R) Madhuri with her dog Mogli (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) My dog’s the best: Dipika Srivastava with Nexa, a German Shepherd (R) Madhuri with her dog Mogli (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Even though the weather was hot and humid, the enthusiasm was at its peak with dogs barking, growling and some even running with their handlers screaming after them. A few of them decked up for the occasion too with hair bands, clips, ribbons, skirts, dressed, coats and even sun glasses in place and posing for the perfect shots. Some just put their nose in the air as they were preened by their owners and handlers in AC vehicles. (L) I’m scared! Austil the Great Dane seems to be telling his handler (R) STAND BY ME: Nitin Kumar with Bruno, a Bull Mastiff (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) I’m scared! Austil the Great Dane seems to be telling his handler (R) STAND BY ME: Nitin Kumar with Bruno, a Bull Mastiff (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)  Taru Gupta, who came for the first time in a dog show, said ‘’It’s so great to see so many breeds of dogs at one place!” Enakshi Chandel, known for her Labrador Retrievers was seen handling her pets while Irshad Khan tended to his Rampur Hounds. With winners being declared on both days, the first day winner was Luke the Labrador owned by Dinkar Pratap Singh, while the winner on day-two was Helada Hills Absolute a Cocker Spaniel who was declared as Best in Show, owned by Pallav Shah. The second best was Red American National Hero a Beagle owned by Palash Ghosh while German Shepherd Gas Di Casa Palombs owned by Lucknowite Siddharth Sharma stood third Best in Show. (L) Rakhi Gupta, Loyala, Breed- Shitzu (R) Dr Dinesh Sharma (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Rakhi Gupta, Loyala, Breed- Shitzu (R) Dr Dinesh Sharma (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Dr Dinesh Sharma, the Deputy Chief Minister of Uttar Pradesh, who was the Chief Guest on the second and final day, distributed the prize to the winners. — Swarnima Upadhyaya (L) Siddharth Sharma showing off Visa Of Deckburg, a German Shepherd (R) T Preetham (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Siddharth Sharma showing off Visa Of Deckburg, a German Shepherd (R) T Preetham (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Tanvi with her pet Barney, the Basset Hound (R) Main Hoon Rambo (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Tanvi with her pet Barney, the Basset Hound (R) Main Hoon Rambo (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Judges Svirteans Radziuk and Tatsiana Ramanouskaya (R) Alop Ghosh (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Judges Svirteans Radziuk and Tatsiana Ramanouskaya (R) Alop Ghosh (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) WHO’S THE PRETTIER OF US TWO? Juli & Rima (R) I’M ALL EARS! Whisky, Miniature Pinscher (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) WHO’S THE PRETTIER OF US TWO? Juli & Rima (R) I’M ALL EARS! Whisky, Miniature Pinscher (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Satya Narayan Sabat (L) and CV Sudarshan (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Satya Narayan Sabat (L) and CV Sudarshan (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) QUITE A BULLY: Lucky, a Pakistani Bully (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) QUITE A BULLY: Lucky, a Pakistani Bully (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Lissome Lass: Ujaala, the Rampur Hound (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Lissome Lass: Ujaala, the Rampur Hound (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) KK Trivedi (R) Deep Arya with his pooch Tin Tin (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) KK Trivedi (R) Deep Arya with his pooch Tin Tin (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Jelly, the Iguana showing its true colours (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Jelly, the Iguana showing its true colours (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Main Pyaasa Hoon: Deepak, with Dio a Rottwieler (R) Gauri Nargolkar (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Main Pyaasa Hoon: Deepak, with Dio a Rottwieler (R) Gauri Nargolkar (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Irshad Khan with his Rampur Hound (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Irshad Khan with his Rampur Hound (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Enakshi Chandel with her winner Labradors (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Enakshi Chandel with her winner Labradors (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Lersie the La Lico Persian Cat was the centre of attraction at the event (R) AAKNHON-AANKHON MEIN: Darshita Srivastava & Fanny her Pomeranian (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Lersie the La Lico Persian Cat was the centre of attraction at the event (R) AAKNHON-AANKHON MEIN: Darshita Srivastava & Fanny her Pomeranian (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

column2: Rape, murder accused arrested after encounter
column3: KANPUR: A rape-cum-murder accused was on Friday morning injured in an exchange of fire with police at national highway -2 near Kurusena village in Etawah district. “Sachin Kumar Jatav, accused in rape-cum-murder of a nine-year-old a few days ago in Jaswantnagar area, was surrounded by police teams of Jaswant Nagar police station and Crime branch after which he started firing,” SSP Etawah Santosh Kumar Mishra said. In the exchange of fire, accused Sachin was hit by bullets. The accused suffered injuries in his leg in the encounter, he said. The accused has been admitted to a hospital and placed under arrest, the police said, adding a pistol and cartridges were seized from him. (The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

column2: Kanpur welcomes Metro, elated to get hassle-free ride
column3: KANPUR: Kanpurites are elated over the commencement of Metro construction work as two years from now Kanpur Metro train will start chugging on the 8.8 km route between IIT-Kanpur and Motijheel. The residents would be able to commute hassle-free on the stretch between the IIT and Motijheel, and after 2021, they would be able to travel up to Naubasta when the second leg of the first corridor of Kanpur Metro would get completed. Reacting to the development, Ranveer Singh of Naubasta area said that the Metro would give the city a boost in terms of infrastructural development. He said he is very happy that after a few years from now, Metro train facility would be available near his house. “One of the Metro stations will be built close to my house. It will be a win-win situation for me and the people of my locality,” he added. Chander, a housewife and a resident of Saket Nagar, also expressed her happiness over the commencement of Metro work. She said that Kanpur too would be a ‘Metro’ city like Lucknow, Delhi and Bengaluru where she had travelled during her stay in those cities. “The Metro authorities should ensure that the work is completed in the stipulated time. The project should not be allowed to linger or getting extended beyond the set time frame otherwise it would be of no use. As promised by the CM, the project should be ready by November 2021,” she added. Students of CSJM University, National Sugar Institute and IIT-Kanpur are a bit concerned as the Metro construction work would cause massive jams. “Metro work would certainly cause severe traffic snarls in the area. Areas such as Kalyanpur, which already bears the brunt of heavy traffic influx, would be definitely hit. But as it is said ‘no pain, no gain, it is not possible that the city gets Metro service without any disruption. , said Meenu, a student of CSJM University.

column2: SP stages stir against ‘relaunch’ of Metro project
column3: KANPUR: Samajwadi Party (SP) workers on Friday held a protest against launch of Metro Rail Project at the gates of IIT-Kanpur. They held a protest at Ramadevi crossing and raised slogans, claiming that while the foundation stone laying ceremony of Kanpur Metro had been done in 2016 by SP chief and then CM Akhilesh Yadav, what was the need of relaunching the Metro project again. They said that the relaunching of the project was a waste of public money. They claimed that the BJP government had just changed the name of the public schemes launched by Akhilesh Yadav and relaunched them. On Thursday, SP workers had given a memorandum addressed to Governor Anandiben Patel to the city magistrate stating the same. The police did not allow the SP workers to march ahead.

column2: 26 years ago, former Ram Lalla priest was shot dead
column3: LUCKNOW: Exactly 26 years ago on this day, Baba Lal Das, the former chief priest of Ram Janmabhoomi temple, who articulated the view that the Ram mandir issue should be settled locally instead of being made a national political issue, was murdered at his village Ranipur Chaltar, 20 km from Ayodhya. A witness in the Babri Masjid demolition case and hailed as a beacon of peace between Hindus and Muslims of Faizabad and Ayodhya, the murder of Baba Lal Das was suspected by many as political foul play. However, a CBI probe held that it was the result of a land dispute. “Baba Lal Das was a revolutionary seer. He blasted those who used the Ram temple issue politically,” said Yugal Kishore Shastri, mahant of the ancient Saryu Kunj temple in Ayodhya, a former district general secretary of VHP. Das was the court-appointed chief priest of the Ram Lalla idol inside the Babri Masjid from 1983. He was removed from the post in March 1992 on allegations of corruption. He was shot on November 16, 1993 at his village in Basti district and the murder was claimed to be over land dispute. Seers and residents of Ayodhya approached both the then Prime Minister PV Narasimha Rao and then state chief minister Mulayam Singh Yadav for CBI investigation. The CBI took over the case in 1994 and chargesheeted two for murder over land. One of the accused was sentenced to life imprisonment. “Police records in the case had found involvement of Baba Lal Das’s son in the case. He was the one who had filed the FIR and had named an accused, but he was also put under CBI investigation,” a senior intelligence officer privy to the case told TOI. Shastri, who had a sweet-sour relationship with Baba Lal Das, said the temple priest had a ‘leftist’ ideology and had also kept the photograph of freedom fighter Bhagat Singh with him inside the central dome of the Babri Masjid. “He had held a press meet in Ayodhya as the then Ram Lalla priest dissuading LK Advani from embarking on his Rath Yatra," Shastri added. “He was a CBI witness in the Babri Masjid demolition case and had spoken against the demolition publicly on that day too,” said M Narayanan, retired CBI official who was the CBI SP at the time of the case. “But the murder was a different angle. Even his family was taken under the ambit of suspicion and one accused was given a life term. The reason was found to be land dispute and nothing else,” he added.

column2: The nine faculty gems of Lucknow University
column3: LUCKNOW: Since the very inception of its extraordinary academic journey, the University of Lucknow has been blessed with mentors of international standing. Its members of faculty have been the brain behind reputable research cradles and were among first Indians to be conferred foreign degrees. Here are the navratna (nine gems) to whom LU owes its excellence Birbal SahniAn eminent scientist from Cambridge, England, Sahni took charge of the botany department as its first professor at the age of 30 in 1921. He was instrumental in the birth of the geology department in 1942. Four years later, he gifted India its first paleo-botanical research institute — Birbal Sahni Institute of Paleobotany (LU) — the foundation stone of which was laid by Jawaharlal Nehru. The University of Cambridge recognised his research by conferring on him doctorate of science (Sc.D) in 1929. He taught at LU till his death in 1949. Radhakamal MukerjeeRecipient of India’s third highest civilian honour Padma Bhushan in 1962, social scientist Radhakamal was associated with several economic commissions of the country. The professor of sociology was vice-chancellor of LU from 1955 to 1958. He is among five Indian thinkers — including BR Ambedkar and Mahatma Gandhi — whom candidates of UGC-NET 2019 will have to study. The national entrance is taken by those aspiring to lecture in colleges and universities. Radha Kumud MukherjeeA renowned historian, Radha Kumud taught in Benares and Mysore before joining LU in 1921. Before his retirement in 1944, he raised a fund of over Rs 50,000 for history scholarship. After retirement, he was nominated member of Rajya Sabha for a short duration. For his contribution to public affairs, he was awarded Padma Bhushan in 1957. Radha Kumud has nearly a dozen books to his credit. KA Subramania IyerAccording to SOAS University of London’s official website, Iyer was one of its first students, enrolling in the Sanskrit and Pali programme in 1917 at the then School of Oriental Studies. He also studied in Paris under eminent sinologist and Indologist Sylvain Levi. After a master’s degree from London, Iyer founded the department of Sanskrit and Prakrit languages at LU, and was its first head. He introduced courses in Vedic literature, among others, and was also a part-time French teacher. Nirmal Kumar SidhantaWith a degree from Cambridge, Bengali scholar Nirmal Kumar joined LU in 1921 as a reader and was elevated to a professor’s post in five years. He was the first Indian to become the head of English and modern European languages department. He was known for his literary genius and close association with Rabindranath Tagore. He left LU in 1951 to become secretary of Radhakrishnan Commission, the first commission on education in independent India. He went on to become vice-chancellor of Calcutta University and Delhi University, besides member of Union Public Service Commission. Wali MohammadSpecialising in spectroscopy, magneto-optics and wireless operations, Wali Mohammad took over as the first head of LU’s physics department in 1921. He did research on the hyperfine structure of spectral lines with a Littrow mounting spectrograph, a rare acquisition for an Indian university at that time. He was the president of the All India Library Association and of the physics and mathematics section of Indian Science Congress. KN BahlIn November 1938, Bahl became the first Indian to receive a D.Phil from the University of Oxford. After a DSc from Punjab University in 1919, he went to Oxford and worked there for two years as an advanced student to bag the degree. He served as zoology professor in Agra, Allahabad and then at LU. RU SinghIn the 1950s, a number of universities took steps to restructure law courses by introducing full-time faculty and shedding archaic instructions. Singh, then dean of LU, was among the architects along with professor Maurice Gawyer, then Chief Justice of India. The faculty of law at LU has been a pioneering legal institution of India established in 1921. Singh held the office of dean till 1956. He also structured the law school at BHU and Delhi University. He holds the distinction of drafting the Constitution of Nepal as well. Masood Hasan RizviA researcher, an expert on manuscript and renowned critic-writer of his time, Rizvi was the head of Persian department at LU Lucknow from 1930 to 1954. Many reputable national and international journals have dedicated special issues on his contribution to literature. He won the prestigious Sahitya Akademi Award in 1960; got a lifetime certificate of honour from the President of India in 1969; and was conferred Padma Shri in 1970. The UP government too feted him for his contribution to literature in 1972.

column2: Railway technician fired at by colleague over office rivalry in Lucknow
column3: LUCKNOW: In yet another incident of firing over petty dispute in the city, a railway technician was injured when his colleague fired at him with an illegal countrymade pistol at the busy Om Nagar crossing in Alambagh on Friday evening. The accused escaped unchallenged, while the victim is undergoing treatment at KGMU Trauma Centre. This is the 11th case in the city this year where firing took place at the drop of a hat. Country-made illegal pistols were used in most of the cases. According to police, both the victim Girija Singh (38) and accused Vishnu Pratap Singh (32) work at the Carriage & Wagon workshop (CWW) of Indian Railways in Alambagh and have an old rivalry over dominance in office. In the afternoon, they had an argument in the office when Vishnu accused Girija of unnecessary staring at him. Girija replied that he was simply looking at him. CO Alambagh Lal Pratap Singh, said that the firing incident occurred in the evening at around 5.15pm when Girija was going to the market. He had barely walked 200 metres from his house when Vishnu intercepted him at Om Nagar crossing and picked up a fight over the same issue which happened in the office. The arguments soon snowballed into fisticuffs and in a fit of rage, Vishnu, who is also a distant relative of the victim, pulled out a .12 bore country-made gun and shot at Girja and fled. The pellets hit Girija on the right arm. Locals rushed him to hospital and informed police.

column2: Dengue Menace: Health department to search for suspected cases in 200m radius of every positive patient
column3: LUCKNOW: Alarmed over surfacing of dengue cases despite change in weather and temperature pattern, the UP government decided to intensify the vector control activities on Friday. Under this, district health and municipal offices will have to visit the neighbourhood of every new dengue positive case. This means, the health staff will search for suspected patients in the vicinity of every new dengue positive case. Giving instructions to this effect in a review of dengue situation in the state, chief secretary RK Tewari said: “Active case search and vector control activities, including fogging and anti-larval spraying, must be conducted in 200 metre radius of every new patient.” To note, more than 7,000 dengue cases have been reported in the state this year. Against the anticipated decline post Diwali, the number of dengue cases has not come down. In Lucknow alone, over 375 cases have surfaced since November 1 which has worried academicians and health experts. In the previous years, dengue cases recorded a decline after the virus subsided due to temperature and humidity change that arrives with Diwali. The chief secretary also directed nomination of a teacher in every school for creating awareness on dengue and vector-borne diseases during morning assemblies.

column2: UP ATS picks up former Army officer from Hyderabad in Kushinagar mosque blast
column3: LUCKNOW/HYDERABAD/GORAKHPUR: Three days after stacked explosives blew up in a mosque in Kushinagar district of Uttar Pradesh, a former Major with the Indian Army, Dr Ashfaq Alam, was picked up from Hyderabad Old City by UP Anti-Terrorist Squad (UPATS) and flown to Lucknow on Friday, en route to Kushinagar for interrogation. The blast took place in Bairagi Patti village under Turk Patti police station area of the district on Monday. The doctor was interrogated before being taken into custody late Friday, taking the arrest count to six. Samples from the blast site have been sent to Agra forensic lab for zeroing in on nature of explosives. Dr Alam served in the Army Medical Corps till 2017 before taking voluntary retirement to prepare for civil services examination. He was picked up around 9am on Thursday in a joint operation of UPATS and Counter-Intelligence, Telangana police from his East Janaki Nagar residence in Golconda area of Hyderabad. Dr Alam, who was present in Kushinagar at the time of blast, is accused of conniving with five other accused for tampering with evidence and criminal conspiracy among other charges. The doctor is the grandson of one of the key accused, Haji Qutubuddin, a resident of the village who would frequent the mosque to offer namaz. Qutubuddin is charged with stashing explosives in the bag. Alam’s wife too is a doctor in the Army and is posted in Hyderabad. “Dr Alam called up police about an explosion in a mosque, citing short-circuit in the invertor’s battery. When police arrived at the spot, the doctor had fled along with his grandfather, Haji Qutubuddin,” said additional director-general of police (ATS) Dhruva Kant Thakur. UP Police, who were on high alert in the aftermath of the Ayodhya verdict, swiftly arrested four people, including the mosque’s cleric, Azimuddin, a resident of West Bengal. During interrogation of the accused, Dr Alam’s antecedents were confirmed and a team was quickly dispatched to Hyderabad to nab him. ATS officials privy to the probe said, Dr Alam came to his hometown, Kushinagar, to attend a relative’s wedding on November 8. Talking to TOI, additional director-general of police, ATS, Thakur, said, “Dr Alam was unable to give a convincing reply on why he fled the blast site after calling police. He was confronted with the other four accused during quizzing. Cleric Azimuddin, who was brought from Bengal at a salary of Rs 6,000 to serve as the muezzin, kept changing his statements. First, he said the bag with explosives was kept in the mosque even before he became imam. Later, he blamed Qutubuddin for keeping the bag.” Besides cleric Azimuddin, Dr Alam and his grandfather Haji Qutubuddin, three others in police net include Javed Ansari, Izhar and Ashiq Ansari. They have been booked for rioting, defiling place of worship with intent to insult religion, criminal conspiracy and under the Explosives Act. Another accused, Salauddin Ansari aka Munna is on the run.

column2: After Ayodhya, thrust on 5-star hotels in Sarnath and Kushinagar
column3: LUCKNOW: At a time when SC has cleared the way for construction of the Ram Temple following the order on title dispute in Ayodhya, luxury hotel groups across India have sought Centre’s assistance in exploring UP’s Buddhist sites to tap into tourists from neighbouring South Asian countries. Three big five star hotels, including one led by the Oberoi Group have made a dash to Niti Ayog, which on Friday approached UP government to help the firms promote tourism around Sarnath and Kushinagar. The government roped in UP tourism department hours after Niti Ayog vice-chairman Rajiv Kumar, who on a visit to meet UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath asked for the development of Buddhist circuit. The Oberoi Group wants to set up its hotel on a minimum 20-acre land in Sarnath, where Gautam Buddha is believed to have delivered his first sermon apart from the Four Noble Truths, the middle path and eightfold path. “We have conveyed the request for Sarnath to Varanasi DM. Besides, we also have a landbank in Kushinagar, where Buddha attained parinirvana after his death. Since we have shelved the Maitreyi plan, we have a pool of 200 acres to assist any potential hospitality firm willing to set up shop here,” said principal secretary (culture) Jitendra Kumar. The government sources said that private hospitality firms also insist that they want to tap South Asian tourist influx into UP via Nepal border, saying casino shops and resorts by Chinese, Myanmar and Japanese companies on the borders have always been popular vacation spots among tourists, but lack of accomodation in the Hindi heartland was a deterrent to the development of tourism industry. The UP government may also approach Nepal government to seek a common visa entry point at Lumbini for Buddhist pilgrims. Government officials said that an international airport is already coming up at Siddarth Nagar district in UP, 20 km from Lumbini. At present, Lucknow, Varanasi, Agra and Noida are the only districts where five star hotels exist.

column2: 546 Ayodhya mosques see 1st Friday prayers after SC verdict
column3: LUCKNOW: The first Friday prayers in Ayodhya since the SC’s verdict in the Ram Janmabhoomi-Babri Masjid title suit went off peacefully as a 6,500-strong police contingent watched over 546 mosques spread across the city. “The WhatsApp groups we had formed as part of our initiative to maintain peace in the run-up to the verdict will continue to operate like before. The message of harmony has helped build a convivial atmosphere among the people here,” Ayodhya SSP Ashish Tiwari said. Police personnel deployed outside mosques were seen greeting and shaking hands with kids stepping out after prayers. In villages, cops interacted with locals over meals and tea before and after the three rounds of prayers. Ayodhya police are engaging in peace efforts with members of 21 outfits representing Hindu and Muslim communities.

column2: 2012 batch KGMU intern sexually harasses junior in library, booked
column3: LUCKNOW: An MBBS intern of 2012 batch in King George's Medical University (KGMU) was booked on charges of sexually harassing a junior in the central library of the university. Though the incident took place on Tuesday, the FIR was lodged by the university chief proctor on Thursday. This is the third incident of harassment or violence involving KGMU students in which a complaint with the police was lodged in this academic session so far. According to the FIR, the accused harassed a group of juniors in the 24-hour central library study hall at around 9.40pm on Tuesday by misbehaving with them and throwing away their belongings. One of the juniors, a 2014 batch girl student, alleged that the accused also touched her inappropriately. She said that the accused first made an attempt to talk to her but when she refused, he touched her with wrong intentions. The group then informed senior faculty members and chief proctor. They also claimed that the accused had harassed them and other batch mates earlier as well. The junior students also lodged a written complaint with the chief proctor, who later registered an FIR. Chief proctor RS Kushwaha said, "Both female and the male students complained about how the accused harassed or assaulted them. Since the behaviour of the accused person was inappropriate, we have lodged the complaint with the police who will investigate the case and based on their findings, will take necessary action. The accused is currently working in the forensic department and his entry in hostels and library has been barred." "The librarian has been instructed to allow entry to only those who have a valid pass," he added. SHO, Chowk, Pankaj Singh said, "We are recording the statements of the eyewitness of the incidents and the victim, following which we will take action against the accused." (The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

column2: Lucknow Metro move: E-scooters on rent to ferry you to stations for Re 1 /minute
column3: LUCKNOW: The Lucknow Metro Rail Corporation (LMRC) is in talks with a Bangalore-based private company for providing e-scooters as feeder service for Metro in the city on the lines of Bengaluru, Delhi, Pune, Mumbai and Bhubaneswar. According to company’s officials, the scooters have a top speed of 25km/hour and no license and helmet is required to drive them. If approved, commuters may be able to take e-scooter on rent at a minimal cost of Re 1 per minute. To use this service, one will have to download the app from Play Store and locate the nearest scooter through GPS. Once located, the user will have to pay Rs250 refundable fee to get QR code to unlock the vehicle. After the service is availed, the app will calculate the amount and display the bill. Once the payment is made through e-wallet, the refundable fee will be deposited back into the user’s account. Commuters may take the scooter from nearest location from house to the Metro station. Users will have to park the scooter in parking lot or an appropriate place on the roadside if parking space is not available. Managing director, UPMRC, Kumar Keshav said Lucknow Metro has approached the company and is negotiating terms and conditions. “If all goes well, we will sign a contract in next 2-3 months,” he said. Co-founder of the company RK Mishra said, “ Once fully charged, these lithium-powered scooters can run up to 6,000 km.”

column2: UP: Local neta's Facebook account hacked
column3: LUCKNOW: A man claiming to be associated with a political party on Friday alleged that hackers targeted his Facebook account and uploaded obscene content on it. Lodging a complaint with Chowk police, Ameel Shamsi of Johri Mohalla claimed that around 1.45pm someone hacked his Facebook account and posted inappropriate content on it. Shamsi said he came to know about the breach when his friends and party colleagues started calling him up to express their anguish. "Initially, I could not understand what went wrong but later found that my social media account has been hacked. I immediately reported the matter to cyber cell of Lucknow police," he added. Ex-MLA gets threat call: Former MLA and BJP leader Brijesh Mishra Saurabh lodged a complaint with Mahanagar police claiming that he received a call from a satellite phone registered in Nigeria wherein the caller, who spoke in Hindi and Urdu, threatened to kill him. Saurabh said he received a similar call about 20 days ago. Police have lodged a case.

column2: Truck hits bike, woman killed
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 23-year-old woman died and her husband was critically injured when the bike they were riding was hit allegedly by an Army truck on Hapur road in Kavi Nagar on Friday. The body was sent for an autopsy and reports are awaited. The woman Beena’s husband Deepak Tomar (27), who works with a private company in Ghaziabad, is battling for life in a private hospital. The couple stayed in Pilkhuwa. Anil Shahi, the SHO of Kavi Nagar police station said, “Initial investigation revealed that the truck was travelling fast (possibly over 60kmph), which is beyond the permissible limit. It hit the bike while trying to overtake a four-wheeler.” The truck driver, who is currently absconding, has been booked for rash driving, mischief causing damage and death by negligence.

column2: Ghaziabad: Girl students to be in-charge of police stations for a day
column3: GHAZIABAD: Police in Ghaziabad will soon start an initiative in which it will give charge of a police station to a schoolgirl for a day. The police department is drawing up the criteria for selection of students for this. The move came after the Federation of apartment owners’ association (AOA) wrote to Uttar Pradesh DGP to invest in building a friendly relationship between police and women citizen. “The aim of this movement is to help women students file any complaint of crime against them without fear of police,” a member of the AOA federation said. Federation members also said that usually girls fear to report any crime to the police due to which many crimes go unreported. FedAOA founder Alok Kumar said, “I am suggesting the police to conduct a quiz and debate programmes in schools, the winner of which will be appointed as in-charge of a police station for a day.” “A few girl students will be selected from across all the schools of the district on a set of criteria and they will be given training on policing in the state. Apart from this, they will also be educated on crime against women and actions to be taken in such cases. Once the training is completed, a counselling session will be done by senior police officers who will then appoint the students as in-charge of a police station for one day,” Kumar added. The police department is also working on the criteria on which the students will be selected. SP (city) Manish Kumar Mishra said, “We are hoping to plan out the criteria for selection within a week and start this program by the end of November.”

column2: Passengers to zip between Delhi & Meerut in 55 minutes
column3: LUCKNOW: As Uttar Pradesh is set to become the first state to get rapid rail transport system (RRTS), the 82-km Delhi-Ghaziabad-Meerut corridor will be the first to become operational. Construction on 17-km section between Sahibabad and Duhai has started which will become operational by March 2023, while commercial operations on the entire stretch will commence by 2025. A presentation on RRTS was made at the 12th edition of Urban Mobility India conference and expo held in Lucknow on Friday. Chief public relations officer, National Capital Region Transport Corporation (NCRTC), Sudhir Kumar Sharma said: “The corridor will be the key to new economic opportunities for sustainable economic development of NCR.” The corridor will have 24 stations – either elevated or underground – originating from Sarai Kale Khan RRTS station in Delhi and ending at Modipuram in Meerut. En route, it will cross Yamuna and Hindon rivers, railway tracks, Eastern Peripheral Expressway (EPE) and pass through dense areas of Delhi, Ghaziabad and Meerut. The distance between the two ends will be covered in 55 minutes and daily ridership is expected to be more than 8 lakh passengers. While the design speed of the train is 180kmph, the operational speed is 160kmph. Infrastructure will be designed for nine-coach trains which will be available every 5-10 minutes. Train services will not be affected even during extreme weather conditions. Implementation of Delhi-Ghaziabad-Meerut RRTS Corridor is expected to shift the modal share in favour of public transport from 37% to 63% in the region. The train will have coaches for ladies and business class to encourage passengers to leave personal vehicles and use public transport. All three corridors of Phase-1 will converge at Sarai Kale Khan – the other two being Delhi-Gurugram-SNBAlwar and Delhi-Panipat – enabling commuters to travel end-to-end from one corridor to another without having to change the train. Stations will be integrated with airports, railway stations, inter-state bus terminus, and Delhi Metro stations, wherever possible. State government has decided to run intra-city services within Meerut North-South region on RRTS network thereby dropping the proposed North-South Metro corridor. This will result in an estimated saving of Rs 6,300 crore.

column2: Air pollution: NCR towns don’t have information on many sources
column3: NEW DELHI: IIT Delhi started providing Central Pollution Control Board with pollution projections and possible measures Delhi’s civic bodies could undertake every fortnight from September. These so-called ‘biweekly plans’, however, pertained only to the capital because gaps in emissions inventory data from various sources prevented the extension of the exercise to most other NCR cities. IIT Delhi, has therefore, requested CPCB to set up an emissions inventory cell to provide accurate and updated data related to each source of pollution across NCR. Harsha Kota, assistant professor of civil engineering at IIT Delhi, who specialises in developing air quality models, explained that the plans forecast the levels of pollution in the coming fortnight and the steps to be taken to tackle the problem. However, she told TOI, “If we don’t have the complete data from the emissions inventory, we will be unable to analyse information effectively or forecast the top contributing source for the fortnight.” IIT Delhi currently uses the emissions inventory data of the Union ministry of earth sciences. But to provide CPCB with plans for NCR cities every fortnight, Kota said a dedicated cell was necessary to fill the gaps in existing information. “The biweekly forecasts are in their first year, and the learnings from this can be utilised to make the preventive system more robust,” Kota said. Plans will be made for Sonipat and Faridabad in Haryana and Ghaziabad in UP, but Mukesh Khare, professor at IIT-D, told TOI that the aim was to eventually provide bi-weekly plans for seven cities in Punjab as well. “The biweekly plans state very clearly what steps need to be taken to curb pollution of each type. We need to improve the coordination among the agencies involved. Once we have better data, we can provide accurate forecasts for Noida, Gurugram, Faridabad and other NCR locations,” said Khare. CPCB officials said it would take some time to set up a dedicated data cell. “The bi-weekly plan for Delhi already covers nearby locations in NCR, but we can certainly expand on this,” an official said. CPCB also intends to use its teams on the ground to provide inputs to IIT-D for the biweekly plans. “We are working on how this can be incorporated in the whole exercise,” the official added. In the bi-weekly plan for Delhi for November 1 to 15, IIT-D had identified unpaved roads as a major pollution source in the seven critical pollution areas of Mayapuri, Wazirpur and Okhla in Delhi, Udyog Vihar in Gurugram, Sahibabad in Ghaziabad and two areas in Faridabad.

column2: Initially, I was scared of Bollywood: Anupriya Goenka
column3: Actress and model Anupriya Goenka of War fame was in Lucknow for a while enroute Ayodhya for personal commitments. Making most of her time in the city, she visited a café run by acid attack survivors. Having learned from the internet about the café, she spent quite some time with them and heard the stories of the acid attack survivors, patiently. "I feel so good after meeting these girls. These acid attack survivors are heroes in real sense. They are so loving and caring, they also showed me a photo album which had photos of different survivors and told the heart-wrenching stories behind them," she shared. During her recent visit to the city actress Anupriya Goenka spent some time with the acidattack survivors who run a cafe in Gomti Nagar (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) During her recent visit to the city actress Anupriya Goenka spent some time with the acid attack survivors who run a cafe in Gomti Nagar (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) The Padmaavat actress also talked about what hurt her the most during her visit there. "The saddest part is that the place (cafe) which is not only a shelter for them but also their source of livelihood and a place where they can feel safe and support each other, is also in danger because they are being asked to vacate the place by the government and a court case is going on for it. I am surprised that we are living in a world like this today where these kinds of things are happening instead of them being given all the support possible. They are not only fighting to stop the acid attacks, they are also being forced to fight for their survival. I really hope we can do something about them," urged Anupriya. Talking of other things, the Kanpur-born actress has been to Lucknow several times earlier too but not in recent times. "As I was born in Kanpur and lived there till I was seven-eight-years old, I used to often come to Lucknow with my family for shopping or meeting my relatives here. There is a nawabi feeling associated with Lucknow, and jab bhi zehan mein yahan ka naam aata hai toh yahan ki language, yahan ka food yaad aaata hai." The Dishoom actress is enjoying the success of her recent release War starring Hrithik Roshan and Tiger Shroff, where she played Aditi, an undercover agent who teams up with the two actors to nab one of the most wanted terrorists in the world. Ask her, how it was working with Hrithik and Tiger and she exuberantly replies, "It was really very very nice! Hrithik is an extremely hard working person and very dedicated. He focuses on minute details and he not only thinks about his own role but he also thinks about the entire unit and the film as a whole.” Talking about Tiger Shroff, Anupriya said, “Tiger, on the other hand, is an extremely humble human being and is very sincere towards whatever he does. So, it was a memorable experience of working with him." During her recent visit to the city actress Anupriya Goenka spent some time with the acid attack survivors who run a cafe in Gomti Nagar (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) During her recent visit to the city actress Anupriya Goenka spent some time with the acid attack survivors who run a cafe in Gomti Nagar (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Now a known face in Bollywood, ask her if she is looking for lead roles and Anupriya, without hesitation, said, "Yes, now I am ready for lead characters where I can get a bigger graph. Till now, whatever work I have done I have always got responsible roles where performance was necessary. So, after all my experience, I now believe that I have evolved as an actor." Sharing her journey from Kanpur to Delhi and then to Bollywood, the Tiger Zinda Hai hai actress said, "My father had a garment business in Kanpur but that was closed when I was seven or eight years old. Then my father started his business in Delhi and by the time I joined his business, after completing my high school, the business again was in heavy loss. So, I had to work in a call center at night while going to the factory in the day time. Later, when I turned 18, due to the heavy losses, my father got mentally disturbed and I had to pitch in to liquidate the assets and moved to Jaipur with my family." Till then acting or Bollywood was not even in her dreams even though she was doing theatre in between in Delhi. "I did join a one-month workshop in the National School of Drama (NSD) and was doing plays but not on a regular basis. Till then I had never even thought of films or television. Later when I shifted to Mumbai for a month and a half only because of the business issues and also my maternal side of the family lives there, I fell in love with the city. I again joined a job there and spent around seven years before I thought of taking a break in life and doing theatre again," shared Anupriya. Anupriya, who’s on-screen debut was with Telugu film Potugadu, shot to fame as the face of a political ad campaign in 2013. Since then there has been no looking back for her. "It was an advertisement of a sanitary napkin by Pradeep Sarkar from where he selected me for that political ad campaign. It was Pradeep Sarkar who instilled confidence in me and changed my perception towards Bollywood. Initially, I was scared of Bollywood but after working with dada (Pradeep Sarkar) I felt that good people are there in this industry. Dada was instrumental in my initial success." From a structured environment of a corporate job to an uncertain life in the film industry, the Kissebaaz actress says the transition hasn’t been smooth for her. “The transition has been very difficult for me, to accept a freelancer’s life took me 3-4 years. From 7-8 auditions daily and then getting rejections in most of them is very hard to digest. I think acting and depression go side by side because you always live in uncertainty ki hoga ki nahi hoga! This profession really tests your perseverance and passion. I think my past experiences and hardships have made me the actor I am.” Ask her what it takes for a girl to be successful in Bollywood and she replied, "Passion with dignity is the most important, according to me. The more you respect yourself, people will respect you. The more you hone your craft, the more people will recognize you."

"I did join a one-month workshop in the National School of Drama (NSD) and was doing plays but not on a regular basis. Till then I had never even thought of films or television. Later when I shifted to Mumbai for a month and a half only because of the business issues and also my maternal side of the family lives there, I fell in love with the city. I again joined a job there and spent around seven years before I thought of taking a break in life and doing theatre again," shared Anupriya. Anupriya, who’s on-screen debut was with Telugu film Potugadu, shot to fame as the face of a political ad campaign in 2013. Since then there has been no looking back for her. "It was an advertisement of a sanitary napkin by Pradeep Sarkar from where he selected me for that political ad campaign. It was Pradeep Sarkar who instilled confidence in me and changed my perception towards Bollywood. Initially, I was scared of Bollywood but after working with dada (Pradeep Sarkar) I felt that good people are there in this industry. Dada was instrumental in my initial success." From a structured environment of a corporate job to an uncertain life in the film industry, the Kissebaaz actress says the transition hasn’t been smooth for her. “The transition has been very difficult for me, to accept a freelancer’s life took me 3-4 years. From 7-8 auditions daily and then getting rejections in most of them is very hard to digest. I think acting and depression go side by side because you always live in uncertainty ki hoga ki nahi hoga! This profession really tests your perseverance and passion. I think my past experiences and hardships have made me the actor I am.” Ask her what it takes for a girl to be successful in Bollywood and she replied, "Passion with dignity is the most important, according to me. The more you respect yourself, people will respect you. The more you hone your craft, the more people will recognize you."

column2: Kanpur ladies become partners in crime!
column3: A ladies club in Kanpur organised a casino theme party titled Partners In Crime, recently. Going by the theme, the venue was beautifully decorated with huge cut-outs of playing cards, roulettes and paper fans. Dolly Manga, Neelam Bagga and Savita Chawla, who played joint hostesses for the evening, were seen exchanging pleasantries with the guests. Making the do more attractive was the red and black dress code which made everyone come fashionably dressed. (L) Aaliya Arora, Vandana Chikker and Krishna Ahuja (R) Mini Arora and Neelu Saluja (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Aaliya Arora, Vandana Chikker and Krishna Ahuja (R) Mini Arora and Neelu Saluja (BCCL/ IB Singh) The shooting corner turned out to be attraction among the ladies and we spotted Shalini Dubey, Shipra Bhatia and Nisha Bhatia checking out their shooting skills. “After such a long time I have tried my hand at shooting. It was so much fun,” said, Shailni Dubey who won a prize for hitting the bulls eye. The femme brigade also entertained themselves by playing Rummy and later, shaking their leg on some peppy Bollywood numbers. Also present were Rashi Bhatia, Neelam Bagga, Rashmeeta Kaur, Micky Khanuja, Vinni Singh, Nisha Bhatia and Shipra Bhatia. (L) Dolly Manga, Neelam Bagga and Savita Chawla (R) Karishma Khanuja (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Dolly Manga, Neelam Bagga and Savita Chawla (R) Karishma Khanuja (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Monika Arora and Simran Bagga (R) Kittu Singh (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Monika Arora and Simran Bagga (R) Kittu Singh (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Micky Khanuja, Rashmeeta Kaur and Rashi Bhatia (R) Preeti Arora and Anupreet Arora (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Micky Khanuja, Rashmeeta Kaur and Rashi Bhatia (R) Preeti Arora and Anupreet Arora (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Neeti Chawala (C) Preeti Nijhawan and Mini Arora (R) Rashi Bhatia (BCCL/ IB Singh) (L) Neeti Chawala (C) Preeti Nijhawan and Mini Arora (R) Rashi Bhatia (BCCL/ IB Singh)

column2: Delhi’s tap water is most unsafe, Mumbai’s best: BIS
column3: NEW DELHI: Tap water in Mumbai is the safest for drinking while Delhi’s water is the worst among 21 big cities, according to a report based on sample tests done by Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS). Of greater concern is the fact that all the samples of tap water taken from 15 out of 21 cities failed to meet one or more safety parameters during tests carried out in laboratories. With Chandigarh, Gandhinagar, Patna, Bengaluru, Jammu, Lucknow, Chennai and Dehradun in the list of cities where the tap water quality was found to be below par, the first-of-its-kind report has exposed the failure of water supplying agencies across cities to provide safe drinking water—a basic right for living. The water samples were tested on 28 parameters as prescribed for drinking water standards of BIS notified in 2012. Releasing the report that ranked the cities based on the quality of potable tap water, Union consumer affairs minister Ram Vilas Paswan said, “We have been working on the task to carry out sample tests to sensitise people and agencies concerned about people’s fundamental right to get clean and safe drinking water. This issue should not be politicised as all of us are concerned about human lives.” According to the test findings, only one of the samples in Hyderabad and Bhubaneswar failed and the two cities were ranked second in the list followed by Ranchi and Raipur. In the case of Delhi, all the 11 samples picked from different parts of the national capital, including Paswan’s home, his office in Krishi Bhawan and several residential areas, failed to meet the norms on a maximum of 19 parameters. The report showed that in most cases samples across cities failed on parameters of total dissolve solids (TDS), turbidity, total hardness, total alkalinity, minerals and metals, and presence of of coliform and E Coli, which can cause severe illness. Citing the alarming test findings, Paswan said there is a need to make the drinking water standard notified by BIS mandatory for all water supplying agencies. He added this becomes all the more important considering it’s not easy to snap water supply and hence efforts have to be made to ensure that the tap water is safe. Sensing that the report may kick off a fresh political battle, the minister said the objective of the study is not to demotivate anyone rather it is to encourage state governments to ensure quality potable tap water is provided to all. He added that samples across states have failed and in the subsequent phases, BIS will come out with test reports of samples lifted from capital cities of north-eastern states and from smart cities. Later, samples will be picked up from the district headquarters and their test results will be made public. The test results of these two batches of samples will be announced in mid-January and by August 15, respectively, consumer affairs ministry officials said. BIS officials said they will soon hold meetings with public health departments, municipal corporations and see how test facilities can be strengthened there, which is key to ensure supply of safe drinking water

column2: At 418 AQI, Kanpur continues to struggle with toxic air
column3: LUCKNOW/KANPUR: Industrial city Kanpur emerged as the most polluted and the only city with ‘severe’ air quality in the country on Saturday. According to the data released by the Central Pollution Control Board, Kanpur’s Air Quality Index (AQI) was recorded at 418. Track the pollution level in your cityThis is for the second time in a week that Kanpur’s air quality has turned severe.  Industrial city Kanpur emerged as the most polluted and the only city with ‘severe’ air quality in the country on Saturday.Pollution level in other cities of Uttar Pradesh dropped by around 60-90 units but still remained in ‘very poor’ category. Five cities of west UP recorded pollution levels above 300. The second most polluted city after Kanpur was Gurugram (360), followed by Ghaziabad (347), Greater Noida (309), Noida (338) and Baghpat (313). As per CBCB’s continuous ambient air quality assessment per hour, PM 2.5 concentration in Nehrunagar locality of Kanpur started rising alarmingly from 349 microgram per cubic metre of air at 6 am to 528 (severe plus) at 9am. It then soared to 660 at 10am which was around 11 times higher than the permissible limit of 60. At 11 am, situation improved a bit when the AQI was recorded at 431. At 1 pm, AQI was 338 and likewise with each hour, the air quality kept improving. Though it did not improve to an extent that it could be said that the air is fit for breathing. At 2 pm, AQI was 274 while at 7 pm, the level settled at 254. Kanpur had attained global infamy last year in May after the World Health Organization (WHO) declared it the most polluted city in the list of 4,300 cities around the world where PM2.5 concentration was monitored. Environmentalist Venkatesh Dutta said: “As weather conditions are conducive to higher pollution level, the situation will remain the same till agencies restrict the practice of open garbage burning and reduce vehicular volume on roads. Heavy penalty on garbage burning should be imposed to deter people and odd-even formula may be applied to reduce number of vehicles.” It is expected that the air quality will again worsen during late night hours on Saturday. This was due to the change in the wind direction and also due to dew which does not allow the dust to rise high. The major cause of pollution in the industrial city is the dilapidated and potholed roads. As and when vehicles run on bad roads, it causes dust to surround the atmosphere which cannot rise high. As a result, during the early morning hours, there was thick blanket of smog which also impacted visibility. It appeared there would be no sunshine. People who were out and driving had to switch on their vehicle headlights for better visibility. People also complained of itching in eyes and redness. Further, such an atmosphere is harmful for asthama patients. Many people were witnessed wearing face masks. Others had covered their face using handkerchiefs. Meanwhile, Lucknow continued to struggle with ‘very poor’ air despite drop in air quality index (AQI) indicating air pollution by units from 313 on Friday to 305 on Saturday. No relief is likely soon as weather condition is conducive for accumulation of pollutants.
