column2: Cop on 65-km protest run over transfer is suspended
column3: KANPUR: A sub-inspector posted in Etawah, who embarked on a 65-km run to protest his transfer to Bitholi police station, was suspended for indiscipline. The cop, who collapsed and fainted after covering 40 km, was admitted to a community health centre where his condition is said to be stable. The incident came to light after the video of sub-inspector Vijay Pratap running in the middle of the road in Etawah went viral on Friday. He had also posted a tweet on Thursday evening. “I am being transferred due to the dictatorial attitude of RI (reserve inspector of police). I was asked by the SSP to stay back at reserve police lines but I am being forcibly transferred to Bitholi by the RI. You can call it my anger or unhappiness but I’ll run & go to Bitholi,” Pratap tweeted. SP (city), Etawah, Ram Yash Singh said: “The sub-inspector was transferred from reserve police lines to Bitholi. Instead of accepting the transfer order like any disciplined officer, he posted a message on social media on Thursday evening.” “A probe has been ordered. If he is found guilty, disciplinary action will follow,” he added. He said several complaints had been received against the sub-inspector in the past. “Many people, including Sadar MLA have accused him of misbehaviour with local representatives as well as residents. The S-I, who seems to be influenced by a particular ideology, has even been warned by his seniors,” he said. The SP said the errant cop had even posted derogatory remarks against the Prime Minister and UP chief minister on social media, for which he had been warned.

column2: Kanpur: Two girls charred to death in house fire
column3: KANPUR: Two girls, aged 4 and 6 years, were charred to death after a fire broke out in a house in Chitaura village in Fatehpur district on Sunday. The cause of fire is yet to be ascertained but it broke out from thatched roof shed, police said, adding that four goats also perished in the blaze. Other family members were away for some work and only the two girls, Shweta (6) and her cousin Rajni (4), were present in the house at the time of the incident. ADM, Fatehpur, Ashish Kumar Singh rushed to the spot to take stock of the situation. Officials said investigations were on and compensation would be provided to the family.

column2: Repertwahr: Get set for a rollercoaster of comedy, drama, music
column3: LUCKNOW: The treasure trove of the 10th edition of Repertwahr festival is bigger and better this year. From getting your funny bone tickled with comedy fest ‘Laugh your tashreef off’ to moving to a different world with its theatre and music festival, #10kaPitara, is set to present different flavours of performing arts all under one roof. Beginning from December 12, the five-day festival will be organised at UP Sangeet Natak Akademi. While last year, a food festival was introduced, this year’s novelty will be the element of comedy-satire woven through five theatrical plays. The environment-friendly stage will be decorated with recycled waste material. On Day 1, theatre and music will enthrall the crowd. A tragic comedy showing the dreams and aspirations of small-town actors, ‘Mosambi Narangi’ by Mohit Takalkar, will be staged along with a rock band performance by Indian Ocean. An all-female cast of the play ‘Aurat Aurat Aurat’ by Naseeruddin Shah, unfolding the legacy of UP-born Ismat Chughtai, will take the fest forward on Day 2. A blend of Urdu and Hindi music will be performed by Delhi-based rock band, ‘The Local Train’ on December 14. Co-founder of the festival Bhoopesh Rai said, “Be it the youth or the elderly, the festival has hosted everybody. There is a thin line that separates laughter, pain, comedy and tragedy and Season 10 of our festival aims to string all chords.”

column2: Lucknow: Three parked cars torched in Old city
column3: LUCKNOW: Three four-wheelers including an SUV were allegedly set afire by miscreants at two different places in the Old City area in the intervening night of Friday and Saturday. An SUV and a hatchback parked in an orchard in Thakurganj were set ablaze by unidentified miscreants, while another vehicle was burned in Saadatganj. In the first case, the driver, Manoj Kumar Kashyap (36), a resident of Gadi Peer Khan in Thakurganj, in his police complaint claimed that the SUV parked in an orchard near his house was set on fire by someone and the fire later engulfed the car parked next to it. A burnt SUV in Thakurganj on SundayKashyap told TOI that the SUV of a property dealer Rajeshwari Rani was being driven by him for the past three years. On Friday, after returning home from work at around 9pm, he had parked the vehicle about 100 meters from his home in the orchard known as 'Raja ka Bagh'. A local resident informed him at around 2.30am that the vehicle was on fire. Locals also informed the police and fire service department which reached the spot and doused the fire. However, by then the vehicle was completely destroyed. Dents above doors suggested that someone first smashed the windows and then set the vehicle on fire, he added. The other gutted car belonged to a businessman who lives in the same locality. Sub-inspector Thakurganj, Ramesh Chandra Yadav said, "Prima facie it appears short-circuit caused the fire, but we are taking help of forensic experts." The other incident took place in Chaupatiyan area under Saadatganj police station where a car parked near the garbage dump outside a residential colony caught fire at around 1am. Station house officer, Saadatganj, Mahesh Pal Singh said, "Someone set garbage on fire, which later spread to the parked car."

column2: Lucknow records 18 new cases of dengue
column3: LUCKNOW: Eighteen new cases of dengue were reported on Saturday taking the count to 1,427 since January and 1,413 since July. Among fresh cases, two patients aged 29 and 25 years, have been admitted to SPM Civil Hospital while the remaining 16 are out of danger and recovering at their homes. Fresh cases were reported from Vibhav Khand, Chinhat, Viraj Khand, Chowk, Rajajipuram, Nakkhas, Thakurganj, Vikas Nagar, Indiranagar, Takrohi, Rashmi Khand, Lal Kuan, Harinagar, Kakori, Aishbagh, Telibagh, Vikaskhand and Gosainganj. Larvae of Aedes aegypti were found at 13 houses during scanning of 1,647 houses in four localities including Takrohi, Ruchi Khand, Balaganj and Keshav Nagar.

column2: Lucknow: Railway technician who shot at colleague nabbed near station
column3: LUCKNOW: A railway technician who shot his colleague with a country-made gun only because 'the victim was staring at him' was nabbed near Charbagh railway station in the small hours on Saturday. Police, however, has not been able to trace the supplier of the gun, which the accused said bought from a illegal arms dealer in Hardoi. Girja Singh, a railway technician at a Carriage & Wagon workshop (CWW) of Indian Railways in Alambagh, was injured when his colleague Vishnu Pratap Singh fired at him with a country-made .12 bore gun at the busy Om Nagar crossing in Alambagh on Friday evening. The victim told police that he had an argument with the accused in the office when the latter accused him of staring unnecessarily. The matter was resolved with the intervention of other colleagues. However, later, in the evening, Vishnu intercepted Girja at Om Nagar crossing and started a confrontation which snowballed into fisticuffs. Vishnu then in a fit of rage pulled out the gun and shot at Girija and fled. According to police, after the incident. Vishnu took refuge in the house of a relative in Telibagh. In the small hours on Saturday, he was trying to flee sneak out of Lucknow when police on a tip off caught him at Fateh Ali crossing near Charbagh railway station. After the arrest, the accused told police that they (Vishnu and Girija) belonged to two rival groups who are continuously at logger heads for dominance in the office. He had to drop the argument in the office because of intervention of others, but decided to teach Girja a lesson later. Circle Officer, Alambagh, Lal Pratap Singh said, "The accused seems to be suffering from depression and appeared mentally disturbed. He had told us about a man who had supplied him the illegal firearm and the bullet in Hardoi. Based on the input we will send a team to Hardoi soon to trace the supplier."

column2: Lucknow Police arrest man for online posts against Ayodhya verdict
column3: LUCKNOW: A man who recently returned from Qatar to start a business, was arrested by Lucknow Police from Delhi on Saturday for his comments against Ayodhya verdict on social media. Sohrab Ali (40), of Siwan, Bihar, was booked after Lucknow police nabbed him from New Delhi where he was staying with his brother-in-law Sabre Alam. Alam told TOI over phone, "We were having lunch when six cops in civvies knocked, asked about Ali and took him away." "I rushed to Nandnagri police station where cops told me that Ali had made objectionable post on Ayodhya," he said. ASP (east) Suresh Chandra Rawat said soon after Ayodhya verdict was announced, Ali started tweeting against it. "We had issued warning to Ali on his posts but he did not delete them, so we lodged an FIR. Ali was also booked for inflammatory tweet on October 20," he added. UP police has arrested 105 persons in connection with inflammatory posts on Ayodhya verdict.

column2: Uttar Pradesh: 'Low-grade explosive used in mosque blast'
column3: LUCKNOW: The Agra unit of state forensic science laboratory analyzed the evidence samples from the blast site at a mosque in Kushinagar district and on Saturday confirmed the usage of low-intensity explosives. The FSL unit was sent blast samples on Wednesday. The blast had ripped windows and doors of a mosque in Bairagi Patti village under Turk Patti police station area of the district on Monday. Kushinagar SP, Vinod Kumar Mishra, said the report from Agra confirms that the blast which occurred on Monday used the material used in fire crackers, mainly lithium. It is a component of fire crackers that causes explosion, he added. Anti-Terrorist Squad (ATS) and intelligence bureau sleuths are interrogating the accused. Meanwhile, on Saturday, the Kushinagar police arrested the seventh accused, Salauddin Ansari aka Munna, from Bhalui in Turkpatti area.

column2: Wider NH-9 sees 25% of all traffic fines in Ghaziabad
column3: GHAZIABAD: A wider NH-9 is good news for traffic. But the high-speed corridor connecting Delhi and Ghaziabad that is being widened into India’s first 14-lane highway is also seeing traffic violations galore. This inference can be drawn from recent challan data of Ghaziabad traffic police — of over 2.75 lakh vehicles prosecuted by the cops for road rule violations from January to October this year, some 25% were challaned on NH-9 alone, with wrong-side travel, speeding, driving without seatbelt and riding without helmet being the major offences. The latest accident on this highway occurred on Tuesday when nearly two dozen employees of a private company were injured after the private bus in which they were travelling collided with a tractor in Vijay Nagar where the highway is now wider than it has ever been. The other two highways — NH-91 and NH-58 — that pass through the city are equally accident-prone. In fact, the traffic police have identified over 15 black spots on these three highways, including Lal Kuan intersection, Kala Patthar in Indirapuram, Mohan Nagar and Ganga Canal in Muradnagar. According to traffic police data, between January and September this year, as many as 694 accidents happened in Ghaziabad, including on these three highways, in which 298 people died and 474 sustained injuries. In 2018, the number of accidents reported in the city was 672, in which 310 people died and 602 were injured. Two-wheelers topped the list of those challaned for breaking traffic rules. Of the 2,75,962 challans issued between January and October this year, some 1.84 lakh were against bikers, followed by cars (63,358), three-wheelers (18,133), trucks (9,288), buses (611) and tractors (45). Of the bikers, 1.21 lakh were challened for riding without a helmet. Similarly, 24,450 people were fined for driving without seat belts and 6,100 for wrong-side driving, according to this year’s data. Pramhansh Tiwari, traffic inspector, said dangerous driving, stunts by youths and underage driving also figure in the challans. “We have issued 1,036 challans for dangerous driving, 57 for road stunts, and 48 for underage driving. Similarly, 2,428 commuters were fined for using cell phones and 35 for drunk driving during this 10-month period.” “Motorists should understand that by driving on the wrong side or speeding, they are not only putting their lives in danger but also those of others. Traffic police are trying to aware people through nukad natak, posters etc, but change will come when people would understand the value of human life,” Tiwari said. Residents said wrong-side driving has become a menace in Ghaziabad. “I have many a time spotted drivers taking the wrong side on NH-9 to access their residential areas. As at some places on NH-9 near Indirapuram and Khora, high-speed driving on the wrong side often put the lives of local residents at risk due to inadequate streetlights in the night,” said Hemat Tyagi, a Vasundhara resident. SN Singh, SP (traffic), Ghaziabad said the traffic police are issuing challans to violators on a regular basis. “We also celebrate road safety months and try to aware people about traffic rules,” he said. NH-9 is being widened to 14 lanes and the six central lanes are being converted into the access-controlled Delhi-Meerut Expressway, the same way the highway has been developed in Delhi.

column2: Ghazibad cops take ex-SHO into custody, recover Rs 9.8 lakh from factory
column3: GHAZIABAD: Hours after taking former SHO Laxmi Singh Chauhan into custody, Ghaziabad police on Saturday evening raided a defunct steel factory in Link Road area and recovered Rs 9.8 lakh. Inspector Chauhan, accused of stealing Rs 70 lakh from thieves during a probe, had hid the money in that factory, police said. Inspector Chauhan, along with constable Dheeraj Bharadwaj, surrendered in an anti-corruption court in Meerut on November 7. The duo was sent to 14-day judicial custody, but the Ghaziabad police took her on a one-day remand for interrogation. Five other cops accused in the case are absconding. Manish Kumar Mishra, SP (city) said anti-corruption court in Meerut accepted remand application for a day. “We brought her to Ghaziabad on Saturday and recovered Rs 9.85 lakh from the factory.”

column2: Ghaziabad: Indraprastha Gas Limited contractor, two others fined for construction
column3: GHAZIABAD: A real estate company, a contractor of Indraprastha Gas Limited and a landowner were fined with Rs 1 lakh each on Saturday for allegedly indulging in construction activities. UPPCB regional officer Utsav Sharma said, “A fine of Rs 1 lakh has been imposed on the builder of SG Alpha in Vasundhara. Likewise, a penalty was imposed on the IGL contractor, DS Enterprises, in Sahibabad for carrying out pipe laying work in the area. The firm had also not taken any permission from the Ghaziabad Municipal Corporation (GMC).” In Vijay Nagar, construction of a private house was found going on and the landowner was fined, Sharma added.

column2: GMC drags its feet as monkeys run amok in two Ghaziabad colonies
column3: NOIDA: About a month ago, everyone in Santosh Kaushik’s family started feeling sick and the cause was difficult to pin down. “Turned out, monkeys had damaged the lid of the overhead water tank. The water got contaminated and everyone started getting sick,” said Kaushik, a resident of Shastri Nagar. Between 2016 and now, Ghaziabad’s monkey population has grown from 5,000 to 18,000. The residents don’t know what to do. “My daughter was attacked by a monkey when she was eating on the terrace. She was injured. She doesn’t feel safe in her own home now,” said Somesh Sinha, a resident of Kavi Nagar. The two areas — Shastri Nagar and Kavi Nagar — are the most affected. “You will hardly find a house in these areas that is not fortified with grills to ward off monkeys. But precautions are not enough. Children fall prey to simian attacks all the time,” said Sanjay Mishra, a resident of Shastri Nagar. “Monkeys keep coming in and they uproot every single plant in my garden,” said Shivangi Mishra, a resident of Kavi Nagar. But what rankles is the lack of action by the Ghaziabad Municipal Corporation (GMC). “My children saw monkeys attack a friend. Now, they are afraid of stepping out. I lodged complaints on GMC’s online complaint cell, but there has been no action,” said Rajeev Verma, a resident of Shastri Nagar. A district forest official said the problem so far has been the approach. “Monkeys movein groups of 10-30. It is the alpha male that directs the group and that male has to be controlled,” said a district forest official. For a while, some resident welfare associations tried to fix the problem with langurs — the bigger simian would scare the monkeys away. Protests by animal rights activists stopped that. The GMC, too, ran into problems when it tried to engage professional monkey catchers from Mathura. “Animal rights organisations questioned the way in which monkeys were being caught. So we had to terminate the contract,” said AK Mishra, a GMC official. The forest department said it doesn’t step in unless asked to. The GMC has decided it will reach out to the forest department. “The GMC board has agreed to this. It has also floated tenders to get monkeycatchers,” Mishra added.

column2: Toxic tap water: BIS sounds alarm bells
column3: LUCKNOW: Tap water supplied in the city by Jal Sansthan is unfit for consumption. The state capital stands at 11th position among 21 prominent cities in the country, according to a report based on sample tests done by Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) — India’s top body which certifies purity and quality of a product. This even as Mumbaikars can directly have water from the tap, the study says. The report was released by Union consumer affairs minister Ram Vilas Paswan in Delhi on Saturday. Ten samples each were taken from all the cities to find out if the tap water was fit for human consumption. The first-of-its-kind report has exposed the failure of water supplying agencies across cities to provide safe drinking water—a basic right for living. All the samples collected from various parts of Lucknow failed to meet six parametres, including organoleptic, chemical composition, adulteration, toxicity and bacteriological substances. The ranking was based on samples found fit and the parametres they qualify. For instance, Mumbai was number one as all samples cleared tests for 21 parametres. All the Chandigarh samples also failed, but the Union territory still got the seventh position. While Chandigarh could not qualify only two parametres, Lucknow failed in six. Lucknow was below Ranchi (third), Raipur (fourth) and Patna and Bhopal (both sharing the ninth position). Jammu shared the 11th position with Lucknow. Regular reality checks by TOI have been highlighting the poor quality of water supplied in the city. Besides odour and bitter taste, people in many areas complain about supply mixed with sand, algae and even sewage. Most people have installed water purifiers at home. Even several tests done by the joint team of the health department and Jal Sansthan during monsoon also found water unfit for drinking at many places, posing a threat of diseases such as hepatitis, diarrhoea, dysentery, typhoid and cholera. General manager of Jal Santhan S K Verma said, “Once we get the report, we will conduct tests again and take measures to rectify the problem.”

column2: Lucknow: Release funds for piped water, CM requests Centre
column3: LUCKNOW: Chief minister Yogi Adityanath requested the Union Jal Shakti ministry to release funds for the piped drinking water supply project for Bundelkhand as he wanted to lay the foundation for the project by December. During a meeting with Jal Shakti ministry secretary Parameswaran Iyer on Saturday, the CM directed his team to finish work on the project within a month so that was ready for launch by year-end. "The chief minister and the secretary discussed ways to conserve water in the state and how the piped water scheme could be implemented in all parts of the state under the Jal Jivan Mission and the Swachh Bharat Mission. Iyer assured the CM that the points raised by him would be incorporated in the ministry's plans and a water supply scheme will be devised keeping in mind an allocation of 55 litre /person per day," said a senior government official. The CM said that families with defunct toilets or those who were not included in the base line survey should not be added to the list and should be provided resources to get toilets built under the Swachh Bharat Mission. A scheme for extending piped water supply scheme to all houses is to be prepared, with special emphasis on Bundelkhand and Vindhyanchal region. He also directed the state Jal Shakti department to focus on revival and rejuvenation of old hand pumps, tubewells and wells to boost groundwater reserves and encourage rainwater harvesting.

column2: Transferred cop's 65-km protest run to Bitholi ends in suspension
column3: KANPUR: A sub-inspector posted in Etawah, who embarked on a 65-km run to protest his transfer to Bitholi police station, was suspended for indiscipline on Saturday. The cop, who collapsed and fainted after covering 40km on Friday, was admitted to a community health centre where his condition is said to be stable. The incident came to light after the video of sub-inspector Vijay Pratap running in the middle of the road in Etawah went viral on Friday. He had also posted a tweet on Thursday evening. "I am being transferred due to the dictatorial attitude of RI (reserve inspector of police). I was asked by the SSP to stay back at reserve police lines but I am being forcibly transferred to Bitholi by the RI. You can call it my anger or unhappiness but I'll run & go to Bitholi," Pratap tweeted. SP (city), Etawah, Ram Yash Singh said: "The sub-inspector was transferred from reserve police lines to Bitholi. Instead of accepting the transfer order like any disciplined officer, he posted a message on social media on Thursday evening." "A probe has been ordered. If he is found guilty, disciplinary action will follow," he added. He said several complaints had been received against the sub-inspector in the past. "Many people, including Sadar MLA have accused him of misbehaviour with local representatives as well as residents. The S-I, who seems to be influenced by a particular ideology, has even been warned by his seniors," he said. The SP said the errant cop had even posted derogatory remarks against the Prime Minister and UP chief minister on social media, for which he had been warned.

column2: Delhi-NCR air pollution: Task force suggests lifting ban on dirty-fuel factories
column3: NEW DELHI: As air quality improved on Saturday, the CPCB-led Graded Response Action Plan task force recommended lifting the ban on industries operating on coal in Delhi-NCR. “Industrial operations such as coal-based industries in Faridabad, Gurugram, Ghaziabad, Noida, Greater Noida, Sonepat and Bahadurgarh, and non-PNG industries in Delhi, which were earlier banned by EPCA, may commence subject to taking adequate control measures and compliance to prescribed environmental norms,” the task force stated. Supreme Court had on November 4 banned construction and demolition activities in the region till further orders. “Hot mix plant, ready mix plants and stone crusher shall continue to remain closed,” the task force stated on Saturday. As part of pre-emptive steps during the polluted Diwali period, SC-appointed EPCA on suggestions of the task force ordered ban on construction from 6pm to 6am from October 26-30. On October 31, the ban was extended four more hours from 6pm to 10am. On November 1, complete ban was announced before the apex court blanket ban. During the meeting on Saturday, officials noted how improvement in AQI was observed, which reached ‘very poor’ from ‘severe’ and ‘severe plus’ categories it was hovering around in the past few days. The state pollution control boards and other implementing agencies have, however, been asked to continue to remain on alert, ensure regular surveillance and take all necessary actions to curb air polluting activities. Earlier, on November 6, the Supreme Court gave Delhi government seven days to fix the 13 spots identified as the most polluted in the city.

column2: When the boys had a ball in school in Lucknow
column3: Sidhartha Bhutani (L) and Ananya Mishra (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)  Sidhartha Bhutani (L) and Ananya Mishra (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Anurag Mishra (L) and Nirbhav (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)  Anurag Mishra (L) and Nirbhav (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Former and present students of a Lucknow boys’ college met one Sunday morning for a game of cricket. After a lot of slegding, cheering, hooting and whistling, it was the past students who managed to rout the younger lot easily. column2: My learning ground has been the Miss Diva audition, says Asha Bhat in Lucknow
column3: Yashi Agarwal Winner of the Miss Supranational 2014 pageant, Asha Bhat after making her acting debut with Bollywood film 'Junglee' is all ready to foray into the south film industry. The model turned actress was in Lucknow recently to shoot her next Kannada film 'Roberrt', opposite Darshan Thoogudeepa. Asha came to Lucknow initially to judge the Miss Diva Lucknow auditions a few years ago. On her second visit to Lucknow, the beauty queen said, “Lucknow is a beautiful city full of lovely people and delicious food. Since I’m a vegetarian, all my friends asked me to try the basket chaat when I told them that I was going to Lucknow. I had chhole kulche for lunch and even managed to go in and around the Bada Imambara as we were shooting there. I must say the Imambara is beautiful.” Telling us about jer journey into the world of glamour, Asha said that she won the Miss India Supranational pageant in 2014 and then went on to win the internatioonal pageant too and became the first Indian to win the said pageant, “It has been a very humbling experience. Whatever and whoever I am today as an actor, the due credit goes to the Miss India organisation for giving me my first platform, which was the pageant. After winning the pageant I moved to Mumbai in 2016 wherein my journey as an actor started with me giving auditions for films,TVCs, etc. In the year 2017, I bagged my first role in the film 'Junglee' opposite Vidyut Jammwal. Now, because of 'Junglee', I got my second film after people saw my work. So one thing led to another, from pageants to films. So I’d say my journey has been fabulous and very gratifying,” said the talented diva. When asked about her journey and the whole experience of winning the pageant, Asha said, “My life changed for good. It was very different earlier. I was studying engineering in Bangalore when my parents were like ‘See, the Miss India auditions are happening, why don’t you try for it?’ So for my parents, it was like Oh meri beti thodi lambi hai, acchi dikhtihai, she should definitely try this out.” Asha went on to add, “In my head, I was like what is happening? Yeh kaisa transition hai from boots to heels, I’ve never even worn heels, never walked a ramp, never been a model! My mother, however, would say that ‘Doesn’t matter what kind of a job it is, even if you’re sweeping the floor, make sure no one sweeps it better than you. Be the best in whatever you do.’ So I took it up as a challenge and I gave my best. I learnt from each and every person that I could, even did a lot of research and learning online after moving to Mumbai. It was quite a challenge when you know no one from this industry and are unfamiliar with the city, but I’m here now nonetheless.” Speaking further about winning the beauty pageant, Asha added, “I’m a practical kind of a person, however, so even before going for the pageant I thought to myself that if there are 83 countries participating, one out of 83, what’s the probability of winning? With probabilities like these, you don’t expect a lot. All you do is give your best and so I did. Life after that has been amazing.” Asha Bhat, Miss Supranational 2014, while in Lucknow (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Asha Bhat, Miss Supranational 2014, while in Lucknow (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Asha managed to bag her first film Junglee with Hollywood director Chuck Russell who directed the film 'The Mask', which was an Oscar nominee. Speaking about the same she said, “Back in 2017, I got a call from casting director Shruti Mahajan to give the auditions for a film. At that time, I didn’t know who's directing the film ya actor kaun hai or anything else, all I knew was the character i was supposed to play. So I auditioned for both the characters,Shankara and Meera. I gave a couple of round of auditions. By the time I finished four rounds I got to know it's being directed by Chuck Russell and I was asked to meet him. That’s when I realised that Chuck Russell is the director, a Hollywood director and I’m playing Meera opposite Vidyut Jammwal in the film! It was overwhelming. I was very very happy. I could see a sense of pride on my loved one's faces. Seeing that I realised that I’ve achieved something significant.” Talking about the idea of venturing into films, the model turned actress said, “I just went with the flow. Khayal mein bhi aaya nahi tha kabhi. The thing is, ever since childhood I was into Bharatanatyam, Karnatakashastriya Sangeeta, veena, painting, studying, sports, everything. So it was a typical south Indian family where studies and cultural things go hand-in-hand. That somehow helped me hone my skills. It was not like I did acting but all this helped me with my expressions and all during auditions. My learning ground I feel has been the Miss Diva auditions. I used to just set out of the house to give auditions right from morning. It made me feel that if I can perform in front of 15 people (during auditions), it is going to help me while I’m actually doing a film where there are more than 100 personalities on a set. It's like a practice.” Suggesting that she would love to do a periodic film or a biopic on some sports personality like PT Usha, Asha said, “I just want to do good work with good directors. My dream film would probably be a periodic film or a biopic for sure. Just hope I get one.” Asha, who has kick-started shooting for a Kannada film 'Roberrt', which is being directed by Tharun Sudhir came to Lucknow for the same. Without revealing much about her character in the film opposite actor Darshan Thoogudeepa, the beauty from Karnataka said, “The film is an action-emotion drama. It's with Darshan sir, Tharunsir and Umapathy films. They’re a deadly combination if you ask down south and I’m grateful for being given the opportunity to play the lead opposite Darshansir with an amazing character and storyline and some lovely people.” — Yashi Agarwal

column2: Have 3 litigants' nod to file review plea: AIMPLB
column3: LUCKNOW: Eight days after the Supreme Court's unanimous Ayodhya verdict, at least three Muslim litigants under the aegis of All India Muslim Personal Law Board (AIMPLB) on Sunday decided to file a petition in the Supreme Court, seeking a review of the judgment. At a meeting here, AIMPLB also decided not to accept the 5-acre ‘alternative’ land for construction of a mosque. The board said it was seeking a review since the Muslim side had approached the SC for ownership of Babri Masjid land and not for an alternative site. However, the main party from the Muslim side, UP Sunni Central Waqf Board, which had said on the day of the verdict that it would not file a review petition, reiterated on Sunday that there was no change in its position. Board chairman Zufar Faruqi, who skipped the AIMPLB meeting despite being invited, told TOI, “We stick to our old stand about accepting the SC verdict. Filing a review petition would mean doing a volte-face. If any other litigant wants to appeal, they can. About allotment of five-acre land, we will decide at the board’s meeting on November 26.” Iqbal Ansari, son of the oldest litigant from the Muslim side, has also opposed a review plea. After a day-long meeting, AIMPLB (which is not a party to the case) claimed that it had received affirmation from three Muslim litigants, Mohammad Umar, Maulana Mahfuzur Rahman and Misbahuddin, to move the review plea with its legal backing within 30 days of the SC verdict. Umar, son of one of the first Muslim litigants in the Ayodhya title suit, told TOI, “I am ready to file a petition seeking review of SC’s verdict on Ayodhya.” Jamiat Ulama-i-Hind (JuH) also announced that it would independently file a review petition after it termed the verdict "not based on evidence or logic". JuH, which was a party in the title suit, had opposed the 5-acre offer on Thursday. AIMPLB claimed the verdict was replete with contradictions, "beyond comprehension at certain" junctions and "prima facie unfair". The meeting was presided over by AIMPLB chief Maulana Rabey Hasani Nadwi and attended by 45 of its 51 working committee members, including JuH representatives Arshad Madani and Mehmood Madani, Hyderabad MP Asaduddin Owaisi and AIMPLB general secretary Maulana Wali Rahmani. “The Ayodhya suit was a representative suit from all Muslims and AIMPLB was chosen as the umbrella Muslim body to take care of legalese. The board will file a review and declines the offer of 5 acres to be allotted by the government,” Babri Masjid Action Committee (BMAC) convener and AIMPLB secretary Zafaryab Jilani told reporters. “It’s not contempt of court if Muslims do not want land from the government,” he said. “Waqf Act 1995 and Islamic Shariah have no provision for exchange or transfer of mosque land. And we believe the UP Sunni Central Waqf Board will respect the view of Muslims in declining the 5-acre land within the Act’s ambit,” Jilani said. On Sunday, the meeting venue was changed from Darul Uloom Nadwatul Ulama to Mumtaz PG College at the eleventh hour after AIMPLB officials claimed that they were asked by the district administration not to hold the meet at Nadwa.

column2: Kanpur: What sparked farmers’ ire
column3: KANPUR: The violent protest by Unnao farmers was triggered by a police officer who allegedly slapped an old farmer on Saturday. The incident took place when senior district officials of Unnao were trying to pacify agitated farmers. Sources told TOI that efforts were on to arrive at a truce when a police sub-inspector first pushed a young farmer. A senior citizen objected to this but he too was beaten up. This ignited the anger and farmers went berserk, fighting six hour long battle with the police.

column2: Two killed as car falls into pond in Dehat
column3: KANPUR:Two persons were killed while four others sustained serious injuries after a car in which they were travelling skidded off the road and fell into a pond near Birhun Marg of Kanpur Dehat district on late Friday night. The driver of the car, however, managed to flee the spot. The dead included Pramod Kushwaha and Jitu Kushwaha of Ghatampur area, the injured identified as Ravi, Pushpendra, Shivam and Shubham, have been admitted to a nearby hospital. The car was coming from Asalaganj area of Kanpur Dehat district. The accident took place near Birhun Marg, where it rolled into a pond. Police had a tough time in extracting the victims from the car. Windowpanes were broken to rescue the occupants The car was pulled out from the pond by a crane. “Occupants of the car had gone to participate in a tilak ceremony in Asalatganj in Rasoolabad area of Kanpur Dehat. The mishap took place on Birhun Marg while they were returning to their native place. Two persons were killed while four others who sustained injuries are undergoing treatment at a nearby community health centre. Searches are underway to locate the whereabouts of the driver, who fled the site soon after the mishap,” said ASP Anup Kumar.

column2: Unnao simmers: Top brass rushes from Lucknow to alleviate tension
column3: KANPUR: To ease out the prevailing tension in villages of the Gangaghat area of Unnao where farmers had clashed with the police on Saturday, senior government officials from Lucknow camped at the site on Sunday where clashes took place and held a meeting with the district officials of Unnao. After over an hour-long meeting, divisional commissioner of Lucknow, Mukesh Meshram and ADG Lucknow zone SN Sabat told reporters that people who had torched vehicles and attacked police on Saturday were being identified so that law could take its course. After the incident on Sunday morning, when PVC pipes were set ablaze, the situation is now under control and nothing untoward happened, Meshram said. "The district administration has started a direct talk with farmers. The effort will be made as per the existing laws to redress their grievances and ensure that no harm is caused to any farmer who has a genuine case", the commissioner said. "Some people are inciting farmers for their vested interests. We have come to know that some people, who do not even have possession of land in the Trans-Ganga city project area, have illegally occupied the land for farming purposes whereas the actual owners of the land had already taken the compensation. We have asked the district authorities to identify such people who have illegally encroached the land", Meshram said. Out of 2,039 farmers whose land was acquired by UPSIDC, 1,925 farmers had accepted compensations. They had handed over their lands to UPSIDC which started the construction work at the site, he added. Meshram said that 134 farmers had not accepted compensation. "We have asked the authorities to peacefully resolve the issue after speaking to the farmers directly. "Three teams of the district administration will talk to the farmers who come under three different gram panchayats", he added. "The farmers were given compensation three times more than the circle rate, and the UPSIDC started work at the construction site only after acquiring the land. This went on uninterrupted for two years and there was no resistance from anyone. We will ensure that the farmers do not remain dissatisfied", Meshram told newsmen. UPSIDC would continue its work at the site and at the same time would construct houses for 1850 farmers, he said.

column2: Unnao farmers run amok on Day two, indulge in arson
column3: KANPUR: Agitated over the arrest of fellow farmers and leaders, villagers of Gangaghat area in Shuklaganj, Unnao, who had fought a six-hour long pitched battle with police on Saturday, continued protest and allegedly set afire plastic pipes and a construction material mixer. Police officials said, the PVC pipes were kept in a godown of Uttar Pradesh State Industrial Development Corporation (UPSIDC), which has acquired the land for Trans-Ganga City project. Latest CommentUp Govt must handle the situation meticulously and help the farmers.Rohit RaiSee All CommentsAdd commentAs the plastic pipes caught fire, tall flames arose and huge plumes of dense smoke engulfed the air, causing panic in the area. Police and firemen rushed to the spot to control the situation and managed to douse the fire after battling flames for two hours. No one was injured in the blaze. A construction material mixing vehicle was also set ablaze but the fire was doused soon, not causing much damage to it. column2: UP: Power staff strike over PF scam may cripple supply
column3: LUCKNOW: In what could trigger a power crisis in the state, power employees will go on a two-day work boycott beginning Monday to protest against their provident fund money getting trapped in the tainted Dewan Housing and Finance Corporation Limited (DHFL). The employees, under the banner of UP Rajya Vidyut Upbhokta Sangharsh Samiti, have given a call of a complete work boycott in distribution and transmission wing of the UP Power Corporation Limited (UPPCL). However, the units generating power have been exempted from the protest. According to samiti convener Shailendra Dubey, power generation units have been exempted to prevent grid failure. However, engineers would refrain from fixing a fault in power plant, Dubey said. The samiti also announced that even faults in transmission and distribution system will not be attended by the power employee, which would directly affect the consumers. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSWhy top JD(U) leaders are shying away from campaigning in Assam?Bihar’s ruling JD(U) has claimed that it has fielded its candidates in 37 out of the 126 assembly constituencies in Assam. But what has baffled poll analysts is that all of JD(U)’s top leaders, including CM Nitish Kumar, have so far stayed away from campaigning. Opposition leaders in Bihar alleged that JD(U) is not campaigning in Assam because of “certain pressure” from BJP.Sporadic violence marks first phase of Bengal pollsSporadic incidents of violence were reported from some areas that are voting in the first phase of the assembly elections in West Bengal on Saturday, even as the overall poll situation was peaceful with 36.09 per cent turnout recorded till 11 am, officials said.Elections are being held in 30 seats, most of which are in the once-Naxal-affected Jungle Mahal region.“We have been forced to stage a work boycott as talks with the government have not been fruitful,” Dubey said. He said power employee are not demanding any immediate release of funds, but a guarantee from the government to lend a back-up in case the money remains trapped in DHFL. PCL to file review petition in HCUPPCL sources said the corporation was gearing up to file a review petition in the Mumbai high court, which had on September 4 barred DHFL from releasing money to its creditors. The corporation had hired a private law firm to take up the legal battle in the high court. Top CommentInvesting 41000 crore provident fund of UPPCL employees in DHFL is a crime ,which has been committed by some top officers in alliance with some top political leaders.It is hard earned money of the em...Read MoreChaitanya AgarwalSee All CommentsAdd commentThis is apart from the UPPCL approaching the Reserve Bank of India to intervene in the issue, which has attained political overtones with the Opposition putting the ruling BJP dispensation in a dock over investing employees’ hard-earned money in a defaulting company. The employees have been up in arms against the UPPCL management, demanding the arrest of former UPPCL chairman Alok Kumar, who was also the ex-officio chairman of the UP State Power Sector Employees Trust which invested more than Rs 4,100 crore in DHFL since March 17,

column2: Jamiat will file review petition in SC independently
column3: Lucknow: Jamiat Ulama-i-Hind (JuH), a key Muslim petitioner in the Ayodhya title suit, also decided to file a review petition in the Supreme Court on Sunday. JuH president Maulana Arshad Madani said the 'Babri verdict was not based on evidence and logic' and this made it necessary for filing a review plea. At a recent meeting of JuH in Delhi on November 14, the body had decided to not accept 5-acre alternative land as mandated by Supreme Court and formed a five-member panel to look into legal and religious aspects of the SC verdict. The panel chaired by Maulana Madani observed the verdict was against Babri Masjid and was not final as the Constitution allowed a window for review. "The judgment accepts that evidence and arguments were in favour of Babri Masjid. But, the order was not based on merit and evidence and defied logic," Maulana Madani said. "A review is then a legal option for Muslims," he added. The 100-year-old national level body, JuH had fought for the country's freedom against Partition and filed the first suit, challenging the 2010 order of the Allahabad high court. "There is also a Sharia obligation to defend a masjid till the last breath and JuH is committed to struggle till its logical end," he said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSWhy top JD(U) leaders are shying away from campaigning in Assam?Bihar’s ruling JD(U) has claimed that it has fielded its candidates in 37 out of the 126 assembly constituencies in Assam. But what has baffled poll analysts is that all of JD(U)’s top leaders, including CM Nitish Kumar, have so far stayed away from campaigning. Opposition leaders in Bihar alleged that JD(U) is not campaigning in Assam because of “certain pressure” from BJP.Sporadic violence marks first phase of Bengal pollsSporadic incidents of violence were reported from some areas that are voting in the first phase of the assembly elections in West Bengal on Saturday, even as the overall poll situation was peaceful with 36.09 per cent turnout recorded till 11 am, officials said.Elections are being held in 30 seats, most of which are in the once-Naxal-affected Jungle Mahal region.The panel opined that both Supreme Court and ASI report had clarified the Babri Masjid was not built after razing a temple and that no archaeological evidence of temple was found under the mosque. It also said that both SC and the Allahabad High Court had accepted the "bitter fact" that idols were placed inside the mosque illegally first in the outer courtyard and then shifted to the central dome in 1949. "The bench also accepted the mosque was demolished by an act of vandalism and evidence was present to prove Muslims offered namaz for more than 90 years. Justice was not done fully in this judgment and shifting the mosque to alternative land is out of question," Madani said.

column2: Wind brings down AQI but Lucknow air poor
column3: LUCKNOW: The pollution level in Lucknow dropped by 50 units as compared to Saturday but the city's air quality was still poor on Sunday. According to Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) data, the Air Quality Index (AQI) of Lucknow was 256. "Over the past week, wind speed has been as low as 0.2-0.5 metre per second which improved to 2 metre per second. There was a drop in humidity levels from 80% to 50% which improved the air. A moderate increase in wind velocity dispersed pollutants to some extent, bringing down the AQI," said Prof Dhruvsen Singh, director of Lucknow University's weather and pollution monitoring cell. Track the pollution level in your cityPollution levels in seven cities of Uttar Pradesh witnessed a drop by 60-130 units due to the improved wind velocity and low humidity. According to data CPCB, AQI of Varanasi was 312, making it the second most polluted city in the country after Muzzafarpur (315) in Bihar. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSWhy top JD(U) leaders are shying away from campaigning in Assam?Bihar’s ruling JD(U) has claimed that it has fielded its candidates in 37 out of the 126 assembly constituencies in Assam. But what has baffled poll analysts is that all of JD(U)’s top leaders, including CM Nitish Kumar, have so far stayed away from campaigning. Opposition leaders in Bihar alleged that JD(U) is not campaigning in Assam because of “certain pressure” from BJP.Sporadic violence marks first phase of Bengal pollsSporadic incidents of violence were reported from some areas that are voting in the first phase of the assembly elections in West Bengal on Saturday, even as the overall poll situation was peaceful with 36.09 per cent turnout recorded till 11 am, officials said.Elections are being held in 30 seats, most of which are in the once-Naxal-affected Jungle Mahal region.Pollution levels in Kanpur dropped 111 units as compared to Saturday when AQI was 418 but still the city figured as the fourth most polluted after Patna (309), which ranked third.  The maximum drop of 130 units was in Baghpat (183) which was 313 a day before. Air quality in other UP cities-Ghaziabad (218), Greater Noida (202) and Noida (203) fell from 'very poor' to 'poor' category.

column2: Lucknow: Auto-lifting kingpin held, was using stolen SUV
column3: LUCKNOW: With the arrest of the prime accused in Badshahnagar auto-lifting case from a car resale showroom on Saturday, all eight stolen vehicles have been recovered. One person was also arrested for buying a stolen SUV from the accused. On November 5, eight vehicles including six automatic expensive four-wheelers were stolen in the small hours in Badshahnagar, 700 metres from Mahanagar police station. Of the stolen vehicles, a BMW, an Audi, a Ford Endeavour and a Hyundai i20 were recovered on November 6 from the campus of KGMU. Two models of Toyota Innova Crysta and a Hyundai i20 were recovered from the parking of Era's Lucknow Medical College and Hospital on November 8. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSWhy top JD(U) leaders are shying away from campaigning in Assam?Bihar’s ruling JD(U) has claimed that it has fielded its candidates in 37 out of the 126 assembly constituencies in Assam. But what has baffled poll analysts is that all of JD(U)’s top leaders, including CM Nitish Kumar, have so far stayed away from campaigning. Opposition leaders in Bihar alleged that JD(U) is not campaigning in Assam because of “certain pressure” from BJP.Sporadic violence marks first phase of Bengal pollsSporadic incidents of violence were reported from some areas that are voting in the first phase of the assembly elections in West Bengal on Saturday, even as the overall poll situation was peaceful with 36.09 per cent turnout recorded till 11 am, officials said.Elections are being held in 30 seats, most of which are in the once-Naxal-affected Jungle Mahal region.The last, a Toyota Fortuner, was recovered from prime accused Ranjeet Kumar when he was arrested near Shaheed Park in Kakori on Saturday. He was using it with a forged registration. Additionally, a stolen Mahindra Scorpio, a Honda City and a Royal Enfield were also recovered from him. A native of Shravasti, Ranjeet lived on rent in Kakori. He told police he was part of a gang that steals expensive vehicles and sells them in other states and in Nepal. Along with his aide Mohammad Saif, he had done a recce of the showroom five times in a month and met the salesman too. They had scaled the wall of the facility and broken its locks. Taking the keys from a cupboard, they drove away with the pre-decided vehicles. ASP trans-Gomti Rajesh Kumar Srivastava said, "We are tracing other vehicles stolen by the accused. Another accused, Girija Mishra, is absconding."

column2: Lucknow University: The mother ship that carried many a cradle of excellence
column3: Seeds of excellence sown by the University of Lucknow grew into independent research and academic cradles of the country. For instance, the first and only institute of paleosciences in India traces its origin to LU while the engineering department became the only Government Engineering College in the city. Here are the famous five who owe their birth to LU’s nourishing environment Birbal Sahni Institute of PaleosciencesThe brainchild of professor Birbal Sahni, BSIP grew in the womb of LU’s botany department in 1946. Three years down the line, it became an independent institute whose foundation was laid by Jawaharlal Nehru, Sahni’ s friend and batchmate from Cambridge. The foundation stone was more than a plaque; it had 77 samples of plant fossils from across the world embedded in a block of coloured cement. Ethnographic and Folk Culture SocietyNEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSWhy top JD(U) leaders are shying away from campaigning in Assam?Bihar’s ruling JD(U) has claimed that it has fielded its candidates in 37 out of the 126 assembly constituencies in Assam. But what has baffled poll analysts is that all of JD(U)’s top leaders, including CM Nitish Kumar, have so far stayed away from campaigning. Opposition leaders in Bihar alleged that JD(U) is not campaigning in Assam because of “certain pressure” from BJP.Sporadic violence marks first phase of Bengal pollsSporadic incidents of violence were reported from some areas that are voting in the first phase of the assembly elections in West Bengal on Saturday, even as the overall poll situation was peaceful with 36.09 per cent turnout recorded till 11 am, officials said.Elections are being held in 30 seats, most of which are in the once-Naxal-affected Jungle Mahal region.A pioneer in the field of anthropology and tribal research, LU professor DN Majumdar founded the Society in UP in 1945 to collect and preserve ethnographic data. A lecturer in primitive economics at LU since 1928, Majumdar held the distinction of being elected as a fellow of the Royal Anthropological Institute of Great Britain and Ireland in 1936. Six years later, he founded the Society that is today one of the foremost agencies working on Indian culture. Regional Centre for Urban and Environmental StudiesEstablished by the Union government in 1968 for effective implementation of urban development policies, RCUES came up on land gifted by LU. The varsity’s department of public administration also played foster parent for the centre. Till 1990, the head of department served as ex officio director of RCUES. In 2000, the government signed an agreement with LU that said its professors would serve as full-time directors of the centre. Institute of Engineering and TechnologyTill August 1984, IET was the faculty of engineering at LU, offering BTech courses in computer science, electrical, electronics civil and mechanical engineering. Its founder-director was professor Suresh Chandra. After it became a separate entity, it remained affiliated to LU till 2000. Currently, it is an autonomous constituent of APJ Kalam Technical University. Giri Institute of Development StudiesThe journey of GIDS began from a classroom in LU’s economics department, thanks to professor VB Singh who was a friend of India’s fourth President VV Giri. It became a full-fledged institute in 1973 while its longest-serving director, development economist TS Papola, was also a professor of the department. The incumbent director, BK Bajpai, is an LU alumnus. Today, GIDS is one of the premiere centres for advanced research on rural development, labour and livelihood, public health, migration and gender studies.

column2: Ghaziabad to name, shame ‘enemies of environment’
column3: GHAZIABAD: People harming the environment and indulging in banned activities that contribute to pollution in the city will now be named and shamed. District magistrate Ajay Shankar Pandey on Sunday said a board, with the heading ‘enemies of the environment’, will be displayed at the District Collectorate where names of defaulters, as well as their address and the fines imposed on them, will be mentioned on a daily basis. Such boards will also be displayed in every tehsil, block and ward of the district. The names of the defaulters will also be shared on WhatsApp and displayed on the district administration’s website. Pandey has written to councillors and gram pradhans to look into the pollution-related issues in their areas. He added that legal action will be initiated against those people on whose plots illegal activities are being carried out. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSWhy top JD(U) leaders are shying away from campaigning in Assam?Bihar’s ruling JD(U) has claimed that it has fielded its candidates in 37 out of the 126 assembly constituencies in Assam. But what has baffled poll analysts is that all of JD(U)’s top leaders, including CM Nitish Kumar, have so far stayed away from campaigning. Opposition leaders in Bihar alleged that JD(U) is not campaigning in Assam because of “certain pressure” from BJP.Sporadic violence marks first phase of Bengal pollsSporadic incidents of violence were reported from some areas that are voting in the first phase of the assembly elections in West Bengal on Saturday, even as the overall poll situation was peaceful with 36.09 per cent turnout recorded till 11 am, officials said.Elections are being held in 30 seats, most of which are in the once-Naxal-affected Jungle Mahal region.“An integrated and detailed plan has been prepared to keep a tab on violators. Councillors and gram pradhans have also been involved. The Ghaziabad municipal commissioner has also been asked to convene a meeting of councillors in this regard. Likewise, panchayat raj officials, sub-divisional magistrates and block development officers have been asked to coordinate with gram pradhans,” the DM added. Pandey said various civic agencies, including GMC, Ghaziabad Development Authority, UP Housing and Development Board and Uttar Pradesh State Industrial Development Corporation, have once again been directed to ensure that garbage or stubble is not burnt in their areas. Top CommentIs this a joke? Ghaziabad got the worst people and the admin system. If they start shame people they would run out of boards WarSee All CommentsAdd comment“They have been asked to take strict legal action, including lodging FIRs, against the violators, besides taking immediate steps to curb those fires,” he said. The additional district magistrate (city) and ADM (finance and revenue) have been made the nodal officers of urban and rural areas, respectively. Lekhpals have been asked to monitor activities in rural areas, while sanitation supervisors will carry out similar work in the urban areas.

column2: IIM-Lucknow: When Ravana cautioned Ram against pollution
column3: LUCKNOW: Sunday saw management students giving a modern twist to the classic tale of Ramayana with themes like corruption and air pollution at Indian Institute of Management- Lucknow's (IIM-L) annual fest 'Manfest Varchasva-2019'. Students from colleges across the country staged plays which spread awareness about challenges like rising air pollution, corruption and the lack of women empowerment with Ramayana as a backdrop on the last day of the fest. It was the first time that plays based on Ramayana were staged at IIM-L. 'Ravana Leela' was the first play to be staged. The audience broke into fits of laughter when Dhaniyah Mehandi, the student who was portraying Ravana, told his arch nemesis Ram, "My wife Mandodri told me that the air on earth is too polluted. If you want to visit earth, wear a mask." NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSWhy top JD(U) leaders are shying away from campaigning in Assam?Bihar’s ruling JD(U) has claimed that it has fielded its candidates in 37 out of the 126 assembly constituencies in Assam. But what has baffled poll analysts is that all of JD(U)’s top leaders, including CM Nitish Kumar, have so far stayed away from campaigning. Opposition leaders in Bihar alleged that JD(U) is not campaigning in Assam because of “certain pressure” from BJP.Sporadic violence marks first phase of Bengal pollsSporadic incidents of violence were reported from some areas that are voting in the first phase of the assembly elections in West Bengal on Saturday, even as the overall poll situation was peaceful with 36.09 per cent turnout recorded till 11 am, officials said.Elections are being held in 30 seats, most of which are in the once-Naxal-affected Jungle Mahal region."We have tried to use a satirical approach to address two problems which our country faces today - corruption and pollution," said Abhishek Shukla, who essayed the role of Ram. In the next play 'Ramlila Machan', the participants shed light on how even mythology stressed on women empowerment and enacted Sita's swayamvar. Latest CommentOur old history is written in symbolic form. We are not able to decode itK P PandeySee All CommentsAdd commentThe last play 'Ravana ki Samsya' was a take on how Ramlila characters are dealing with corruption. "The play explores how Ramlila characters are exploited. The villain is not the actor who plays Ravana, but the producer of the Ramlila who doesn't share the profits of the show with his team," said MBA student Anubhav. IIM-L had approached the Ayodhya Research Institute (ARI) to sponsor Ramayana-based events in October. The institute, which comes under he UP culture department, wrote to the tourism department seeking funds. IIM-L received Rs 2.50 lakh to organise the events.

column2: Air quality index: NCR towns fare well, Gurugram best
column3: NEW DELHI: NCR towns of Ghaziabad, Noida and Greater Noida fared well in terms of air quality on Sunday, with readings in the "poor" category. Meanwhile, the air quality in Gurugram and Faridabad was in "moderate" range, according to CPCB's index. In fact, Gurugram was the cleanest in NCR with an AQI reading of just 136 at 4pm on Sunday. SAFAR, a body under the Union ministry of earth sciences, stated that the contribution of stubble burning to Delhi's PM concentration was just 2% on Sunday with the strong surface winds helping matters. Track the pollution level in your cityLatest Commentwhat about Vaishali GhaziabadAshishSee All CommentsAdd comment "Strong surface and boundary layer winds have contributed to the quick recovery for Delhi. The high surface winds are forecast to continue for the next 24 hours and, thereafter, likely to decrease slowly. AQI is likely to stay in the 'moderate' to the lower end of 'poor' category for Monday," it stated. column2: A memorable farewell in Lucknow
column3: A private club of Lucknow recently organized a farewell meeting for its Chairman Dr Anup Chandra Pandey, former Chief Secretary, UP. The party was held at a well-known hotel in Hazratganj. RN Bhargava presented the achievements of the club chairman where he talked about some of Pandey’s achievements including setting up of the Environment Cell, Science Cell, Technologies Cell and Culture and Heritage Cell, among others. (L) Alok Ranjan (R) Atul Gupta (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Alok Ranjan (R) Atul Gupta (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) “It had been a pleasure to work with Dr Pandey. He always spared time to discuss club matters with a smile. His commitments towards his work was exemplary. He once even hosted a meeting at his residence,” shared RN Bhargava. (L) Dr Mansoor Hasan (R) Dr PK Seth and NN Upadhyay (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Dr Mansoor Hasan (R) Dr PK Seth and NN Upadhyay (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) The meeting concluded with a dinner where the members personally congratulated Dr Anup Chandra Pandey and appreciated the service he bestowed on the club. — Saad Abbasi (L) Jayant Krishna (R) KL Satapathy and SC Sharma (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Jayant Krishna (R) KL Satapathy and SC Sharma (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Kanak Rekha Chauhan (R) Prem Lata Gulati and Rinoo Verma (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Kanak Rekha Chauhan (R) Prem Lata Gulati and Rinoo Verma (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Qamar Rahman (R) Rajeev Verma, GK Chaturvedi and NK Trivedi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Qamar Rahman (R) Rajeev Verma, GK Chaturvedi and NK Trivedi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Usha Gupta (R) Sadhana Agarwal (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) (L) Usha Gupta (R) Sadhana Agarwal (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

column2: The whole family laughs at the memes made on Neha: Tony Kakkar
column3: In Lucknow to perform for the first time, music composer, singer and songwriter Tony Kakkar of Coca Cola Tu fame seemed quite excited about his gig. In a freewheeling chat with us, Tony talked about his Lucknow visit, sibling bond with sisters Sonu and Neha Kakkar, the trend of singles, and more... You are performing in Lucknow today. Is this your first visit to the city?Well, if you talk about performing, yes, I am performing live for the first time for Lucknowites. But talking about coming here, I have been to Lucknow a couple of times before too. When Sonu didi used to perform here, I have come with her. The thing that I remember about Lucknow is the tehzeeb. Bahut hi tameez aur tehzeeb se Lucknow ke log baat karte hain. And yes, not to forget, yahan ke Tunday Ke Kebabs ki bhi bahut charcha rehti hai har jagah though I am a vegetarian. If I will have time after the performance, I will be going to have the famous Lakhnawi chaat. Is there any specific reason why you prefer composing only Hindi songs and not Punjabi?NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSWhy top JD(U) leaders are shying away from campaigning in Assam?Bihar’s ruling JD(U) has claimed that it has fielded its candidates in 37 out of the 126 assembly constituencies in Assam. But what has baffled poll analysts is that all of JD(U)’s top leaders, including CM Nitish Kumar, have so far stayed away from campaigning. Opposition leaders in Bihar alleged that JD(U) is not campaigning in Assam because of “certain pressure” from BJP.Sporadic violence marks first phase of Bengal pollsSporadic incidents of violence were reported from some areas that are voting in the first phase of the assembly elections in West Bengal on Saturday, even as the overall poll situation was peaceful with 36.09 per cent turnout recorded till 11 am, officials said.Elections are being held in 30 seats, most of which are in the once-Naxal-affected Jungle Mahal region.The trend of Punjabi singles and albums was always there. But for some time, the trend of non-filmi Hindi singles and albums faded away. But believe me, it is really difficult today to get a Hindi single hit because our competition is directly with Bollywood music. Punjabi mein ek edge hoti hai as Punjab is a country-like state. The support there is too much. I am really happy that woh agar hit ho rahe hain aaj ke time pe mere toh I am blessed. I am really happy to see today that the number of singles all over the country has increased manifold. Aaj ke time pe toh bahut zyada non-filmi music ho raha hai hamari industry mein. The top 10 songs list in the country today has majority of non-filmi songs. Tony Kakkar (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) Tony Kakkar (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav) What is your personal favourite genre of music?I like soft romantic tracks and ghazals a lot. But unfortunately there is hardly any demand for ghazals these days, which is really sad! I did compose a ghazalish kind of a song Zindagi Mil Jayegi with Neha (Kakkar) but I gave it a different twist to it so that it can be liked by the youth of today. Your sister Neha mentioned the struggles all three of you had before making it big in the music industry. How has the journey been so far?When my sisters Sonu didi and Neha used to go for jagratas in Delhi, I too would accompany them as a backing vocalist. I also used to compose Mata ki bhetein for them. Even though all three of us are quite well settled now, that was the best phase of our lives as we used to perform together. As unbelievable as it might sound, but we would be booked for bhajan sandhyas and mata ke jagrate for the whole month. It was only during monsoons that we used get a break. We did that for almost 12 years. So as siblings all three of us came together a lot. Hamare koi dost hi nahi hote thay and we used to be each other’s friends as well. So did anyone of you help each other in making a career in the music industry?No, all three of us had our own share of struggles and couldn’t help each other. Sonu didi got her first break when she participated in a reality show and music directer Sandeep Chowta loved her voice and promised her a break in his next venture. Neha was busy with her own set of struggles. She participated in Indian Idol and then couldn't make it but then met Pritam da who gave her Second Hand Jawani. I met Pooja Bhatt ma’am, who made me meet Bhushan Kumar sir, who gave me Saawan Aaya Hai song. So hum teenon hi struggle karte rahe apni apni and couldn't help each other. How did you help your sister cum friend fight depression after she broke off with her boyfriend Himansh Kohli?We siblings are really well connected and bonded even though we might not meet daily now. Time healed Neha automatically. yes she used to feel weak emotionally a lot. In fact, Neha is the most emotional of us three. I advised her to not react and say things openly. I explained to her to not show the sad side of her to her fans and we should make our fans feel happy all the time. Neha has a lot of young fans who get depressed seeing her sad. Aur waise bhi Neha ki toh smile bahot achhi hai. What about the memes made on Neha’s habit of crying at the drop of a hat?Neha ke rote hue memes toh maine bhi bahot dekhe hain. The whole family laughs at the memes made on Neha. We actually take them in a lighter way. You have also been advocating for equal royalties for singers and writers. How successful has it been so far?Main thodi apni pakad bana loon then definitely I will work towards it. I need the support of the singers. I was hearing about Santosh Anand ji who has written the song Ek Pyaar Ka Nagma Hai, he now needs financial help today though his song is a nation wide hit even today. The song has earned a lot of money but none of that went to the song writer, which is really sad to know. I want to make a route for that money to reach all levels and that can happen only once I know the real business secrets of this music industry.

column2: Kanpur jail inmate dies in mysterious condition
column3: KANPUR: A 22-year-old district jail inmate, booked for indulging in a brawl, died after developing complications, under mysterious circumstances on Sunday morning. Mohammad Adil, a resident of Talaq Mahal, was admitted to the district jail hospital after he complained of chest pain on early Sunday morning. When his condition deteriorated, the jail administration shifted him to the Ursula Horseman hospital where doctors declared him brought dead on arrival. He was arrested by the Beconganj police on August 8 this year for his alleged involvement in disrupting the peace of the area following a protest erupted after the death of a private worker who had died of electrocution on July 26. The Beconganj police informed the deceased family members about his death who have demanded a probe in this regard. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Taufeeq, Adil's elder, said the Beconganj police had nabbed his brother on August 8. "About a fortnight ago, I visited the jail to meet my brother and found him fit," Taufeeq said. He has demanded a fair probe in the case. Jail superintendent, Ashish Tiwari said that Adil, after his arrest, was lodged in the district jail on August 8. "On Sunday morning, he complained of chest pain, and he was admitted to the jail hospital. When his condition deteriorated, we took him to the Ursula hospital where doctors declared him brought dead on arrival. As per police officials, since the cause of his death in the postmortem report could not become clear, his viscera has been preserved, Tiwari added.

column2: Three more Muslim litigants will file review petitions in SC against Ayodhya verdict
column3: LUCKNOW: Three more Muslim litigants in the Ayodhya case on Monday said they would file review petitions against Supreme Court’s November 9 verdict. With this, seven of the 10 Muslim litigants have declared their intention to go for a review. On Sunday, three Muslim litigants under the aegis of All India Muslim Personal Law Board (AIMPLB) had announced that they would file review petitions against the verdict. Besides, Jamiat Ulama-i-Hind, another party to the dispute, said it would separately file a review plea. Ayodhya verdict: Complete coverageThe three parties who gave their consent for the legal drill on Monday are Haji Mehboob, Maulana Hizbullah and the two sons of late Haji Abdul Ahad (one of the first Muslim litigants), Haji Asad Ahmad and Hafiz Rizwan. “I have given my consent to AIMPLB and I will join the other Muslim parties on the Ayodhya issue,” Haji Mehboob told TOI. Mehboob did a U-turn on Monday as just two days ago, he had met AIMPLB’s expelled cleric Maulana Salman Nadwi on the outskirts of Ayodhya on Saturday, claiming that a review was not required. Nadwi was accompanied by a representative of mediation panel member Sri Sri Ravi Shankar. Haji Asad Ahmad, told TOI: “We will exercise our constitutional rights to file a review petition. I and my brother Rizwan are buoyed by hope and we wish to fight the legal battle.” Asad is a corporator of Ayodhya Municipal Corporation. Maulana Hizbullah told TOI that he had given his consent to AIMPLB for a review petition. “It’s necessary. We must exercise our constitutional rights and we will fight till the end.” On Sunday, AIMPLB, an umbrella body of Muslim organisations in the country, said though it was not a party in the case, it had been extending legal support to Muslim litigants. The only three Muslim litigants which have decided not to go for a review petition are UP Sunni Central Waqf Board, Shia Central Waqf Board of UP and Iqbal Ansari. On Sunday, besides Jamiat, Mohammad Umar, Misbahuddin and Maulana Mehfuzar Rehman had given nod for filing review petitions.

column2: Three more Muslim litigants to file Ayodhya review plea
column3: LUCKNOW/AYODHYA: A day after All India Muslim Personal Law Board (AIMPLB) announced its decision to go for review of the Ayodhya verdict, three more litigants from the temple town confirmed their readiness to file pleas in Supreme Court, taking the count to seven. On Monday, three others who gave their consent to go through the legal drill included Haji Mehboob, Maulana Hizbullah and Haji Asad Ahmad/Hafiz Rizwan, sons of one of the first Muslim litigants, Haji Abdul Ahad. With this seven of 10 Muslim parties have agreed to go for review, barring UP Sunni Central Waqf Board, UP Shia Central Waqf Board and key litigant Iqbal Ansari. On Sunday, besides Jamiat Ulama-i-Hind, which announced its decision to independently file a petition, three litigants who were first of the blocks included Mohammad Umar, Misbahuddin and Maulana Mehfuzar Rehman. Talking to TOI, Haji Mehboob said, "I have given my consent to AIMPLB and I will join the Muslim parties on the Ayodhya issue." Mehboob had met AIMPLB's expelled cleric Maulana Salman Nadwi on Ayodhya's outskirts on Saturday, where he claimed a review was not required. Nadwi was accompanied by a representative of mediation panel member, Sri Sri Ravi Shankar. I and my brother Rizwan are buoyed by hope and we wish to fight the legal battle." Asad, a corporator of Ayodhya Municipal Corporation, is continuing his father's legal legacy. column2: 108 ‘Rams’ from India set to wed ‘Sitas’ in Janakpur
column3: Week after the Supreme Court cleared the construction of the Ram Temple on the disputed site in Ayodhya, the Karsewaks have made a clarion call for an alliance between eligible bachelors in Uttar Pradesh and women in Nepal’s Janakpur. Latest CommentCrazy.Niladrinath MohantySee All CommentsAdd commentAs many as 108 men from Meerut, Saharanpur, Ayodhya, Lucknow in UP to Indore, Bhopal in MP and Patna and Sitamarhi in Bihar have signed up for the event, organisers of Dharmyatra Mahasangh, a Vishwa Hindu Parsiahd body said. The event is being billed as Shri Ram Janaki Vivah Barat Yatra — Ayodhya se ShriDham Janaakpur.The marriage procession and subsequent ceremonies will be spread over 13 days, including Tilokatsav, Kanya pujan, beginning November 21 from Janki Ghat in Karsevakpuram in Ayodhya.

column2: What was Agra called before it was named Agra? Scholars splitting hair
column3: LUCKNOW: Agra based Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar University (BAU) has a new task these days that has put its history department blowing dust off old books and digging deep into state and central libraries. District administration of the Taj Mahal city has asked the university to look for ‘verifiable evidence’ of Agra’s ancient names, if there were any. The university, which received the letter from the administration a few days back, has handed over the task to its history department, which has already put research scholars and professors to work on the project. “A letter from the administration was sent to our vicechancellor who forwarded it to the history department. As per the correspondence we have been asked to find verifiable and solid evidence on ancient names of Agra, if there were any,” said Prof Sugam Anand, head of BAU’s history department. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.While no time limit has been set for the university to research on the topic, Prof Anand said that apart from members of the university, even individual scholars working on the city’s history, archaeologists and historians will be approached by BAU for the research. “We will try our best to go through all resources present on the subject, be it state or central libraries or other reference points,” he added. Prof Anand also said that it was not the first time the university was asked to research on a particular topic of interest. “We were asked by the central government through the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) to research about Shivaji’s prison,” said the history department head. Latest CommentYogi govt taking UP to dark and regressive age, and wasting public tax money in unnecessary work.ravidas599See All CommentsAdd comment“There are a number of theories tracing Agra’s origin, some are around Rishi Angira, some from the Mahabharat times Agravan. We need to verify these,” he said. “If the request of finding ancient names for Agra has been brought up, there must be something to be found about it in ancient Indian history,” he added.
