column2: Uttar Pradesh: How to stop child marriage? Girls who resisted to offer help
column3: LUCKNOW: One act of courage can lead to a big change. A bunch of brave school girls in Uttar Pradesh have proved this. As many as 375 girl students of classes up to VIII who had opposed their own marriage at an early age and helped in changing their family’s thought process would now become a part of a case study to formulate plans to deal with the menace. Five girls would be selected from each district for the study. Their stories are expected to help in preparing plans for their betterment and to present them as example in front of other students. The state education department has sought a detailed and in-depth case study from officials of each of the 75 districts. The state government would also launch a fourmonth-long campaign titled ‘Khushiyon ke sapne buno, baal vivah nahi shiksha chuno’ (Weave dreams of happiness, chose education and not early marriage). NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.This is aimed to make people aware of the ills of child marriage. State coordinator for gender equity in Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan Sarita Singh told TOI, “There is a notion in urban society that early marriages do not happen in today’s era. This is not true. According to data, lakhs of girls are married before they turn 18.” She said, “The girls’ cases will be evidence for people who consider child marriages a thing of the past.” The department will also felicitate these girls. Top Commentwe need to help rural grow out of this to progressKaran ParwaniSee All CommentsAdd commentThe campaign will start in the first week of December and will end on Women’s Day on March 8. In schools, students themselves will be prepared to fight against child marriage through ‘Meena Manch’. The platform will be used to raise awareness among parents in the area.

column2: Ram Janki baraat: Nepal brides for 108 men from UP, MP, Bihar
column3: LUCKNOW: A week after the Supreme Court cleared the construction of Ram Temple on the disputed site in Ayodhya, kar sevaks have made a clarion call for an alliance between eligible bachelors in Uttar Pradesh and women in Nepal's Janakpur. As many as 108 men from Meerut, Saharanpur, Ayodhya and Lucknow in UP, Indore and Bhopal in MP and cities from Bihar have signed up for the event. Organisers of Dharmyatra Mahasangh, a Vishwa Hindu Parishad body, said that the event is being billed as Shri Ram Janaki Vivah Baraat Yatra-Ayodhya se Shri Dham Janakpur. The marriage procession and subsequent ceremonies will be spread over 13 days, including tilokatsav and kanya pujan, beginning from November 21 from Janki Ghat in Karsevakpuram in Ayodhya. The procession will culminate on December 4 in Gorakhpur, the bastion of chief minister Yogi Adityanath upon return from Nepal. The procession will have eight welcome points, where extravagant meals by devotees and enthusiasts will be served. These are Ambedkarnagar, Mau and Azamgarh in UP and Buxar, Pataliputra, Hajipur, Muzaffarpur, Sitamarhi, Darbhanga and Motihari in Bihar. In Nepal, the weddings will take place at Dashrath Mandir.  "Jo is vivah lila yagya ka darshan karta hai, woh bhakti bhaav ki surmari mai avgahan karta hai (the person who watches this marriage immerses in worship of God)," the event's invitation says.  The invite also says the event will strengthen ties between Nepal and India, which are culturally one country yet separated by borders. "We should not see the event as a milestone after Ram Temple verdict or reinforcement of VHP's efforts to build the temple. This happens every five years. We will also organise a Dhanush Yagya. From saints, to UP CM and PM Narendra Modi and Nepal's kingdom, we have invited everyone," said Rajendra Singh Pankaj, the organiser.

column2: With 22,300 road accident deaths, Uttar Pradesh tops India list
column3: LUCKNOW: Uttar Pradesh with 22,256 causalities topped the chart of road accident deaths in the country in 2018. On an average, 60 road crash deaths were recorded in the state every day, according to the latest Road Accident Report. The state was at the top of the same list in 2017 too. Though Tamil Nadu (Rank 1) and Madhya Pradesh (Rank 2) recorded more road accidents in comparison to UP (Rank 3), the number of fatalities in these two states was lesser than Uttar Pradesh. In 2018, a total 63,920, accidents were reported in Tamil Nadu, which was 50% more than UP but the number of deaths was 39% lesser than UP. Likewise, Madhya Pradesh, recorded 51,397 accidents in 2018 which killed 10,706 persons. When compared to UP, the number of accidents was 20% higher but that of death was 51% lesser than UP. In Tamil Nadu, the rate of accidents came down by 2.5% and in MP by 3.7%. But UP recorded an increase of 9.8% in the same period. Experts attribute the higher number of road crash fatalities in UP to poor referral system. Dr Ajai Singh of KGMU’s orthopaedics and surgery department said there is no dedicated medical arrangement in place to attend to road accident victims. “Road accident victims must be provided medical aid during the golden hour, but our state lacks proper network of ambulances, police also react late while primary health centres are ill-equipped to tackle such cases,” he said. Ashutosh Soti, founder of Shubham Soti Foundation, a Lucknow-based NGO working for road safety, said that awareness about road accidents and primary treatment to victims should be made part of school curriculum. “The state has started taking initiatives like adding ambulance in UP 112 emergency helpline and conducting road safety audits but more has to be done like regular awareness drives to curb road crashes and deaths,” he added.

column2: Two thrash and rob jeweller, pregnant wife at gunpoint
column3: GHAZIABAD: Two robbers allegedly broke into a jeweller’s showroom in Loni on Saturday evening. The assailants allegedly robbed the showroom owner at gunpoint and fled with jewellery worth Rs 4 lakh and over Rs 20,000 in cash. According to police, the shop’s owner has been identified as Rajnath Gupta, a resident of Ghaziabad. Rajnath told TOI that the two men had also thrashed him and his three-month pregnant wife. “My wife suffered a miscarriage, as she was thrashed very badly by the assailants,” he added. “Around 8pm on Saturday, I was in the shop along with my wife. We both had to meet one of my friends in Delhi. Suddenly, two people stopped a bike in front of my shop. They came inside and asked me to show some good gold rings. I showed him five rings, but one of them kept the rings in his pocket and pointed a pistol at me and my wife. I tried to resist but they started beating me and when my wife tried to intervene, they thrashed her as well,” Rajnath said. He further said the assailants took jewellery worth Rs 4 lakh in a bag and Rs 20,000 cash. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Rajnath told TOI that at first, the police refused to take his complaint but agreed to take it after sometime. But they never lodged it. “I have given my complaint but sub-inspector Ramnarayan denied to take it,” he added. Neeraj Kumar Jadaun, SP (rural), said Ramnarayan Singh, chowki-incharge of DLF, was sent to police line on Monday as he had not informed the higher authority about the case and did not lodge Rajnath’s complaint. “A police inquiry will be conducted against the chowki in-charge and if I find there is any involvement of Singh into the robbery, then he will have to face action accordingly,” Jadaun said. The SP said an FIR has been lodged on Rajnath’s complaint under Section of robbery and sections will be increased once police receive the medical report of miscarriage.

column2: School kids’ fun and learn lessons with Vartika Singh in Lucknow
column3: With the aim to spread awareness about proper diet and nutrition, Vartika Singh, Miss Diva Universe 2019, visited an intermediate college in Mohanlalganj district of Lucknow on Friday afternoon. An excited lot of students waited eagerly for Vartika to arrive, standing in a long queue that started from the college gate. More than a thousand students gathered at the college campus and welcomed Vartika with a huge round of applause the moment she stepped out of her car while a few showered flower petals on her. Vartika sat down with the students and had the mid-day meal of pulao and kheer served to them at the school (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Vartika sat down with the students and had the mid-day meal of pulao and kheer served to them at the school (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Seeing the excited students and the faculty at the Navjeevan Inter College, Vartika, who belongs to Lucknow, said, "It’s so wonderful to be here. As a founder of my NGO, Pure Humans, I want to talk to these kids and youngsters about the importance of proper nutrition and how they should follow a basic health routine. These are growing kids and they need to be well informed about nutrition, especially at an early age because when you grow up, there’s nothing that you can reverse so the foundation needs to be strong, that’s what we believe in. As Pure Humans, our idea is to make the foundation as strong as possible so that our tomorrow is really bright. I’m sure it’s going to be a fun session today and I’m really looking forward to it." Vartika Singh was greeted with warmth and enthusiasm by students of the Navjeevan Intermediate College, Mohanlalganj, who lined up on both sides of the road to welcome her (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Vartika Singh was greeted with warmth and enthusiasm by students of the Navjeevan Intermediate College, Mohanlalganj, who lined up on both sides of the road to welcome her (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Dressed in a blue gown, Vartika interacted with the kids and their parents and ditching the chair and table set for her, instead addressed them standing under a huge banyan tree. "I want to interact with them on a one to one basis. I don’t want a barrier of a table in between us," said she as she climbed on the platform built around the tree. The interaction kick-started with a formal introduction of Vartika and the students and soon after that she briefed them about the need for proper nutrition and about the various sources of basic vitamins and how to derive them from our daily food items. "You know when your nails start turning inside, that means that your body is deficient in some nutrition. If the nutrition intake is good, your nails will also look healthy and shiny," shared the glamorous diva, who also gave students tips on hygiene and sanitation. SMILE PLEASE! Vartika clicking a selife with the kids (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) SMILE PLEASE! Vartika clicking a selife with the kids (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Having arrived at the college in the afternoon when the students are served the mid day meal, Vartika joined the school staff enthusiastically to distribute the food to some of the students. Having a beauty queen serve them pulao and kheer was the most cherished moment for the students, most of whom come from humble backgrounds. But even after serving all of them, when they didn’t start to eat, Vartika was slightly perplexed. She asked them the reason for not eating the food, to which one of the girls quipped, "Ma’am haath nahi wash kiya hai!" The answer had Vartika pleasantly surprised who promptly led the students outside to wash their hands and then sat down with them to eat the pulao. Emphasising on the need to include fruits in their daily diet, Vartika, later, distributed bananas to the kids. While giving out bananas, the diva spoke about the health benefits of the fruit. Vartika teaching the kids the importance of washing the hands before meals (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Vartika teaching the kids the importance of washing the hands before meals (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) What made the event more special for the kids of the Navjeevan Inter College was when Vartika distributed gifts to the kids which she had especially brought for them. The elated kids cheered out a lot and said "thank you ma’am" in unison after having got lunch boxes, pencil boxes and also piggy banks from the her. Vartika also spent some quality time with the faculty members of the school and tasted the famous gulab jamuns of Mohanlalganj (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Vartika also spent some quality time with the faculty members of the school and tasted the famous gulab jamuns of Mohanlalganj (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) After having spent the better of nearly three hours, Vartika as well as the kids, got a tad emotional when she was to leave for another event. While the students and their parents wished her all the best for the Miss Universe contest, Vartika promised to come and meet them again.  — With inputs from Yashi Agarwal

column2: Dengue? Same symptoms trigger confusion over fever in Lucknow
column3: LUCKNOW: For five days, the Alam family in Balaganj was in a state of terror when Mohammad Hayat (8) was down with high fever and severe muscular pain. As drugs provided little relief and blood test reports took time, news of dengue deaths in city escalated their fear. “After five frightening days, we heaved a sigh of relief when it was confirmed that my child was suffering from high-grade viral fever and not dengue or malaria,” said Hayat’s father Mohammad Parvez Alam. “I took leave from office, browsed internet, and consulted several doctors,” he said.  Like the Alams, several families were distressed for days while waiting for dengue report. Doctors said cases of high-grade fever with temperature soaring to 103-104 degree Fahrenheit have increased. Fever is a common symptom of viral flu, dengue, malaria, typhoid and chikungunya. Blood test generally takes at least three days to confirm virus. During this period, people try all sorts of remedies at home but experts say self-treatment could be fatal. “All these diseases —viral, vector-borne or any other bacterial infection—if monitored and managed properly, are curable,” said associate prof D Himanshu, medicine department of KGMU. Dr Vikaram Singh of Ram Manohar Lohia Institute said, “Most patients take over-the-counter medicine, which can be fatal.” NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“Since lab reports take time, patients switch doctors in pursuit of quick relief, which is also not advisable,” said Dr Tahir Raza, a private practitioner in Chowk.

column2: UPPCL trusts to plead as ‘unsecured creditors’ in Bombay high court
column3: LUCKNOW: The UP State Power Sector Employees’ Trust and UPPCL CPF Trust, which invested employees’ money in the tainted firm DHFL, will claim to be ‘unsecured creditors’ who need to be treated differently when the case comes up for hearing in the Bombay high court on Wednesday. An unsecured creditor is an individual or institution that lends money without obtaining specified assets as collateral, and is thus exposed to higher risk as it does not have anything to fall back on. On Tuesday, UPPCL chairman Arvind Kumar, who is also ex-officio chairman of both trusts, dashed off to Mumbai to meet attorneys of the law firm J Sagar Associates hired for the case. When contacted, Kumar told TOI, “We are keeping our fingers crossed. It is hard earned money of employees which needs to be brought back. We are trying our best.” UPPCL sources said the trusts will inform the Bombay high court about the feeling of insecurity and resentment brewing in employees who are on strike over their PF funds being trapped in DHFL and will request it to lift the freeze on remittances. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.A senior UPPCL official said that the trusts would seek release of over Rs 500 crores which became due on maturity in October but could not be released as the high court had barred DHFL from releasing any money to creditors. “The rest of amount may be released gradually as and when the court permits,” he said. The trusts moved the Bombay high court on Monday as an intervener in the original suit involving Reliance Nippon Life Assets Management Company versus DHFL wherein remittances by the latter were frozen by court. UP energy minister Shrikant Sharma told TOI, “The state government is playing proactive role in ensuring that the interests of employees are not hit.” Convener of UP Rajya Vidyut Karmchari Sangharsh Samiti, Shailendra Dubey, said, “Employees will wait for the high court to deliver its judgement and will then decide future course of action.” The employees have gone on a 48-hour work boycott demanding state government to take guarantee of Rs 2,268 crore trapped in DHFL and seeking a white paper on the investments.

column2: When Lucknow University saw light after three dark decades
column3: In the countdown to LU centenary, TOI through various articles recalled the glorious history of the institution. Beginning today we will focus on the challenges faced by the varsity since 1970s and its struggle for revival 2000 onward. LUCKNOW: Lucknow University which came into existence in 1921 had a golden run till 1960s. It boasted of internationally acclaimed faculty and students from across India who went on to make illustrious careers in their respective fields. But the advent of 70s set in the downturn, recall LU old timers. It started with nepotism, casteism and political interference in the appointment of vice-chancellors and teachers, followed by the derailment of the academic session in 70s. Teaching standards began to drop in 80s while 90s saw the criminalisation of students politics and university’s struggle to procure funds for development works. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.However, the university’s slow revival began in 2000 with regularisation of the academic session and crackdown on students with criminal record. Some departments again rose to prominence. In the present time, fund crunch and academic excellence remain the biggest challenges for the institution in its centenary year. ACADEMICS Most of the LU’s illustrious faculty retired by 1959 and gradually political influence began in the appointment of VCs and teachers, said former LU vice-chancellor Prof Roop Rekha Verma, adding that this had an adverse impact on the varsity’s fortunes. “The academic standard was high till 1967 when I was a student. But gradually favouritism took over merit, and by 80s, caste became a major factor in appointments,” said Prof Dinesh Kumar, former botany HOD who served on various administrative posts in LU. “PAC revolt in 1973, which was supported by a section of students, dealt a severe blow. It led to arson and closure of LU for three months. Thereafter, academic session remained derailed for 25 years, during which meritorious students from across the country stopped opting for LU,” he added. Old timers recall that while the student numbers doubled between 1970-2000 due to the introduction of more courses and evening classes, LU did not see the corresponding increase in the number of teachers. As a result, teacher-student ratio came down from 1:30 in 1970 to 1:90 by 2000. STUDENTS’ UNION Student outfits backed by political parties made debut on LU campus only after Independence. They galvanised students on ideological lines and even produced political stalwarts. But blatant interference of parties in students’ union elections began in 90s when politicians started visiting the campus and openly endorsed candidates. “As students’ union election became launch pads for political careers they became a do or die battle for candidates. Gradually, criminal elements entered the unions, leading to lawlessness on the campus,” said former head of political science department, Prof SK Dwivedi. Lucknow University Alumni Association president and former proctor Prof MP Singh said, “Students’ union became a platform for grabbing government contracts and launching political careers rather than making students aware of various ideologies. Hostels became hideouts of criminals. Every union election witnessed violent clashes and shootouts on the campus. Several murders also took place.” LU alumni recalled how PAC was stationed permanently on the campus and a police outpost was set up due to frequent law and order problem. In 1997, seven student leaders with criminal cases were expelled. They included Abhay Singh and Dhananjay Singh, both of whom are now politicians in UP. Police raids in hostels during that period saw recovery of illegal fire arms and crude bombs. “Between 2004 and 2007, when students’ union system was in place, over a dozen students were killed and hundreds injured in clashes related to union politics. Student leaders extorted money from traders, attacked teachers, abetted mass-copying in examinations and forcibly ensured bogus admissions,” said a retired LU professor FINANCE LU couldn’t keep pace with technology and infrastructure required for quality teaching because of financial constraints post 90s. First blow came in 1995 when the state government said grants would be given equivalent to funds raised by LU through its resources like fees. In 1998, the state government froze the grant of Rs 16 crore and directed state universities to become self-sufficient. “LU introduced several self-finance courses to generate money. But since additional teachers were not recruited, it impacted teaching standard,” said Prof Dinesh Kumar Prof Yashveer Tyagi, former dean of commerce faculty, said, “Cash crunch consumed most of our energy in arranging funds at that time. It reflected in decline in infrastructure and research on the campus.” REVIVAL In 2001, academic session was regularised by then VC Prof DP Singh. In 2006, then VC Prof RP Singh purged hostels and ousted over 100 students with criminal record. Since then LU has had a peaceful atmosphere and some of its departments have shot into prominence again.

column2: Haryana has 5 of 10 cleanest districts; half of 10 dirtiest are from Odisha: Swachh rural survey
column3: NEW DELHI: Five of the top 10 cleanest districts in 2019 are from Haryana while five of the 10 dirtiest districts are from Odisha, according to the latest Swachhta Survey report released by sanitation ministry. Peddapalli in Telangana was found to be the cleanest district, a distinction which went to Satara in Mahrashtra in 2018. Two districts each from Tamil Nadu and Gujarat made it to the list of top ten cleanest districts. In Delhi’s neighbourhood, Faridabad was adjudged the second cleanest district while Gurgaon, Ghaziabad and Gautam Budh Nagar ranked 25th, 129th and 172nd in the list. Delhi was not included since all districts in the city are largely urbanised. The drinking water and sanitation department under the Jal Shakti ministry released the report on ranking of 683 districts on Tuesday, which was based on a set of parameters including self-reporting by districts, data from Swachh Bharat Mission – Grameen, village-level surveys of public places like schools, anganwadi centres, health centres, haat, panchayat and citizen’s perception of Swachhata. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Prime Minister Narendra Modi had released the list of only three top ranking districts and states on October 2 at Sabarmati in Gujarat to mark the culmination of Swachh Bharat Mission, which was launched in 2014. According to the report, 77 districts of 683 districts scored more than 80 on a scale of 0-100. The survey covered 17,209 villages for little over a month in August-September this year. It found that over 97% of citizens claimed to be aware of the Swachhta survey and over 81% ascribe improvement in rural cleanliness. Strikingly, 84% of respondents reported efficient solid waste management arrangements which included garbage pits, compost pits and waste collection and disposal pits. The report said 83% citizens claimed efficient disposal of liquid waste in their villages in terms of drains, soak pits, kitchen garden. The third party observers who visited public places such as religious places, ‘haats’, health centres and government schools found that at least 72% of such areas had access to toilets. They also found that nearly 88% of the public places were free of plastic litter and over 92 % were devoid of stagnant waste water. Latest CommentWell done.narasaraoSee All CommentsAdd comment“The survey was highly extensive and rigorous in its coverage. Participation of citizens was voluntary. Feedback was garnered from over three crore citizens via mobile app and over 12 lakh people sent their feedback via interactive voice response. Another 1.74 lakh face-to-face interactions were carried out with key informants to capture village level information and about 17,197 group meetings with citizens were held to capture their perceptions on key indicators,” the report said. Officials said to ensure no survey conditions were flouted, the entire process used GPS technology to check on the interviewer.

column2: Two former district magistrate’s of Ghaziabad face probe in Rs 27 crore land scam
column3: GHAZIABAD/LUCKNOW: The state government on Tuesday approved action against two former district magistrates of Ghaziabad, more than two years after they were indicted in a Rs 27crore scam related to acquisition of land for the Delhi-Meerut Expressway. The decision was taken at a state cabinet meeting held in Lucknow, officials said. Uttar Pradesh home secretary Bhagwan S Srivasatava said that the decision to initiate criminal proceedings against former DMs Vimal Sharma and Nidhi Kesarwani, along with other officials posted in Ghaziabad, was taken on the September 2017 recommendations of then Meerut divisional commissioner Prabhat Kumar. “We would seek opinion of legal experts and decide whether a CBI inquiry is required, otherwise state police would be asked to carry out the investigation,” Srivasatava said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The scam pertains to purchase of agricultural land at throwaway prices from farmers of Dasna, Rasoolpur Sikrod, Kushalia and Nahal villages by family members of some Ghaziabad officials in 2013 after it got notified for Delhi-Meerut Expressway project, for which they later got enhanced compensation than the prevailing circle rate from the government. According to Prabhat Kumar, the then ADM (land acquitistion) Ghanshyam Singh’s son Shivang, land accountant of Nahal village Santosh Kumar and his four relatives, and an agent got the enhanced compensation from the UP government through arbitration proceedings presided over by two successive DMs — Vimal Sharma and Nidhi Kesarwani. Thanks to the arbitration proceedings, Shivang and others made a profit of Rs 26.96 crore from the sale of their land to the government for the expressway project, the commissioner had said in his report on the scam that he unearthed while investigating the complaints of three farmers. While Vimal Sharma retired from the administrative services in April 2018, an IAS officer of 2004 batch, Nidhi Kesarwani was repatriated to her home cadre (Manipur) in March 2018. Sharma served as Ghaziabad DM between June 2014 and July 2016. Having replaced Sharma as the Ghaziabad district magistrate , Kesarwani's tenure ended in April 2017. Latest CommentThis is the primary reason why these officials did everything to try to kick out a good DM like Ritu Maheshwari. When everything failed, they got her ''promoted'' to Noida. Ghaziabad''s entire set up...Read MoreSurinder GujjarSee All CommentsAdd commentIncidentally, the income tax department had carried out searches across multiple locations in May 2017 to find out if Vimal Sharma and his wife Mamta Sharma, also a government official, had amassed wealth disproportionate to their known income sources. Prime Minister Narendra Modi had laid the foundation stone for the Delhi-Meerut Expressway project in December 2015. The acquisition of land began soon.

column2: Ghaziabad: Five illegal units sealed for flouting pollution rules, 49 booked, 2 held
column3: GHAZIABAD: In a crackdown against illegal units involved in burning cables to extract copper and other metals in Loni, a joint team of district administration and police lodged an FIR against 49 people for creating public nuisance, endangering lives and disobedience to government order at Loni Border police station. According to sources, two persons were arrested. The district administration officials said action under the Gangster Act would also be initiated against them. The joint team, headed by district magistrate Ajay Shankar Pandey and SSP Sudhir Kumar Singh, raided the factories in Behta Hajipur and adjoining areas on Tuesday and seized around 150 quintals of wires from various illegal warehouses. As many as five warehouses were sealed. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.DM Pandey said instructions have been given to the Loni Border police to ensure that prohibited consignments are not brought here for disposal. Moreover, Loni Nagar Palika Parishad has been directed to ask the public to refrain from prohibited activities and deposit the illegal raw materials at its office within two days. Meanwhile, taking a strong view of construction as well as garbage burning in the Uttar Pradesh State Industrial Development Corporation (UPSIDC) area, Pandey on Tuesday ordered adverse entry against UPSIDC senior manager (civil) Panna Lal in his service record for lackadaisical approach towards duty. The senior official recommended suspension of assistant manager (civil) Satish Chaudhary to UPSIDC managing director in Kanpur. The DM also sought a clarification from UPSIDC regional manager Smita Singh for the failure to implement orders related to pollution control. A day earlier, the district administration had ordered registration of an FIR against the owner of a plot in Bulandshahr road industrial area at Kavi Nagar police station after a heap of garbage was found to be set on fire. A sum of Rs 25,000 was also imposed on the accused as a compensation towards environmental damage in accordance with the National Green Tribunal’s directive.

column2: In Ghaziabad, cyber crime cases up by 90 times in 4 years
column3: GHAZIABAD: The city, which recorded only 24 cases of crimes under the Information Technology (IT) Act in 2015, has registered 2,133 incidents till August this year. According to police data, Ghaziabad has seen a steep rise – around 8,785% – in the number of cyber crime cases in the past few years. For instance, the number of FIRs related to cyber crime lodged last year was 1,935. Police said that in 2018 and till August 2019, the number of persons arrested under the IT Act from the district was 30 and 20, respectively. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.In the 2,383 cyber crime cases reported between 2015 and 2018, people lost over Rs 1 crore to fraudsters. According to police officers, around 40 per cent of cyber fraud cases were lodged by private firm employees and 20 percent of the registered complaints were made by women who had not received formal education. A senior police officer in the cyber cell said in 85 per cent of the cases, the accused were duped by people who claimed to have called on behalf of some bank. “When police trace such phone numbers, they usually belong to Jharkhand, Nepal, Afghanistan and other places,” he said. Meanwhile, 325 cases were registered between 2015 and 2018 against people for objectionable posts on social media, of which 52 persons were arrested. Till August this year, 229 cases relating to objectionable social media posts were reported in the district. Ten people have been arrested, police data stated. As per police records, 50 cases of hacking and data leaks were reported between 2016 and 2018 and in 2019, 17 cases have been reported so far. Manish Kumar Mishra, SP (city) and head of Cyber-Forensic Laboratory in Ghaziabad said that most of the frauds are related to online shopping done via credit and debit cards. “People very easily reveal their card details to fraudsters who take advantage of that,” he added. Police said, in 25 percent of the cases, victims claimed that there was a withdrawal of money even when they didn’t use their ATM cards. Some of the recent incidents have put the focus back on conversations around how to be vigilant while using bank cards to ensure that they are not misused.

column2: Toxic tap water leaves Lucknow residents high and dry
column3: LUCKNOW: City residents are not only battling toxic air but also receiving water contaminated with bacteria, pesticides, faeces, detergent and metals which make it completely unfit for consumption. Residents of 10 localities of the city where samples were found to be contaminated in a study by Bureau of Indian Standards, confirmed on Tuesday that they are getting supply of pale yellow water which has strong odour and is bitter in taste. The BIS study revealed that all samples taken from 10 localities -Aishbagh, Talkatora, Husainganj, Lalbagh, Charbagh, Jankipuram, Gomtinagar, Alambagh, Aashiana and Balaganj-which get water supply from Lucknow Jal Sansthan were not fit for drinking. TOI visited these localities and spoke to residents who confirmed poor quality water supply and said they had to installed purifiers at their home. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Similar complaints were received from Aashiana, Charbagh, Husainganj, Lalbagh, Aishbagh and Talkatora. According to experts, presence of impurities shows that purification process is inadequate and there are leakages in pipelines that allow mixing of dust and sewage in water. These impurities can cause hepatitis, diarrhoea, dysentery, typhoid, cholera, skin cancer and kidney failure, they added. Latest CommentAn alarming story. Concerned officials must take a note of the issues brought out by the team.Pradip TewariSee All CommentsAdd comment"We try to maintain standards and will take remedial measures to improve purification process," a Jal Sansthan official said.  (With inputs from Akshata Mishra)

column2: Lucknow: 'Munnabhai' constable held for fraud
column3: LUCKNOW: It was an act he pulled off for five years before being busted. A man in the guise of a 'dabang' police constable had been serving sub-divisional magistrates since 2014 before he was finally arrested in Gorakhpur by the Special Task Force (STF) on Tuesday. Ashish Chaturvedi (30) was serving as a gunner to sub-divisional magistrate of Khajani Vivek Kumar when he was arrested. He has been booked for fraud, cheating by impersonation, among others. Chaturvedi's arrest shocked many in Khajani. He used to visit the SSPs office with confidence and was also a part of the meetings with senior police officials, said an officer. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.A khaki uniform with insignia of Uttar Pradesh Police, a fake ID card of UP Police and Rs 60,000 were recovered from him. IG Gorakhpur JN Singh has asked CO Khajani to conduct a probe into Chaturvedi's inclusion as gunner in the SDM's office. SSP STF Rajeev Mishra told TOI that they had received inputs from local intelligence that a man was serving in the guise of police constable. "We conducted an identification drive and it came to light that the batch number Chaturvedi claimed was fake," said Mishra. Latest Commentpunish him hardRewardingSee All CommentsAdd commentChaturvedi began working with SDM Ganghata in Sant Kabir Nagar in 2014. In 2015, after the SDM got transferred, Chaturvedi's guise was exposed. However, in 2017, Chaturvedi migrated and started working with SDM Rudauli in Faizabad, again posing as a constable. In February 2018, Chaturvedi was arrested but released on bail after which he started working with SDM Khajani.

column2: Uttar Pradesh: Census 2021 from May, staff to use mobile app
column3: LUCKNOW: The UP government on Tuesday issued notification for the commencement of Census 2021 in the state from May 2020. It would be the first time when the census enumerators will use an app on their smartphones to collect and upload data as they visit households during the 45-day exercise, instead of feeding data manually in registers. The secretary of general administration, Hari Om, who issued the notification on behalf of the state government, told TOI that the enumerators would be armed with an app on their smart phones for recording data instead of the traditional way of entering it in bulky registers. “The enumerators will use a mobile app for headcount and facilities in households. The digital system being introduced for the first time in this census would be a huge benefit and will reduce chances of flaws as compared to the old system and will also save time in uploading the census data,” said Hari Om. The secretary informed that the next census data would be released in 2021 for which a 45-day massive exercise would begin from May 16, 2020. Before issuing the notification, the Directorate of Census Operations, UP, started a week-long training of master trainers, who would train the census supervisors in the coming days. The training camp was inaugurated by Director of Census Operations, UP, Narendra Shankar Pandey while director-general, Rural Development Training Institute, Venkateshwar Loo, was the chief guest while Hari Om was special guest. The training programmes for the census operation have started and would be subsequently held at district-level to prepare enumerators who would be engaged in the exercise, he said. For the first time, census enumerators will seek information from households on smartphones, DTH/Cable TV connection, internet access, number of members of households having bank accounts, ownership of house other than rented accommodation of a household, bottled water availability and mobile number, Hari Om said.

column2: Ready for patch-up with SP, let Akhilesh be CM: Shivpal Yadav
column3: KANPUR: Shivpal Yadav, the estranged uncle of Samajwadi Party chief Akhilesh Yadav, on Tuesday, expressed willingness to patch up with his nephew, saying he was ready for an alliance for 2022 UP polls and doesn't aspire for CM's post. Talking to reporters in Etawah, Shivpal, the founder-president of Pragatisheel Samajwadi Party (Lohia), said Akhilesh will be next CM if the alliance wins in UP. Shivpal further announced that SP patriarch Mulayam Singh Yadav's birthday would be celebrated in a big way at their native village Saifai on November 22. He said he never aspired for the chief minister's post and if Akhilesh agrees to the alliance, then he will head the government.  " Agar bhatije maan jayenge to sarkar bana lenge, pehle bhi unko hi CM banna tha, mujhe to mukhyamantri banna nahi tha (If Akhilesh agrees, then we will form government. He would have become CM earlier also. I never aspired to become the chief minister)," he added. "I have invited all family members to celebrate Netaji's birthday. It will be good if family ties are strengthened on the occasion. My priority will be to forge alliance with Samajwadi Party," he added. "I have worked very hard with Netaji for a long time and have followed Samajwadi ideology. We are true Samajwadis. Pragatisheel Samajwadi Party is functioning on same Samajwadi ideology," he said. Shivpal's statement comes after Mulayam Singh made efforts to bring Shivpal and Akhilesh together after the party suffered a rout in Lok Sabha elections.

column2: Ready for patch-up with SP, let Akhilesh be CM: Shivpal Yadav
column3: KANPUR: Shivpal Yadav, the estranged uncle of Samajwadi Party chief Akhilesh Yadav, on Tuesday, expressed willingness to patch up with his nephew, saying he was ready for an alliance for 2022 UP polls and doesn't aspire for CM's post. Talking to reporters in Etawah, Shivpal, the founder-president of Pragatisheel Samajwadi Party (Lohia), said Akhilesh will be next CM if the alliance wins in UP. Shivpal further announced that SP patriarch Mulayam Singh Yadav's birthday would be celebrated in a big way at their native village Saifai on November 22. He said he never aspired for the chief minister's post and if Akhilesh agrees to the alliance, then he will head the government.  " Agar bhatije maan jayenge to sarkar bana lenge, pehle bhi unko hi CM banna tha, mujhe to mukhyamantri banna nahi tha (If Akhilesh agrees, then we will form government. column2: The Campus Princess 2020 finalists from Lucknow are...
column3: One platform, two judges, three rounds and 21 participants trying their luck. The Campus Princess 2020 contest, a Miss India organization initiative to scout young and raw talent in colleges at pan India, was held at Asma Hussain Institute of Fashion Technology was recently conducted in the city. The contest had 21 talented girls participating from across the country. (L) Noyonita Lodh (R) Anuj and Vipul Varshney (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Noyonita Lodh (R) Anuj and Vipul Varshney (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) The Campus Princess 2020 was segregated into three different rounds. In the first round, as per the dress code, all the participants wore black coloured dresses, walked the ramp and introduced themselves before the jury. The jury members included Miss Universe India 2014, Noyonita Lodh and fashion designer Asma Hussain. Asma said, "The Campus Princess provides opportunities to girls to participate and get groomed. The quality of girls is also getting better and better by the year." A total of 12 contestants managed to qualify for the second round in which they were required to impress the judges with their intelligence. The participants were asked questions on women empowerment, reservation, humanity, casteism and juvenile act which they answered very thoughtfully. Later, 6 contestants managed to win the hearts of the judges with their responses and entered the final round. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.(L) Asma Hussain (R) Naila Ansari (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Asma Hussain (R) Naila Ansari (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) The final round was a talent round where the participants showcased many talents, one of which happened to be dance performances on trending Bollywood tracks. After a long discussion, the judges picked three finalists Shivani Singh, Megha Sachdeva and Ambika Shukla. The finalists will not compete for the national title of Campus Princess to be held in Mumbai. "When my tag number was announced, I was stupefied for the first few seconds. I feel blessed to have gotten selected and have become one of the finalists for the Campus Princess 2020," said an excited Megha, who is determined to put her best foot forward for the upcoming competitions and challenges. Miss Universe India 2014, Noyonita Lodh said, "All the girls were very well-groomed. It was a tough call selecting one winner so we ended up choosing three lovely girls instead." — Yashi Agarwal and Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui (L) Ridhima Kalra and Aarti Vaid (R) Smriti Raj (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) (L) Ridhima Kalra and Aarti Vaid (R) Smriti Raj (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

column2: Sunni Waqf Board split over SC review plea
column3: LUCKNOW: Three more Muslim litigants in the Ayodhya case on Monday said they would file review petitions against Supreme Court’s November 9 verdict. With this, seven of the 10 Muslim litigants have declared their intention to go for a review. On Sunday, three Muslim litigants under the aegis of All India Muslim Personal Law Board (AIMPLB) had announced that they would file review petitions against the verdict. Besides, Jamiat Ulama-i-Hind, another party to the dispute, said it would separately file a review plea. The three parties who gave their consent for the legal drill on Monday are Haji Mehboob, Maulana Hizbullah and the two sons of late Haji Abdul Ahad (one of the first Muslim litigants), Haji Asad Ahmad and Hafiz Rizwan. “I have given my consent to AIMPLB and I will join the other Muslim parties on the Ayodhya issue,” Haji Mehboob told TOI. Mehboob did a U-turn on Monday as just two days ago, he had met AIMPLB’s expelled cleric Maulana Salman Nadwi on the outskirts of Ayodhya on Saturday, claiming that a review was not required. Nadwi was accompanied by a representative of mediation panel member Sri Sri Ravi Shankar. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Haji Asad Ahmad, told TOI: “We will exercise our constitutional rights to file a review petition. I and my brother Rizwan are buoyed by hope and we wish to fight the legal battle.” Asad is a corporator of Ayodhya Municipal Corporation. Maulana Hizbullah told TOI that he had given his consent to AIMPLB for a review petition. “It’s necessary. We must exercise our constitutional rights and we will fight till the end.” On Sunday, AIMPLB, an umbrella body of Muslim organisations in the country, said though it was not a party in the case, it had been extending legal support to Muslim litigants. Top CommentBarbaric Muslims invaders, with nothing fight and wanting free Hindu land. They were given free Hindu land to form their own barbaric Muslims country and they turned it into a barbaric terrorist Musl...Read MoreKosmic PowerSee All CommentsAdd commentThe only three Muslim litigants which have decided not to go for a review petition are UP Sunni Central Waqf Board, Shia Central Waqf Board of UP and Iqbal Ansari. On Sunday, besides Jamiat, Mohammad Umar, Misbahuddin and Maulana Mehfuzar Rehman had given nod for filing review petitions.

column2: BJP government’s policies are anti-farmer: Shivpal Yadav
column3: KANPUR: President of the Pragatisheel Samajwadi Party (PSP), Shivpal Yadav while dubbing BJP as ‘anti-farmers’ has demanded necessary compensation be given to farmers of the four villages of Unnao district whose land had been acquired by the UPSIDC. Shivpal, who met the farmers of Shankarpur Sarai village in Unnao on Wednesday, accused BJP of being insensitive to their plight. “The policies of the BJP government are anti-farmer. Instead of giving proper compensation to them, they are being brutally hit with lathis. They are reeling in debts as they have been deprived of their land and their standing crop is being razed by JCB machines. They have abandoned their houses and are running for their lives, and many among them have been booked on criminal charges,” Shivpal alleged while talking to mediapersons at Ram Lila ground in Shankarpur Sarai village. He has demanded withdrawal of all cases filed against them. “The Pragatisheel Samajwadi Party (PSP) will fight for the rights of the farmers and force the government to provide necessary compensation to them else the party will stage a protest at the chief minister’s residence in this regard”, he said.

column2: Lucknow landmarks to come alive at Metro stations
column3: LUCKNOW: On the lines of Lucknow Metro, the Uttar Pradesh Metro Rail Corporation (UPMRC) will seek help from students to re-create historical monuments of Industrial City, which will be put on display outside on the walls of Metro stations. According to UPMRC officials, several historical buildings and educational institutes like the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Kanpur, Chandra Shekhar Azad University of Agriculture and Technology, Kanpur railway station and Jain glass temple are proposed to be showcased outside Metro stations through tile work. Moreover, along the lines of Lucknow Metro, the UPMRC will conduct art competitions in several colleges and universities of Kanpur, the selected artwork of historical buildings and monuments will be depicted outside the stations. UPMRC will also hire an experts from Surat, who has previously developed art pieces into huge panels through tile work in Lucknow. UPMRC managing director Kumar Keshav said, “Depending on the concept and availability of space outside the stations, art work will be displayed in all the 31 stations expected to come up in Kanpur Metro.” NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.

column2: Mayor, team catches 40 cattle from Kanpur dairies, realizes Rs 30,000 fine
column3: KANPUR: Following a campaign launched against private dairies operating in the city, a team, led by mayor Pramila Pandey on Wednesday, caught around 40 cattle at Natwan Tola in Juhi area of the city and sent them to a 'gaushala' in Jajmau. The mayor also realized a fine of Rs 30,000 from the dairy owners. The mayor and her team first reached Juhi Natwal Tola along with cattle catching squad and asked the dairy owners to remove their dairies outside the city limits by vehicles to be provided by Kanpur Municipal Corporation (KMC). When the dairy owners opposed the move and accosted the mayor, the police resorted to lathi-charge and dispersed the protestors. During an inspection of another dairy, she found just three animals there. She asked the dairy owner to open the attached room but he refused to provide the keys of the lock. Then the police, on instructions of the mayor, broke open the lock and found that a large number of animals were tied there. The mayor thereafter imposed a fine of Rs 30,000 and realized it from the dairy owners. On Tuesday also, the mayor raided dairies at the 80 Feet road and Ashok Nagar. At one dairy, there were around 50 cattle but the cattle catching squad could catch only three cows and three buffaloes because the squad expressed its helplessness to transport all the cattle to some other place. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The mayor then caught six cattle and sent them to a gaushala warning the dairy owner to shift the dairy at the Cattle Colony situated outside the city limits. She said despite sufficient time given to the dairy owners to remove their dairies, they just ignored the deadline and added that KMC would continue its operation against private dairies, She said the sewer lines get choked and sewage overflow on roads at several places in the city because the dairy owners discharge cow dung in the sewer lines. The KMC has started the campaign against the private dairy owners on the demand of residents. The state government too had issued directives to shift dairies from the city either in the suburbs or outside of the city limit, she added.

column2: Priyanka facing rebels? Only 40 attend UP meet
column3: LUCKNOW: Congress general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra’s plan to rebuild the party in politically crucial UP is facing stiff resistance from the old guard. The discord in ranks was visible at the meeting of former MPs, MLAs, MLCs and 2017 Vidhan Sabha and 2019 Lok Sabha election candidates at UP Congress headquarters on Wednesday, when just 40 of the 350 invitees turned up. Unhappy over the exclusion of old timers from UPCC, the veterans are consolidating to raise the issue with party president Sonia Gandhi and have held two meetings in past fortnight to voice resentment against the ‘undemocratic and ‘arbitrary’ way in which new leadership has been imposed on loyal cadres. The first meeting took place at the residence of Siraj Mehndi in November first week. Mehdi had tendered resignation to Sonia in October, saying not a single Shia was there in the new team. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The second meeting on November 14 was ostensibly called to pay tributes to former PM Jawaharlal Nehru. “One leader even pointed fingers at Priyanka, saying Congress was not a private limited company,” said an insider. The third meeting is likely to be held at former MLA Ranjan Singh Solanki’s residence in Noida where members of the delegation for meeting Sonia will be chosen. Priyanka’s plan of giving command to young faces appears to be backfiring,” said a leader, adding the party needs to strike a balance.
