When asked to comment, Lallu said, “Congress is a big joint family, so difference of opinion is natural. However, each one of us knows how to keep national and party interest above personal opinion.”

column2: Uttar Pradesh: Rajputs want Sultanpur renamed Kushbhawanpur
column3: LUCKNOW: The Sultanpur-based Rajputana Shaurya Foundation on Wednesday met deputy chief minister Keshav Prasad Maurya to push forth their demand for Sultanpur to be renamed Kushbhawanpur—the land where Kush (Lord Ram’s son) lived. A delegation of Rajputs from the foundation had earlier met former UP governor Ram Naik in March 2019. In April, the governor had sent a letter to CM Yogi Adityanath, putting in a word about the delegation’s request. “The deputy CM was in Sultanpur, so we extended our request of renaming the city to him,” said senior lawyer and member of the foundation Arvind Singh ‘Raja’. “Two district gazetteers of Sultanpur, one from 1903 under the British government and the other from 1982 under the UP government, refer to Sultanpur as Kushbhawanpur, Kushpur and Kushvati,” he added. A traditionally held belief that Lord Ram’s son Kush founded the city situated on the banks of the river Gomti has become the foundation’s premise to ask for Sultanpur to be renamed. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The city has a lone bronze idol of Kush on Sitakund Ghat, which came up during the Samajwadi Party’s rule in 2004. Evoking the sentiments of all Sultanpur residents towards the cause, the foundation’s letter claims that renaming the city would also uphold ‘sanatan’ traditions. The foundation’s letter to Maurya on Wednesday also made a reference to poet Kalidas’s ‘Raghuvnash Mahakavya’ and city-based writer Rajeshwar Singh’s book ‘Sultanpur: Itihas ki Jhalak’. The Hindi book mentions that Ram had two sons: Luv and Kush. When the kingdom was divided between the two, Luv ascended the northern portion and the southern went to Kush, which extended till the river Sindika (now Sai). This region, under Kush, is what is today known as Sultanpur.

column2: UPPCL staff warns of indefinite strike
column3: Lucknow: The employees of UPPCL on Wednesday threatened to go on indefinite strike from November 28 against the alleged provident fund scam in the tainted DHFL. The announcement came after the Bombay high court on Wednesday deferred the hearing in the case till November 28. UP power employees’ trust and UPPCL CPF trust had moved the high court on November 18 seeking release of employees’ PF stuck in Dewan Housing and Finance Corporation Limited (DHFL). Sources in UPPCL said the court heard the case of the two trust for three hours before deciding to defer it till next week. The decision to go on an indefinite strike was taken in a meeting of employees held under the aegis of UP Vidyut Karamchari Sangharsh Samiti. The employees have been demanding that the state government releases a white paper on the amount invested in DHFL between March 2017 and December 2018. Earlier, the employees had boycotted work on November 18 and 19. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The junior engineer association of UPPCL has also decided to join the indefinite stir and this will lead to problems in power distribution and transmission system, said Samiti convener Shailendra Dubey. Earlier in the day, Dubey submitted a memorandum to UP BJP chief Swatantra Dev Singh seeking his intervention in the case. On Tuesday, Samiti had sought CM Yogi Adityanath’s intervention to bail out the employees from the crisis. Energy minister Shrikant Sharma said the state government is concerned about the employees’ grievances and considering all options. “This is why a petition was filed in the Mumbai high court and UPPCL chairman Arvind Kumar sent to monitor the proceedings,” he said. Sources reiterated that the government cannot take the guarantee of the money trapped in DHFL because it was invested by a trust. “The trust breached the guidelines that required it to invest in secured government securities,” said an official.

column2: Lucknow: Ignored for days, youth stands on garbage pile, forces LMC to act
column3: LUCKNOW: One man alone can make a difference, even if nobody comes forward to support him. This was proven by a 25-year-old activist in the city on Wednesday. After several complaints about a garbage dump in his locality Daliganj fell on deaf ears and authorities and other residents refused to support him, Rahman Saifi decided to take a stand. Standing firm, literally, Saifi stood on a pile of garbage with posters explaining his protest for one full day. The video of his unique protest went viral on social media, forcing Lucknow Municipal Corporation (LMC) to act. They cleared the rotting garbage dump lying on the roadside for three days, within 20 minutes. According to Saifi, for three days, the dump was not only attracting scores of stray animals, making the area accident-prone, but also leading to dangers to health. Two children in the area had fallen sick—one was down with viral fever and another with diarrhoea. Adding to the menace was the foul smell emanating constantly. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Saifi lodged complaints with LMC zonal officers and the corporator but none of them responded. He then asked his neighbours and family members to hold a demonstration to draw attention of authorities but all of them excused themselves. While some said they were busy, others claimed it was no use doing so as LMC reacts only VIPs are involved. However, this did not stop Saifi, who decided to stage a protest alone. “I printed posters with messages and decided to stand on the garbage pile so that people would notice,” he told TOI. In the morning, he pasted several posters on the wall and held one in his hand which read, “this garbage can take our lives” and “will do or die but not leave”. His act encouraged some of his friends who came forward in support. One of them started a live video on Facebook. Soon, the video went viral and within 20 minutes, LMC officers led by zonal officer JP Yadav were on the spot, persuading Saifi to leave. LMC got the area cleaned and gave in writing that from now, trash bins will be put up at the spot and open dumping won’t be allowed. Residents who had earlier refused to stand with Saifi were all praise after his protest worked. “Thanks to Saifi’s initiative, the area is clean now. We did not take part in the protest because LMC workers are thick-skinned and our earlier protests made no impact. In fact, on Bakrid, somebody threw animal carcass here which kept rotting for days and our complaints went unheard,” said Anshul Gupta, a resident. The zonal officer said, “We will find out who was responsible for collecting garbage from the area and take action.”

column2: Etawah safari to be opened for public on November 24
column3: KANPUR: After a long wait, the Etawah lion safari is finally all set to be opened for public on November 24, but partially. The authorities have started preparatory work on a war-footing. “Forest minister Dara Singh Chauhan and MP Etawah and chairman of the National Commission for Scheduled Castes Dr Ram Shankar Katheria will inaugurate the safari on November 24,” said MLA Etawah Sadar Sarita Bhadauria. However, the lion segment will not be opened for public as it doesn’t meet the required CZA norms yet, a senior safari official said and added that as of now, only deer, antelope and bear safaris would be opened for public. “Lion Safari, which is USP of the park, will be opened only after meeting the required CZA norms of having 10 cubs,” said the forest official. The safari has presently only six cubs. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The Etawah lion safari is the first in the country to have a lion breeding centre set up with an aim to develop a research facility on Asiatic lions. The lion safari will be a pride of Etawah, said the MLA expressing the hope that the requirement of housing 10 cubs at the Lion Safari would be fulfilled soon. Spread in 350 hectares of land, the safari is being developed as an educative tourist destination for children as well as youths. The park has multiple safaris — antelope safari having 65 deer and six swamp deer, and bear safari consisting of three female bears. Etawah lion safari was formally inaugurated by chief minister Yogi Adityanath on June 1, 2018 but is not open for public yet. Etawah safari park is categorised in multiple safaris, Asiatic Lion Breeding Centre & Visitor Facilitation Centre. The park is located at a driving distance of 2 hours from Agra, 5 hours from New Delhi, and 3 hours from the state capital. The work on the safari started in 2005, but smooth way was paved in May 2013 after environmental clearances.

column2: Ayodhya: Sunni Waqf Board split over SC review plea
column3: LUCKNOW: Six days ahead of the crucial UP Sunni Central Waqf Board meeting, differences arose among its members on Wednesday over filing a review petition in Supreme Court against the Ayodhya verdict and accepting the five-acre land for a mosque. While four of the eight Board members are against filing a review petition, two of them told TOI they hold the contrary view. TOI could not speak to the remaining two Board members. Six days ahead of the crucial UP Sunni Central Waqf Board meeting, differences arose among its membersThe Board will meet here on November 26 to decide its strategy after the SC verdict. Board chairman Zufar Faruqi has been consistent in his stand from the day of the verdict that a review petition should not be filed. Three other members - Abrar Ahmad, Mohammad Junaid Siddiqui and Adnan Farrukh Shah – told TOI on Wednesday they backed Faruqi on this particular issue. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.However, two others, Abdul Razzaq Khan and Imran Mabood Khan, said they favoured going for a review. Imran, who is former chairperson of UP Bar Council, said: “If All India Muslim Personal Law Board is going for a review in SC, the Sunni Waqf Board should also take into account the sentiments of the Muslim community, even if there may not be much hope.” Will land be used to construct a mosque or for charity: MuslimsTOI could not contact the remaining two Board members - Tazeen Fatima (Samajwadi Party leader Azam Khan’s wife) and Maulana Syed Ahmed Ali alias Khushnood Miyan – for their views on the review petition. Both of them are from Rampur. The two dissenting members in the Board, Abdul and Imran, also said that the offer of five-acre land for a mosque should not be accepted. Abrar also agreed with the duo on the five-acre and offer, though he toed the Board chief ’s line that a review petition should not be filed. “A lot of Muslims have approached us on whether to accept the alternative land. Another issue is, if it is accepted, what use would it be put to -- to build a mosque or for charitable purpose? We will bring all these suggestions to the table on November 26," said Adnan. Questioning the rationale for the five-acre land offer, Imran said: “SC accepted that the mosque was built in 1528. So, its existence was proven. That it was desecrated in 1949 was also accepted and so was its demolition in 1992. On what basis then is the compensation being given to Muslims?" Supporting Imran, Abdul said: “Alternative land should not be accepted for ‘Allah ka ghar’ (house of God). A review of the order should also be done.” Both Imran and Abdul claimed they had maintained a distance from Board’s meetings for the last few years. However, they, would voice their opinion on the twin issues in the November 26 meeting, they said. Board chief Faruqi, on his part, has said that the fate of the five-acre alternative land will be decided in the November 26 meeting and nothing could be said on this issue before that. The Board, which has received a number of suggestions on the use of the alternative land, will deliberate on these, including ideas like establishing a hospital or an educational institution.

column2: Lucknow: Girls’ morphed pictures go viral, three booked
column3: LUCKNOW: Three youths have been booked for uploading morphed photographs of their female batchmates on social media through fake IDs in separate cases in the city. The cybercell of city police has registered FIRs in all the three complaints and IP addresses of the fake IDs are being traced to nail the accused. The cybercell of Lucknow police has registered FIRs in all the three complaints and IP addresses of the fake IDs are being traced to nail the accusedIn the first case reported at Chinhat police station on Tuesday, a 20-year-old student of a private university alleged in her FIR that one of her friends took her photographs and morphed them to blackmail her by threatening to make them viral on social media. She also said the accused also created a fake Facebook profile in her name using her morphed photographs. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“Later, through different numbers he made WhatsApp calls and demanded Rs 1 lakh for removing the pictures,” she claimed. In another case reported at Vibhutikhand police station, a 22-year-old girl studying at a technical institute in Lucknow alleged that her male batchmate first took her photos from his phone, pretending to use it during farewell. “But, he later created a fake Facebook ID in my name and posted my morphed photos on it,” she said. Later, when she confronted him, he said he was upset with her closeness with another male student, she stated in her complaint. In the third incident reported from Gomtinagar, a 20-year-old student lodged a case against a senior male student of her college. She said during a college picnic, students clicked some group photos. “He somehow managed to take my individual photographs and morphed them. On Tuesday, he sent me the morphed photos and threatened to leak them on social media if I did not agree to go with him on a trip,” she said in her complaint. CO Hazratganj Abhay Mishra said, “The accused have been booked under charges of dishonesty and various sections of IT Act. We are working on the cases and tracing the IP addresses through which the profiles were created on Facebook. It will help us in verifying complaints and take action against the culprits.”

column2: Uttar Pradesh: On way to receive a friend, two youths crushed by speeding truck
column3: LUCKNOW: In yet another hit and-run case, the 11th this year in the city, two youths, aged 19 and 20, were crushed to death by a speeding truck in Banthra on Wednesday. The deceased were identified as Shaktimaan (20) and Rohit (19), both residents of Kallan Kheda, Banthra. Some commuters on the stretch chases the truck but it managed to escape. As many as 11 hit-and-run cases have been reported in 2019 and 13 lives were snuffed out. “They were going on a bike to receive a friend who was coming from New Delhi by bus. As they reached Mohan road, a truck coming from Kati Bagiya side crushed them,” said Banthra SHO Ramesh Singh Rawat. The incident took place around 10am. The impact was such that Rohit and Shaktimaan got trapped in the bumper of truck and were dragged for about 500 metres before being smashed against a divider, added Rawat. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Some commuters chased the truck to catch the driver but he sped away, while others rushed the critically injured duo to a private hospital where they were declared brought dead, said police. “An FIR have been registered against the unidentified driver on charges of causing death by negligence and rash driving. The footage of CCTVs in the areas is being scanned to trace the truck. The deceased youths were employed as executives in a private company,” said Rawat. “Police have still not been able to do anything about the black spots that witness fatal accidents. The Mohan road turn at Kati Bagiya is very risky, but neither a sign board has been put up nor have the administration and road safety cell constructed any speed-breakers on the stretch,” said, Vikas Tripathi, a local resident.

column2: Mercury dips below 13°C, Met says winter is coming
column3: LUCKNOW: Shruti Pant had to put on a jacket while riding her scooter home after tuition on Tuesday evening; she pulled over a bed sheet at night; and found the warmth of a cuppa endearing on a misty Wednesday morning. The 19-year-old student exemplified collective behaviour of Lucknow’s residents as the city’s minimum temperature dropped below 13 degrees Celsius in the intervening night of Tuesday and Wednesday, the lowest reading post-monsoon. Weathermen say the nippy night and morning are clear indication that winter is knocking on the door and is expected to set in by the first week of December. State Met director JP Gupta said the mercury had plummeted owing to unhindered flow of the North Wind from the hills. On Wednesday, the maximum dropped to 27.9 degrees Celsius while the minimum was a chilling 12.6 degrees Celsius, a notch below normal. Similar temperatures are expected to prevail for a week followed by a gradual drop in Celsius next week. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.A western disturbance, which will hit the hills of Himachal Pradesh and Kashmir on Thursday, is expected to cause rain and snow in a few places up north for two days. Since this extratropical storm will cut off wind flow from the hills to the plains, temperatures will rise by a degree or two in northwest India, including Lucknow, before a wintry plunge, Met officials said. “It is too early to predict the intensity of fog and to what level temperatures will drop in December. As of now, we can say that the onset of the winter is expected to be normal with chilly nights, foggy mornings and sunny days,” said Gupta.

column2: Uttar Pradesh government sets up seven-member team to acquire land for Project Ayodhya
column3: LUCKNOW: Ahead of the Centre forming a trust for the construction of Ram temple in Ayodhya as directed by Supreme Court, the Yogi Adityanath government in UP has constituted a seven-member committee to acquire land for a proposed project in the vicinity of Ram Janmabhoomi. Titled Project Ayodhya, the plan was cleared by the Yogi government on November 1, eight days before Supreme Court delivered its verdict on the vexed issue. The project will house a 202-metre-tall statue of Lord Ram, an interpretation centre, a library, a food plaza and a parking centre. The BJP government allotted Rs 447 crore for the project. A day before the verdict, the Yogi government appointed UP Tourism as the nodal agency for identifying land for the mega project. The seven-member committee for acquiring land, which includes the director and chief architect of UP Rajkiya Nirman Nigam and the chief engineer of the irrigation department, among others, was formed on November 18. A legal representative has also been included in the committee to ensure that the land acquisition does not face any obstacle from any litigant in the Ram Janmabhoomi case or any shop owner. "A district administration advocate (civil) in Ayodhya will be part of this committee," according to an order which has been sent to the Ayodhya district administration. TOI has a copy of the order. However, the government has ruled out including any representative of civil society or priests for this project. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The Yogi government's move comes even as seven of the 10 litigants from the Muslim side in the Ayodhya case have announced that they would seek a review against the SC's order. Reacting to the development, Hizbullah, one of the petitioners in the Ayodhya title suit, said, "We are doing whatever we want legally in SC. The government is free to initiate any beautification project".

column2: Uttar Pradesh constable found hanging from fan
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 28-year-old constable with Uttar Pradesh police committed suicide by hanging himself from a ceiling fan at his residence in Modinagar on Tuesday night. According to police, the constable was identified as Nitin Sharma, who was posted at Dial 100 in Titawi police station of Muzaffarnagar. Police said on November 14, Nitin left duty in Muzaffarnagar without informing his seniors and returned home to Modinagar. On Tuesday night, he had an argument with his wife and locked himself in his room. Latest Commentइस कलियुग में हरेक इनसान इतना ज्यादा महात्य्वकांसा में डूबा हुआ हैं कि स्वार्थ और संम्बंध को एक ही तराजू में तौलने की हर मुमकिन प्रयास कर रहा हैं। इससे चलते वैचारिक मतभेद पैदा कर रहा हैं, इससे तनाव प...Read MoreTarun Roy ChowdhurySee All CommentsAdd commentNitin’s father Ajaypal Sharma told TOI that he was an early riser. “When he didn’t come out of his room till 6am, I knocked on the door several times but he didn’t reply. Then I went to call him from the window but found him hanging from the fan,” he said. The couple had got married in February 2018 in Ujjain and have a one-year-old son. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Jitendra Yadav, SHO, Modinagar police station, said that police got the information about the incident around 7am on Wednesday and immediately sent a team to the spot. The body has been sent for autopsy and the report is awaited.

column2: Two try to extort cash from Jal Nigam official, held
column3: GHAZIABAD: Two men, who were allegedly planning to extort Rs 5 lakh from a junior engineer with the irrigation department, were arrested on Wednesday following a gunfight in Modinagar area. The irrigation department official had gone to address where he was supposed to handover the money to the duo when the shootout took place. Neeraj Kumar Jadaun, SP (rural), Ghaziabad, said the police had information and laid a trap. A few Rs 2,000 notes were packed along with several white papers between them and when the duo came to take money, the police caught them. “The duo snatched the bag from the junior engineer and tried to flee the spot but the police surrounded them. They were asked to surrender but the men allegedly fired at the policemen and tried to run away. The policemen fired a few shots and the duo, identified as Akash (30), from Aligarh district, and Ravi Sharma (35), from Ghaziabad, suffered bullet injuries in their legs,” Jadaun said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Surajpal Singh, the Jal Nigam officials, told TOI: “On November 15, at 6.30 in the morning, a person called me and asked me if I was Surajpal Singh. When I said yes, he asked me to give him Rs 56 lakh. I refused to give him the money and threatened me saying that he will kill my family members,” he added. “After that, he kept calling me from several numbers and kept threatening me. On November 18, the man called me again and said if I did not pay up, he will kill me and my wife. I contacted the police and lodged a complaint. The police assured me and my family that we would be safe and then they made a plan to lay the trap. After that I just followed the instructions they gave me,” Singh said. “On November 19 morning, I received a phone call from a new number and a man asked me about the money. I told him I could only pay Rs 5 lakh. They agreed and I was asked to go to Modinagar junction on the night of November 20 to pay the amount,” he added. SP (rural) Singh said: “The accused men would call from stolen phones, public booths and from other people’s phones. More than 30 police officers were involved in the operation.” Latest CommentGood Story, I wish it''s trueLay Day KaySee All CommentsAdd commentTwo illegal pistols, live cartridges, three mobile phones and one motorcycle have been seized from the place, police said. The men have been sent to jail. They have been booked under sections 307 (attempt to murder) and 386 (extortion by putting a person in fear of death or grievous hurt) of the Indian Penal Code.

column2: Pacific Mall fined for using gensets
column3: GHAZIABAD: The Uttar Pradesh Pollution Control Board (UPPCB) on Wednesday imposed a fine of Rs 25 lakh on Pacific Mall near Kaushambi for using gensets despite prohibitory orders. The Ghaziabad Development Authority (GDA) also levied a fine of Rs 1 lakh from the mall for carrying out construction on the premises. Three officials – the mall’s assistant general manager, Rupesh Kumar Srivastav, and managers Varun Saxena and Arun Saxena – have been prosecuted under Section 151 of the CrPC. On Wednesday, a meeting of administrative authorities was held to review the measures being taken to curb pollution in the district. Following a tip-off about gensets being operated in the mall, district magistrate Ajay Shankar Pandey, a joint team of officials from the UPPCB and the administration conducted an inspection. “We have imposed a fine of Rs 25 lakh on Pacific Mall,” Pandey said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The team found that five diesel-run gensets, of 1,250 kVA capacity each, were installed in the mall’s basement. Officials said the gensets operators told them that the machines were used in case of power cuts. The team also took action against a landowner in Nandgram for digging up earth and selling it illegally. Besides imposing a fine of Rs 1 lakh, the team also seized an earthmover and three tractor trolleys. Pandey said a five-day drive was launched on Tuesday against vehicles using adulterated fuel (diesel mixed with kerosene) and petrol pumps selling it. Five petrol pumps and 34 vehicles have been inspected so far. Instances of large quantities of prohibited polythene being stored and garbage burning in the slums of Hindon Vihar have also come to light. After a survey, 88 violators were identified and a complaint was submitted against them with Sihani Gate police station. Police are investigating the case. Pandey has instructed the officials of the pollution department and the district administration to take action against garbage burning in the district.

column2: 'I still have a long way to go,' says actor Arham Abbasi in Lucknow
column3: Lucknow lad, actor Arham Abbasi, gained popularity after playing the role of Rishi on the television drama Suhani Si Ek Ladki. The actor, who is now settled in Mumbai, was recently in Lucknow. "I have come to Lucknow after almost one and a half years and I already feel that Lucknow has completely transformed and in a good way. I’m happy to see the new changes in my hometown, especially the connectivity that the city has got with the launch of the Lucknow Metro." Fondly reminiscing his childhood memories, the actor said, "We came to Lucknow in the year 1993. I was crazy about cricket, and I even played for the under-19 cricket team. My friends and I would go to KD Singh Babu Stadium and to different parks around to play cricket matches. Padhai likhai mein waise hi zyaada dhyaan nahi tha toh college time pe we would end up going to Rovers to have the frankies or to Marksmen for the chowmein and Tunday of course. I miss all that so much now that I’m living in Mumbai. I’m so used to Lucknow ka khana." Arham Abbasi (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Arham Abbasi (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Arham who has been in the industry since 2013, speaking about his journey, says, "I was 18 years old and my friend asked to accompany him somewhere. I readily agreed, not knowing that he was taking me to a modelling contest. Although I didn’t win the contest, an inclination towards modelling rose. Thereafter I won a few pageants, I thought of trying my luck in Mumbai. I must say, till now the journey has been an interesting one. Although I still have a long way to go," says Arham, who has also done films like Game Over and Zindagi Mumbai and is starring in another untitled project, which he is reluctant to talk about. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.- Yashi Agarwal

column2: Two die while cleaning chemical tank of tannery
column3: KANPUR: Two labourers died after they entered a chemical tank at a tannery in Unnao to clean it on Thursday morning. The incident occurred at Industrial area in Dahi Chowki. Two labourers, identified as Anil Rawat of Makhi and Anil Katheria of Ajgain, fell unconscious after they entered the chemical tank of a tannery to clean it, said SP Unnao MP Verma. Latest CommentWho is accountable for loss of precious human lives?Why no arrests were made?Why owners of factories were not taken to task for failing to adhere safety measures to labourers who are assigned this wo...Read MoreSheik MohamedSee All CommentsAdd commentThe two were rushed to the hospital, where doctors declared them dead on arrival, the SP said. As soon as the news spread, their family members reached the tannery and created ruckus demanding stern action against the tannery owner. The police later pacified them assuring them of action. “A case will be registered and action will be taken as per the law,” said the officer. It is also being ascertained whether the labourers were wearing safety gears, the officer added. column2: VHP: Don’t want ‘sarkaari’ Ram temple
column3: LUCKNOW: Vishwa Hindu Parishad national general secretary Milind Parande has said the government should refrain from making the proposed Ram temple in Ayodhya a ‘sarkaari’ (government owned) one and should instead place in a mechanism to facilitate its construction at the earliest. Speaking exclusively to TOI on Thursday, Parande said temple’s construction should instead be made out of people’s contribution since it is associated with the faith of Hindus. “We believe that the society should contribute and the temple should be built out of those contributions. The government should not spend its money,” he told Parande. On November 12, TOI had reported that VHP was working on a plan to raise money for the temple through crowdfunding. Parande’s observation comes over 10 days after the Supreme Court ruled in favour of a Ram temple at the disputed Ramjanmabhoomi-Babri Masjid site and asked the state government to form a trust for construction of a temple. Latest Comment👍🏻👍🏻👍🏻SagarrathoreSee All CommentsAdd comment “The government should only use the original architectural plan and ‘shilas’ (marble stones) which have been carved out at Ramjanmabhoomi workshop in Ayodhya. About 60% of temple construction material and the architectural plan is also ready,” he said.  “Basic things have been taken care of. If the government puts in a system then the Hindu society can start construction of Ram temple immediately,” he said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.

column2: Governor Anandiben Patel invokes Germany to back epic womb ‘sanskar’
column3: LUCKNOW: Citing Abhimanyu’s learning in the womb in the epic Mahabharata, Governor Anandiben Patel on Thursday said all universities should have a ‘garbha sanskar’ corner where girl students can be taught dos and don’ts during pregnancy and (moolbhoot sanskar) primary values for family life (grahasth jeevan). This would help improve mother-child health and curb malnutrition, she said. The governor, said, while an institute in Germany adopted the Mahabharataa concept of learning in the womb, no formal education is even imparted to girls on procedures to be adopted during pregnancy. According to Mahabharata, the governor said, Abhimanyu, son of Arjuna, learnt war skills in his mother’s (Subhadra) womb. He is said to have heard Arjuna narrating to Subhadra how to break the ‘chakravyuh’, a seven-layer military formation by enemy. Abhimanyu learnt how to smash six layers, but did not hear the last one as Subhadra fell asleep, she said, while addressing students and teachers at fourth annual convocation of Khwaja Moinuddin Chishti Urdu, Arabi-Farsi University in Lucknow. Anandiben Patel, who is also chancellor of universities in UP, sought setting up of camps for health check-up of girl students. “A report should be submitted to my office on adoption of villages where students can volunteer to educate others,” she said. “Every university should have a books corner which caters to healthcare during pregnancy, after delivery and general health issues of women,” she said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Quoting a recent health survey in universities of Kanpur and Agra, she said, 30-50% girls were found anaemic during pregnancy. “We teach everything, but not healthcare,” she said. “People in Germany read about the Abhimanyu episode in the Mahabharataa, conducted research and opened an institute where prospective parents can take admission and educate themselves on ‘sanskars’ (conduct) of what to eat, read and speak, which music to listen, what kind of movies to watch and environment to live, from the first month of the pregnancy. This helped Germany to be ahead of others,” the governor said. Absence of information and lack of care cause pre-mature delivery and malnutrition after birth, she said. The governor also said she was left shell-shocked after meeting acid attack survivors at Sheros café run by them. “I came to know girls were attacked only because they rejected proposals of boys. Our universities should also teach boys to respect girls and their decisions,” she said.

column2: Garbage on roads mocks LMC’s clean pledge in high court
column3: LUCKNOW: Unattended garbage in Daliganj, which prompted a youth to get his feet literally dirty in protest on Wednesday, is only the tip of an iceberg. A TOI reality check on Thursday exposed mounds of trash across city neighbourhoods, most of them rotting and throwing up an olfactory challenge for residents of New Hyderabad, Alambagh, Jankipuram, Chowk, Campbell Road and Gomtinagar, among others. While the widely circulated picture of the Daliganj youth standing in a heap of garbage for hours prompted the authorities to mount an immediate cleaning drive, complaints of citizens elsewhere have failed to jolt the LMC out of slumber. This despite the civic body assuring the high court and Uttar Pradesh Solid Waste Management Monitoring Committee in May that it would come up with a mechanism to free roads of rubbish within a month. In New Hyderabad, Manisha Ahuja complained that the LMC’s own sanitation workers were dumping garbage along roads. “On a daily average, half a dozen vehicles leave garbage behind. Stray animals make it more messy,” she said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Jatin Shukla of Vivek Khand, Gomtinagar, recalled the monsoon nightmare. “Unattended trash choked drains and we were stranded on an island surrounded by dirty water,” he said. At Chowk, residents are already planning to hire private workers. “LMC workers are lazy. Do we have an option?” said Sanjay Singh. Additional municipal commissioner Amit Singh said the LMC had installed compactors at open sites from where garbage was transferred to the solid waste treatment plant in Shivri. “Agency workers are expected to bring garbage to the sites by 8am. However, some often come late. As a result, the garbage they bring is left on the roadside,” Singh added.

column2: Against all odds, their grit glittered like gold
column3: LUCKNOW: They say when the going gets tough, the tough get going. Convocation Thursday at Khwaja Moinuddin Chishti Urdu-Arbi-Farsi University offered some shining examples. Son of a marginal farmer in Sitapur, Rohit Kumar Singh was beaming in joy with a BEd degree in hand and three gold medals around his neck. No stranger to poverty and struggle, Rohit says he can never forget how his father and elder brother toiled hard to fuel his higher education dreams. “My family is my rock. My father and brother could not complete their studies owing to financial crunch. They ensured I did,” the young man said, his eyes moist. “I want to become a professor to help students from humble background,” he added. Among the 55 elated medal-winners, there was yet another student who deserves a special mention. Badre Alam of Nepal knows his gold medal in MA (Arabic) was no cakewalk. It was in fact the result of a difficult balancing act between work and studies. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“I worked at the Nepali (sic) embassy to support my education. It was tough, but I didn’t give up. My hard work has been aptly rewarded,” Badre said. Many an inspiring story like the above glittered amid the usual convocation musts of clicking selfies and planning parties. The venue reverberated with the cacophony of future plans while winners of gold, silver and bronze medals earned hugs from friends and family.

column2: EOW traces firm in Panipat, finds nexus
column3: LUCKNOW: UP Police’s economic offences wing (EOW) probing the UPPCL provident fund scam has traced another brokerage firm to Panipat. The firm had facilitated the investment of UPPCL employees’ PF money in tainted firm DHFL. EOW officials privy to the probe claimed that they have got documents showing connivance of the three arrested former UPPCL officials, A P Mishra, Sudhanshu Dwivedi, P K Gupta, with the man who registered the brokerage firm in Panipat and showed it to have been working for DHFL. Officials, on Thursday, said their probe revealed that proprietor of a firm in Panipat had hired a chartered accountant. EOW managed to trace the chartered accountant and has already recorded his statements. The officials said statements of the proprietor are yet to be recorded and a notice has been served to him. In case he does not turn up on his own, a team will be dispatched to trace him. Till now, EOW has only been able to arrest one Ayush Chaudhary, proprietor of a brokerage firm in Delhi. Officials revealed that two firms of Lucknow have also been traced and their co-proprietors were questioned late on Thursday, while another firm has been traced in Delhi. EOW sleuths said questioning of owners and employees of brokerage firms will continue and they will be later confronted with arrested accused officials. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.

column2: Sohrab, six cops handed over to Delhi Police team
column3: LUCKNOW: Dreaded criminal Sohrab of the notorious Salim-Rustam-Sohrab gang and the six Delhi Police personnel caught having biryani in an Aishbagh hotel late Wednesday night, while the undertrial they were escorting from Tihar Jail to Lucknow for court hearing was spending time with his family, were handed over to a six-member team of cops that arrived from the national capital on Thursday. “Sohrab was handed over to six-member Delhi Police team, which had come to take his custody, on Thursday night, said ASP (west) Vikas Tripathi. Meanwhile, sources told TOI that Rustam has been kept in Unnao jail and will be presented in a Lucknow court on Friday. The six arrested Delhi Police personnel, sub-inspector Ram Kishan, head constable Naresh Kumar, constables Deepak, Anil, Virendra and Suresh Kumar, were granted bail on Thursday, but Sohrab’s wife Sanno Khan, sister Yasmeen and hotel manager Ankit Mishra were sent to 14-day-judicial custody. Sohrab, and his brother Rustam had been brought from Tihar jail in the custody of Delhi police for hearing of cases in Kanpur and Lucknow courts. They were produced in Kanpur court on Wednesday. Sohrab had to be produced in Lucknow court and was brought for hearing to the city. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Sohrab, Rustam and their elder brother Salim have multiple criminal cases lodged against them in Lucknow, Kanpur and Delhi since 2004. The brothers had grabbed attention after a sensational triple murder in the state capital in 2004 after their eldest brother Javed was murdered.

column2: Student-teacher ratio skewed, Lucknow University cries for faculty fillip
column3: LUCKNOW: Once upon a time, the University of Lucknow boasted professors with degrees from Oxford and Cambridge. Cut to the present: it is grappling with acute faculty crunch. Both LU and its 170 affiliated colleges fail to meet the teacher-student ratio set by the University Grants Commission (UGC). The sanctioned faculty strength at the varsity alone is 516 while the number of students on the rolls is 25,000. In other words, the preferred teacher-student ratio is 1:50. Currently, the varsity is short of 172 professors and posts lying vacant for around three years. With only 344 permanent appointments in place, the teacher-student ratio is 1:70. A maximum of 75 posts are vacant for assistant professors while there are 37 and 60 vacancies, respectively, for professors and associate professors. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“We had filled up some vacant posts in 2018. Thereafter, there was a freeze on appointments by UGC, owing to change in rules. Hence, all posts couldn’t be filled up. We will plug vacancies soon,” said former vice-chancellor SP Singh. The situation is no different in degree colleges, where an entire department is being run by a single professor or a course has been discontinued because there is no one to teach. Several departments also face closure with the retirement of 20% teachers. For 20,000-odd students in 19 government-aided colleges, the sanctioned teaching posts are 817. Of these, 197 are lying vacant. According to UGC, the student-teacher ratio should be 1:40 in affiliated colleges. It is expected to cross 1:60 from the next session in many colleges. At Shri Jai Narain PG College, for instance, 50 posts are lying vacant. Departments like geology and anthropology have no permanent faculty members. For 10,500 students, there are 139 sanctioned posts, but only 89 have been filled. The student-teacher ratio has touched an alarming 1:90. “Around 50% of our departments are dependent on guest faculty. In geology, there are three sanctioned posts, but two are vacant. The only faculty member is on leave,” said principal SD Sharma. For 4,000 students at Bappa Sri Narayan Vocational Degree College, the sanctioned teaching posts are 77. Of these, 31 are lying vacant. “If the posts are not quickly filled up, many departments will face the threat of closure,” said principal Rakesh Chandra. Here too, the approximate student-teacher ratio is 1:90. “Departments like ancient Indian history and Arab culture, which were running with a single faculty member, have no teacher now with those serving having retired,” Chandra added. At Navyug Kanya Mahavidyalaya, there is only one teacher each in the departments of botany, education and philosophy for the past four years. In all, 19 posts are vacant and there are 3,500 students. The ratio is 1:70. “The college, with its own resources, has appointed guest faculty so that courses are not discontinued. The UP Higher Education Service Commission should fill up vacant posts soon,” said principal Shrishti Srivastava. Posts at LU-affiliated colleges are lying vacant because recruitment has not been conducted by the higher education commission in the past few years. “Quality of education at a 100-year-old university cannot improve unless appointments are done,” summed up Manoj Pandey, the president of Lucknow University Teachers’ Association.

column2: ‘What’s language got to do with religion? Premchand learnt Urdu from a Maulvi’
column3: LUCKNOW: As unrest sweeps Banaras Hindu University (BHU) over a Muslim professor, Firoz Khan teaching Sanskrit, grandson of one of India’s great Hindi-Urdu writer Munshi Premchand tweeted how his ‘Kayastha Hindu’ grandfather had learnt Urdu from a ‘Maulvi Saheb’ in his early life. He asks what has language got to do with religion? Munshi Premchand was born in Lamhi, a small village about six kilometres from Varanasi in 1880 as Dhanpat Rai. The tweet by Premchand’s grandson, Pravir Rai (45), went viral on Thursday after which speaking to TOI he recalled all the Muslim influences on Premchand and his writings that made him a celebrated writer. These included his Urdu teacher Maulvi saheb and the village storyteller, Kazaki whom Premchand remembered even on his death bed. It was on Wednesday evening that Rai, who is the grandson of Premchand’s younger brother Mahtab Rai, wrote on his social media account, “My grandfather Munshi Premchand, a Kayastha Hindu, learnt Urdu from Maulvi saheb. He became the greatest Hindi-Urdu writer of all time. What has language got to do with religion?” NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.By Thursday, the post had garnered around 20,000 likes and close to 5,000 retweets. Rai claimed he was only stating a fact from his grandfather’s life when he mentioned it on social media. When TOI contacted Rai, who is currently also writing a book on his grandfather, he said, “Premchand baba had started his education from a madrasa in Lalpur which was two kilometres from his village Lamhi. There at the madrasa he was taught Urdu and Persian by a Maulvi saheb.” The tweet by Premchand’s grandson, Pravir Rai went viral on Thursday. My grandfather Munshi Premchand, a Kayastha Hindu, learnt Urdu from Maulvi saheb. He became the greatest Urdu-Hindi… https://t.co/Ik235DsxZi— Pravir Rai (@raip74) 1574254628000‘What if we are told to learn, teach foreign languages?’Not just Maulvi saheb, he was also mesmerized by the stories of one named Kazaki. A Muslim storyteller who was the post office clerk, Kazaki would tell Premchand innumerable stories about the evils plaguing the Indian society — untouchability, oppression of farmers, women and widows,” said Rai. “These stories along with that of the magical Persian fantasy — Tilism-e-Hoshruba — all were an influence on the writings and life of Premchand baba. Their impression on his young mind was such that he remembered them till he died,” Rai, who himself writes poetry in Hindi, English and Urdu, added. Latest CommentNot that it''s right what the BHU students are doing but Sanskrit is related to the Indian dharm. Can''t compare writing literature in Urdu to teaching or learning Sanskrit.Indian SnakeCharmerSee All CommentsAdd commentSpeaking on the current controversy revolving around religion and language, Rai told TOI that in his opinion all such protests were irrelevant and he did not support such a divide on the basis of religion or language. “Some people are talking about Sanskrit in terms of religious studies, which is untrue. Furthermore, it was an open position for which the teacher was selected by due process. Teaching or studying a language should not be decided on the basis of religion. What if Indians are asked to learn and teach foreign languages then? Where are we heading with this?” he questioned.

column2: Uttar Pradesh: Seven-year jail term for forced conversion in law panel draft
column3: LUCKNOW: Forced conversion in Uttar Pradesh may attract a jail term of up to seven years, while changing one’s religion for the sake of marriage may be nullified if either party contests it as ‘forced’. However, reconverting someone, as in ‘Ghar Vapsi’, may not be a crime at all. These recommendations are part of the state law commission’s draft bill on religious conversion submitted to the government on Thursday. Commission secretary Sapna Tripathi said in case of marriage where either party is forced to convert for the purpose, “both the conversion and marriage may be declared null and void”. The draft will be considered by the government which may then choose to adopt it in parts or entirety. Stressing that the current provisions of the IPC are not sufficient to prevent religious conversions, the law commission has drafted a new law, titled ‘The Uttar Pradesh Freedom of Religion Act, 2019’. In the submission to chief minister, chairman of state law commission Justice Aditya Nath Mittal said: “…katipay sangathan Hinduon, aur visheshkar anusoochit janjaati ke logon ko, pralobhan dekar apne nihit swarth hetu dharmantaran karakar Bharat ki sadiyon purani sabhyata dhara ko bhulane va dharmik paramparaon aur pooja paddhatiyon ka apmaan sikha kar apne dharm ko sarvochch shikhar par darshane ka kutsit prayaas kar rahe hain. (Some organisations are enticing Hindus, especially SC/STs, to convert for their own gains. In the process, these organisations are making people insult their religious traditions and rich culture).”In the past, largescale conversions took place under Mughal and British rules as the then rulers encouraged it, he adds. “There is no data as such to say how many forced conversions have taken place, but in 2014, CM Yogi Adityanath himself had raised the matter and we gave him a set of news clippings of the past six months to prove our point,” Tripathi said, adding at least 10 states have anti-conversion laws. Under the proposal, if one is found to have forcefully converted someone, the person can be jailed for a minimum of one year to a maximum of five years. However, if the person converted is a minor, woman or from SC/ST community, the jail term extends from two to seven years. The draft further stipulates that a person wishing to convert and the person who conducts the ceremony have to submit an application to DM or ADM a month before. The authorities will carry out a thorough investigation to determine the reason for conversion. There is a jail term of up to two years if one fails to inform the district administration about a proposed conversion.

column2: Home guards scam reaches Lucknow, district commandant held
column3: LUCKNOW: The district commandant of home guards, Lucknow, was arrested by Gomtinagar police on Thursday for fraudulent withdrawal of salary by showing inflated figures of personnel deployed at two police stations in the state capital, leading to loss of Rs 10 lakh to the state exchequer. District commandant Kripa Shankar Pandey was arrested from flat number 406, Chandra Panorama Apartments in Golf City under SGPGI police station area and booked on charges of criminal breach of trust, dishonesty, forgery of valuable security, forgery for the purpose of cheating under and using genuine as forged. SkipA similar scam had surfaced in Noida recently and five officials had been arrested. Lucknow SSP Kalanidhi Naithani said inconsistencies in disbursement of wages of home guards had surfaced at Gudamba and Vibhutikhand police stations for the months of July and August. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“There were repeated complaints from Gudamba police station that only eight home guards come for duty, though payment was done for 23. A subsequent probe found that fake muster rolls were prepared with inflated numbers and attendance of home guards without the approval of local station house officer, but his signatures were forged and submitted to department for salary,” said Naithani. Rs 5 lakh fraudulently claimed at Gudamba, Vibhuti khandGudamba SHO was asked to lodge an FIR and when probe was carried out in other police stations also, similar anomalies surfaced from Vibhutikhand police station also, he added. Vibhuti Khand SHO Rajeev Diwedi said only 8-10 home guards reported to duty but attendance of 15 was shown. Investigations are still underway in the scam in Lucknow, said a senior police officer. Each home guard was paid Rs 500 for eight-hour duty per day, and Rs 5 lakh was claimed fraudulently for home guards deployment at each of the two police stations, said officials. Home guards do not get fixed monthly wage and are paid on the basis of number of days they work. The scam is suspected to have been orchestrated by an organised syndicate of platoon commandants overseeing their deployment.

column2: Drop Urdu, Arabi, Farsi from Moinuddin Chishti University's name, suggests governor Anandiben Patel
column3: LUCKNOW: UP governor Anandiben Patel on Thursday suggested authorities of the Khwaja Moinuddin Chishti Urdu, Arabi-Farsi University and higher education minister to delete ‘Urdu, Arabi and Farsi’ from varsity’s name. “The mention of three languages — Urdu, Arabic and Persian — in the name of the institution gives an impression that it only teaches these three language subjects, whereas the fact is that it imparts education in various streams, including arts, science and technical,” she said while addressing the 4th convocation of the university. On the occasion, senior Rashtriya Swayam Sangh (RSS) leader Indresh Kumar, Shia cleric Maulana Kalbe Jawad, Hindu spiritual leader Swami Sarang and principal of Darul Uloom Nadwa-tul Ulama Saidur Rahman Azmi were conferred with ‘honoris causa’ (honorary degrees). Honoris causa degrees for Indresh, AzmiNEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Indresh and Azmi were conferred with honoris causa DLitt for contribution to spreading peace and academics respectively, while Jawad and Sarang were honoured with PhDs for academics and communal harmony respectively. Latest Commentthe governor is absolutely right. any university should not take a name which reflects religious or community feelings. look how European and American universities are named. RiazSee All CommentsAdd commentTaking a dig at teachers on seeing that they were not cheering the students, she said what is the use of such an event, if professors do not applaud students.“Even the primary school students who were brought to get inspired by from university students are more excited,” she said. Deputy CM Dinesh Sharma said government has sanctioned a grant of Rs 10 crore for the development of the university.

column2: Lucknowites enjoyed this musical evening
column3: Ghazal singers Chandan Das and Lucknowite Dr Hari Om performed at a musical concert held in the city. The hall was all jam-packed as music lovers turned up in the large numbers to enjoy the concert. Dr Hari Om (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Dr Hari Om (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) The evening kick-started with Dr Hari Om singing Meer’s ghazal Dekh Toh Dil Ki Jaan Se Uthata Hai and few of his own ghazals. Thereafter, Chandan Das sang several ghazals including Apna Gham Leke Kahin Aur Na Jaaya Jaye. The duo not only earned several rounds of applause from the audience but also encores from them. column2: UP Metro stations to have food joints, coffee shops
column3: KANPUR: A long ride in Metro will mean a complete outing for the commuters. The Uttar Pradesh Metro Rail Corporation (UPMRC) is planning to bring food joints, coffee shops and convenience stores at stations on the 23.79km North-South corridor from Indian Institute of Technology (IIT), Kanpur to Naubasta. Like Lucknow Metro, UPMRC is planning to introduce these facilities under its property development project on the North-South corridor. According to UPMRC officials, the Metro rail corporation will at least provide these facilities at two stations falling under 9km priority section from IIT-Kanpur to Motijheel, which will have food joints, coffee shops and convenient stores. Once the construction work of whole North-South corridor gets completed, the facilities will expand to eight stations as proposed. The food courts will offer fast food options, like burger, pizza, soft drinks, chips and ice-creams. Commuters can also enjoy beverages like coffee, tea, and light snacks from the proposed coffee outlets. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Commuters will be able to purchase stationery, newspapers and magazines from convenience stores. UPMRC managing director Kumar Keshav said, “The revenue target to be achieved by us cannot be fulfilled by only operating Metro. We have to provide these services too. Apart from these services, provision of ATMs and medical stores has also been made.”

column2: UP government to look for land after Sunni Waqf Board’s clarity
column3: LUCKNOW: The Ayodhya district administration has decided to put on hold its search for an alternative site for a mosque till Sunni Waqf Board expresses its intent to accept the 5-acre plot. The UP Sunni Waqf Board, which is split on accepting land or going for a review, is scheduled to meet on November 26 to hammer out a consensus. Sources in the government said preliminary work for identifying land for the mosque took place in the first week after the verdict. Now, they are waiting for clarity from the Sunni Waqf Board before offering options. “As per court’s directions, the district administration began work on identifying land, a day after the judgment. Now, the Board is unsure on accepting the offer so there’s no point going through the exercise in advance,” said a senior government official. A day after Supreme Court delivered the Ayodhya judgment, UP Sunni Waqf Board chairperson Zufar Faruqi had said the Board would not seek review, but would decide on the 5-acre plot after the Board meeting. “We had not sought an alternative site. However, we respect court’s judgment and will decide at the meeting,” he had said. Ahead of the meeting, few members categorically said alternative land is unacceptable, while others are waiting to hold a discussion before taking a call. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.On the ground, the local administration kept land options under wraps without a go-ahead from the Centre. Asked to zero in on at least five sites, the administration scoured revenue records to identify land within and outside Ayodhya. Possible locations included an area close to Babar’s general Mir Baqi’s grave in Sahjanwa village, credited to have constructed the mosque, across the Saryu or outside city limits along Faizabad Road.

column2: A Karachi man’s search for his parents’ Lucknow-wala love
column3: LUCKNOW: Artist and poet Moeen Faruqi’s parents migrated to Pakistan from Lucknow during Partition, but he still lives on the imagery of nostalgic bylanes of Chowk. He was born in Pakistan and grew up listening to stories of Lucknow and the longing to travel to the city of his roots only grew stronger. Moeen’s story penned by him and printed on a postcard with his photograph on another side, is among the 47 stories of Partition that Delhi-based artist and photographer Manisha Gera Baswani has collected from both sides of the border — 22 from Pakistan and 25 from India, including three from Lucknow. The collection was put on display at the exhibition ‘Postcards From Home’ in the four-day Kabir Festival inaugurated on Friday. In most stories, people pined to visit what was once their ancestral homes and shared memories narrated by their parents or grandparents of pre-Partition India. Moeen, who now lives in Karachi, has narrated his parents love story. His mother, Maryam Jaffer was from Pune who defied family traditions to pursue education and was a topper. Her success story made it to the pages of the newspapers. Moeen’s father, Nooruddin Hassan Faruqi, a civil servant from Lucknow, saw Maryam’s picture in a newspaper and wrote to her. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“The letter triggered off a correspondence that unfolded into a love story between a Memon girl and a Lakhnawi man. Their marriage took place before Partition. In Pakistan, they found a house in Amil Colony that belonged to a Hindu family, who migrated to India. We grew up hearing stories of their families and lives in India,”(sic), wrote Moeen in the postcard. Manisha, whose parents migrated to India from Pakistan in 1947, got the idea of documenting such stories when she visited the neighbouring country in 2015 for an exhibition and found there were many like her who grew up listening to stories of pre-Partition India. “Then I decided to document stories that represent our common history,” she said. Like Moeen, Karachi-based sculptor and artist Adeela Suleman’s mother Shaheena Suleman also belonged to Lucknow. Writing on the postcard on behalf of her mother, Adeela, she mentions though Shaheena was a child during Partition, images of Lucknow are still fresh in her mind. She recalls how she was nicknamed Rani because she was born in the haveli of Raja Suggur, where monkeys frequented the ‘kathal’ tree in the haveli and how her mamujan would take her on his cycle for breakfast on Gomti Bridge. Meher Afroz’s parents migrated to Pakistan and left her in Lucknow with relatives to complete her studies. She moved to Karachi in 1965 after completing her studies in Lucknow’s Arts College. In her postcard, she weaves the image of the erstwhile Lucknow. “…And as soon as the tonga reached Daliganj bridge that crossed the Gomti river, I could see the magical view of rising minarets and the dome of historical buildings in the pouring rain (sic).”

column2: Lucknow: Gomtinagar taps gurgle muddy water, only day’s supply in store
column3: LUCKNOW: Hundreds of households in Gomtinagar area are not only receiving inadequate water supply for nearly a month, they are also getting dirty water for last two days and the problem is expected to continue till Monday. Kathauta lake, the source of water supply to Gomtinagar, has turned shallow due to drop in water level after replenishment from Sharda Canal was stopped by irrigation department for dredging on October 28. Jal Sansthan had to lower the pipes close to the lake’s bed to draw water through pumps. In the process, pumps are also sucking in sand along with water. Executive engineer, Jal Sansthan, Ram Kailash said: “Water level should be 11-12 metres for proper supply but by Friday night it dropped to a metre. This means, just a day’s stock. Earlier, we were assured by the irrigation department that supply from canal would start from November 18 but now it has informed us that it will begin from Sunday.” NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The affected areas include Vibhuti Khand, Vishal Khand, Viram Khand, Vivek Khand and Vyom Khand.

column2: Lucknow: Filth raising a stink, where are trash cans?
column3: LUCKNOW: Piles of garbage are dotting the city in the absence of adequate number of waste bins as prescribed in the Swachh Bharat Mission guidelines. A day after a man was forced to stand amid rotting trash for hours in Daliganj to protest open garbage dumping after his complaints to Lucknow Municipal Corporation (LMC) went unheard for months, TOI, in a reality check, found that many areas do not have sufficient garbage bins.
