column2: Congress created hurdles for Ram temple: Yogi Adityanath
column3: Lucknow: Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath accused Congress party of creating hurdles in way of Ram temple construction in Ayodhya. Addressing election rally in Garhwa and Bhavnathpur assembly seats in Jharkhand on Wednesday, CM Yogi said BJP paved the way for temple construction and raised the ‘gaurav’ (pride) of India. “A grand temple of Lord Ram is all set to be constructed, thereby showing the strength of democracy and judiciary,” he said, amid loud chants of ‘Jai Shri Ram’ by BJP supporters. Targeting Congress, Yogi said, “Everyone knows that parties like Congress and Rashtriya Janata Dal are here only to create problems. For them, political party means using funds meant for public welfare for personal benefits of a family. They can’t think beyond that.” NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Giving the credit for the dilution of Article 370 in J&K to PM Narendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah, Yogi said they not only fulfilled the dreams of B R Ambedkar but also ended the influence of Pakistan in the region. BJP government also brought a law to ban triple talaq in a big relief to Muslim women, he added. Yogi said Jharkhand CM Raghubar Das has been following the footsteps of Modi and Shah. “Like Modi, Ragubar Das did not discriminate on caste, region and religion in providing benefits of government schemes to beneficiaries. All people of Jharkhand got benefits of schemes,” he said. Jharkhand and UP are geographically close and understand each other’s problems. If there is same government in Jharkhand, UP and Delhi, problems would get solved quickly,” he said, while appealing people to vote for BJP. “Jo karya karega usi ko vote milna chahiye,” said Yogi. Top CommentYogi ji ,  common mass of India is fed up  with over dose of  hinduism  served by  BJP. .Be sure Modi and your party BJP  never got elected on agenda of Hinduism . They are living in fools paradise ....Read MoreRam Dularay VermaSee All CommentsAdd comment“You have seen five years of Modi and Ragubar Das. You have seen 2.5 years of UP. We did not leave any problem unaddressed,” Yogi said while recall people-centric schemes like PMAY, Ujjwala and Saubhagya Yojana. People in Jharkhand got a house under PMAY and Ambedkar Awas scheme. “There were no toilets. People used to fall ill. Now, the state government is providing toilet to every household,” he said. “Besides Rs 6,000 provided under PM Kisan Nidhi, the Raghubar Das government was giving an additional Rs 5,000 to farmers. Around one lakh youths in Jharkhand got employment and recruitment is in process for 50,000 posts. When the steel plant comes up in Jharkhand there would be more employment opportunities,” he said.

column2: Uttar Pradesh: Shias want five acres if Sunni board refuses
column3: LUCKNOW: A day after UP Sunni Central Waqf Board’s passed a resolution against seeking a review of the Ayodhya verdict, the Shia Central Waqf Board too followed suit. Though Shia Board won’t file for review, it resolved to ask the government to hand over the five-acre plot to the board for setting up a hospital, if the Sunni waqf board refuses to accept the land mandated by Supreme Court as an alternative site for the mosque. Powered By                          10 Sec      Blocked Suez Forces Ships to Look at Long Trip Around Africa	.stlp0{fill:#FF3E5F;}	.st1{fill:#fffffe;}	.st2{fill:#FF3E5F;}         .clsx-1{isolation:isolate;}.clsx-2{fill:#ff3e5f;}.clsx-3{fill:#fff;}NextStay     Blocked Suez Forces Ships to Look at Long Trip Around AfricaNOW  PLAYINGSuez Canal Not Expected to Open Anytime SoonNOW  PLAYINGBangladesh deploys border guards after deadly anti-Modi protestsNOW  PLAYINGAt least four dead in Bangladesh Modi protestsNOW  PLAYINGIndia tells overseas vaccine buyers it must prioritise local needNOW  PLAYINGThe secret network helping Myanmar police fleeNOW  PLAYINGIndia orders deportation of migrants who fled Myanmar military coupNOW  PLAYINGWork to Re-Float Stuck Boat in Suez Canal SuspendedNOW  PLAYINGStuck Ship in Suez Canal Holds Up Oil and LNG ShipmentsNOW  PLAYINGIndian farmers dance to mark four months of protestsNOW  PLAYING  Arrow Left #1 Icon Created with Sketch.                 Arrow right #1 Icon Created with Sketch.               “If Sunni waqf board decides not to accept the five acre, then Shia waqf board is ready to take the same to end the dispute,” Board chairperson Waseem Rizvi said. “We will propose to build a hospital on that land which will be beneficial to the society,” he said. Five of seven board members, including the chairperson, were present in the meeting in Lucknow. “Though the Supreme Court dismissed the petition of Shia Waqf Board in the Ayodhya case, we will not file a review petition,” Board Rizvi said in a press statement. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“Shia Waqf Board lost a court case in 1946 against which we had filed an appeal in Supreme Court. On judgment day, our appeal was dismissed under the Limitation Act since a span of 71 years had passed since 1946,” Rizvi said. “We will not appeal against it and so there will be no review from our side. The dispute should end here in national interest and SC order should be accepted by everyone,” he added.

column2: Kanpur: Chargesheet filed in POCSO case against guard in record time
column3: KANPUR: The Nazirabad police has filed a chargesheet in the molestation case of an eight-year-old girl that took place at a kids’ school in the city on November 24. The shocking incident had led to panic and sparked protest by the family members of the girl and locals of the area. The girl was allegedly molested by a school guard, Anil Kumar, at a school in the city on November 24. Police arrested the accused on the basis of complaint lodged by the girl’s parents the same day. “During investigation, it came to fore that the guard lured the girl over some pretext and later molested her on the school premises,” said Inspector Nazirabad Manoj Kumar Raghuwanshi. The police completed its investigation in just 46 hours after family members and locals demanded strict action for the accused. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The chargesheet was filed in the POCSO court of additional district judge (VII) on Wednesday. According to SP South Raveena Tyagi, who headed the investigation, the chargesheet against the accused has been filed under section 354 of the Indian Penal Code and sections 7 and 8 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act. “Police have also filed a list of evidence that have been picked up from the spot, besides details regarding the medical examination performed on the girl and latter statement under 164 CrPc. The chargesheet was filed in record 46 hours on November 26 at around 8 pm. It was submitted in the POCSO court of additional district judge (VII) on Wednesday for trial,” she added. The survivor, meanwhile, is still in trauma.

column2: Gangster escapes from police lockup in Etawah
column3: KANPUR: An alleged gangster escaped from the lockup of Etawah Kotwali police station on Tuesday evening taking advantage of the smoke caused by fogging in the lockup to ward off mosquitoes. Police arrested the gangster from his friend’s house in Sati Mathiya temple locality of the city on Wednesday. His friend was also arrested for giving him shelter. Three constables and a home guard have been suspended for dereliction of duty. According to police, one Vinay Pal of Sati Mathiya temple locality, after being arrested under the Gangsters Act, was lodged at the lockup of Kotwali police station on Tuesday. “Pal fled taking advantage of the smoke due to fogging at the police lockup,” said a police official. ASP Omveer Singh that the alleged gangster has been arrested from his friend’s house on Wednesday and sent to jail with his friend. “We have also arrested his friend Ankit Yadav and sent him to jail for giving shelter to a criminal,” said the official. Constables Mahesh Kumar, Pankaj Kumar, and Sachin and home guard Ranveer Singh have been suspended for dereliction of duty. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“A case against three policemen has also been lodged while recommendation for action against the home guard has been made to the home guard commandant, said the ASP.

column2: BJP names Arun Singh for Rajya sabha bypoll
column3: LUCKNOW: BJP on Wednesday named party national general secretary Arun Singh as its candidate for Rajya Sabha bypoll in Uttar Pradesh. The seat has been vacated by SP MLA Tazeen Fatima, wife of SP MP Azam Khan. She had resigned from the seat to contest Rampur assembly bypoll which she won. Singh is expected to get elected unopposed given the present strength of BJP in UP Assembly and a divided Opposition — SP, BSP and Congress are no more supporting each other. If elected, his tenure will be till November 25, 2020. Latest CommentCongratulations to him on his elevation as RS MP.Sheik MohamedSee All CommentsAdd commentBJP nominees Neeraj Shekhar, Sanjay Seth, Surendra Nagar and Sudhanshu Dwivedi were also elected unopposed to the Rajya Sabha from UP in the bypolls held a few months ago. They had resigned from the Samajwadi Party to join the BJP. Sudhanshu Trivedi was elected from the seat which fell vacant following the demise of former finance minister Arun Jaitley. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The last date for filing nomination is December 2 and for withdrawing nomination is December 5. If necessary, the election will be held on December 12 and the result will be declared the same day. If the Opposition does not field any candidate then the result will be announced on December 5.

column2: Officials inspect Ganga before PM Narendra Modi ’s proposed december visit
column3: KANPUR: In view of the proposed visit of Prime Minister Narendra Modi to the city, a team of officials on Wednesday inspected Ganga, the barrage, ghats and the nullahs discharging effluent into the river. The team comprised of director-general, National Ganga Clean Mission Rajiv Ranjan Mishra, principal secretary, urban development, Manoj Kumar Singh, divisional commissioner Sudhir M Bobde, district magistrate Vijay Vishwas Pant, municipal commissioner Akshay Tripathi and other district officials. The PM is expected to visit the city next month to address a seminar on Ganga conservation. The officials contemplate that the PM, during his stay in the city, might inspect Ganga which, according to several reports, is much polluted in Kanpur. Moreover, the PM himself had stressed on tapping of 128-year-old notorious Sisamau nullah. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The focus of the team was on Sisamau nullah. Though the jal nigam authorities claimed that the nullah had been tapped, the team found it not fully tapped as some effluent still being discharged from it into the river. The two officials--Rajiv Ranjan Mishra and Manoj Kumar Singh--sought an explanation from the Jal Nigam officials as to why the nullah had not been completely tapped. The team also observed that a nullah near the city jail was also discharging effluent into the river uninterruptedly. The team members after visiting the Rani Ghat expressed their dissatisfaction when they saw that some small nullahs were discharging effluent of the locality into the river and that the ghat had also not been cleaned. The principal secretary asked the officials to build a septic tank to check the discharge of the locality flowing into the river. The team officials also expressed their anger over garbage accumulated at Parmat and other ghats and asked the officials to get the ghats cleaned and also get the ground levelled. Earlier in the morning, the team members at a meeting held with the officials of the irrigation department sought information about other nullahs discharging effluent into Ganga. Later, talking to media persons at Sarsaiya Ghat after making inspection, Rajiv Ranjan Mishra said, "Kanpur is in the priority list as here Ganga is much polluted. The government is collecting the discharge data of cities situated on the banks of Ganga, he said and added that a company has been given the task to operate both old as well as new STPs of the city.

column2: Uttar Pradesh: Bill not paid? PCL to snap power line
column3: LUCKNOW: Uttar Pradesh Power Corporation Limited will begin a special drive from Thursday to recover dues from electricity bill defaulters. The drive will continue for two weeks. Power connections of defaulters who will fail to clear the dues will be snapped. The main aim is to recover dues from big defaulters, said principal secretary energy and UPPCL chairman Arvind Kumar. UPPCL has set a target of recovering dues from at least 250 defaulters in each division, he added. In sensitive areas, the corporation will take the help of district administration and police in locating the defaulters. Kumar said employees engaged in maintenance of distribution lines will also be part of the drive. During the drive, bill counters of power department will remain open from 8am to 8pm. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The number of total connections snapped will be uploaded on the corporation’ portal for internal reference. The power department has also introduced easy installment scheme for consumers to clear the dues. The corporation aims to tap about 71 lakh such consumers.

column2: Home guards scam: Police to scan bank accounts of accused
column3: LUCKNOW: Police grilled four staffers working under the arrested district commandant Kripa Shanker Pandey in the home guards office and took their statements to unravel the roles of all those who played a part in siphoning off public money in the wage scam. On Wednesday, Gomtinagar police picked up two subordinates of Pandey for questioning after it had recorded the statements of two others on Tuesday night. SHO Gomtinagar, Amit Dubey, who is investigation officer of the case, said, “We have taken the written statements of Pandey’s four sub-ordinates. We will now use their submissions to grill Pandey. Discrepancies have also been detected in some documents for which a detailed letter will be sent to the department of home guards.” Dubey refused to share the names of the four staffers, but said they were responsible for the upkeep of the muster rolls of Gomtinagar, Vibhutikhand, Indiranagar, Gudamba, BKT, Madiaon and Itaunja police stations. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.We have sought all details of the bank accounts of all those arrested and will also their deposits, properties and valuables and any spike in them in the last two years. Gomtinagar police had arrested district commandant Kripa Shankar Pandey on November 21 for fraudulent withdrawal of salary by showing inflated figures of personnel deployed at Vibhutikhand and Gudamba police stations. Raids were carried out at the district office of home guards. On Tuesday, platoon commander Sushil Singh had surrendered in court while block officer Raj Kumar was arrested by police.

column2: Lucknow: Nothing fast about tag delivery, deadline skips
column3: LUCKNOW: Several vehicle owners who have applied for FASTags online are complaining that its delivery is taking 8-10 days against the 3-5 days promised at the time of booking. A few also complained about technical glitches. “The FASTag was delivered to me on Tuesday, 10 days after I booked it through an e-commerce site on November 16. The site had assured delivery in 3-5 days. When I inquired, the customer care executive told me that the delay was due to the courier company,” said Sunil Singh, a businessman. “Had I not booked in advance, the delivery would have been after December 1. It would have caused major inconvenience because I travel frequently by road,” he added. Similarly, Ruchi Rastogi of Balaganj said, “It has been seven days since I placed an order with a private bank but have not received my tag though it was expected to be delivered on Monday. The bank says the tag was dispatched on Monday.” Latest CommentThinking about this at last moment. Tends to happen like this.Athul NairSee All CommentsAdd comment“I received a faulty FASTag from an e-commerce site after seven days. They have now promised to change it within five days after a complaint,” said Sudhir Singh of Aashiana. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The corporate communications official of a private bank said, “We get FASTags dispatched in a day and it gets delivered in three to five working days. We have asked the courier company now to expedite delivery of FASTags.”

column2: Rain, hail and winds turn NCR air ‘safe’ after 27 days
column3: Delhi received light rain on Wednesday NEW DELHI: Delhi’s air was officially safe to breathe for over 13 hours till Wednesday morning in terms of PM2.5 levels and the day’s average air quality index was the best since October 8, after strong winds and rain, including hailstorms at some places, washed away pollutants. Track the pollution level in your cityThe improvement was so dramatic that PM2.5 levels stayed below the safe limit of 60 micrograms/cubic metre from just after 7pm on Tuesday till around 9am on Wednesday. The clean-up was the result of rainfall in the northern plains, with strong northwesterly winds bringing clean air into Delhi-NCR. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Such clean air is rare in NCR this time of the year. As per CPCB’s 24-hour average data, the last time Delhi-NCR’s PM2.5 level was in safe zone was on October 19. Later, most parts of Delhi received light rain in the afternoon, along with hail in some parts of NCR. The AQI improved to ‘moderate’ – a level last seen on October 9, when monsoon had yet to withdraw. Cleaner air: Good news at 20km / hrWhile Delhi’s AQI was recorded at 270 (poor) on Tuesday, it fell to 134 (moderate) in the next 24 hours – the lowest reading since October 8, when the AQI was recorded at 112 (moderate). Met officials said a number of factors helped the cleaning up the air, with a spell of rain over the last two days in the northern plains negating the impact of stubble burning. Good wind speed did not allow the moisture levels to increase and trap pollutants, officials said. “Wind speed was around 15-20 km/hour on Wednesday which along with the rain has helped settle pollutants. Wind speed is expected to drop slightly on Thursday, but it will slow down only on November 29,” said Kuldeep Srivastava, scientist at IMD. The Safdarjung observatory, the city’s main weather station, recorded ‘trace’ rainfall till 5.30pm, while Jafarpur in northwest Delhi received the most rainfall at 7mm. Srivastava said parts of Ghaziabad and north Delhi recorded hailstorm activity, a phenomenon not uncommon at this time of the year. “Good wind speed and rain in the region have not allowed the moisture content to increase and trap pollutants. While wind speeds will dip by November 29, the deterioration in air quality will not be significant as the impact of rain will continue,” said Srivastava. The System of Air Quality and Weather Forecasting And Research (SAFAR) said the air quality would remain in the ‘moderate’ range on Thursday before slipping to the ‘poor’ range on Friday. “Under the influence of a western disturbance, precipitation recorded in Delhi and its north-western regions has led to washing out of suspended pollutants and rapid improvement in air quality. The SAFAR model forecast suggests AQI is likely to be on the moderate category for tomorrow. Marginal deterioration to poor AQI category is forecast for November 29,” said SAFAR. In NCR, Gurugram was the cleanest with an AQI of 104 (moderate) in the last 24 hours, while Noida, Greater Noida, Ghaziabad and Faridabad all recorded ‘moderate’ AQI. While Delhi’s minimum temperature was 14.5 degrees, met officials say mercury is likely to fall to around 12 degrees by November 30 and to 10 degrees by December 1.

column2: These students had quite a ball in Lucknow
column3: A four-day intra-college festival titled Ohr7.0 was recently held at the Dr Ram Manohar Lohiya National Law University, Lucknow, under the chairmanship of Dr Vandana Singh. The fest included many functions like inter-batch competition, paper dance, intern-batch antakshari, among others. (L) Prakhar and Shilpi (R) Shuaib Saifi and Tanmay (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) (L) Prakhar and Shilpi (R) Shuaib Saifi and Tanmay (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) However, the most talked about event of the fest was the Ball Night, a social gathering of teachers and students. The campus of this law college was full of colours and smiles as the students were dressed as their favourite rom-com hero as per the theme of the ball night. The students were seen having lots of fun dancing on the floor with their dance partners on songs like Ghazab Ka Hai Din, My Name Is Lakhan, Hungama Ho Gaya, etc. The excitement was at its peak when the DJ announced the last song of the night, Tum Hi Ho. column2: Play based on the father-daughter relationship staged in Lucknow
column3: A play titled Tum was recently staged at the Thrust Auditorium of Bhartendu Natya Akademi showcasing the relationship between a father and a daughter. The drama was about Pooja who, in search of her real father finally finds him after a lot of struggle. Brahmanand Vashishth, the father was played by veteran theatre and film actor Dr Anil Rastogi. Pradeep Shivhare (L) and Vikas Vishwakarma (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) Pradeep Shivhare (L) and Vikas Vishwakarma (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui) However, the story takes a surprise turn when Pooja conceals her identity and decides to become friends with her father. Later, Brahmanand also realizes that she is his daughter and together they begin a new journey. The play was written and directed by Hemendra Kumar Bhatia, an alumnus of the Film and Television Institute of India (FTII), Pune. column2: Four killed, 60 injured as bus hits divider, overturns
column3: Kanpur: Four passengers died and 60 others were injured when a Bihar bound private bus coming from Jaipur overturned after hitting the divider on Agra-Lucknow Expressway in Kannauj district on Wednesday night. The bus carrying about 65 passengers met with the accident near the Faguha Bhatta area in Kannauj around 10.30 pm, said police. Four passengers died on the spot and the injured were ferried to the Government Medical College in Kannauj by Uttar Pradesh Expressways Industrial Development Authority (UPEIDA) personnel. The condition of some of the injured are stated to be critical. The four deceased are yet to be identified, said police. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Circle Officer (city) Subodh Jaiswal, who reached the spot after the accident, said, “As per initial findings, the bus overturned after hitting the divider when one of its tyres deflated. It started from Jaipur and was headed to Bihar.”

column2: President kin alleges threat call from Pakistan, gets security
column3: KANPUR: Rajiv Kumar, a distant relative of President Ramnath Kovind and state vice-president of NaMo Sena India (Bharat), has been provided police security after he complained of receiving a threat call on his WhatsApp number from an unknown person in Pakistan on Thursday and filed an FIR with the Kalyanpur police. Rajiv, a resident of Kalyanpur, claims to be brother of Deepa Kovind, daughter-in-law of President Kovind. He also holds the post of state vice-president of the Sena, a social organization named after Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The threat assumes significance in view of President Kovind’s visit to the city on November 30. He is scheduled to attend functions at CSJM University, Kanpur Nagar Nigam (KNN) and a private institute in Bhaunti area of the district. “I received a WhatsApp call at around 2 pm on my mobile phone. The number displayed on my screen was of Pakistan — 92-3096943288. When I picked up the call, the caller started threatening and asked me to disassociate myself with NaMo Sena. He also threatened to blow up my family using RDX if I did not listen to him,” Rajiv told TOI. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“The call lasted 40 seconds. When I asked the caller to introduce himself, he disconnected the call,” he added. Rajiv then approached the Kalyanpur police and submitted a complaint. Subsequently, a case was registered under relevant sections of IPC. “We have launched an investigation and scanning the number, from which the WhatsApp call was made, with the help of E-surveillance and cybercell experts,” said Circle Officer (CO) Kalyanpur Ajay Kumar. “A case against unknown persons under IPC sections 503 (criminal intimidation) and 504 (intentional insult to provoke breach of the peace) has been registered on the complaint of Rajiv Kumar, who claims himself to be a distant relative of President Kovind. It seems the call was made to terrorise the complainant,” the officer added. “Though 92 is Pakistan code, I believe that it could be the handiwork of someone known to the complainant or could also be a spoof call. However, we are not taking any chance and have provided police security to the complainant,” the CO added.

column2: Kanpur: 39 factory workers injured in collision between bus, truck
column3: KANPUR: As many as 39 factory workers were injured after a bus carrying them rammed into a truck near Bhawanipur village on GT road under Chaubeypur police station on Thursday. The bus was heading towards a factory in Chaubeypur industrial area from the city when it rammed into a truck approaching from the opposite direction. On being informed, police reached the spot and rushed the injured to a private hospital in Mandhana, said SP (rural) Pradyumna Singh. Around 19 workers were discharged after first aid while the rest are undergoing treatment, he added. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“Initial findings suggest that the truck driver applied brakes all of a sudden on the road. Unalramed bus droiver couldn’t control the vehicle and rammed into the truck. However, the investoigation is on ,” said a senior police official.

column2: NHAI to begin repair work on Old Ganga bridge today
column3: KANPUR: The National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) has decided to start the repair work of the Old Ganga bridge in Jajmau from Friday. The decision was taken after a recent inspection. There would, however, be no restriction on the movement of vehicles on the bridge, though traffic is likely to be affected during the repair period. Over 40-year-old bridge connecting Kanpur and Lucknow via Unnao needs major repairs, including the road. A recent inspection revealed that the joint bearings were damaged, road had developed potholes and at many places Ganga flowing beneath the bridge could be seen through damaged portions of the bridge. Talking to TOI, project director, NHAI, Purshottam Lal Chaudhary said that the maintenance work on the Ganga bridge would commence from Friday. It would take a couple of days in the repair work and till then heavy vehicle will be passed through the bridge at a restricted speed of 30 km/hour, he said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Apart from the construction of road, damaged bearings, joints would also be replaced or repaired as per the requirement. However, NHAI official denied closing the bridge for repair work and said that there would be no need for restricting the traffic and the maintenance work would go on parallel with the vehicular movement. It is expected that when the maintenance work would go on, the traffic load on the bridge will increase as the movement of heavy vehicles will be slowed down. On the other hand, the repair work may also lead to increase in traffic load on the new Ganga bridge. A few days ago, an inspection of the old Ganga bridge was carried out by the officials following which it was decided to conduct repairing work of the bridge. During the inspection it was found that the joints were damaged, road was withered off and even the iron mesh laid below the road was visible at some points.

column2: Smoggy Kanpur, Lucknow most polluted in country
column3: LUCKNOW: The air quality improved in many parts of the state, but continued to be unhealthy in central UP with Kanpur and Lucknow being the most polluted in the country on Thursday. As thick smog cloaked this part of the state for the third consecutive day, the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) recorded a ‘very poor’ air quality index (AQI) of 379 in Kanpur. Lucknow was close on the heels with an AQI of 374. Though the pollution levels were down by seven and three units, respectively, since Wednesday, there seemed to be little respite. There is no relief in sight either. Dipping day temperatures, low wind velocity and high moisture content in the atmosphere will facilitate smog, experts say. Cold days and moist air result in fog, which then couples with tiny pollutants to create smog. The suspended particles will stay close to the Earth’s surface because there are no strong winds to disperse them, the experts explained. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Kanpur had attained global infamy in May last year when the World Health Organisation (WHO) had declared it the ‘most polluted city’ on a list of 4,300 cities around the world where PM 2.5 concentration is monitored. Across Lucknow, the average concentration of superfine particulate matter was 250 microgram per cubic metre (µg/m³) of air throughout Thursday. The most polluted area was Talkatora with a PM 2.5 level of 386µg/m³, followed by Gomtinagar with 376µg/m³, Lalbagh with 358µg/m³ and Aliganj with 301µg/m³. Latest Commentevery thing in UP is pollutedRewardingSee All CommentsAdd comment“Since weather conditions are conducive to higher pollution levels, the situation will remain the same till agencies and authorities restrict the practice of open garbage burning and reduce vehicular volume on roads of Lucknow and Kanpur,” said environmentalist Venkatesh Dutta. In Lucknow, the maximum temperature was 29.7°C, a notch above normal, and the minimum 17°C, six points above normal. The relative humidity was moderate to high between 49% and 94% while the wind velocity was around 2kmph. In stark contrast, the AQI in western UP cities like Ghaziabad and Noida, which was ‘severe’ until last week, improved to ‘moderate’ on Thursday, courtesy light rainfall and high wind velocity.

column2: Steeped in loan, businessman’s family consumes poison
column3: LUCKNOW: A trader, his wife and son consumed poisonous substance at their house in Gosaiganj in the intervening night of Wednesday and Thursday. The family had taken loans from banks and money lenders but suffered losses and was unable to repay. The victims, residents of Khurdahi Bazaar locality, were rushed to KGMU Trauma Centre where the trader Ramesh Verma (52) and his wife Savitri (50) died while their son Vikas (23) is undergoing treatment. Gosaiganj SHO, D K Upadhyay got a message about the incident around 1.56am on Thursday and rushed to the spot. “Ramesh’s son-in-law Kamlakant was at the spot. He told us that the trio had consumed poisonous substance. We rushed them to hospital where Ramesh and Savitri were declared brought dead. Kamlakant said Vikas had informed him about consuming the poisonous substance,” the SHO said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Kamlakant informed that Ramesh had taken loans from Gramin Bank and Corporation Bank for his business of ply boards, but suffered heavy losses over the time and could not pay the bank loan instalments, the SHO added. Ramesh was served by bank officials twice and git jittery. Fearing penalty and seizure of property, Ramesh took loans from some money lenders to pay instalments while hoping his business will flourish again. Ramesh’s fortunes in business failed to revive and he was left neck deep in debt,” Kamalkant told police in his statement. Ramesh, a native of Kapera Madarpur village in Gosaiganj, had shifted to his new house in Khurdahi Bazaar locality after he married off his three daughters. He sold some land to construct the house and later opened a shop in his residence by taking loans from different banks.

column2: Lucknow: Stray cow gores trader to death near his residence
column3: LUCKNOW: A 30-year-old man was gored to death by a stray cow in Alambagh late on Wednesday. This was the sixth incident of a stray cattle killing a person in the city this year. The incident again highlights the negligence of civic authorities to tackle the stray cattle menace on the roads. The deceased was identified as Rajeev Singh, a trader. He lived with his wife and two children in Sector-D of Alambagh. Singh was returning from his shop on his motorcycle when a stray cattle attacked him near his home. He lost control on the bike and fell on the road. He suffered injuries on head, leg and shoulder. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Neighbours chased away the animal and took a profusely bleeding Singh to a hospital where he was declared brought dead. More than 25 incidents of stray cattle attacks have been recorded in the city this year while several similar incidents go unreported. When TOI visited Alambagh on Thursday, residents complained about the daily menace of stray animals in the area. Top Commentabki baar...cattle sarkar hogi bahaar...RewardingSee All CommentsAdd commentOn January 3, state government had ordered the Lucknow Municipal Corporation to catch all stray cattle and put them in shelter homes constructed by the civic body. But the civic body has failed to comply with the order even after 11 months. LMC officials instead claim to have caught more than 5,000 stray cattle and conducting regular cattle-catching drives. “We had conducted drives in Alambagh last month. We will conduct more drives in Almbagh to ensure no such incidents occurs again,” said an LMC official.

column2: A piano from the 1800s and more at House of the Sun
column3: LUCKNOW: If you wish to catch a glimpse of the 150-year-old history of La Martiniere Girls’ College (LMGC), mark your date with Khursheed Manzil now. The campus monument — also known as the House of the Sun — is inspired by an English Lord’s castle and was built in 1818. It has been converted into a museum to mark the institution’s sesquicentennial year. Said to be India’s first museum housed in a school, it will be opened to the public soon. The oldest keepsakes are a desk and a wooden piano dating back to the 1800s. There are also historical documents, the constitution of the college, paintings, handwritten diaries, postcards and letters in calligraphy by the alumni and teachers. Trophies, certificates, photographs, teaching aids, the first college magazine published in 1947 and a miniature of Khursheed Manzil and the market around it from the 19th century are among other fascinating souvenirs from LMGC’s past. In months to come, a few tokens from the First War of Independence in 1857, which have been preserved by the institution, will also be on display. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The LMGC began as a school with 35 students in 1871 and currently has over 3,000 girls on its rolls. Urdu was introduced in 1884 to preserve Lucknow’s culture, but was replaced with Hindi a 100 years later. The restoration of the historic monument, with an objective to convert it into a museum, began in 2013 with a grant from the Union ministry of culture and tourism. “Apart from the history of the institution, insights into the life of founding father Major General Claude Martin are also on display,” said college principal Ashrita Dass. Its construction was completed by his son Ghazi-ud-din Haider in 1818. The monument witnessed the revolt of 1857 up close. In 1889, the then British government approved conversion of the campus into a school, founded by French officer Major General Claude Martin, for European students.

column2: Lucknow: Strong wind gives first chill of season
column3: LUCKNOW: Following strong winds and slight drizzle in some areas and adjoining districts, Lucknow experienced a slight nip in the air on Thursday night. Though the weather is expected to be partly cloudy on Friday as well, possibilities of rainfall are low. Met officials said that a western disturbance (WD) over Himalayas and a cyclonic circulation over Rajasthan led to the thunderstorm in many parts of western UP on Thursday. Even though the storm brought down air pollution levels, it added to the chill. The impact was also felt in central parts of the state including Lucknow when a squall hit the city around 11.30pm. Wind velocity increased suddenly from around 2 km/hour to above 15km/hour. The sky was overcast and a drizzle was reported for a brief period in isolated places. On Thursday, the maximum temperature was reported as 29.7 degrees Celsius, a notch above normal, while the minimum temperature was six points above normal at 17 degrees Celsius. The relative humidity was reported as moderate to high between 49% and 94%.

column2: Agra gets first microbrewery in Uttar Pradesh
column3: LUCKNOW: Agra has become the first city in the state where one will be able to savour freshly brewed draught beer. The excise department is in the process of clearing five more applications for a microbrewery, one of which is for Lucknow and should be granting licences in the coming weeks. The MB-5 licence granted to a restaurant in Agra for setting up of a microbrewery is the first such licence issued by the government under the newly amended UP Brewery Rules of 1961. The city was selected, say officials, due to the large flow of both foreign and domestic tourists in the city known for the Taj Mahal. “There is a huge demand for freshly brewed beer because of which the state had brought this policy. States like Maharashtra, Karnataka and Telangana have had provisions for microbreweries for some time now and this will encourage both tourism and employment generation in the state,” said a senior official. He added that the government was processing five more applications and would grant more licences as and when they received more applications. Latest Commentऊ इ सब की आजादी को एक साथ काम करना शुरू की आजादी की थी इस लिए मैंने अपनी जान से प्यारा था की शुरूआत केGanesh kohliSee All CommentsAdd commentPermission to the restaurant in Agra has been granted on the condition that the UP Brewery Rules will be complied with. Violation of the rules attracts a penalty of Rs5,000 per day. The excise department said that it will become the first place to serve “non-pasteurised and fresh beer” to clients. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The UP Brewery Rules-2019, announced in June this year, has set an annual license fee for microbreweries to Rs2.5 lakh, up from Rs25,000 which was fixed in 1974. A guarantee fee of Rs1 lakh has also been fixed. The rules have fixed a limit of 600 litre which a microbrewery will be allowed to produce each day. Working on an average of 350 days a year when any establishment will work, an annual production limit of 2.1 lakh litres has been fixed.

column2: Niti Aayog thumbs-up to Kumbh Mela for economy boost
column3: LUCKNOW: The organisation of the 2019 Kumbh Mela in Allahabad has received a thumbs-up from the Niti Aayog. Calling the arrangements a huge success, a Niti Ayog report has said that the Mela was not only successful in promoting economic activity in the state, boosting the country’s image and tourism, and increasing local employment generation, it also showcased “the grandeur that is India, to the world, besides demonstrating the organizational skills of the state government”. The report was prepared after a team of Niti Aayog officials visited Allahabad in April this year to study how the mega event was executed. The Mela was held from January 15 to March 4. The report says that the team documented various aspects of the Mela’s organisation, including institutional arrangement, infrastructure, development of the Mela area, use of technology for intelligent traffic management and disaster management. The team also called the Mela “the best example of crowd management and cleanliness in the world”. The Mela, says the report, was marketed not just as a religious event but also as a major cultural and social event. Convention centres, Ganga Pandal, Pravachan Pandal and an Interpretation Centre were set up as venues for over 200 cultural and social events. For tourists, food trails and walks were planned around the venue. The report compliments the laying out of the temporary city with key infrastructure like electricity, water and sanitation facilities, public accommodation, convenience shops, food courts, vending zones, banks, ATMs, transport facilities, 40 police booths and health centres. “The Indian Inland Waterways Authority set up five jetties in the Mela area which facilitated operation of large cruises and motor boats in the Ganga and Yamuna rivers in Prayagraj for the first time,” the report says. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Sanitation is another aspect which finds mention in the report, the Niti Aayog team complimenting the government for over 1.2 lakh toilets located at every 200 metres.

column2: Medical tourism MoU at global expo
column3: LUCKNOW: Aiming to give a fillip to the services sector in the state, with special focus on medical tourism, the UP government signed an MoU with the Health Tourism Development Center of Islamic Countries at the three-day expo, Global Exhibition on Services – The India Opportunity, in Bengaluru on Thursday. The Yogi government inked the pact to draw business for the services sector, primarily health and education, besides inviting foreign investment. The government showcased the state as a medical tourism destination and expects people from Islamic countries to come for availing quality healthcare at affordable rates, thereby earning foreign exchange. The MoU was signed in the presence of MSME and exports promotion minister, Sidharth Nath Singh, who said UP has immense potential in hospitality, health, education, IT and logistics and offered to host the next global expo. Principal secretary, Navneet Sehgal, who signed the MoU, said the government aims to tap the medical tourism sector to earn foreign exchange and achieve CM Yogi Adityanath’s resolve of turning UP into a trillion dollar economy into a reality. UP has good hospitals having infrastructure of international standards along with expert doctors and has immense potential as medical tourism destination for people from countries where treatment costs are very high while quality infrastructure and manpower are lacking, Sehgal added. Uttar Pradesh also offered to host the next global exposition to showcase the state’s immense potential in services sector also, apart from traditional exports, he said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.We are the fourth largest state, have a high consumer base and have grown to second largest economy by contributing 8.5% to India’s GDP, claimed Sehgal. The state has identified tourism, IT, logistics, health and education as focus sectors with huge potential in terms of investment and revenue generating potential, he said after final session on ‘UP — The Next Engine for Services Exports’.

column2: Tejas hurtles into big row, 20 crew members sacked amid hush-up cry
column3: LUCKNOW: Indian Railways’ first corporate train, Tejas Express, chugged into a controversy after 20 members of its crew were allegedly sacked within a month of its high-profile flag-off. Eleven women and nine men, who were part of the launch crew are now on a warpath after they were shown the door on November 4. They claimed, no reason was attributed for retrenchment. While most employees alleged they were made to work on a gruelling 18-hour shift, some women crew members claimed they were harassed by passengers, but their complaints were ignored. Avantika Bajpai, who was deputed manager of a 48-strong team, told TOI, “We were hired by the contractor, Brindavan Food Products, on September 25 and trained to serve passengers of Tejas Express. We would do an 18-hour shift daily, without rest. The appointment letter mentioned that we were hired on a six-month probation, but we were sacked within a month without citing any reason.” Powered By                          10 Sec      Suez Canal Not Expected to Open Anytime Soon	.stlp0{fill:#FF3E5F;}	.st1{fill:#fffffe;}	.st2{fill:#FF3E5F;}         .clsx-1{isolation:isolate;}.clsx-2{fill:#ff3e5f;}.clsx-3{fill:#fff;}NextStay     Suez Canal Not Expected to Open Anytime SoonNOW  PLAYINGThe secret network helping Myanmar police fleeNOW  PLAYINGIndia tells overseas vaccine buyers it must prioritise local needNOW  PLAYINGBangladesh deploys border guards after deadly anti-Modi protestsNOW  PLAYINGAt least four dead in Bangladesh Modi protestsNOW  PLAYINGStuck Ship in Suez Canal Holds Up Oil and LNG ShipmentsNOW  PLAYINGIndian farmers dance to mark four months of protestsNOW  PLAYINGBlocked Suez Forces Ships to Look at Long Trip Around AfricaNOW  PLAYINGIndia orders deportation of migrants who fled Myanmar military coupNOW  PLAYINGWork to Re-Float Stuck Boat in Suez Canal SuspendedNOW  PLAYING  Arrow Left #1 Icon Created with Sketch.                 Arrow right #1 Icon Created with Sketch.               IRCTC, which is operating the train, had created an all-woman WhatsApp group in October, stating that any woman attendant can seek consultation or assistance when in distress. The group was formed after it was reported by media about a craze among passengers to click selfies with train stewardess, which was sometimes very unpleasant. “We were added to the official WhatsApp group of Tejas Express, where we would record our attendance. But, after a month, 20 of us were removed from service. On November 13, we were also removed from the official WhatsApp group ‘Tejas Crew’,” said Avantika. Namrata Mishra, who also lost her job, said, “The salary quoted in our appointment letters was Rs 10,500, but we were given much less than what was promised. Some were given Rs 6,500 while some were handed out Rs 7,000 or 8,000. When we lodged a verbal complaint with Shubhangi ma'am and Aman Sir (from the agency which hired the women), we were told the salary has been credited according to our working days. We were told the salary was being given by RK Group.” “When we were hired, we were told about a day’s off after an 18-hour shift, but after one week, we were asked to do an 18-hour shift daily. We were also threatened that if we raised our voice about working conditions, we will be fired,” she said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Zuhaib Alam, another coach attendant who lost his job, said, “We were hired as coach attendants and trained to help women staff. We often found the girls complaining to the agency about harassment by passengers and we were often witness to passengers forcibly clicking selfies without permission. We have been terminated by the company without citing any reason, though we have our appointment letters. Sometimes, we were forced to give waste water of RO machine to passengers. When we protested, we were threatened with termination.” Owner of Brindavan Food Products, Rajiv Mittal did not respond to repeated calls from TOI. IRCTC, meanwhile, distanced itself from the controversy. Chief regional manager, IRCTC, Lucknow, Ashwini Srivastava, said, “We did not receive any complaint from any woman on any kind of harassment.”

column2: Constable’s foot patrol effective policing: Kiran Bedi
column3: LUCKNOW: It was a DSP, junior by rank but 20 years her senior in age, who taught former ace cop and Puducherry Lieutenant Governor Kiran Bedi one of the most important lessons of her professional life—beat policing. Speaking at the inaugural session of the 47th All India Police Science Congress at UP Police headquarters on Thursday, the retired IPS officer recalled how one KK Chhabra had told her that it was by repositioning constables that she could fulfil her dream of preventing crime. “Constables and head constables must get centre stage in policing while officers should guide them,” said Bedi. In her 22-minute interaction, Bedi said that constables and head constables must be nurtured and also given protection, adding that policing should be thought about from their perspective. “When I started my career as a district in charge, I wanted to prevent crime, come what may. Chhabra told me: Madam aap bahut peeche padi hai prevention ke. Ye aise nahi hone wala, ye sab beat policing se hoga (Madam, you would only be able to prevent crime through beat policing),” she said. “It is always crime prevention and then detection...If beat system is judiciously followed, then crime would be monitored automatically and hotspots of crime would be visible,” she added. These days, nobody follows the beat system, she said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“Beat policing is the architect of policing. Even if a law and order situation arises or an emergency situation comes up, the beat system must not be disturbed,” she said. Constables should be encouraged to file daily reports about what’s happening in their areas and senior policemen should interact with lower rung cops daily, she said. “I used to accompany constables on walks in the areas allocated to them. I used to reward them based on how many people used to greet them with a ‘namaste’.” “My research shows that attending the roll-call and through exchange of information, 100% beat officers knew what was happening in the city. The same system needs to be implemented across the country to improve detection of crime,” the 70-year-old said. The 70-year-old also said that an officer must consider ‘khaki’ similar to a temple/mosque/gurdwara/church (place of worship). Referring to the Ayodhya case, Bedi said she was looking at the developments with a sense of nervousness. She complimented the Uttar Pradesh Police for ensuring that the situation remained under control after the verdict. “This and the success of Kumbh Mela have done the country proud. I wish there was a Magsaysay award for the police for these achievements,” she said. She also said that UP DGP should interact with each police station in the state via video conferencing. “Nyay aur himmat (justice and courage) must be the motto of every police officer,” she said. DGP OP Singh, in his welcome address, outlined the achievements of UP Police. The two-day event is being organised by the Bureau of Police Research & Development (BPR&D). Union home minister Amit Shah will be present for the closing day on Friday. UP is getting the opportunity to host the annual event after 22 years.

column2: ‘Bring forensic course to crack sex crime’
column3: LUCKNOW: At the conclusion of each session conducted at the 47th Police Science Congress being held in Lucknow, two resolutions will be drafted and adopted after discussion. These will then be read out in front of Union home minister Amit Shah on Friday for implementation at policy-making level, said Renuka Mishra, ADG, recruitment & promotion board, UP Police. On Thursday, the first resolution in the session on women’s safety was about investigation of sexual crimes against women. The resolution says that medical examination of a victim, as required in criminal investigation of sexual crimes, should be taught in detail as part of the curriculum in medical schools. While forensic medicine exists, the depth of the subject is such that there should be an entire course or specialisation in it. The idea came from Amol Deshmukh, a Mumbai-based forensic and investigation expert, who is also an adviser in the Union ministry of home affairs. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“In cases of sexual assault, the medical report often remains inconclusive. The life of a person depends on that medical report. The training for medical examination cannot be limited to one or two questions or a few lectures. If medical examination is not done correctly, even compensation that is due to the victim is denied because rape is not confirmed by medical examination even if it has taken place. Forensic gynaecology subject should be introduced as a branch of study,” said Deshmukh. He also said that courses specific to sexual offences against children need to pay more attention in medical education. Additionally, refresher courses in medico-legal examination should be held for doctors because the nature of sexual crimes has changed over the years. Latest CommentFor non-finance people who want to learn the subject, I recommend this book published by Sandeep Goel who teaches a course with me on Forensic Accounting and Corporate Governance at MDI.....................Pinku SinghSee All CommentsAdd commentThe resolution proposes that doctors should provided a detailed protocol for medical examination in criminal cases. The second resolution was regarding strict implementation of Supreme Court regulations on sale and purchase of acid to prevent acid attacks, most of the victims of which are women. The regulations include asking the acid buyer for what purpose is the product being purchased and also the the seller recording details of the person in the form of an ID, among others. While both forensic medicine training for doctors and regulations on sale of acid exist on paper, their actual implementation is very weak, said experts in the panel.

column2: Ayodhya verdict: Can ‘illegally placed’ idol be called deity? Muslim litigants to ask in review
column3: LUCKNOW: How can an “illegally placed” idol, forced on another person’s property, be a deity? This will be the key point of a review plea to be filed by Muslim litigants of the Ayodhya dispute backed by All India Muslim Personal Law Board (AIMPLB). The petition for review of the   November 9 verdict   of SC will be put in court during the first week of December. Powered By                          10 Sec      Del Monte Saw Double-Digit Growth During Covid, CEO Says	.stlp0{fill:#FF3E5F;}	.st1{fill:#fffffe;}	.st2{fill:#FF3E5F;}         .clsx-1{isolation:isolate;}.clsx-2{fill:#ff3e5f;}.clsx-3{fill:#fff;}NextStay     Del Monte Saw Double-Digit Growth During Covid, CEO SaysNOW  PLAYINGHindustan Petroleum: Costly Oil Hurting Indian EconomyNOW  PLAYINGSuez Canal Not Expected to Open Anytime SoonNOW  PLAYINGLibya to Lift Oil Output to 1.45 Million BPD by Year EndNOW  PLAYINGMobius Sees Turkish Lira Remaining Steady as Dollar WeakensNOW  PLAYINGOil Rallies as Stuck Ship Blocks Suez CanalNOW  PLAYINGEurope Struggles with Vaccine RolloutNOW  PLAYINGWork to Re-Float Stuck Boat in Suez Canal SuspendedNOW  PLAYINGThe World is Protein Short: Green Plains CEO Todd BeckerNOW  PLAYINGStuck Ship in Suez Canal Holds Up Oil and LNG ShipmentsNOW  PLAYING  Arrow Left #1 Icon Created with Sketch.                 Arrow right #1 Icon Created with Sketch.               “The idol of Ram Lalla, which was worshipped at the Ram Chabutra adjoining the Babri Masjid since 1885, had assumed the status of a deity following Hindu rituals and traditions. We never contested this,” AIMPLB secretary and Babri Masjid Action Committee (BMAC) convener advocate Zafaryab Jilani told TOI. “However, since the idol was illegally placed under the Babri Masjid’s central dome, thereby desecrating it as observed by the Supreme Court, it cannot become a deity when on someone else’s property,” said Jilani. Ram Mandir-Babri Masjid case verdict, as it happened: HighlightsNEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The idol of Ram Lalla was placed inside Babri Masjid in the intervening night of December 22-23, 1949, an act which SC has termed illegal in its November 9 verdict. “The deity had judicial rights to fight for its property when it was worshipped at the Ram Chabutra from 1885 to 1949,” said Jilani. ‘1949 FIR stated idol was forcibly placed’But SC accepts that the mosque was not an abandoned one and Muslims offered namaz in it from 1857 till 1949. SC also recorded that the idol was illegally and forcefully placed inside the mosque’s central dome in 1949. When the act of placing the idol was deemed illegal, can the idol become a deity?” asked Jilani. The Muslim side, which is currently drafting the review petition, said this is a point that has not been touched upon in the legal proceedings till now. And, it will be this point on which the review plea will be based, added Jilani. Jilani went on to claim that such an idol, which was forcefully placed inside another’s rightful property, does not assume sanctity even under Hindu rituals and culture. “According to Hindu traditions, an idol is only an idol until ‘praan-pratishtha’ (the ritual of infusing life in an idol, turning it into a deity) is conducted and it is consecrated inside a temple,” said Jilani. “A deity would not encroach upon another person’s land. A person or body that has encroached upon another’s land, cannot lay claim on that property,” he said. SC verdict on Ayodhya: Sunni Central Waqf Board won't file review petition“Also, Hindu traditions do not bestow sanctity on an idol or consider it pious if the idol is established illegally on a piece of land. We will raise this contradiction in court,” Jilani explained. He told TOI that the FIR lodged in 1949 mentioned that the idol was forcibly placed inside the Babri Masjid in the intervening night of December 22 and 23. This, Jilani said, was also accepted in court by the Uttar Pradesh government and the Faizabad district administration as well as police officials. AIMPLB will file review plea against SC's Ayodhya verdict before Dec 9: Zafaryab Jilani“Even the Lucknow bench of Allahabad high court had not given the status of deity to these idols in its 2010 order,” he said. “Since SC accepted the idol as a deity, it became the main premise for the judgment. The outcome can be different if our point is legally considered,” said Jilani. Top CommentDid Babar made the mosque legally or by force?Shamik RoySee All CommentsAdd commentJilani, who has been BMAC’s convener since its inception, had also represented UP Sunni Central Waqf Board in court till the board decided not to file a review petition and end the litigation.

column2: UP’s coffers to disburse farm insurance directly
column3: LUCKNOW: The UP government is all set to directly disburse insurance benefits to farmers and the poor from its coffers and shut out private insurance companies to cut red tape. A proposal from the revenue board has already been sent to the CM’s office and is likely to be approved soon, despite a powerful lobby of insurance firms working overtime to stall the proposal. The proposal states insurance companies deliberately delayed or denied insurance cover of the state government to farmers and below-poverty-line (BPL) people and those who were insured were running from pillar to post to get relief, but companies remained insensitive to their concerns, said the proposal from the revenue board. Attempt to cut red tape‘Insurance cos denied or delayed benefits to poor on flimsy ground’ NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.As soon the Yogi government took charge in March 2017, it renamed Samajwadi Kisan Beema Yojana (Samajwadi Farmers Insurance Scheme) to Mukhya Mantri Kisan Aur Sarvaheet Beema Yojana (MMKSBY). Initially, it was limited to farmers, but later the Yogi government expanded the security net to those earning below Rs 75,000 per annum. Uttar Pradesh being an agriculture-based economy with highest number of farmers (11crore) and a huge BPL population, the state government launched a scheme in 2012 to provide insurance cover to farmers. Initially, the scheme provided Rs1 lakh cover to farmers, but later it was augmented to Rs 5 lakh in case of death and Rs 2.5 lakh for permanent disability, apart from treatment in empanelled hospitals up to Rs 5 lakh. The Yogi government, however, rechristened the scheme to MMKSBY in 2017, providing insurance cover to farmers by paying premium to insurance firms from its budgetary provision. Initially, the scheme was implemented by the institutional finance department, but later the revenue board supervised and implemented it. However, the revenue board was flooded with complaints from officials in the district that insurance companies were harassing farmers and the poor and denying benefits on trivial grounds, despite the state paying premium. Speaking to the TOI, a senior official in the revenue board shared that in FY 2017, the insurance companies received 20,803 claims, but only 13,867 received insurance benefits while 6,113 were denied on flimsy ground. In FY-2018, 24,726 claims were received, but only 14,868 got relief and 8,595 people were denied or kept in tenterhooks by the insurance firms. Similarly in FY-2019, while 24,321 claimed insurance, only 11,340 received benefits and a large number of 7,804 people were denied. While the delay and denial was done by insurance firms, BPL and farmers put the blame on the state government. “By denying insurance, companies ploughed in huge profits from the government’s social-safety scheme,” said a senior officer of the revenue board. Keeping this in mind, the state government decided to cast aside insurance firms from its flagship scheme and provide benefits through the office of district magistrates. Talking to TOI, chairman of the Revenue Board, Deepak Trivedi, confirmed that a proposal has been sent to the chief minister office for approval and the insurance scheme would now be directly implemented by the state government.

column2: Ghaziabad: Man sentenced to life for wife’s murder
column3: GHAZIABAD: A 27-year-old man was sentenced to life imprisonment by a Ghaziabad court on Thursday for killing his wife with a 5kg gas cylinder on January 18, 2017. The district and sessions judge Dinesh Kumar Sharma also imposed a fine of Rs 10,000 on the convict — Rajkumar, a resident of Tronica City in Loni, who originally belongs to Bulandshahr. The district government counsel (DGC) Rajesh Chandra Sharma said, Rajkumar killed his wife Pooja (20) as she used to fight with him because he was already married and had two children with his first wife. He had hidden this information from Pooja for quite sometime. Rajkumar also used to beat up Pooja whenever a fight on this issue ensued between them. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Rajkumar married Pooja on April 25, 2016 in Bulandshahr. During marriage, the convict had not informed Pooja about his first marriage and after marriage when Pooja came to know about it, Rajkumar used to beat her. A total of eight witnesses were present in the court following which the judge declared Rajkumar guilty.

column2: Ghaziabad: Man booked for raping 15-year-old girl
column3: GHAZIABAD: A man has been booked for allegedly raping a 15-year-old girl in in Kavi Nagar on Wednesday night. Police said they have registered an FIR while the accused is absconding.
