column2: Ghazals will never become extinct: Chandan Dass in Lucknow
column3: Well-known ghazal singer Chandan Dass was in Lucknow recently to perform at a concert. The Iss Tarah Mohabbat Ki ghazal singer while talking to Lucknow Times, talked about the current trend of ghazals, present generation’s inclination towards them and more... Ask Chandan, why the trend of ghazals has almost faded from the music scene in Bollywood and he says, "Yes, I agree that ghazals are not too much in demand these days, but one thing I can be sure of is that ghazals will never become extinct. Its style will change over time, the type will change but ghazal will always be there." Mention to him that even the demand for classical music is not much these days and commenting on the trend, he says, "Today, youngsters are more in love with rap. The reason for this is because they want everything to be really fast paced. Even the artists today prefer singing rap music more as it gives them instant fame. But one should realise that it is not long lasting. Aajkal online fame toh mil jati hai aise music se but woh sustain nahi ho pata." Latest CommentJanak pant , wah, lakhnow walo , gaatey bajaatey ho , humm fidaaye lakhnow .Janak PantSee All CommentsAdd commentIn love with Lucknow, Chandan spoke what all he likes about this city. "The culture of Lucknow is very good. Ek time tha jab Lucknow mein log aake yahan ki zubaan aur tehzeeb seekhte thay. In fact, a lot of people used to send their children to Lucknow to learn all this. This city holds a very special place in our country. In fact, aaj bhi Lucknow waalon ko sher-o-shayari ka shauk hai and people here understand it. Aur yahan ke khaane ka toh koi jawaab hai hi nahi," he said. column2: Glamour & limelight is an industry where demands from an individual are very high: Aditi Govitrikar
column3: Actress Aditi Govitrikar of 'De Dana Dan' fame was in the city, recently for a personal engagement. The '16 December' actress, who has been to the city several times before, in a candid chat with us shares what she loves about Lucknow, about her long hiatus in Bollywood, her personal life, upcoming projects and more. The actress and model Aditi, who ventured into acting through a Telegu movie, Thammudu in 1999, has been away from mainstream cinema for quite a long time. Ask the model turned actress the reason for such a long hiatus as far as her Bollywood career is concerned and she says that she hasn't been entirely missing from the silver screen. "I worked in a movie in 2016 which was to release at the end of 2017, but the project got shelved due to roadblocks in the producer’s way. As for movies this year, I was a part of this spectacular Marathi movie called Smile Please directed by Vikram Phadnis. As far as Bollywood is concerned, I’m also playing a part in Amin Hajee’s next, titled Koi Jaane Na which is set to release early next year." Aditi has also done quite a lot of TV shows and serials like Bigg Boss, Fear Factor: Khatron Ke Khiladi and was last seen in the show Suryaputra Karn in 2015. "Until last year I was quite preoccupied with my degrees. Fortunately, this year Harvard has graced us with flexible learning schedules, so I could take up more work on-screen," says Aditi, who is currently pursuing a Masters in Psychology from Harvard University. Aditi Govitrikar (BCC/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Aditi Govitrikar (BCC/ Vishnu Jaiswal) NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.And ask her about pursuing education now and she says that age doesn’t matter for her when it comes to education. "It never does and it never will. I follow a simple funda – be a lifelong learner. That’s what motivates me to better myself with every chance I get, and I also add more value to people I meet and work with. I want to remain active and exercise my grey cells for as long as I can," she replies with a smile. So, it must be difficult for her to manage studies, professional life, and personal life at the same time to which the Bheja Fry 2 actress admits, "It gets hectic at times honestly, but as long as it’s something I love doing, I find a way. My friends and family know I love studying, but there’s absolutely no way I wouldn’t give up my time for friends and family. So, it somehow just always works out." She has been creating awareness about mental health and has been counselling people to deal with mental illness. Ask Aditi what kind of depression and mental illness celebrities go through and she says, "Every industry comes with their own levels of challenges. Glamour and limelight is yet another such industry where demands from an individual are very high. Some common causes of depression I see are - lack of real personal connections and time outside work, performance pressure, then forcing oneself to look or be perfect all the time has its own drawbacks and pressure." Talking about her upcoming movie 'Koi Jane Na', which is being directed by Amin Hajee and is slated to release next year, Aditi is excited not only about the movie but also about the recreation of a famous old song from the movie 'Mr India', 'Zindagi Ki Yehi Reet Hai Haar Ke Baad Hi Jeet Hai', which she is a part of. Sharing her feeling on how it was to recreate such an iconic song, she says, "It was amazing. The way an entire story is portrayed in such a short frame of time, is simply fabulous! Plus, it’s a song with such profound lyrics, it’s always been a reminder to me that failures are not the end but stepping stones to something bigger and better. There are times, even today when I listen to this song for inspiration." Having been to Lucknow many times before, she has fond memories of her visits here. "I have been to Lucknow before and have been to Imambada, Shahi Baoli, the main Chowk market and other popular places in old Lucknow. I love shopping in Hazratganj for Chikan work. And of course, I love the Lakhnawi food too," she says as she signs off.

column2: Swedish royals arriving with high-level team tomorrow
column3: NEW DELHI: India and Sweden will start their first ever dialogue on innovation during the visit of Swedish King Carl Gustaf and Queen Silvia beginning Sunday. Speaking to TOI on the visit, Sweden's ambassador to India, Klas Molin said, "their Majesties will be joined by the minister of foreign affairs, the minister of industry, the state secretary and the minister of social affairs, and over a 100-strong business delegation from about 60 Swedish companies." The innovation dialogue will take place after the formal delegation talks at Hyderabad House between the two governments on Monday morning. Political discussions between India and Sweden may be strained however, particularly after the Swedish foreign minister issued sharp criticism of India's Kashmir policy in their parliament earlier this week. On Wednesday, the Swedish foreign minister Ann Linde told the country's parliament, Riksdag, that "Sweden and the EU support a bilateral political solution through contacts between India and Pakistan. We emphasise the importance of respect for human rights, that an escalation of the situation in Kashmir is avoided and that a long-term political solution to the situation must involve Kashmir's inhabitants. Dialogue between India and Pakistan is crucial. Sweden and the EU urge the Indian government to lift the remaining restrictions imposed on Jammu and Kashmir. It is crucial that free movement and communication opportunities are restored." NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The main focus of the royal visit will though be on innovation and business, education and environment. The Swedish ambassador said, the two sides expected to sign several MOUs on health, energy and sustainable transportation. The highlight, said Molin would be a virtual launch of a machine by a Swedish company BioEndev "that takes rice stubble and makes 'green' coal out of it. Farmers will be paid a premium for the stubble and it will be transported by the company. The first tests are being done in Mohali" and they have been successful." The innovation dialogue, the ambassador said, "is a way of encouraging research and innovation in order to create a more sustainable future including creating employment. It will start getting innovators together in both Sweden and India. We have a number of science parks, India does too, hubs for start-ups both in tech and other sectors, which will lead to investment, creation of companies, and, by extension employment creation." Given the onset of winter, the ceremony at the forecourt of the Rashtrapati Bhavan will take place at 11 am rather than the customary early morning. Foreign minister Jaishankar is expected to call on the King, while Modi will host them for lunch at Hyderabad House and the President Ram Nath Kovind will host them at a state banquet on Monday evening. Latest Commenthari bhajan sukh shanti nahi.. hari naam bina anand nahi.. om shanti shanti shantihi..vivek beriSee All CommentsAdd commentThe ambassador said, "We think these technologies have great potential. BioEndev are supplying several cities in Sweden with heating from agriculture waste. They have refined their methods so they can use rice stubble. They make fine green pellets which are then used for energy. Ikea in the past couple of years has been using rice stubble, mixing it in various degrees with cotton, among other things, to make textiles and home decor. They have a whole collection out in spring based on stubble from northern India." Ericsson, a leader in 5G, is partnering with IIT Kanpur, he said, on a pilot project to use 5G technology to predict and collect data on air pollution. The Swedish royals will spend a couple of days in Mumbai before travelling to Uttarakhand to witness a Ganga Aarti by women priests at Ramjhula, inaugurate a sewage treatment plant and tour Corbett national park.

column2: Uttar Pradesh: Light-weight revolver ‘Nishank’ launched at FGF
column3: KANPUR: Nishank, a light-weight revolver, built indigenously, was launched by Field Gun Factory (FGF), on Friday. Additional director general of police (zone) Prem Prakash, the chief guest, on the occasion. He congratulated senior GM Field Gun Factory (FGF) Anil Kumar and his co-workers for the achievement. The new 7.65-calibre revolver weighs just 625 grams. The gun with .32 bore comes with 76.2 mm barrel, a range 15 to 20 meters and is only 177.8 mm in length. “Chrome plating is being done to make Nishank -revolver lightweight,” said Kumar. He further said, “Nishank’s firing range has been increased. With a barrel length of 76.2 mm, it is capable of covering a range of 15 to 20 meters.” “It’s completely a ‘Make in India’ product,” he added. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.According to senior officials at FGF, the new revolver’s safety mechanism has been modified making the chances of misfiring almost nill. Additional GM PK Bandhopadhyai and other senior officials were also present on the occasion. A smart biometric firearm holster with 3D printing technology to prevent misuse and theft of firearms was also launched on the occasion. “One cannot open the lock of the holster, aptly named ‘Kavach,’ without the fingerprint impression of its owner,” said an official. “The ‘Kavach’ will also record the count of shots fired and is equipped with lethium battery,” he added.

column2: Kanpur: Another survey to be done to identify unnoticed nullahs
column3: KANPUR: Kanpur Municipal Corporation (KMC), Jal Nigam and Jalkal department will conduct one more survey of Ganga to identify unnoticed nullahs discharging their effluent into the river. Though Jal Nigam had already conducted a survey earlier, it failed to check the discharge of the effluent. Principal secretary, urban development Manoj Singh, and director-general, National Ganga Clean Mission Rajiv Ranjan Mishra while inspecting Ganga on Wednesday had witnessed several small and unnoticed nullahs discharging their effluent into the river uninterruptedly. They directed the KMC and Jal Nigam officials to conduct a survey and identify the unnoticed nullahs and stop their discharge. The two officials had also directed the KMC and Jal Nigam to prepare a list of localities situated on the banks of Ganga discharging their effluent into the river. Around one-and-half a-dozen localities are situated on the banks of the river. The officials are contemplating to construct community lavatories at each locality to check the discharge of unnoticed nullahs. According to municipal commissioner Akshay Tripathi, a meeting with the officials of Jal Nigam and Jalkal would be held and thereafter a joint survey would be conducted. column2: Truck cabin catches fire, driver charred to death on highway
column3: Kanpur: A truck driver from Etawah was charred to death after the vehicle’s cabin mysteriously caught fire near Bara JOD toll plaza on Kanpur-Etawah highway in Kanpur Dehat district in the wee hours of Friday. The deceased, Mahendra Chauhan (50), was sleeping when the incident took place, the police said. He had come to the city from Bharthana to load goods to be transported to Gwalior. Though police are yet to ascertain the exact cause of the fire, they suspect sparks from a mosquito repellent which the driver had lit in the cabin might have caused the blaze. According to police, the incident came to light at around 8 am when employees of a fuel station saw smoke billowing out from the truck’s cabin. They informed the police and the fire department. Later, police and fire department personnel along with fire tenders reached the spot, but it was too late. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Inspector Akbarpur Kotwali Dharmendra Singh said that by the time the fire could be doused, the driver was completely charred. However, the fire brigade personnel prevented the fire from spreading to the rear portion where the consignment of sesame was loaded which was to be transported to Gwalior from Kanpur, he added. “The smoke in the cabin might have made the driver unconscious, making it impossible for him to escape,” the inspector said and added,”As the body was beyond recognition, we after taking permission of his family members will conduct a DNA test and send the sample to the forensic lab to confirm the identity of the deceased.” Drivers of other trucks parked at the Bara Jod toll plaza said drivers usually light mosquito repellent coils while sleeping in cabin of their vehicles.

column2: PF scam: Enforcement Directorate shifts focus on money laundering
column3: LUCKNOW: The Enforcement Directorate (ED) is looking into the possibility of money laundering in the Rs 2268-crore employees provident fund scam in UPPCL and has sought details from economic offences wing (EOW) of UP Police. Director general, EOW, Rajendra Pal Singh said the Delhi unit of Enforecement Directorate was looking into money laundering angle in the scam and would register a case once the preliminary probe was over. According to EOW officials, the FIR of the case and some of the documents seized from the office of UPPCL employees’ trust have been sent to ED in Delhi. A source privy to the probe claimed huge money laundering had taken place which could only be probed by a specialised agency. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.ED has already lodged a case under the Prevention of Money Laundering Act against Dewan Housing Finance Limited (DHFL) and has also raided 18 places. Soon after irregularities in investment of Rs 2,268 crore in UPPCL employees’ provident fund surfaced, police lodged an FIR against former secretary of the Power Sector Employees Trust Praveen Kumar Gupta and former director (finance) of UPPCL Sudhanshu Dwivedi on November 3. The same day, UP government also recommended a CBI probe into the scam though the central agency is yet to lodge an FIR. Now, if ED detects money laundering and registers a case, it will be one of the few instances where ED has first lodged a case and CBI took it up later. Latest CommentScams are increasing day by day😡😡Siddhartha OmerSee All CommentsAdd commentOn Friday, EOW recorded statements of the chartered accountants of two brokerage firms. Now, only three brokerage firms are left to be questioned after which a detailed report will be prepared and submitted to the court on December 4. Former UPPCL MD AP Mishra has applied for bail.

column2: Uttar Pradesh tops corruption in MDM scheme: Report
column3: LUCKNOW: Uttar Pradesh tops the chart in corruption in mid-day-meal (MDM) scheme with 14 cases in three years, according to data provided by Union minister for human resource development (MHRD) Ramesh Pokhriyal in response to a query in Lok Sabha. The figure came months after ‘salt-roti’ expose wherein a video showing students eating roti with salt at a primary school in Mirzapur went viral on social media. Bihar is close second to UP in corruption with 11 cases, followed by West Bengal with six cases. The written reply by Pokhriyal was tabled before Parliament on November 25 in response to a question from another BJP MP Bharati Pravin Pawar from Maharashtra. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.In UP, mid-day meal is served to 1.59 crore students every day which is the highest in any state across the country. The revelation also evoked sharp reaction from Congress general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra. “The MHRD report says that UP is number 1 in corruption. In UP, head of the state government daily boasts about action being taken against corruption. But in reality, a make-believe situation is being created. Corruption is taking place under the nose of the BJP government,” Priyanka tweeted on Wednesday. “Hatya Pradesh me bhrashtachar apne charm seema par hai (Corruption is at its peak in the state). First PDS, PF, education and homeguard scams took place, and now, UP tops in mid-day meal irregularities as well,” a tweet posted from the Samajwadi Party’s Twitter handle read.

column2: Economic offences wing quizzes union agriculture secretary
column3: LUCKNOW: Economic offences wing (EOW), which is probing PF scam, questioned union agriculture secretary Sanjay Agarwal in Delhi late on Thursday. Agarwal has served as UPPCL chairman. DG (EOW) Rajendra Pal Singh said a team visited Delhi to quiz the senior IAS officer. “We had gone to seek answers to some questions,” the DG said. Officials privy to the investigation said the officials who held the post after Agarwal could also be questioned. On November 10, EOW had sent a notice to Agarwal for recording of his statement. Agarwal, a 1984-batch officer, joined UPPCL as chairman on May 16, 2013 and remained on the post till May 18, 2017. It was during his stint when UPPCL, for the first time, made investments in private companies, PNB Housing and LIC, in December 2016. The decision to invest in tainted DHFL was also taken during his tenure.

column2: Swine flu: No isolation beds, separate queues in hospitals
column3: LUCKNOW: The H1N1 virus has already infected 550 people in the city and claimed seven lives, but three major government-aided hospitals here are doing precious little to prevent the swine flu scourge. It becomes more important given the fact that December-February are most conducive for the spread of H1N1 virus. A TOI reality check on Friday exposed how blatantly safety protocol and guidelines of the World Health Organisation are being violated at a time the seasonal intensity of the disease is expected to increase. According to WHO, every hospital should have separate registration counters for suspected swine flu patients and isolation wards for confirmed H1N1 cases. Posters with dos and don’ts for visitors must be put up everywhere while OPD signs should guide patients to exclusive waiting areas. There is no separate registeration counter for swine flu patients at Balrampur HospitalKing George’s Medical UniversityNEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.In the absence of separate registration counters, evaluation chambers and waiting areas for suspected swine flu patients in the OPD, they were freely mixing with other patients. While the trauma centre and medicine department have isolation wards for swine flu cases, no exclusive bed was found in the casualty ward where critical patients are brought first. Doctors said a patient was sent to the isolation wards after swine flu confirmation. However, since test results take two days to arrive, it leaves enough scope for other patients in the casualty ward to be infected. Chief medical superintendent of KGMU professor SN Shankhwar said signs and awareness posters would be installed in a week across the campus. “All suspected cases will be directly transferred to isolation wards,” he added. Civil HospitalThe hospital neither has exclusive queues and waiting areas nor did TOI spot any awareness poster anywhere on the premises. To top it all, there is no isolation ward. Director of hospital Dr DS Negi promised to make all “required facilities available soon”, but didn’t specify how soon. Balrampur HospitalSuspected swine flu patients were seen coughing and sneezing without masks/handkerchiefs in common registration queues and waiting areas at the OPD. The hospital though has isolation wards in the emergency (one bed) and medicine (18 beds) wings while signs have also been placed. Spokesperson SM Tripathi said, “Separate queues/counters for suspected flu patients will be arranged soon and awareness posters too will be put up.”.

column2: Lucknow: Zoo marks 99 years of animal care, delighting kids
column3: LUCKNOW: The Lucknow zoo celebrated its 99th birthday on Friday. Established in 1921, the zoological garden was the third in the country at that time after Delhi and Kolkata and today, is among the few in the world to be located in the heart of the city. Despite malls and other indoor modes of entertainment for children, the zoo remains a popular and much-loved hangout every weekend, especially in winter and on holidays. SkipNow known as Nawab Wajid Ali Shah Zoological Garden, it still houses the first cage brought here in 1925. Zoo director RK Singh, at an event to mark the occasion, narrated the history of the landmark to visitors. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“The zoo was established with just 100 animals and today houses more than 1,000 from 104 different species. The animals include 463 mammals and 298 birds,” he said. A cake was cut and various competitions were organised to celebrate the event. The excitement was palpable as visitors clicked selfies with exotic animals and took part in various events. Former directors of zoo were invited to share anecdotes with the audience. Conceptualised by Sir Harcourt Butler, the then-governor of United Provinces (now Uttar Pradesh), the zoo was built to commemorate the visit of Prince of Wales to Lucknow and named after him. A society was formed with a contribution of Rs 7.3 lakh by Taluqdars and Zamindars for maintenance of the place, he added. A 29-acre plot of land—an orchard was planted here by the second nawab of Awadh Nasir-ud-Din Haider—was converted into the zoological garden. Its foundation was laid on November 29, 1921. Latest CommentVery nice pic from the following ad the same the same in a few minutes to beGanesh kohliSee All CommentsAdd commentCalled ‘Prince of Wales Zoological Garden’, till 2011, it was renamed ‘Lucknow Zoological Garden’ in that year. In 2015, it was named after Nawab Wajid Ali Shah. Chief conservator of forests and head of the department (UP) Pawan Kumar lauded Lucknow zoo staff for its efforts in maintaining the place and its inmates.

column2: ‘Class’ apart: LMGC batch of 1975 takes nostalgia trip
column3: LUCKNOW: It was almost 100% attendance in the ‘Class of 1975’, the batch of 27 bright girls of La Martiniere Girls’ College, now grandmothers, who were back to their school after 44 years. In their early 60s, these former students have the unique distinction of participating in centenary celebrations of the school in 1969 as students, and also witnessing the 150th year celebrations on Friday. Going down memory lane, Radhika Srivastava, an alumna, said: “We completed our schooling from La Martiniere in 1975. Back then, the school was only till class XI. Our batch is special as we witnessed two big events, the school’s 100 year celebrations when we were in class V and the visit of Mother Teresa when we were in class XI.” “Coming back to school is quite a nostalgic trip for me. I still have the picture of the cake that was cut during the centenary celebration of the school. Now, I can boast of having the pictures of sesquicentennial celebrations as well,” she added. She was the one who ensured that all her classmates turned up to celebrate the big day. She created a social media group in which everyone marked their presence. “I felt I was back to my class the moment I stepped into the school. Out of 27 students of our batch, 26 gathered to click priceless pictures of togetherness and school’s success,” said Savitri Bharat Singh who came all the way from Singapore. Poonam Shukla, another alumna, who came from Jaipur to celebrate the 150 years of her alma mater, said: “The memories of our sports day and PT display are still fresh in our minds. The ground gave us a feel that again we have to perform confidently in front of our teachers and parents in the sports meet.” Filled with enthusiasm, the old students were busy sharing group pictures of school days, remembering their teachers and relished visiting every corner of the institution narrating their unforgettable school days.

column2: Uttar Pradesh: Obscene posters put up in Babasaheb Bhimrao Ambedkar University girls’ hostel
column3: LUCKNOW: Cocking a snook at security arrangements at the hostels of Babasaheb Bhimrao Ambedkar University (BBAU), some miscreants entered Yashodhara girls’ hostel and pasted obscene posters with explicit messages outside the rooms of some inmates. The incident took place a few days ago but the inmates did not report it to the authorities fearing backlash from the culprits. However, one of the inmates made a video clip of 16 posters and shared it with her friends making strong objection to the act. All the posters were handmade and had sexually explicit content and inappropriate sketches. The university took note of the matter on Friday after the video clip went viral on social media and ordered a probe into the matter by a committee headed by dean students’ welfare which is responsible for resolving hostel-related issues. When TOI contacted girl inmates of the hostel, they said somebody entered the hostel during the night and pasted obscene posters near the door of some of the rooms on the first and third floors of the hostel. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“We are scared. If the culprits can enter our hostel in the night and execute the act, they can also harm us some day,” said an inmate on condition of anonymity. University spokesperson Prof Rachna Gangwar said a committee was looking into the matter. She refused to comment further.

column2: Onion prices shoot to Rs 100 per kg: Staple flies off plates, budgets hit
column3: LUCKNOW: Daily meals in the Tiwari household do not taste as delightful as they used to, three months ago. Since September, the family of foodies has replaced onions with radish in their salad and limited the preparation of dishes that use onions in large quantity. The price of onion skyrocketing to Rs 100 per kgWith the price of onion—a staple ingredient in Indian kitchens—skyrocketing to Rs 100 per kg across the city, many families have been forced to make changes in their eating habits. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“I used to purchase around 2 kg onion every week, but now I buy not more than 250 gm per week because high prices are drilling a deep hole in the pocket,” said Madhu Tiwari, a government official. Fast food joints and restaurants have also reduced the quantity of onion in salads. Some have started charging for the item, which earlier used to be complementary. “We now charge Rs 10 per plate of salad which was earlier free,” said the owner of a famous restaurant in Lalbagh. Even the menu of wedding parties has been altered with more onion-free preparations on the list. Of the five weddings that a city caterer has hosted this week, onion was not served in salad or main course in three. “Onion is priced at Rs 7,000 per quintal. Most organisers are not prepared for this kind of expenditure,” said Amit Srivastava, a caterer. The relentless rise in prices of onion started in September when crops in Maharashtra and Karnataka—the main producers—got damaged due to excessive rain. From Rs 10-15 per kg in July to Rs 80-90 per kg in September, the price of onion fell slightly in October to Rs 50-60 per kg. Now, it has soared to Rs 90-100 per kg, disturbing the budget of many families. Wholesale traders said prices might rise further by Rs 5-10 per kg in the coming days. However, prices could drop after a fortnight by Rs 40-50 per kg as fresh supply is expected by December 15. “Onion prices during this time of the year are generally Rs 20-30 per kg. This year, they have gone up by three-five times. Besides damages due to floods, the increase in demand due to the ongoing wedding season is the prime reason for the hike at present. We expect fresh crop to arrive in 2-3 weeks. That should bring down the prices by about 50%,” said Raju, a wholesaler at the Sitapur Road Mandi, the largest in the city.

column2: ‘IS sympathiser shot in UP radicalised on Telegram’
column3: LUCKNOW: With Facebook-owned WhatsApp embroiled in a cyber-espionage row, another end-to-end encrypted messaging platform, Telegram, has gained currency. But this lesser-known app is more vulnerable to security breach after police stumbled upon Telegram messages of a suspected ISIS sympathizer, who was killed in a police encounter in Lucknow in March. “Suspected ISIS sympathiser Mohammed Saiful killed during a siege in Haji Ali Colony in Thakurganj was radicalised on Telegram. He was very active on this messaging service,” said former ATS ADG Asim Arun, who led the commando operation in the state capital. Arun, who is now ADG Technical Services, was speaking to TOI on sidelines of the 47th All India Police Science Congress (AIPSC) organised in Lucknow, where a special session on social media and radicalisation was held with top officials from different security wings. With social media playing an active role in radicalisation of young minds, another top police official said: “At least 53 youths from UP were radicalised on social media platforms. Of this, 17 have been de-radicalised and others critically analysed.” NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Earlier, Kalraj Mahesh Kumar, DIG, Ernakulam range in Kerala, said: “Telegram was launched in Russia in 2013 and subsequently banned in 2018. Indonesia was quick to follow. Then why can't Indian police agencies impose intermediary liabilities against social media platforms? This is due to misinterpretation of Section 79(3) of IT Act.” “Under this section, an intermediary is duty-bound to remove or block content on instructions from authorities. Since Telegram has no nodal office in India unlike Facebook, YouTube, Twitter and WhatsApp, it's impossible for police to enforce intermediary liability against it. There’s no law in India that enables police to bypass encryption.” Germany, US and EU enforced strict laws which forces these social media platforms to target and take down materials that propagate, spread terror content and ideologies. “India also needs to look forward to new frameworks that adopt similar set of regulations,” he said.

column2: Uttar Pradesh: ‘Cop training must focus on right attitude’
column3: LUCKNOW: On the concluding day of the 47th All India Police Science Congress on Friday, deputy director of Sardar Vallabhbhai National Police Academy, Nikhil Gupta deliberated upon growing negativity in public perception of the police. He was among several bureaucrats who called for an attitudinal change in the police force. The session ‘inculcating right kind of attitudes in police officers — training and beyond’ was moderated by UP DGP OP Singh. ADG (PTC) Raja Srivastava explained how challenges like lack of a work-life balance lead to an inadvertent shift in attitudes. IPS officer Mahesh Dixit, said that demanding lives led by policemen may lead to inefficiency and a deviant attitude.

column2: ‘$5 trillion economy impossible sans strong law & order’
column3: LUCKNOW: Union home minister Amit Shah on Friday said that the country’s economy could not achieve the $5-trillion dream till a strong law and order situation is in place. Speaking at the 47th All India Police Science Congress in Lucknow on Friday, Shah said that India had massive cultural diversity but high vulnerability, which could be checked with better policing. “I am confident that we can become a $5-trillion economy. But the Centre cannot do it alone. Every state needs to contribute towards it,” Shah said. It was because of better policing, he said, that no untoward incident had happened in the country after the Supreme Court verdict on Ayodhya and the nullification of article 370 in Jammu & Kashmir. Shah also said that law and order situation in Uttar Pradesh was poor before BJP came to power in UP in 2017 but has improved immensely since. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.The Bureau of Police Research & Development (BPRD), the organising body of the event, Shah said, should try to incorporate views from the grassroots level. “Events like police congress should not be a formality or a picnic for officers. Conclusions drawn from the congress should be implemented,” he added. Latest Commentलेकिन आपने 2004 से 2014 के दौरान अपनी भ्रष्ट माँ को कभी नहीं लिखा जब वह भारत को लूट रही थी। नहीं ! आप नहीं कर सकते क्योंकि आपका इस देश से कोई लेना-देना नहींGanesh kohliSee All CommentsAdd comment“We need to question what happened to the resolutions passed by the police congresses between 1960 and 2019. Were they really implemented?” he asked. The home minister said the BJP government had come up with a national memorial in Delhi for police personnel. “Can we make the memorial the centre of people’s conscience,” he asked. “Police personnel are depicted with big fat bellies in cartoons. But they play a great role in security of people. They work tirelessly during festivals and even on borders. We need to change the perception about the police,” Shah said.

column2: Uttar Pradesh: ‘Devise Ways To Win Over The People’s Confidence’
column3: LUCKNOW: Chief minister Yogi Adityanath on Friday asked the police force to shun its archaic image and win people’s confidence. Despite being in the public sphere, police personnel appear to be distant from people, the CM said in his address at the 47th Police Science Congress. The CM asked the police department to devise ways to win people’s confidence. Laying stress on community policing, Yogi called for more intense training to check crimes, many of which now have a global nexus. “We need to use technology to check crimes, especially like cyber crime,” he said. The CM said Kumbh Mela was a big challenge before the state government as it had to be projected internationally. “We used command and control centre and ensured that no untoward incident happened. More than 25 crore people visited Kumbh. It was all about better crowd management,” Yogi said while crediting PM Narendra Modi and BJP chief Amit Shah for extending all support to the state government. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Yogi reiterated there was no untoward incident in the state after the Supreme Court verdict in favour of Ram temple. “India has shown the strength of democracy and judiciary to the people,” he said. The CM said issues discussed in the Police Science Congress were contemporary and important.

column2: Lucknow: Woman kills husband over his illicit relationship
column3: LUCKNOW: A woman allegedly killed her husband over his drinking habit and illicit affair in Krishnanagar locality during early hours of Friday. Police said Ravi Prakash(35) returned home drunk on Thursday night and started talking to a woman over the phone. His wife Neelam (30) got furious when she overheard him inviting the woman to his house. SHO, Krishnanagar, PK Singh said, “As soon Ravi went to bed, Neelam, with the help of her minor cousins, strangulated him using a bed sheet.” Later, they dumped the body near the boundary wall of their house to make it appear a murder case. “We were informed about the murder on Friday morning and sent the body for post-mortem examination. The spot where the body was found showed no signs of murder. There was no forced entry too,” the SHO said. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.“When the two minors were questioned about the sequence of events, they spilled the beans. On the basis of their statements, Neelam was taken into custody. She informed cops that Ravi was having an affair and frequently invited her to his residence. The two minors have also been taken into custody,” he said.

column2: Ghaziabad: Child rape cases rose 20% in 5 years, most in rural areas
column3: GHAZIABAD: Cases of child rape have seen over 20% rise in Ghaziabad district over the past five years. According to data sourced from the police, as many as 116 cases of rape were reported in 2015 and the figure rose to 152 in 2018. Between January and September this year, 141 cases of rape against minors have already been registered in Ghaziabad district. Police pointed out that the increase in numbers also suggested that more and more people were coming out in open to report rape cases, battling the social stigma attached to it and reposing faith in the cops.  What’s more interesting is that 60-65% of Pocso cases have been filed by the residents of rural areas and those from urban areas account for the remaining part. Around 30% of the cases have been registered against neighbours while 27% against friends and relatives. According to the officials, the only Pocso court in Ghaziabad has as many as 1,477 such cases pending. Police said that cases under the Pocso Act — which defines a child as any person below 18 years of age and is gender-neutral — are regularly monitored by a special cell and investigation is given precedence. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.In 487 Pocso cases that were reported between 2015 and 2018, arrests have been made in around 80% of them. In total, 632 cases have reached the court between 2017 and 2018, and 58 of them have resulted in acquittals. Between January and July this year, 226 cases were brought before the Pocso court and eight of nine cases decided so far have ended in acquittals. Asked about the rise in numbers, SP (rural) Neeraj Kumar Jadaun said that people are becoming more aware and coming out to file complaints, instead of reaching a compromise. “The number of Pocso cases is higher in rural areas because the village population is more than that in urban areas,” he said. “Police are also helping people become more aware. They are holding various programmes with help from NGOs in the district. Nukkad natak and door-to-door campaigns are being organised across the district. The police have even asked the schools to educate students about the crime,” added the SP (rural). According to the police officer, in most cases, the accused are either relatives or someone known to the survivor. In such cases, there is a high chance that the two parties might reach a compromise. Varun Pathak, a human rights activist in Delhi, said the rate of rapes against minors is increasing because in most cases, the accused are uneducated and poor. “Porn sites also play a major role in the crime,” he said. Top CommentIndia rapist country ..Tim See All CommentsAdd comment“NGOs are doing their best to educate such types of people. We are going around villages and making people aware so that they come out and report such incidents to police. If children can’t go to cops, they should at least tell their parents,” he added. (The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

column2: Ghaziabad: As students write law test, phones stolen
column3: GHAZIABAD: More than 40 students were allegedly robbed of their mobile phones, wallet and other valuable items on Friday when they had left their belongings in their cars and two-wheelers to write an LLB exam, which started at 10am and ended at 1pm. Police said some miscreants broke the window glass of the cars and unlocked the scooters, parked outside IPEM college in Vijay Nagar, and stolen the valuables. According to the rules, carrying mobile phone or bags is banned inside the exam centre. Over 20 students had apparently kept their mobile phones, wallet, ATMs and credit cards into a Brezza car belonging to Ashish, a resident of Karhera colony. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.Others had kept their valuables in their two-wheelers or inside their friend’s vehicle. column2: Police, forensic universities on the anvil: Amit Shah
column3: LUCKNOW: Union home minister Amit Shah on Friday announced a slew of measures, including setting up a central police university, a national forensic science university and changes in the Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC) and Indian Penal Code (IPC), for better policing and ensuring a robust law and order situation in the country. Speaking at the 47th All India Police Science Congress, Shah said that the Centre has conceptualized a central police university with affiliated colleges in all states. Latest CommentPromises to be forgotten.Parth GargSee All CommentsAdd comment“The university and the colleges would teach all aspects of policing which touch every citizen of this country. State governments should provide their support for such a college. They should give priority to graduates of this university while recruiting police personnel,” he said. Shah also announced that the Centre was planning a national forensic science university to ensure better conviction rate. column2: UP ropes in PwC to recreate Ram’s Treta Yug Ayodhya
column3: LUCKNOW: After the Supreme Court verdict paved way for a Ram temple in Ayodhya, grandiose plans are afoot to catapult Hinduism’s most revered city to the glory of Lord Ram’s ‘treta yuga’ and surpass the Vatican and Mecca in annual footfall. And the blueprint for this magnificent makeover has been hammered out by the prestigious London-based consultancy firm, Price waterhouse Coopers (PwC). While recreating the era of Ram at a sprawling Vedic village on Saryu banks, the PwC layout buttresses the temple town with modern infrastructure. Sources said the state government gave an “in-principle nod” to PwC’s plan earlier this week after the Sangh Parivar green flagged the mega project. The cost outlay would be worked out after every detail in the blueprint is finalized by the consultancy firm, developers and the state government. While recreating the era of Ram at a sprawling Vedic village on Saryu banks, the PwC layout buttresses the temple town with modern infrastructureSenior officials of the culture, tourism and other departments gave a three-hour presentation of the PwC blueprint before the Sangh brass at a closed-door meeting in Varanasi on November. NEWS IN BRIEFEXPLORE BRIEFSAmid Covid surge, Centre's 5-step containment strategy for statesIndia witnessing a sharp rise in coronavirus infections, Union health secretary Rajesh Bhushan on Saturday held a meeting with officials from 12 worst-hit states and presented a five-fold containment strategy to bring the situation under control.Over 60 protesters killed in Myanmar on 'day of shame for armed forces'Myanmar's security forces shot and killed at least 64 people - including a young boy - on Saturday, news reports and witnesses said, even as the ruling junta's leader said the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.26. The meeting was convened to review development of Kashi, but the agenda was Ayodhya. Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath also attended the key meeting with senior government officers and there was a unanimity that Ayodhya would be transformed into a top religious destination for Hindus from across the world with worldclass infrastructure, hospitality services, renovated mutts and mandirs that would draw more pilgrims than Mecca or Vatican. PwC, which recommended a complete revamp of infrastructure, logistics, services and ambience of the existing town, also stated that once the Ram temple is constructed, the footfalls is expected to spiral to around 2 crore annually and could outpace pilgrim count at Amritsar’s Golden Temple, which clocks 1.2 crore devotees annually. Currently, the Golden Temple draws the largest number of pilgrims at one place in India, the PwC said. “To cater to swelling crowds to Ayodhya, the infrastructure has to be bolstered to cater to not just the wealthy, but also those from humble background,” said a senior officer, who attended the meeting. And the government plans to construct at least six 5-star hotels, seven 3-star hotels and 4,000 “dharamshalas” (inns). Also, mutts, mandirs and lanes of Ayodhya would be renovated and beautified. Five RoBs would straddle the temple town and all roads leading to the city from Sultanpur, Basti, Prayagraj and Varanasi would be widened into six-lane for seamless traffic movement. Soon, Ayodhya to be nodal centre of Hindu pilgrimageThe five railway overbridges in the works include one at Maudaha, Darshan Nagar, Tedi Bazar, Badi Bua and another at the Parikrima route. Similarly, a Hindu pilgrimage circuit will be developed along the lines of the Buddhist and Agra circuits, making Ayodhya the nodal point. Also, modern eateries and vending zones will provide cuisine and ethnic food of different Indian states. Top CommentJai shri RamHappyTimes UserSee All CommentsAdd commentDuring the PwC presentation, the state government was also flooded with enquiries from major tour operators to allow them to set up office in Ayodhya for tour packages and operations, including running luxury buses for tourists. A cruise service, a commercial airport and bus stations with modern facilities and maximum capacity of housing nearly 4000 buses, has already been finalised by the state government.

column2: More from UP: Kids can’t read, neither can their teachers
column3: KANPUR: When Unnao district magistrate Devendra Pandey reached the government junior high school in Chaura village for a surprise inspection on Friday, a shocker awaited him: an English teacher who couldn’t really read English, reports Faiz Siddiqui. Interacting with students and teachers of Class VIII, the DM and basic shiksha adhikari Pradeep Kumar Pandey asked some children to read their English book. When the students fumbled, the officials asked Rajkumari — who teaches English and other subjects to students of Classes VI to VIII — to read a chapter for the students. She also flunked the reading test.
